fields.headline: Youhana restores Pakistan pride
fields.standfirst:
Pakistanis make progress despite trouble back home
Scoreboard
More about corruption in cricket
fields.trailText: BC Pires Pakistan made their best start of the series in the third Test against the West Indies at the Recreation Ground here yesterday. Which is not to say the start was good.
fields.body:
Pakistan 267-8

Even with four players in the team named and fined by Justice Malik Mohammad Qayyum in his report into match-fixing, Pakistan made their best start of the series in the third test against the West Indies at the Recreation Ground here yesterday. Which is not to say the start was good.

In the first test in Guyana, the fifth wicket fell with the score on 39; it went two runs cheaper in the second test in Barbados; relative to those scores, then, having only three wickets down at 33 is not too bad. The tea-time score of 135 for five was positively prosperous.

And if the start in this final test was marginally better than in the two previous ones, both drawn, the recovery was also up to scratch. In Guyana Pakistan eventually got to 288, while in Barbados they reached only 253; with a score of 267 for eight at stumps here yesterday, it is possible a pattern may be emerging.

It is not one of Pakistan batsmen being intimidated by match-fixing reports. West Indies may have had, on balance, the better of the day but Pakistan finished a long day considerably happier than they began it.

Inzamam-ul-Haq may or may not have been an informant at some time in the past but he remains the in-form Pakistan batsman of this tour. Coming in at 27 for two in what some might consider the unlucky 13th over, Inzamam showed no sign of being troubled by idle superstition, Justice Qayyum's findings or the West Indian bowling.

Apart from what was eventually a surprisingly soft dismissal, when he was caught for 55 slashing Courtney Walsh to Adrian Griffith at cover point, the burly batsman was troubled only once. That was when he was on 37 and an inside edge off a slower Walsh delivery stopped an inch or two away from his stumps.

Otherwise Inzamam batted as solidly as he appears, reaching his half-century by pulling Curtly Ambrose for six on his home ground with disdain.

Inzamam may have been placed on shaky ground by Justice Qayyum but he had firm support in the middle from Yousuf Youhana, who offered only one chance, off Walsh, that was even more slight than Inzamam's. It was a faintly possible catch that did not carry to Shivnarine Chanderpaul at second slip which, had he leapt forward and twisted himself like a pretzel in spaghetti, Chanderpaul might have held spectacularly.

Youhana was not implicated by the Qayyum report and was obviously not distracted in scoring his second century in as many tests. He even managed to make it look easy to hook Wals6 for six and avoid being caught by the giant Ambrose jumping high on the boundary.

Inzamam and Youhana seemed to have taken on board their manager's declaration that the team would put the Qayyum report behind them as effectively as they put the early collapse out of their minds and then put on 97 runs for the fourth wicket.

The ease with which they dispatched decent bowling went a long way to justifying their captain Moin Khan's pleasure at being put in by the home captain Jimmy Adams.

If Wasim Akram, another player recommended to be fined in the report, was rattled by anything, it was not the bowling of Ramnaresh Sarwan, whom he hit for 11 (including a six) in Sarwan's second (and, understandably, last) over of the day before being out for 26.

Waqar Younis, another player in the judge's report, also seemed untroubled. Like his predecessor in the order, Mushtaq Saqlain, who dawdled for 44 balls to score four runs, Younis hung around - and it was long enough for Youhana to score his hundred.

webTitle: Dot.com chill cuts Egg share for executives

fields.headline: Dot.com chill cuts Egg share for executives
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Mike Harris, the founder of Egg, and his senior colleagues, will between them receive shares worth £6.3m and options of more than £8.6m in shares when the loss-making banking unit of the Prudential is floated next month.
fields.body:
Mike Harris, the founder of Egg, and his senior colleagues, will between them receive shares worth £6.3m and options of more than £8.6m in shares when the loss-making banking unit of the Prudential is floated next month.

But their potential payouts might have been higher had it not been for cooling demand for dot.com stocks which has slashed the potential value of Egg from £2bn two weeks ago to between £1.1 and £1.4bn.

Publishing the prospectus for the share sale, Prudential tried to distance the telephone-cum-internet banking business from other dot.com share sales, highlighting its 18-month track record and its longer-term potential.

Roberto Mendoza, the former JP Morgan investment banker and new non-executive chairman of Egg, said: "This is the single most exciting opportunity I have seen". He is also joining Prudential's board.

Egg will raise £150m from the share sale, while Prudential, which has said the flotation is necessary to give Egg an acquisition currency and offer incentives to staff, will retain an 82% stake. "Egg is not just a concept. It's got key strategic assets in place," said Mr Harris, who is on a one year contract and basic salary of £320,000.

The 170-page prospectus shows that Egg is facing opposition from a design company over its attempts to register its name as a trade mark. It also admits that Egg will continue to make losses until the end of next year and that the savings account is only ever likely to operate on a break-even basis.

Analysts said this meant that Egg needed to rely on selling more than one product to its savings customers to make profits and Mr Harris admitted yesterday that over the next three years 25% of its profits were likely to be derived from its online broking service.

Mr Harris, who will become vice-chairman of the company next year, will be awarded shares over a four-year period worth almost £1m after the flotation on an assumption of mid-price for the float of 152.5p, and granted options for more than 525,181 shares - neither of which are subject to any performance criteria.

The range for the shares ahead of their pricing next month was yesterday set at between 130p and 175p, although spread-betting firm Financial Spread was estimating a price at the end of first day's trading of 185p to 190p.

The sale is being restricted to £1,000 in shares for the 1m customers of Egg and Prudential banking, who will only be able to apply for shares over the internet with a debit card.

Egg's 1,400 employees are also being awarded £100 in free shares and options worth more than £900.

The prospectus, which kicks off the marketing of the shares to institutional investors in Britain, Europe and the US, shows that Prudential pays Mr Harris' remuneration into a company called Oxford Executive Consulting. It also shows that Mr Harris has a 10% stake in a company which provided IT consultancy to Egg although it is understood he made his investment after the company won the contract.

Paul Gratton, who will become chief executive next year, also owns a 20% stake in another consultancy firm, Direct Valuations, which received £2.3m from Egg last year. It is understood he did not participate in board discussions about the appointment of the company. Mr Gratton is to receive £676,000 of shares and options for more than 426,000 shares.

fields.headline: Boos from the crowd
fields.standfirst:
Christopher Allsopp's appointment to the Bank of England's panel that sets interest rates may not deserve the barracking it received
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Christopher Allsopp's appointment to the Bank of England's panel that sets interest rates may not deserve the barracking it received
fields.body:
It is always hard to be the sub coming on halfway through a match when your side is winning. But for Chris Allsopp, the new boy on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee (MPC), the welcome he received from the crowd this week was like an over-the-top tackle from Vinnie Jones. Even before he had stripped off his tracksuit, the catcalls began. At his confirmation hearing in front of the Commons' Treasury select committee, Brian Sedgemore said the MPC was losing a player of "Arsenal or Manchester United" standard, with the departure of Charles Goodhart of the London School of Economics. His replacement came from the "Vauxhall league, maybe Kidderminster".

Mr Allsopp is not, it is true, in the running for the Nobel prize. Writing papers for the influential economics journals has never been his game during his 33 years as a don at New College, Oxford, so it is hardly surprising that on paper there are a host of names from British universities who look better qualified. However Mr Allsopp does know what makes an economy tick. His hands-on experience, both here and overseas, leaves most of the rest of the MPC standing.

The Treasury committee's non-binding decision to reject his nomination for the vacant position on the MPC is an own goal. MPs and industrial leaders have attacked it for being packed full of pointy heads lacking real world experience. Only DeAnne Julius has the names of big British businesses on her CV. Here comes Mr Allsopp with a distinguished track record advising governments around the world on practical policy issues. His international experience, including spells at the OECD, World Bank and as consultant to the governments of Poland, China and Sweden, fills a significant gap in the MPC, one exposed two years ago by the Asian financial crisis. For MPs to be so critical now smacks of inconsistency when in the past they have complained about the bias towards highly theoretical economists.

There is no doubt Mr Allsopp made a poor impression on Monday. His answers were at times hesitant and he seemed genuinely puzzled by some of their questions, though that may have been a reflection of their quality and relevance. However, all that shows is that academics can be made to feel ill at ease when confronted by a panel of aggressive (and partisan) MPs; to reject him as unsuitable without any explanation seems a little harsh. It does however raise the question of what does make an ideal MPC member.

Business often suggests the committee would make better decisions if it had more non-economists on it, people who know how companies are run. At the one central bank in the world which has tried this plan - the Reserve Bank of Australia - the economists run rings around the laymen. When the chancellor gave the Bank of England control of interest rates in 1997, he deliberately rejected the idea that it should contain representatives from different regions or sectors of the economy. If MPC members were representative rather than expert, there is a danger that they would simply vote for themselves and their friends rather than the good of the economy as a whole.

Mr Brown believes the MPC's remit of keeping inflation under control is best achieved by leaving the job to technicians. So the Treasury has tried to build a team which balances different areas of expertise in the field. Sushil Wadhwani used to work in a hedge fund and is an expert on financial mar kets. Steve Nickell, Mr Allsopp's fellow new boy, is a distinguished labour market economist. The Bank's deputy governor and former chief economist Mervyn King is well known for his work on tax and fiscal policy. With the departure of Willem Buiter, the MPC lacked a macroeconomist - someone who looks at the big picture - which is precisely the area where Mr Allsopp shines. Manchester United would not get very far if they fielded a team of 11 centre forwards.

So far the MPC has performed well since it was set up in May 1997. Inflation has remained close to the government's 2.5% target and the economy is enjoying one of its most stable period of sustained growth for decades, partly due to the MPC's good judgment on interest rates.

However experts still have to be accountable and able to explain their decisions if they want to succeed in their wider mission of convincing the public of the benefits of low inflation. While Mr Allsopp's primary duty is to make the right decisions on interest rates, if the MPC wants to overcome its image of being deaf to the pain being felt by sectors of the economy, he must be able to defend and explain his decisions in a robust and convincing manner. From now on, his every move will be watched closely. Gordon Brown also needs to learn a lesson from the latest episode. The Commons' committee, though it cannot veto the chancellor, is performing an important constitutional duty in holding the performance of the MPC to public account. Its chairman, veteran Labour MP Giles Radice, rightly takes this role extremely seriously.

Yet Mr Brown's dismissive response to the committee's reservations about Mr Allsopp suggests he has little if any respect for the committee's views. Even if they are wrong, the MPs deserve a courteous and reasoned response. Otherwise Mr Brown appears contemptuous of the legislative's role in holding the executive to account.

Mark Atkinson and Charlotte Denny are, respectively, economics correspondent and reporter.

Mark Atkinson

fields.headline: Exchange turns on the charm
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The London stock exchange is embarking on a crucial charm offensive of its members in a frantic attempt to win support for its controversial merger with its German rival.
fields.body:
The London stock exchange is embarking on a crucial charm offensive of its members in a frantic attempt to win support for its controversial merger with its German rival.

Careful not to prejudge the outcome of the September vote on the merger, Don Cruickshank, who yesterday took over as chairman of the London exchange, made it clear that he wanted to avoid confrontation, saying he was in "listening mode" at this stage.

Since the announcement of the merger between the London exchange and the Deutsche Börse, and its link with Nasdaq of the US, earlier this month, the exchanges have faced anxiety over whether London or Frankfurt is getting the better deal along with protests that the London exchange is trying to propel Britain to adopt the euro.

Mr Cruickshank, who is expected to become chairman of the merged exchange which will be known as iX, insisted that after initial, early meetings with members and users of the exchange, fears about the forced adoption of the euro for British listed stocks in London had been allayed.

He will now lead a round of meetings with members of the exchange, who recently backed its plans to demutualise, before the publication of key documentation on the merger in six weeks.

He said he did not want to judge the outcome of the vote in September, which needs support from 75% of the mem bers, before completing the meetings but said he expected to focus on three issues.

The first, he said, was the structure of the exchange between the large capitalised stocks in London and the high-growth stocks in Frankfurt; the second is the corporate governance issues surrounding the initial voting rights of the German exchange, while the third is clarifying the benefits for smaller brokers.

"I genuinely want to listen. I'm still very much in listening mode," Mr Cruickshank said, noting that he believed members saw the merger between London and Frankfurt as a "good first step" on a way to improving the efficiency of Europe's stock exchanges.

webTitle: Whitbread calls last orders for beer

fields.headline: Whitbread calls last orders for beer
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Whitbread yesterday called last orders on its 258-year history of brewing in the UK by selling its beer operations for £400m to Interbrew, the Belgian group which owns the Stella Artois brand.
fields.body:
Whitbread yesterday called last orders on its 258-year history of brewing in the UK by selling its beer operations for £400m to Interbrew, the Belgian group which owns the Stella Artois brand.

In a further shake-up for the beer industry, Bass confirmed that it was poised for a similar sale. The brewing group said it was in "confidential discussions" to dispose of its breweries, with the Dutch group, Heineken and Denmark's Carlsberg-Tetley tipped as likely buyers.

Both Whitbread and Bass cited pricing pressure, a trend towards consolidation and the need for international brands as their reasons for exiting the brewing industry.

Whitbread's strategic planning director, David Richardson, said: "Brands are getting more important and production is getting more efficient. There are going to be bigger brands and fewer of them."

Whitbread is the country's third largest brewer. It produces Stella Artois and Heineken under licence for the brands' European owners, and its own portfolio includes Boddingtons, Wadworth 6X and Murphy's Irish Stout.

Mr Richardson admitted that there were "mixed feelings" in the company about the move. He said: "Two hundred and fifty years is quite a heritage, but I've got an absolute conviction it's the right thing to do."

The group's head office, an ancient brewery in the City, is to be converted into flats.

webTitle: SFO chief hits at new regime

fields.headline: SFO chief hits at new regime
fields.standfirst:
Warning that innocent people could be punished along with City villains
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Innocent people could be punished along with the guilty under the government's proposed tough new regime for regulating the City, serious fraud office director Rosalind Wright warned last night.
fields.body:
Innocent people could be punished along with the guilty under the government's proposed tough new regime for regulating the City, serious fraud office director Rosalind Wright warned last night.

She said the bill going through parliament was riddled with "anomalies, lacunae and peculiarities" which could, potentially, produce "extraordinary" results.

Mrs Wright said that while villains would be more likely to be punished, "the danger is that some innocent men - and firms - may be punished too. This, I suggest, may prove too high a price to pay for muscular regulation."

SFO sources denied any suggestion of a turf war between the SFO and the financial services authority - the new regulator that will achieve full legal status when the financial services and markets bill becomes law. Mrs Wright said that "overall the picture is one which should reassure those who want to see true villainy punished".

However, her comments will delight the bill's critics inside and outside parliament, who claim that - despite modifications to the original blueprint - the FSA will have sweeping powers as judge, jury and executioner over the financial services sector.

The bill has been heavily amended and has drawn fire from City professionals, the Conservative opposition and lawyers, who claim it could drive business from London.

Mrs Wright was speaking to 150 practitioners in the areas of regulation and fraud prevention at a London reception arranged by accountants Chantrey Vellacott DFK.

She concentrated on the FSA's proposed powers to pursue "market abuse", the section of the bill that marks the most radical departure from the present system. This allows the FSA to demand civil penalties against anyone in the country, not just City professionals, accused of insider dealing or related offences.

Mrs Wright, who was herself a regulator before moving to the SFO in 1997, said the existing system of solely criminal prosecution for insider dealing required regulators to prove "intent" on the part of the insider dealer. With the market abuse offence, she said, "no proof of intent is necessary".

In fact, provided the market in question could have been accessed from Britain, a deal done in New York could become the subject of civil action here by the FSA, a "potentially extraordinary result".

Mrs Wright said: "Effective regulation means proportionate, just and fair regulation. It means coming down hard on the real villains and keeping them out of the market - perhaps for ever. It means giving honest and competent business the chance to thrive ... It also means clarity."

She repeated earlier concerns at the shrinking resources devoted by chief constables to the investigation of fraud. The SFO has no police officers of its own and relies on local forces to supply personnel when an SFO case emerges in their areas. Mrs Wright said: "Nobody pretends the present level of resourcing in adequate."

She repeated her call for a national police resource to be made available to the SFO, and said she hoped a ministerial working group, due to be set up shortly to tackle the problem, would agree.

To make anti-fraud action a national priority was essential, she said. "Money laundered and salted away ... is money which is kept out of the national economy."

fields.headline: Microsoft falls on analyst's warning
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Shares in Microsoft fell about 5% yesterday morning after an influential Wall Street analyst warned that the company would be worth much less if broken up.
fields.body:
Shares in Microsoft fell about 5% yesterday morning after an influential Wall Street analyst warned that the company would be worth much less if broken up.

In a note to investors issued yesterday morning, Rick Sherlund, an analyst at Goldman Sachs, the investment bank, said that Microsoft's stock market value could be worth 10% less in the event of a break-up.

His comments came after Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson gave the first public indication that he was considering dividing the company.

Judge Jackson abruptly dismissed Microsoft's request for a further trial to discuss the US government's proposals on Wednesday.

He could deliver his ruling as early as next week after ordering the justice department and 17 states to send him a "clean copy" of their break-up proposals today. Lawyers for the government are expected to file their amended proposals after the American stock markets close.

Last month they demanded that the company be broken into two businesses: one controlling Windows, the PC operating system, and the other the programming software, such as Office. Judge Jackson asked the government why it had not considered a three-way split, and such comments helped send the company's shares down almost $3 to $62 at noon yesterday.

At these levels the shares were trading at a 52-week low, down almost 50% from a January high. Microsoft's decline helped drag the 30-strong Dow Jones industrial average down. Conversely, a rally among Microsoft's rivals helped lift the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index.

Mr Sherlund said yesterday that Oracle, Red Hat, Sun and AOL would benefit from "Microsoft's misfortune".

Duplicate costs, the loss of development momentum and the likely loss of key staff would hit the valuation of the mini-Microsofts.

Although it was still too early to predict whether Microsoft would be broken up, Goldman's analyst questioned the group's ability to deliver on its new internet strategy, to be launched next week.

However, other observers were more bullish about the impact of the legal travails. Joe Farley, of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, repeated his buy rating and said that Microsoft should win its case on appeal.

webTitle: McManaman the matador toys with Valencia

fields.headline: McManaman the matador toys with Valencia
fields.standfirst: Richard Williams on the England midfielder's triumph
fields.trailText: When Kevin Keegan announced earlier this week that he considered Steve McManaman to have been the most effective player in Europe over the past six weeks, plenty of eyebrows were raised. As well as McManaman had performed in the latter stages of the Champions League, surely Keegan was simply talking up the morale of a player whose inclusion in the England line-up for Euro 2000 was still a matter of debate?
fields.body:
When Kevin Keegan announced earlier this week that he considered Steve McManaman to have been the most effective player in Europe over the past six weeks, plenty of eyebrows were raised. As well as McManaman had performed in the latter stages of the Champions League, surely Keegan was simply talking up the morale of a player whose inclusion in the England line-up for Euro 2000 was still a matter of debate?

Well, it can hardly be a matter of debate now. McManaman was the man of the European Cup final in Paris last night, beyond all question, and if he can produce the same form for England then maybe the prospects are looking better for a passage through the group phase. The former Liverpool man was his team's metronome in the first half, scored the second of Madrid's three goals, and accomplished much, much more besides. As he intercepted a long pass from Gaizka Mendieta, the Valencia captain, in the closing minutes, turning away from the ensuing challenge with a flicker of his hips, you would have thought that he was performing a media veronica in Las Ventas, Madrid's bullring.

The fact that this edition of the European Cup final was being contested for the first time by two representatives of the same country might have seemed to devalue an historic competition. But whatever the rights and wrongs of Uefa's decision to enlarge the entry, the finalists had certainly earnt the right to be there, and the way the fans of both sides turned St Denis into the setting for a fiesta meant that no one could begrudge their good fortune.

McManaman was at the heart of Real's play in the first half. He and Redondo probed the fringes of the Valencia rearguard with short passes, but were clearly mindful of the capacity of their opponents for murderously swift breakaways. It was from Redondo's error that, in the 18th minute, three Valencia forwards suddenly appeared goalside of the entire Madrid defence, but astonishingly failed to take advantage with Casillas's goal at their mercy.

The price of their failure was made clear 20 minutes later, when Morientes scored the opening goal after Anelka's persistence had enabled Salgado to put in a cross to the far post. It was just reward for Madrid's patient endeavour, embodied in McManaman's willingness to fetch and carry, and his ability to change the pace of the game with a brisk reverse pass or a meandering dribble across the pitch. A long ball out to Roberto Carlos brought spontaneous applause, as did a sidefooted flick to Salgado.

His awareness of the movement of Raul, loitering behind the front two, gave Farinos and Gerard a hard time, even though the Real midfield machine was not moving as smoothly as in the previous rounds. The combination almost brought about an earlier breakthrough, when Anelka was encouraged to dribble round Gerardo and hit a shot at Canizares, who had more work to do on the half-hour when McManaman responded to Morientes's cross from the left with an instant shot which brought a fingertip save from Valencia's goalkeeper.

For Anelka, returning to his home city, the first half was largely an ordeal evoking his words of a week earlier, when he said that Valencia's style of play would have suited him better than Real's. The truth behind this apparently provocative remark was clear to see as he struggled to receive balls with his back to goal and a defender in close attendance, and the cross with which he created the opening for the goal was a tribute to his willingness to do what does not come naturally.

There was a flash of the real Anelka four minutes into the second half, when he raced on to Casillas's long clearance, outran Gerardo and put in a low shot which Canizares fumbled round the near post. That was a move from the blackboard of Hector Cuper, rather than the chessboard of Vicente Del Bosque. Fifteen minutes later the Frenchman showed another flash of initiative when his 30-yard drive almost caught Canizares unawares. And two minutes after that he was popping up in the right-back position, covering for Salgado with an alacrity which might have shocked his old colleagues in the Highbury dressing room. Even more stunning was his last act before being substituted with 10 minutes to go, when he held up his hand to acknowledge an inaccurate pass to McManaman. Some people would have travelled a lot further than Paris to see that.

webTitle: Red faces as Kinnear keeps Wednesday waiting

fields.headline: Red faces as Kinnear keeps Wednesday waiting
fields.trailText: Sheffield Wednesday were left red-faced and empty-handed yesterday after failing to persuade Joe Kinnear he should resurrect his managerial career in south Yorkshire.
fields.body:
Sheffield Wednesday were left red-faced and empty-handed yesterday after failing to persuade Joe Kinnear he should resurrect his managerial career in south Yorkshire.

Plans to unveil the former Wimbledon manager as the successor to Danny Wilson, sacked two months ago, were cancelled amid confusion and embarrassment after Kinnear insisted he needed more time to consider Wednesday's offer.

Wednesday, who are about £12m in debt, have offered him a lucrative contract, worth £3m over four years or £15,000 a week before bonuses, which would make him the highest paid manager in their history. They remain confident he will eventually agree to oversee their attempt to reclaim Premiership status, but the 53-year-old Dubliner is believed to have reservations about relocating his family in the north of England.

Kinnear may delay giving Wednesday an answer until the future of the Leicester City manager Martin O'Neill has been decided. If O'Neill accepts the expected invitation from Celtic to be their coach, Kinnear will put Leicester above Wednesday on his job wish-list because they are a Premiership club - and some 100 miles south of Hillsborough. Leicester yesterday denied that they had had any contact with Celtic.

After two rounds of negotiation involving the chairman Howard Culley and secretary Alan Sykes, Wednesday were confident that Kinnear would sign before a press conference yesterday afternoon. However, after discussing the offer with his wife by telephone, Kinnear informed Culley that he was unable to reach a decision.

Kinnear has not worked since suffering a heart attack 14 months ago, coincidentally at Hillsborough. "Joe has now gone home to consider some personal details with his family," said Sykes. "He is happy with the football side of our talks. We are optimistic that he will get back to us before the weekend."

However, Kinnear's agent Jonathan Barnett said: "There will not be a decision made before the weekend. Joe will make his mind up one way or the other, and at the moment I would say that things are in favour of him saying yes." But he added that if not all details were satisfactory "there are plenty of other fish in the sea".

Nigel Winterburn is poised to turn down the offer of a "fantastic" one-year contract from Arsenal. "It's been a heart-wrenching decision and one made purely from a footballing point of view," the full-back said. He felt he would be picked for a maximum of only 15 or 20 games if he stayed.

Christian Vieri was ruled out Italy's Euro 2000 squad last night and Paolo Maldini is also doubtful. Vieri has a hamstring strain and Maldini has hurt the big toe on his right foot and admitted: "To be honest I'm a little worried."

Denmark's coach Bo Johansson named five British-based players in his Euro 2000 squad yesterday: Sunderland's Thomas Sorensen, Chelsea's Jes Hogh, Allan Nielsen of Spurs, Fulham's Bjarne Goldbaek and Derby's Mikkel Beck.

Danish squad : Schmeichel, Sorensen, Kjaer; Laursen, Henriksen, Colding, Schonberg, Heintze, Hogh, Helveg, Steen-Nielsen; Tofting, Gronkjaer, Nielsen, Jorgensen, Goldbaek, Bisgaard, Gravesen; Sand, Molnar, Tomasson, Beck.

webTitle: O'Neill can claim pot o' gold if he does not get vertigo

fields.headline: O'Neill can claim pot o' gold if he does not get vertigo
fields.trailText: Few of us own a living room large enough to accommodate the television punditry of Martin O'Neill. Urgent, intense, leaning forward, arguing with passion and with vast, manic eyes behind thick glasses, he is more comfortably viewed from the distance of the kitchen and through half-closed fingers.
fields.body:
Few of us own a living room large enough to accommodate the television punditry of Martin O'Neill. Urgent, intense, leaning forward, arguing with passion and with vast, manic eyes behind thick glasses, he is more comfortably viewed from the distance of the kitchen and through half-closed fingers.

It is hardly surprising, then, that when the Leicester City manager demanded a unique clause in his contract the directors nodded in assent and backed quickly away.

When O'Neill, with the shrewdness of a former law student, negotiated a new three-year deal last summer worth £800,000 a year, he insisted upon an eight-week close-season "window", from May 15 to July 15, when he would be free to talk to prospective suitors.

This is the window that Celtic, the club he supported as a boy, have kicked in and clambered through. They will offer him something like £2m a year to be their next manager.

Leicester have only themselves to blame for the clause. Two years ago O'Neill thought he had a gentleman's agreement to talk to the Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale. His employers, he felt, reneged.

"Obviously the chairman has Alzheimer's disease or something," he said at the time, with some bitterness. "I will never have dinner with him again."

There was a suspicion, however, that O'Neill was perfectly happy to remain at Filbert Street. And there he remained when Everton made their approach, followed by Nottingham Forest and Northern Ireland.

The worry with O'Neill, the former manager of Grantham Town, Shepshed Charterhouse, Wycombe Wanderers and Norwich City, is that he has never proved himself in a big job. And, if he shuns yet another opportunity, those who will applaud his loyalty will be drowned out by those who will question his ambition.

A number of well known managers, such as Brian Horton, Frank O'Farrell and Graham Turner, have built reputations in the lower leagues only to falter on a wider stage.

Even the great Brian Clough, the manager who influenced O'Neill more than any other, failed at his one big club. He lasted only six weeks at Leeds, although it might be argued that he would have succeeded if he had been given enough time.

O'Neill is the ultimate make-do-and-mend manager. He was never one of the more fashionable members of Clough's highly successful Forest side of the late 70s and early 80s and, perhaps recalling those days, he appears to have an affection for misfits and misanthropes.

Under him those unlikely footballers Steve Guppy, Matt Elliott, Neil Lennon and Muzzy Izzet have become international footballers. Elliott is a former bricklayer, Lennon a Manchester City reject. Robbie Savage was an apprentice with Sir Alex Ferguson at Manchester United. Stan Collymore's career, on and off the field, is well known.

This is not to say that O'Neill would not make an excellent manager of Celtic and, having played as a Catholic in Northern Ireland at the height of the troubles, he is certainly well apprenticed to the religious schism he would experience in Glasgow.

But for once the man who is an expert at telling footballers what to do - and managers, directors and TV presenters for that matter - must give himself a few words of advice.

And, if he really is up to the job, should he go anyway? Scottish football, after all, is a two-horse race, even if the bloodstock is close to the highest quality.

Leicester supporters, meanwhile, are already reviving old campaigns to persuade him to stay. But the club should not stand in his way, even though they have a clause in his contract that would call for £1m compensation from his new employers.

Leicester should stand aside for a manager who has given them four successive top-10 Premiership finishes and two Worthington Cups.

In the end, though, it will be down to O'Neill. The man is fanatical about westerns, once jumping from his seat while watching Gunsmoke because he recognised the ranch from The Man From Laramie. His favourite films usually feature James Stewart. So he should have a nicely developed sense of destiny.

webTitle: Hull locked out by landlord Lloyd

fields.headline: Hull locked out by landlord Lloyd
fields.trailText: Hull City staff arrived for work yesterday morning to find they had been locked out of Boothferry Park. The club's former chairman David Lloyd, the former Davis Cup captain, had repossessed the ground.
fields.body:
Hull City staff arrived for work yesterday morning to find they had been locked out of Boothferry Park. The club's former chairman David Lloyd, the former Davis Cup captain, had repossessed the ground.

"We had no notice of the bailiffs coming in," City's commercial director Andy Daykin told the Hull Daily Mail. "They are not asking for money. They've locked the ground and are sitting in the car park."

Lloyd, for whom Boothferry Park remains the last bastion of a troubled empire that once threatened to swallow Hull City and the town's two rugby league clubs, claims that the City directors to whom he sold the club 18 months ago owe his company £103,000 in rent.

"There's nothing I can say," he said yesterday. "It's all pretty self-explanatory."

Solicitors for Lloyd's company, which has the freehold of the ground, issued a statement yesterday morning. "Having deliberately deferred taking action in this matter to ensure that Hull City could complete the 1999-2000 season, it has been decided, with regret, to forfeit the lease of the stadium and the ground has been repossessed."

Daykin said that the club were seeking an injunction against the bailiffs.

Lloyd took over City and the Hull rugby league club three years ago with a plan to sell the two grounds for development and move both clubs into a new stadium. Difficulties mounted, supporters grew disenchanted and Lloyd lost patience. "It's been a nightmare," he said.

A new stadium is planned on the site of the West Hull amateur rugby league ground at the Circle but it will not be ready for league football until the beginning of the 2002-03 season at the earliest.

Chelsea have begun their summer shopping by targeting the Dutch international and former Leeds striker Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink. But the fee appears to be a sticking point.

Atletico Madrid paid £12m for Hasselbaink nine months ago. Although he has increased his value by scoring 24 goals in the Liga this season, Chelsea are not prepared to pay much over £14m.

Atletico are prepared to let their top scorer go now that they have been relegated. His last game will be the Spanish Cup final against Espanyol on Saturday.

"I've had many offers but it now looks as though my future is sorted out," Hasselbaink said. "With Atletico going down I know that back in Britain I can carry on at the top."

Chelsea are desperate to boost their flagging firepower. They appear ready to listen to offers for Gianfranco Zola and Chris Sutton and the on-loan George Weah looks likely to join Monaco.

 There are changes in the way bonus points are earned in the millennial revision of the County Championship.

As before, a win earns 12 points , a tie 6 , a normal draw 4 (see later *) and a defeat none, plus any bonus points accrued for batting and bowling in each first innings.

Bonus points are now reckoned on the score in the first 130 overs, not 120 overs as in recent seasons.

Batting: now 5 pts can be earned (4 last year)

200 -249 runs (1pt);

250-299 (2);

300-349 (3);

350-399 (4);

400 or over (5)

Bowling: now only 3 points available (4)

three-five wickets (1);

six-eight wickets (2);

nine-ten (3).

The new ball can still be taken after 100 overs.

A no ball is worth two runs to the batting side; runs scored off a no ball count in addition to the two-run penalty.

A single-innings match may be played when bad weather prevents any start until less than eight hours remain. A win earns 12 points, a tie six and a draw three but there are no bonus points.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Even the Zimbabweans were spotted smiling briefly yesterday. It was one of those rare days, as Donald Fagen and Walter Becker put it, "when the sidewalks are safe for the little guy".
fields.body:
Even the Zimbabweans were spotted smiling briefly yesterday. It was one of those rare days, as Donald Fagen and Walter Becker put it, "when the sidewalks are safe for the little guy".

With their openers having totalled a dozen runs at Lord's, the tourists may convince themselves they have an alternative for next week's Trent Bridge test in Guy Whittall, who made 89 in nearly five hours against a weakened Yorkshire attack at Headingley. But Andy Flower's side still wilted from 165 for three to 235 all out, Grant Flower and Alistair Campbell going first ball.

Being capped after eight years at Leicestershire has evidently had the desired impact on Jon Dakin. His 89 in the First Division match with Durham at the Riverside, after a career-best 135 in Taunton a fortnight ago, helped raise the 1998 champions from 167 for eight to 256 for nine.

Prior to the latest chapter of Australian mano a mano in Bristol, the odds on Glenn McGrath outshining Ian Harvey bordered on the subterranean. Yet, though Worcestershire, the Second Division leaders, reduced Gloucestershire to 176 for eight, the all-rounder from Wonthaggi won the day. Undaunted by the loss of six wickets in the first two hours, Harvey hustled to 70 off 125 balls; McGrath, having jump-started his new side with 18 wickets at 8.88, managed a resoundingly mortal one for 37.

Ricaldo Sherman Glenroy Anderson is clearly not content with the most sonorous name on the circuit. Told to improve his batting after narrowly missing an A tour, the Essex outswing bowler was an improbable saviour in Chelmsford, hoisting his side from 140 for eight to 255 with 67 not out off 87 balls - nearly half his tally from 18 knocks in 1999. Better yet, he frustrated Sussex , one of five clubs to reject him.

Nick Knight, allowed by England to play for Warwickshire , made 80 in a total of 184 for one against Glamorgan , just to keep the Zimbabweans' smile in check.

webTitle: Long haul by Ward wasted short of more declarations

fields.headline: Long haul by Ward wasted short of more declarations
fields.standfirst: Surrey 283-7 v Kent
fields.trailText: There was a strong feeling of deja vu here yesterday, all over again. Sunshine in the morning was followed by rain in the afternoon; the last 49 overs were washed away, compared with 57 the day before.
fields.body:
There was a strong feeling of deja vu here yesterday, all over again. Sunshine in the morning was followed by rain in the afternoon; the last 49 overs were washed away, compared with 57 the day before.

A second deja vu kicked in when it was recalled that these sides had played each other only a week ago, when the damp weather jostled the captains into a contrived finish, with Surrey then set 320 to win from 93 overs. It ended in a draw.

Something similar will be required again from Matthew Fleming and Adam Hollioake. The first innings of the match is likely to continue this morning, with Surrey in search of further bonus points to bolster their soggy season.

The fixtures are a disgrace. The season has not started yet - not properly anyway - and already these two great clubs have all but finished with each other in the First Division until next year. They must be sick of the sight of each other, and of the umbrellas.

The story yesterday was of Ian Ward, who must feel a little like an extra amid an all-star cast. He is 26 and has been playing for Surrey for four years, although still uncapped.

It is curious that he thinks less cricket should be played, and that players should be given more time for rest and preparation, for he went into this season with only 33 matches and 56 innings to his name. His wife Joanne, meanwhile, reminds him that she hates cricket and that footballers are much better paid.

Before yesterday Ward's best score was the 103 made at Derby last year, when bad light initially drove him from the field when still two runs short of his maiden century.

He is a patient batsman, which is no bad thing in this team of strokeplayers. He has batted for seven hours for his unbeaten 127, facing 310 balls and striking 14 fours. Another Surrey left-handed opener, John Edrich, would have been proud of such an innings. If Surrey do bat on he will fancy carrying his bat.

Surrey resumed yesterday on 135 for two, with Ward on 73 and Ben Hollioake on 24. They had added only eight runs when Hollioake, pushing to a lifter from Fleming, was caught by Rahul Dravid at second slip for 29.

Alistair Brown then played a skittish little innings. He kept the score moving but, unusually, struck only one four in his innings of 28. He was showing increasing signs of aggression, and had just survived a difficult chance to wide mid-off, when caught by Min Patel at midwicket off David Masters.

Ward must have thought he would find a more adhesive partner in his captain. But Hollioake the elder had made only 17 when he tried to play Dravid's off-spin to fine-leg and was caught, down the leg side, by Paul Nixon off the last ball before lunch. Jonathan Batty then fell lbw to Kristian Adams without offering a stroke to the old ball before Martin Bicknell was caught behind off the new.

 Pakistan hope to have their fast bowler Shoaib Akhtar back after a series of injuries and illness for the decisive final test against West Indies in St John's, Antigua, today but have doubts about the all-rounder Abdur Razzaq because of a thigh strain. Franklyn Rose, who missed the first two tests because of an injured finger, is fit for West Indies.

webTitle: Lively Francis leaves Warne in the shade

fields.headline: Lively Francis leaves Warne in the shade
fields.standfirst: Lancashire 125-7 v Hampshire
fields.trailText: It has taken Hampshire until their fourth championship match to realise that the presence of a blond Australian leg-spinner in their attack does not in itself guarantee victory, but yesterday the penny seemed to have dropped.
fields.body:
It has taken Hampshire until their fourth championship match to realise that the presence of a blond Australian leg-spinner in their attack does not in itself guarantee victory, but yesterday the penny seemed to have dropped.

Shane Warne played his part in Lancashire's collapse, having Joe Scuderi caught behind with an orthodox leg-break in a fascinating 11-over spell from the Northlands Road end. But by then Hampshire's seamers already had Lancashire in trouble, and Warne's most memorable contribution to a rain-shortened day was to join the umpire David Shepherd in his Nelson jig when the total reached 111.

Hampshire's team selection for the First Division match after the rained-off first day confirmed a change in strategy after their poor start to the sea son, with John Stephenson returning in place of Shaun Udal to bolster the batting and seam bowling, leaving Warne as the sole spinner.

Robin Smith did his bit by winning the toss, allowing his seamers to bowl first in cloudy conditions, but the early signs were not good as, in the absence of the resting Mike Atherton, John Crawley and Mark Chilton put on 41 without serious alarm. However, in the 10th over Chilton steered a short ball from Simon Francis, a tall 21-year-old making his first appearance of the summer, to Jason Laney at third slip, and batting never looked so straightforward after that.

Andy Flintoff stayed all too briefly, following a powerful pull off Stephenson which thudded first bounce into the advertising hoardings with an overambitious drive off Francis which Laney, again, brilliantly caught one-handed. Flintoff could have done with runs here after his Lord's failure, and immediately called on the services of Lancashire's 12th man Mike Smethurst for a net.

Crawley gave Adrian Aymes the first of four catches in Dimitri Mascarenhas's second over, and Mascarenhas then gave Neil Fairbrother a nasty shock with a big inswinger which clipped the top of his off stump.

It took Warne all of two balls to scream his first lbw appeal at Shepherd, and there were plenty more oohs and aahs before he deceived his fellow Australian Scuderi just before lunch.

Graham Lloyd maintained his usual positive approach, twice using his feet to strike Warne over the top. But when the scoring rate slowed he was sufficiently frustrated to slash at Peter Hartley and give Aymes his third catch, and later in the same over Warren Hegg gloved an attempted hook to leave Lancashire with an even tougher task to maintain their promising start to the season.

webTitle: He had it all - but it wasn't enough

fields.headline: He had it all - but it wasn't enough
fields.standfirst: More about corruption in cricket
fields.trailText: As from today, all Salim Malik's deeds as a player of substance will become secondary to his manipulation of the game.
fields.body:
As from today, all Salim Malik's deeds as a player of substance will become secondary to his manipulation of the game.

This was a seriously good player, who made an unbeaten century on his debut against Sri Lanka in Karachi in March 1982 when he was only 18 years old, the youngest Pakistani at the time to have done so, and in the course of 103 tests he scored 5,768 runs, including 15 centuries, at an average of 43.70. There were 7,169 runs in 283 one-day internationals as well. How many more might he have scored had he not been getting himself out?

He played county cricket too, in the early 90s for Essex, a club who prided themselves on the quality of person they employed as an overseas player. Malik was an outstanding success, well integrated and popular with his team-mates and the public alike. It is a picture at odds with what has happened subsequently.

So too are some of his finer moments in international cricket. His bravery for example. In 1986, on a relaid pitch in Faisalabad, Courtney Walsh broke his arm above the left wrist. In the second innings, when, says Wisden, runs were vital, he batted at No11, faced one ball playing left-handed, then reverted to right-handed and contributed to a last-wicket partnership of 32.

And the skill? Well, in one series against Australia he batted six times and scored 557 runs. In Rawalpindi he made 237, the highest score of his life, and followed with 75 and 143 in the final match in Lahore. Shane Warne took 18 wickets in the three-match series, not one of them Malik's.

He must have thought it easy money. Furtive conversations at official functions, clandestine meetings in hotel rooms, a phone call here and there, offering big bucks to his colleagues and making a pile for himself. Only when his finances have been examined by the criminal investigation recommended in the report of Justice Malik Mohammad Qayyum will the extent of his corruption even be hinted at, and even then it might be hard to pin down.

Even while Qayyum's report was being compiled, Malik appears to have been continuing as before. Last Sunday the News of the World published allegations that he had been in London touting for more illicit business on behalf of an international betting ring.

"The allegations are false and baseless," he told the inquiry, knowing perhaps that it was his word against that of individual cricketers, some of whom had already had their credibility shredded.

Qayyum had been insistent that, in proving guilt, he had to be convinced of the specific offence. In particular he needed to know to his satisfaction that one particular match had been fixed. And on the evidence of Mark Waugh, Warne (whom Malik dismissed as someone with a grudge because the great bowler could not dismiss him) and Tim May he found not one but two in the first test match between Australia and Pakistan in Karachi in October 1994 and the first one-day international in Rawalpindi later on the same tour.

 Manoj Prabhakar, the former Indian test batsman, claimed yesterday that his team-mate Kapil Dev had offered him a 2.5m rupee (£38,000) bribe to underperform against Pakistan in 1994. "I started shouting, 'You are a traitor'," Prabhakar recalled. "'If you have to sell your country against Pakistan I'm not ready for this'."

webTitle: Australian murder trial dropped after web 'prejudice'

fields.headline: Australian murder trial dropped after web 'prejudice'
fields.standfirst: The Melbourne Age story
fields.trailText: An Australian murder retrial was abandoned after a supreme court judge ruled it could be prejudiced by information published on a controversial crime website.
fields.body:
An Australian murder retrial was abandoned after a supreme court judge ruled it could be prejudiced by information published on a controversial crime website.

Judge George Hampel made legal history in the state of Victoria by saying he feared the jury may learn of information about the accused man's criminal past from CrimeNet, a new website which offers details on 4,000 criminals convicted in Australian courts.

Victoria's attorney-general Rob Hulls yesterday called for the closure of the site, which has received one million hits since its launch less than a month ago. Mr Hulls is to meet other state attorney generals and Australia's federal attorney general about the matter on July 27.

In a letter to CrimeNet's managing director, Ken Schultz, Mr Hulls expressed concern that the site could be used by jurors to obtain details of convictions of accused people or witnesses.

"If this occurred, the accused would not get a fair trial. The community may also lose confidence in the integrity of criminal trials," he said.

But Mr Schultz said yesterday he was appalled at the suggestion that the site, which compiles information that is in the public domain, should be closed down.

"We have a legitimate business operating within the law," he said. "Perhaps Mr Hulls could close the public libraries and ask the [Melbourne] Age to close until this is sorted out," he said.

Judge Hampel refused to call off another murder retrial two weeks ago after the defence complained that the accused man's case was featured on CrimeNet.

Criticism from the Australian government and civil libertarians has already lead the site owners to restrict access to the site after criticism from civil libertarians, the federal government and the New South Wales privacy commissioner.

The site plans to get users to sign a declaration that they are not jurors looking for information as well as pay a fee before being able to access any information. Previously they could see search information before paying for the full details.

fields.headline: Cross-media ownership
fields.standfirst: As the government considers changes to the rules of media ownership, Gideon Spanier explains what the effects of the reform are likely to be
fields.trailText: The government says it is preparing to scrap restrictions on media ownership rules, which forbid big newspaper proprietors from owning terrestrial TV channels. We explain what the existing limitations are and what the effects of the reform are likely to be
fields.body:
What does cross-media ownership mean?
The term refers to any company that has a significant stake in several different media organisations like, for example, newspapers and TV stations.

What restrictions are there on cross-media ownership in Britain?
The short answer is many, which are implemented by the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) and the Department of Culture, Media and Sport. The Broadcasting Act of 1996 is a key piece of legislation in that area: it forbids any company that controls more than 20% of national newspaper circulation from having more than a 20% stake in an ITV company or Channel 5. Among the many other regulations, no commercial TV company may have more than 15% of the total TV audience. That could affect any possible merger involving the ITV companies Carlton, United or Granada.

But why should the government limit cross-media ownership?
To ensure power is not concentrated in too few hands in an anti-competitive way and to protect free speech. As early as 1962, the Royal Commission on the Press had concluded that, in the words of the DTI, "action should be taken to regulate the increasing concentration of newspaper ownership which could threaten the freedom and variety of expression of opinion and perhaps even the unbiased presentation of news."

How do the rules in Britain affect a powerful owner like Rupert Murdoch?
His company, News Corporation, publishes four national newspapers: the Sun, the Times, the News of the World and the Sunday Times. Together, they have more than 20% of the market, so News Corp may not hold a terrestrial TV licence as a result.

But do these ownership restrictions make sense in an increasingly global market?
Many media companies don't think so, and the government may be coming round to their point of view. The merger of US giants AOL and Time Warner has upped the ante. The government now believes British media companies may be better off if they are allowed to expand at home to compete globally.

So what restrictions are likely to remain in place?
That question will probably only be answered in the autumn, when the DTI and Department of Culture are due to publish a joint white paper outlining their plans for the reform of broadcasting and telecommunications regulation. The Department of Culture suggests that media ownership rules are likely to be relaxed: "With the legislation, we want to ensure that Britain builds on its strengths in the broadcasting, telecommunications and information technology industries, whilst taking measures that are necessary - and only those which are necessary - to protect the interests of consumers."

webTitle: Orchard of Spain crumbles into dust

fields.headline: Orchard of Spain crumbles into dust
fields.standfirst:
Drought, tourism and intensive cultivation all helped to transform lush farmland into a desert . . . in just 20 years

The weather: special report
fields.trailText: Ismael Verdu's farm is a green oasis in a barren landscape of bare rock and grey dust just 25 miles from the Mediterranean skyscraper resort of Benidorm.
fields.body:
Ismael Verdu's farm is a green oasis in a barren landscape of bare rock and grey dust just 25 miles from the Mediterranean skyscraper resort of Benidorm.

The nearest town, Xixona, is the centre of Spain's Turron -Christmas nougat - industry. Once it was surrounded by almond trees.

A few miles away lies the lush flat land that surrounds Valencia, known as the orchard of Spain. But every year it shrinks back further, sliding into desert.

"Twenty years ago this landscape was totally different, full of the fragrant smell of apricots, almonds and apple trees," Mr Verdu says.

"At the height of the harvest I'd take 20,000 kilos of produce to the market in one day. Now I barely manage a 10th of that."

Desertification may be a more familiar plight in Africa, but it now threatens 12% of Europe's land surface. Parts of Spain have always been desert - David Lean's film Lawrence of Arabia was made in the Almeria desert -but this is different.

The phenomenon is by no means new, but, after a particularly dry winter, the situation in this area has become critical.

"Soil isn't a sexy environmental subject," says Dr Jose Luis Rubio, who runs the European Society for Soil Conservation from a desertification thinktank linked to Valencia University.

"We think of it as something mundane, worthless. We talk about things being dirt cheap. We couldn't be more wrong."

Deserts are caused by soil erosion in conjunction with drought. Wind and weather play their part in ridding the earth's crust of its protective and fruitful cover. But according to Dr Rubio "man is the soil's worst enemy".

The Mediterranean area is particularly at risk because it has shallow soil, sparse vegetation and rocky outcrops. Intensive agriculture, pasture, forest fires, urban sprawl and tourism have all done their worst.

The region also tends to suffer periods of drought. The river near Mr Verdu's farm is called Rio Seco - dry river .

After the civil war in Spain and the second world war in France, Italy and Greece, human hunger led to the cultivation of marginal areas and forests were hacked down for firewood. As people moved to the cities in the 50s and 60s the land was abandoned.

"That is one of the worst things that can happen," Dr Rubio says. "Good agricultural practice is good for the land. "

Mr Verdu, 62, fears that no one will want to farm his land when he retires.

"I used to have 10 people working here. Now it's just me. My sons aren't interested."

He has seen the climate change dramatically.

"It hasn't rained here properly for 13 years," he says looking at the sky. "I can tell it's not going to this one."

As the soil erodes, water becomes an enemy rather than a friend. "A drop of water on this dry land has the power of a missile," says Dr Rubio.

Tourism is the other great threat; a greedy slurper of precious water.

"Benidorm would go bankrupt if there was no water," Dr Rubio says.

When water is scarce the precious underground reserves are drawn down to provide it. Golf courses and garden lawns not suited to Mediterranean conditions compound the disaster. "We're building a new theme park near Benidorm. In environment terms it's a disaster," says Dr Rubio.

Desertification is a major contributor to global warming and climate change. In the past, efforts to curb the problem have focused on Africa, Asia and Latin America - it was not until the 90s that Europe was brought into the frame and an international convention on desertification drawn up.

Dr Rubio believes that mea sures can still be taken to save the areas under threat and prevent the spread of desert. "While there is still soil, there is still hope," he says. "It isn't really a question of money but of creating awareness."

Top of his list is public education, encouraging the balanced use of resources, preventing forest fires and replanting threatened areas. An action plan has been promised by Spain's environment industry but is slow in coming.

"You have to take a long-term view on this sort of problem and politics is short term," he says.

webTitle: Thank God for the Champions League

fields.headline: Thank God for the Champions League
fields.standfirst: Sean Ingle has reservations about the Champions League like anybody else. He still thinks it was the best competition this season, though
fields.trailText: Sean Ingle has reservations about the Champions League like anybody else. He still thinks it was the best competition this season, though.
fields.body:
Last night's Champions League final was the kind of match to remind even the most cynical of souls why they fell in love with football in the first place.

Because it had everything: outrageous pace (Robert Carlos sizzling back to catch Mendieta, who had a 20-yard start); outrageous skill (Raul's pull back and flick in the first half or Redondo's mazy dribble); and - incredibly for a match of such importance - two sides prepared to really go at it from the off.

In short, this was how football was meant to be played. And the result was a classic final for what has been, in recent weeks, a classic tournament.

And thank goodness too. Because if it wasn't for games like Manchester United v Fiorentina, Barcelona v Chelsea, United v Real or Valencia v Lazio, this season would have been desperately dull. It's true to say that the Champions League didn't really get going until the later stages. But at least it did get going.

Which is more than you can say for the Premiership, which was a foregone conclusion by February and featured only a scattering of half-decent matches all season (all which seemed to involve the champions).

Or the devalued FA Cup, which was about as about as romantic as a wet weekend away with David Mellor, and which hasn't produced a decent final since 1991.

It's barely worth bothering with the Worthington Cup (especially as no-one else seems to), except to say that it was as irrelevant this year as it's been since about 1988. How many of you can name all this year's semi-finalists, for instance?

But the Champions League was different. Not only were the best players on the world displaying all their tricks and talent, but they also brought a refreshing attacking mentality that - United apart - you rarely see in the English game.

For instance, we watched weaker teams who were prepared to rip apart - rather than merely contain - their more illustrious opponents, as Valencia showed against Lazio and Barcelona.

And even when two evenly-matched sides met, there was rarely the stale shadow-boxing that pervades the Premiership, with both teams seemingly happy to go in goalless at half-time. Instead they were prepared to attack - trusting that no-matter how many they let in, they'd always score one more.

Furthermore, it was wonderfully refreshing that a competition designed to further cement the big clubs dominance saw Valencia reach the final, and smaller sides like Willem II make the group stages. As the likes of Milan fell by the wayside.

Of course Europe wasn't perfect. The two sets of league groups were too long and unimportant while the Uefa Cup was a big waste of time. So here's an idea for Uefa to consider: merge the two competitions.

That way you could have one group stage at the beginning before getting into a 32-team knockout. And you'd satisfy the insatiable money-lust of the big clubs whilst also having more of the ecstatic highs and the hellish lows that only knock-out competition can provide.

But despite its faults, this year's Champions League was still a resounding success. It brought romance (Valencia and Chelsea), sublime skill (step forward Giggs, McManaman, Mendieta, Redondo, Effenberg and the rest) and drama (where else could you see a side come to Old Trafford and completely annihilate the hosts?).

That's why this year's Champions League was not just a victory for Real Madrid or Uefa. It was also a victory for football.

webTitle: Absolute nonsense, Absolute disgrace and Absolutely nothing

fields.headline: Absolute nonsense, Absolute disgrace and Absolutely nothing
fields.trailText: TEDIOUS TRANSFER RUMOURS II
fields.body:
TEDIOUS TRANSFER RUMOURS II

The second in an occasional series profiling those "Rivaldo to Arsenal" and "Ray Parlour to Barcelona" transfer rumours.

2. Kevin Phillips to Leeds United.

According to the Sun, David O'Leary has made a "record-busting" £20m bid for the Sunderland striker. But even using our exceptional Baldrick-like cunning we can't find anything (eg: a fact) to back up the story - unless the line "Leeds make second raid on Sunderland" counts. Which it doesn't. So we weren't exactly choking on our Pukka Pie when Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale described the news as "absolute nonsense" and warned that "reports like these about a player who is under contract don't help relationships between clubs".

But just when we're about to lose our faith in the tabloid press, Chelsea managing director Colin Hutchison goes and confesses that he's been given permission to talk to Jimmy-Floyd Hasselbaink. "It is true we have made an enquiry but other clubs are going down the same road," Hutchison told Chelsea Clubcall. "We were given permission by Atletico to talk to his agent and open negotiations. That's as far as it's gone although we hope to take the matter a little bit further." Which the Fiver takes to mean that all rumours ever are completely true.

And just to prove the point further, news then came through that Liverpool had signed former Scotland skipper Gary McAllister. The reputation of the tabs is fully restored... Brian Woolnough, we love you!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ROLL UP TO SIGN UP

The Euro, the Fiver's extra low-down from the lowlands brought to you in association with breathe, starts on the morning of June 5. To make sure you get it, go here. Or send a mail to euro2000-request@footballunlimited.co.uk with 'subscribe' in the subject line. Get your act together!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ADVERTISEMENT

Gimme goals. Gimme prizes. Gimme Euro 2000. Visit this site to experience the action and glory of the EA Sports Euro 2000 game. Plus, click here to enter a free prize draw to win the latest multimedia PC.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ANYONE NEED TICKETS?

Two weeks to go until the start of Euro 2000 (have you booked your Flemish night-classes yet?) and everyone's getting down to business. The coaches are naming their squads, the organisers are sticking another couple of quid on a pint of lager, and the players - well, they're complaining that they're not getting enough freebies.

"It's ridiculous," an unnamed England 'star' told the London Evening Standard today. "We make all this money for the FA during major tournaments and we are being limited to just one free trip per player. That means all the players are having to pay for their kids to come out and watch the games." Which is an absolute disgrace whichever way you look at it. Unless you look at it from the "they earn £30-grand-a-week so paying for their families to go on holiday once in a while wouldn't hurt" perspective. But we wouldn't advise it.

This draconian restriction of unprecedented proportions has come about as the result of a little outsourcing. The FA have handed all England's travel arrangements over to a company called CSS Stella. So while the FA can claim (as they did today) that "the players are getting the same amount of tickets that they got for France 98", it is up to CSS to tell them that they have to pay for all but one of them. A fantastic piece of delegation it has to be said. Now if only they could get Arthur Andersen to select the team...

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"We have prepared a fiesta at the Santiago Bernabeu, but we didn't want to announce it before the game so that we couldn't be accused of being overconfident and arrogant" - But you arranged it all the same, eh? Real Madrid chairman Lorenzo Sanz basks in the glow of Big Cup.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

BE AFRAID, BE VERY LLANSANTFFRRAID

It's Saturday afternoon and the matches are over. Want to know what happened between Hartlepool and Macclesfield? Grandstand will tell you. Need to check the result of Queen of the South v Stenhousemuir? Steve Rider's your man. Desperate to find out what went on in the big Inter Cardiff and Flexys Cefn Druids clash? Tough cheese on toast, mate - they don't bother with the League of Wales on Final Score.

It's a situation LoW champions Total Network Solutions are trying to rectify. Currently, the results are only read out on the Welsh version of the programme, an opt-out rugby-fest presented by Ian Gwyn Hughes. But if you live in Llansantffrraid, the near-the-border town where TNS obviously come from, you can only receive the oppressive Rider-fronted English version.

"Some people get a bad reception on BBC Wales and tune in to BBC Midlands, who obviously don't broadcast Welsh results," Del Thomas, who is co-ordinating the campaign, explained to a sleeping audience. "If they show the Scottish Second Division results, they should show the national League of Wales results," he argued reasonably.

BBC director-general Greg Dyke has deemed the current coverage sufficient, perhaps having better things to worry about. But that's not going to stop Thomas, who has contacted all 40 Welsh MPs in order to get some momentum behind his campaign. The Fiver is convinced the honourable members won't think their time is being wasted, and wishes Thomas all the best.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

(INORDINATELY LATE) COMPETITION TIME!

Organisation is the Fiver's strong point, which is why we're happy to announce a competition to win tickets for, er, Saturday's match between the mighty England and some cloggers called Brazil at Wembley. We've got one pair of tickets to give away thanks to Back the Bid. At www.backthebid.com you can register your support (anecdotes encouraged!) for the FA's bid to bring the 2006 World Cup to England. If you want to register your support for South Africa, you should go someplace else.

Due to the rather unwieldy time restrictions, this competition is limited to UK-based readers only. So if you hail from Barbados it might be best to enter under a false address. Anyway, here's the question: Who scored for England the last time the two sides met at Wembley? Answers on an email to the.boss@theguardian.com and all entries should reach us by 10am on Friday morning (ie: tomorrow).

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Besiktas have offered Liverpool £5m for Rigobert Song. The Cameroon international defender joined Anfield last year for £2.6m.

Arsenal have failed to complete the signing of Real Mallorca midfielder Lauren. The Cameroonian's representatives met David Dein in Paris yesterday, but no contract was signed. Other clubs are believed to have expressed an interest in the player, including one unnamed Premiership side.

Celta Vigo are prepared to offer Celtic a player exchange in order to sign top scorer Mark Viduka. Unsettled Israeli winger Haim Revivo is believed to be one of the names on offer.

Middlesbrough have played down claims that Real Madrid have accepted a £2m bid for Christian Karembeu. "The club has expressed an interest but nothing has been decided," the club said today.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

webTitle: Prescott tells rail firms to improve services

fields.headline: Prescott tells rail firms to improve services
fields.trailText: The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, told Britain's privatised train companies at the national rail summit today that they must do better.
fields.body:
The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, told Britain's privatised train companies at the national rail summit today that they must do better.

He said the rail companies' performance was still too patchy and that they needed to improve punctuality, the quality of services, reliability, passenger information and security.

"I want to see the worst-performing companies reaching the standards of the best," he said. "There will be no easy ride for anybody in this industry except for one person - the passenger."

Mr Prescott was speaking at the second annual national rail summit, where he was meeting train operators and rail regulators. Few improvements have been made to the system since the deputy prime minister branded it a "national disgrace" more than a year ago.

He gave no hint of the government money that the rail companies are hoping for, but said he was a great fan of the public-private partnership. "It's controversial, but I believe it to be right. Government money can lever in a lot of private money," he said.

The government will publish a 10-year plan for the railways in July. At the moment, the public subsidy to the rail industry is falling.

Before Mr Prescott spoke at the summit in Westminster, delegates stood with heads bowed in a one-minute silence in memory of the victims of the Paddington rail crash.

Transport minister Lord Macdonald said Paddington was an awful tragedy. "This has been a harrowing year for all involved in the railways," he added.

"There is never a conflict of interest between safety and punctuality," Mr Prescott said. "Safety must come first."
