webTitle: Tony rushes in where Bill fears to tread

fields.headline: Tony rushes in where Bill fears to tread
fields.trailText: For all those conspiracy cranks and paranoid anti-globalisers who imagine that the planet's corporate elite and government functionaries actually meet to conspire about their blueprint for rewriting the laws of sovereign nations, be advised that the next meeting of the New World Order is being held this week at the Swiss Hotel in Brussels. It is the mid-year meeting of the Transatlantic Business Dialogue.
fields.body:
For all those conspiracy cranks and paranoid anti-globalisers who imagine that the planet's corporate elite and government functionaries actually meet to conspire about their blueprint for rewriting the laws of sovereign nations, be advised that the next meeting of the New World Order is being held this week at the Swiss Hotel in Brussels. It is the mid-year meeting of the Transatlantic Business Dialogue.

In 1997, just after Labour's general election victory, the United States commerce secretary, Bill Daley, had a private meeting with Britain's new Trade Secretary, Margaret Beckett, to instruct her on the ways of the world.

According to the US secretary's own briefing notes - obtained under the US Freedom of Information Act - Daley dictated a list of four changes in UK law and policy required to smooth the path of American corporations in Britain. In addition, further guidance would be provided by what Daley described as "the most influential business group advising government on US-EU commercial relations", the Transatlantic Business Dialogue (TABD). "Your encouragement", he admonished the Minister, "would be helpful."

As Butch said to Sundance, who are these guys? TABD is a working group of the West's 100 most powerful chief executives. When political leaders meet at the World Trade Organisation, this more permanent grouping provides their agenda.

The TABD's system is very efficient. One US bigwig is paired with one European for each sector grouping. For example, Monsanto's Robert Harness and Unilever's Huib Vigeveno are in charge of Agri-Biotech.

The US government and the European Union each assign an official to each industry pair. TABD has privileged access not to small fry, but to top bananas such as Pascal Lamy, the European trade commissioner, and Erkki Liikanen, commissioner for enterprise and the information society.

This week the officials are due to report to their corporate duos on the headway made on the 33 items on the current TABD implementation table. This lists 33 environment, consumer and worker protection laws in selected nations that TABD wishes to defeat or water down. The corporates will render their verdict on what TABD calls the scorecard. This will then be turned over, along with a new implementation table - including agenda items for the WTO - to President Clinton and Romano Prodi, the European Commission president, at their meeting in Portugal later this month.

The 1988 implementation table, one of the first documents obtained, grudgingly, from the Commission under its access to information rules, reveals what's planned for our brave new world. For example, several of the "tetra-partite groups' (the two-on-two government-business trysting sessions) seek expansion for something called the MRA (Mutual Recognition Agreement), or what the TABD describes as "approved once, accepted everywhere". It is the globalisers' cruise missile. Here's an example of how it works. Years ago Pfizer manufactured defective heart valves that cracked, killing 165 patients. Europe became understandably wary of accepting devices merely because they had been blessed by the US Food and Drug Administration. But the MRA brushes aside individual nations' health and safety regulatory reviews - including individual regulation of medical device manufacturing plants.

Given the ill-feeling in Europe about genetic modification, the MRA rules for GM products are devilishly complex, effectively applying only to the developing nations. Does Brazil have a problem with Monsanto's bovine growth hormone? Sorry, approval by the WTO's Codex Alimentarius committee means Brazil must accept the product or face WTO trade sanctions.

The US, too, is a target. TABD's products liability group, under the guise of eliminating "non-tariff" trade barriers, takes aim at the right of US citizens to sue corporate bad guys. One TABD proposal would reverse the $5bn judgment against Exxon in the Exxon Valdez oil spill.

Recently the TABD locomotive has been slowed by lambs on the tracks. The demonstrations in Seattle and Washington achieved an effect far beyond anything the demonstrators themselves could have imagined. The first purpose of the WTO meeting was to launch a new round of cuts in import duties and to eliminate more of the rules covering imports, known as non-tariff regulatory barriers. That all went up in tear-gas smoke.

Worse, TABD's deregulation pro gramme was publicly rejected by an erstwhile ally. The implementation table clearly told government officials, on page 17, that "the basic purpose of an MAI [Multilateral Agreement on Investments] should not be undermined by language on labour policy and environmental policy", dicta adopted by the US and EC.

Yet there was President Clinton, spooked by opinion polls showing support for the demonstrators, telling the Seattle audience weepy-eyed stories of the horrors of child labour in Brazil. Business leaders were infuriated. Frustration with their former champion, Clinton, burst into the open earlier this month when, at a meeting of the International Chamber of Commerce in Budapest, industrialists shouted down a proposal to "dialogue" with non-governmental organisations such as Amnesty International.

"I don't believe that those who were in Seattle represented somebody with a legitimate stake," fumed Peter Sutherland, head of investment bank Goldman Sachs UK. Sutherland, who jumped to Goldman from his post as director of the WTO, prefers the company of his own kind. "We have to be very careful on engaging in this debate, as those NGOs [non-governmental organisations] should not have a say with government!"

If Clinton has wimped out on business, the Chambers of Commerce have found a new knight errant. "Tony Blair, he was great! He had guts! That's the leadership we need," Jagdish Bhagwati, an economist and globalisation guru, told the disheartened suits in Budapest. He applauded the British PM for speaking out "against anti-capitalist NGOs".

Businessmen lobbying their way into government offices is an old story, but the supercharged TABD version - infiltration by invitation - began only in 1995 as the brainchild of Ron Brown, President Clinton's first commerce secretary. Brown, who died in a 1996 air crash, was the president's Peter Mandelson, architect of the scheme to turn Democrats into New Democrats, the party of business. When Brown died, Clinton's passion for pairing with business passed away too, not uninfluenced by the demolition of the New Democrats in the 1994 congressional elections.

Clinton lopped off the "New" label when his buddies in industry, sensing his weakness, rushed back home to the Republican party. The president still goes through the motions of meeting TABD, as required by commercial realpolitik, but its leaders, such as Jim Wootten of the US Chamber of Commerce, tell me they doubt his sincerity.

But Blair is different. "Blair really believes," says Bhagwati admiringly of the British prime minister's globalising fervour. And TABD members agree. Blair is a man of convictions. His heart leaps at visions of a flexible labour force, of entrepreneurs liberated from bureaucrats' rule-books, of a new economy relieved of the antique task of bending metal into Rover cars.

In 1997, according to US documents, Blair personally stepped over Beckett to water down regulations permitting Americans to build gas-fired power plants in the UK. He also hopped about to accomplish the other three tasks on the US commerce secretary's favours list.

Don't dismiss this as just a series of tawdry fixes. Blair rolled out the doormat in Downing Street to US companies because he looks on these bold screw-the-rules operators as an entrepreneurial stud pool whom he hopes will breed with and revitalise the hoof-dragging local stock.

It's sad, really. Unlike Clinton, who wised up quickly, Blair confuses the TABD's self-serving wishlist with a programme of economic salvation. But as his poll ratings keep slipping, he will find that, as they say in Arkansas, Tony's been kissed - but he ain't been loved. The Observer

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: Timeshare touts
fields.body:
Timeshare touts

Those infamous rogues, timeshare touts, have made few appearances on this page, but don't be tempted into thinking that they've gone away. Poor RM Askham of North Yorkshire did and was therefore sanguine as he was whisked off by a friendly rep while holidaying in Gran Canaria. "In the car, I was promised it wasn't a time share operation, but of course it was." He and his wife were given the usual hard sell, promised exchanges and five-star late breaks all over the world and told they could pick their unit. Only afterwards did they discover that they had no say over where their timeshare apartment was or when they could take their annual week's break.

Nevertheless, the sales company, Palm Oasis, persuaded them to part with £8,000 for a one-bedroom apartment. When the Askhams attempted to register it with Interval International, the UK-based broker company which manages exchanges, they discovered that their unit had not yet been built. They were promised alternative accommodation, but none was forthcoming, so instead Askham tried to book a Latebreak week at another resort but was told that none of the 30 properties listed in the scheme were available. Askham has written to Palm Oasis to confirm that the unit would be available by November but has received no reply.

Interval International points out that while it provides exchange and leisure services to Palm Oasis clients it does not sell or manage the resort. Askham, it says, was not given an alternative week at another timeshare resort because, since his own unit was unfinished, he would have nothing to offer other timeshare owners in exchange. Nor could he console himself with the Latebreak scheme because the week he requested was in high season. Palm Oasis has failed to reply to Consumer's overtures.

Anyone else tempted to try timeshare (which can work well if you're careful) can glean tips from the Timeshare Consumer's Association on 020-8296 0900 or consult their website at www. timeshare.org.uk. And always beware of companies who resort to expensive hard-sell promotions. Those with a good product at a good price can attract customers without pressure tactics.

Spinning a line

Here's an update on 1st Line, our favourite telesales firm. It's the one which promises you free trials of mobile phones and asks for your bank account details as a security. The next thing many of our readers knew was that a direct debit had been set up without their knowledge. The idea is that you are released from your contract if you notify 1st Line before the fortnight's trial is up, but it doesn't always work like that.

Denis Dunn of Essex wrote in a while back after line rental charges began vanishing from his account, despite returning his trial phone. 1st Line apologised via Consumer, but since then he's been threatened with a debt collection agency unless he pays money he doesn't owe.

Nigel Harris of Nottingham was cold called by a 1st Line salesman who claimed to be from BT Cellnet and offered him a trial phone with £50 worth of free calls. Harris asked if it could wait until he returned from a six-week trip but he was told the offer would have closed by then. He agreed to accept delivery there and then, to leave the phone at home with a call bar in place, and to take advantage of a month's free line rental as an incentive.

When he returned, he found line rental charges had been debited from his account. He rang to cancel the deal and was persuaded to hang on to take advantage of the free calls. Only afterwards did he discover that he was not eligible for the offer because the phone bar had not allowed him to make the qualifying number of calls. His subsequent attempts to contact 1st Line have been in vain and he too is being threatened with a debt collection agency.

1st Line takes several weeks to digest this information, then announces its repentance. The accounts of both customers have now been cancelled and outstanding charges waived. Shame it forgot to inform the aggrieved parties about it - Dunn says he still hasn't heard a word.

Unanswered call

Sue Lukes' problem is, conversely, that she can't entice a certain company to the phone. "Can you find out what BT Cellnet has against phone calls?" she asks. Lukes paid her phone bill by telephone banking, then found her service suspended. A letter from BT explained that it did not recommend such a method because payments took three weeks to process. Instead she was asked to call a BT number and give her credit card details over the line. The trouble is that the line is permanently engaged and she can't get through.

BT Cellnet says that Lukes' experience has been "fed back in to the business to investigate how debit card payments can be speeded up". It has now permitted her to pay her dues.

fields.headline: Shopping animals
fields.standfirst: So, what kind of internet consumer are you - a gazelle or a gorilla? New research suggests there are five distinct species of online buyer.  Lorraine Eames  investigates
fields.trailText: So, what kind of internet consumer are you - a gazelle or a gorilla? New research suggests there are five distinct species of online buyer. Lorraine Eames investigates
fields.body:
Shopping online is still a relatively new phenomenon. As consumers get into the swing of clicking, rather then queuing for their goods, they develop new shopping habits - habits which retailers are keen to cash in on.

According to a recent survey by market analysts Datamonitor, web consumers have quite different habits to those shopping on the high street. Online customers fall into certain categories, exhibiting characteristics which identify them as a particular "breed" of e-shopper.

One of the most telling results of the survey is that, despite the flurry of dot.com adverts filling the airwaves and billboards, many of us are still wary of making a purchase over the internet. Although 80% of respondents had browsed the net for anything from CDs to cars, less than a third had actually taken the plunge and ordered online, and even fewer - just 15% - had paid over the internet.

But, according to the report, all this is about to change. Falling prices mean that computer ownership "is ceasing to be the preserve of the young and affluent." And the increasing popularity of interactive TV, games consoles and WAP phones means you don't even need a computer to shop online. More than 70% of Europeans already own at least one interactive device and it is thought that, by 2004, more than threequarters of all households with PCs will be connected to the internet, increasing the potential online shopping population from its current 19m brave speculators to a whopping 100m big spenders.

Overall, the proportion of internet users who buy online is expected to rise from 25% to 70% over the next four years.

Once consumers progress from starter to expert they will inevitably spend more time, and money, on the internet. Datamonitor spoke to a total of 12,000 people, aged from 18 upwards, in the UK, Sweden, Germany, France and Spain. According to their findings, we are all shopping animals. Which one are you?

The rhino

Not always, but mostly elderly, with 61% of the group being over 65. Rhinos tend to belong to a relatively low income household, often due to retirement. This consumer wants to see, feel - and if possible sniff - their groceries before they hand over the ready cash. In fact, cash is the preferred method of payment and the thought of putting credit card details on to a computer and clicking on a "mouse" which sends them to someone they've never met or spoken to is enough to send even the toughest, most thick-skinned rhino charging into the bushes for cover. Only a third of all rhinos have gone online at least once.

The puma

At the opposite end of the shopping jungle lies the puma. Usually young, often single, with a high income and fearless disposition, these predators want their shopping delivered yesterday and aren't afraid to try out new technology. If you can get it online, they'll buy it , anything from the latest Nike (or possibly Puma?) trainers to a new car. They'll even hunt for food online - provided it can be delivered within the hour - and can usually be relied on to try anything once. However, this big cat should remember what curiosity did and be a little more cautious when handing over their financial details, if they don't want to get their claws burned.

The gazelle

Generally 30-somethings, and usually computer literate, these are the lowest spending group in the younger categories. Youthful and energetic, yes, but unlike the puma, the gazelle has a more timid approach to shopping on the internet. Moving in herds, often with a young family in tow, they prefer to hang back, saving their hard-earned cash for the things they really need. They're not averse to the web, and will occasionally dip their toe in the water, but they'd rather wait to see if it's safe before wading in. Their average online spend in the past six months was £170.

The gorilla

Still preferring to spend most of their substantial income on the high street, this group are not as conservative as the rhinos and are open to new suggestions. They will eventually get into the swing of shopping on the net, but only after carefully weighing up the pros and cons. Classic gorilla behaviour involves starting slowly with low risk, familiar items - something from amazon perhaps, and then moving on to bigger transactions as confidence builds. Despite being financially better off than rhinos only 18% of this group, had logged on to the internet.

The jackal

This pack animal has got the internet sussed and spends most of their day persuading other, less adventurous types, to try out the latest technology. If they're not surfing for a new coat or digging up a bargain CD, they're ordering groceries at home and breathing a contented sigh at not having to fight their way through the crowds in the high street. Around 10 years younger than gorillas or rhinos, jackals spend approximately 10 times more money on internet shopping - an impressive average of £440 over six months.

fields.headline: Full  Ulster Freedom Fighters' statement
fields.trailText: Our British government has called on the UFF to replicate the confidence-building measure recently outlined by the IRA. The UFF does not consider the verification of selected IRA dumps as a step it is required to reciprocate. The absence of confidence in respect of IRA commitment to permanent peace is a matter for the IRA alone to address.
fields.body:
Our British government has called on the UFF to replicate the confidence-building measure recently outlined by the IRA. The UFF does not consider the verification of selected IRA dumps as a step it is required to reciprocate. The absence of confidence in respect of IRA commitment to permanent peace is a matter for the IRA alone to address.

During the announcement of its end to hostilities in 1994 the UFF expressed abject and true remorse to the innocent victims of the conflict. In August 1995 the UFF committed itself to non-initiation of conflict and has continued to maintain a no first strike policy. These gestures were made in good faith as honourable contributions to the process of conflict resolution and as enhancements of the peace process. Republicans declined to respond in kind in those instances.

For its part the UFF remains fully committed to the peace process and the removal of conflict from this society. The UFF is the only armed group to have endorsed the Stormont agreement and continues to view it as the best vehicle to achieve long term political stability.

The UFF is not convinced the IRA commitment to put its arms beyond use represents an intention to disarm. We retain a concern that uncertainty around this issue will foster instability in any future Northern Ireland government. The bona fides of republican intent on this matter will, however, be established in the course of time. The UFF will continue to monitor the situation closely.

In addition we wish to draw attention to continued agitation on the part of republicans and the government of the Republic of Ireland on issues of nationality. Their determination to attack Northern Ireland's sovereignty and erode the identity of the majority of its people will be resisted and can only undermine the prospects for the Stormont agreement achieving the stable society we hope for.

fields.headline: Bitter memories overshadow Pinochet decision
fields.standfirst: Tito Tricot, who was tortured under the Pinochet regime, reacts to the apparent decision to lift Pinochet's immunity from prosecution
fields.trailText: Tito Tricot, who was tortured under the Pinochet regime, reacts to the apparent decision to lift Pinochet's immunity from prosecution.
fields.body:
It's raining heavily in Chile today as if the sky wished to cleanse the deep wounds of the past, perhaps because a learned pelican or a joyful cormorant informed the silver clouds that the old dictator's immunity from prosecution has been lifted. Or has it?

The fact is that no one knows for certain what the Court of Appeal decision is, with no official announcement due until next week at the earliest.

However, everyone in the country knows, "off the record" as is usually the case in this part of the world, that General Pinochet's immunity from prosecution will indeed be lifted.

Social, political and human rights organizations that have filed 109 lawsuits against the dictator called it "a victory of democracy over militarism".

I wish I could rejoice at the latest development in the Pinochet saga, but the bitter memories of my pregnant wife being kept in solitary confinement in a dark and filthy cell, overshadow any feelings of happiness.

I wish I could at least smile, but the horrifying screams of friends being savagely tortured by the secret police, are still ingrained in my memory.

I wish I could share some of my countrymen's contentment, but the recent discoveries of more mass graves, the untold suffering of those whose toenails and teeth were extracted before being killed, the incredible sadism of cowardly army officers who raped and murdered defenceless women, the smashed skulls of little children, the sight of elderly men hanging naked from their wrists while being beaten to death, prevent me from being happy.

Pinochet's crimes are so horrendous that no judicial decision or eventual sentence can ever make up for so much suffering and pain.

Besides, I'm absolutely convinced that he will never be tried, let alone sentenced to serve a single day in prison.

Former police chief and now designated senator, Fernando Cordero, has synthesized Pinochet supporters' feelings towards the case by unequivocally stating that "the court has no right to try Pinochet".

He is wrong, yet at the same time he is sadly right, because for over three decades now Pinochet and armed forces personnel at large have been above the law.

The military are still very powerful and they know it, so does the government and other cowardly politicians who are afraid to confront the military.

Pinochet's defence is going to argue that he is unfit to stand trial, that he is mentally incapacitated to follow complex legal arguments.

The courts are going to accept such spurious arguments and the criminal will walk free on so called humanitarian grounds.

On that day, a bewildered pelican and an outraged cormorant will kiss the clouds to unleash a furious storm to cleanse the wounds and the names of the fallen ones.

webTitle: Ashcroft plants British roots with university donation

fields.headline: Ashcroft plants British roots with university donation
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: May 25 2000: Michael Ashcroft yesterday donated £5m to a British university, prompting accusations that the controversial Conservative party treasurer and tax exile is attempting to "curry favour" as he prepares to take up his seat in the House of Lords.
fields.body:
Michael Ashcroft yesterday donated £5m to a British university, prompting accusations that the controversial Conservative party treasurer and tax exile is attempting to "curry favour" as he prepares to take up his seat in the House of Lords.

Labour MPs reacted with suspicion to Mr Ashcroft's announcement, which comes hard on the heels of the unprecedented decision of a cross-party committee of peers to bar him from sitting in the House of Lords until he starts paying full British taxes.

Peter Bradley, the MP for The Wrekin, said: "If Mr Ashcroft wants to show his commitment to this country he should follow the example of the rest of us and start paying taxes now."

Mr Ashcroft, who says he will move to Britain by the end of December, attempted yesterday to demonstrate that he is putting down roots in Britain, announcing a £5m donation to fund a new business school at Anglia Polytechnic University. The centre will be named the Ashcroft International Business School after the multi-millionaire businessman who completed an HND in business studies at the Chelmsford campus in the 1960s.

Mr Ashcroft said he had decided to make the donation after being impressed by his old college during a recent visit. "I was impressed with the enthusiasm of the management team but at the same time I recognised some of the difficulties associated with developing a university of this type," he said. "I expressed a desire to help, and my commitment to the new business and management centre is the result."

His donation was immediately dismissed by Labour. Mr Bradley said: "Mr Ashcroft can well afford such generosity - what he donates in Belizean dollars is more than compensated by what he saves in not paying British taxes."

Labour MPs were angered in March when Mr Ashcroft was awarded a peerage less than a year after his passage to the Lords was blocked by the cross-party political honours scrutiny committee. The committee said Mr Ashcroft would only be allowed to take up his seat if he settled permanently in Britain by the end of this year. Mr Ashcroft is currently based in Florida.

The row over his peerage rumbled on last night when the honours scrutiny committee came under fire for refusing to give details of how it will ensure that Mr Ashcroft has fulfilled the conditions to take up his seat. Sir Anthony Merifield, the clerk to the honours committee, said in a letter to Mr Bradley that he had "no reason to doubt that Mr Ashcroft will abide by his undertakings".

Mr Bradley dismissed Sir Anthony's letter as "highly unsatisfactory" and an example of the establishment closing ranks. "This high-handed response suggests that the committee is prepared to make a gentleman's agreement with the Conservative party which is not known for its straight dealing," he said.

Mr Ashcroft's spokesman, Alan Kilkenny, rejected suggestions that Mr Ashcroft's donation was a cynical gesture ahead of taking up a seat in the Lords.

fields.headline: Fiji's fragile flower trampled down
fields.standfirst: The nationalist bullying behind the latest coup will set Fiji's development back years, says Christopher Zinn
fields.trailText: The Fijians are a talkative people, but of all the many words spoken about the now largely successful armed coup, it was former coup leader Sitiveni Rabuka who perhaps summed up the mood best by lamenting that democracy is a foreign flower in Fiji. He is aware that the traditional chiefs' capitulation to most of gunman George Speight's demands - including a pardon for those involved and replacing the ethnic Indian prime minister with an indigenous Fijian - mean big trouble for the little islands.
fields.body:
The Fijians are a talkative people, but of all the many words spoken about the now largely successful armed coup, it was former coup leader Sitiveni Rabuka who perhaps summed up the mood best by lamenting that democracy is a foreign flower in Fiji. He is aware that the traditional chiefs' capitulation to most of gunman George Speight's demands - including a pardon for those involved and replacing the ethnic Indian prime minister with an indigenous Fijian - mean big trouble for the little islands.

"We should brace ourselves for the modern day ... curses which people can bring upon a nation," he said, mentioning trade and aid bans, isolation and a new pariah status. And Rabuka should know. It was his two coups in 1987 which led to Fiji being expelled from the Commonwealth until its recent re-admittance.

Business and tourism were booming until last Friday, but it had taken the nation years to recover from the instability. Today, an Indian businessman puts the damage at setting Fiji back another 15-20 years in the development stakes. But he is unlikely to remain, and will probably join a new wave of exiles akin to the 50,000 white-collar Indians who fled overseas last time.

Speight is reportedly unhappy with the peace plan from the Great Council of Chiefs because it does not agree to his demands for President Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara to step down at once and for the constitution to be scrapped as opposed to just reviewed. But the bankrupt businessman shouldn't complain. The barefaced cheek of his plan to depose PM Chaudhry and hold him and his MPs hostage for a week paid off handsomely. webTitle: Asylum applications at lowest for a year

fields.headline: Asylum applications at lowest for a year
fields.trailText: A shorter working month meant that the number of people seeking asylum in Britain during April fell to the lowest level for almost a year, new figures showed today.
fields.body:
A shorter working month meant that the number of people seeking asylum in Britain during April fell to the lowest level for almost a year, new figures showed today.

A total of 5,890 applications were made in April, the smallest monthly total since May 1999, the home office figures showed. However, between February and April, requests averaged 6,230 a month - 32% more than the 4,715 figure for the same period last year.

Last month, 9,650 initial decisions were given, 15% down on March's record of 11,340, but a substantial improvement on the 2,320 processed in December.

A home office spokeswoman said the figures showed the effectiveness of home secretary Jack Straw's measures to reform the asylum process.

"The figures show the successful impact of the reform programme so far," she said. "There is more to be done, but we have evidence that the new measures are working."

More Sri Lankans applied for asylum than any other nationality. Applications from the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, which had headed the table in March, fell by 46% in April.

British diplomats have pointed out new regulations on asylum seekers to eastern European media, and a Downing Street spokesman cited the subsequent press coverage as proof that the message to people thinking of "abusing our process of asylum" was "going out loud and clear".

webTitle: May 25: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: May 25: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Survey shows discrimination against America's Latino actors, mixed fortunes for Oz memorabilia, Bruce Willis in Ocean's Eleven talks, and Jack Black enters the million dollar bracket
fields.body:
 Two-thirds of America's Latino actors claim that they have been rejected for a role because of racial stereotyping, while 50% feel that a Spanish surname is an impediment to a successful career. The findings are the result of a survey published by the non-profit making Tomas Rivera Policy Institute. It concluded that America's Latino population remains worryingly short-changed by the entertainment industry. While few of the actors surveyed felt that they had experienced racism on set, many claimed that they were discriminated against when looking for work. The report found that fair-skinned Latinos are more likely to be cast than those with darker skin and that the parts they have access to remains limited. "We continue to see Latinos largely cast in servant-class roles, like Jose the bus-boy and Maria the maid," said institute president Harry Pachon.

 It emerged today that Mission: Impossible 2 (pictured), the $90m spy thriller starring Tom Cruise, started filming without a finished script. What's more, Entertainment Weekly reported yesterday that the writer, Robert (Chinatown) Towne, was making changes to his work as recently as two weeks ago. The writer disputes rumours, however, that his non-stop revisions were a desperate attempt to save a faltering movie.

 There were mixed fortunes for the Wizard of Oz memorabilia auctioned at Christie's in New York last night (see Tuesday's story). The ruby slippers worn by Judy Garland in the 1939 classic went under the hammer for an impressive $666,000, but the Cowardly Lion costume worn by Bert Lahr was withdrawn from sale after the bidding topped out at a figure below the starting price. The slippers were bought by Dave Elkonby, 36, a private collector who plans to open a movie memorabilia museum in his native LA. Elkonby described his purchase as "the cat's miaow."

 Bruce Willis is in talks to hook up with Ocean's 11. Backed by Warner Brothers, the film is a remake of the 1960 comedy-thriller which starred the complete Rat Pack (Frank Sinatra, Sammy Davis Jr, Dean Martin and Peter Lawford). The new film is to be directed by Steven Soderbergh, currently riding high in Hollywood following the success of Erin Brockovich. George Clooney (who collaborated with Soderbergh on 1998's Out of Sight) has already signed on to play the Sinatra role. If Willis commits to the project, it is thought that he will take the slot originally filled by Dean Martin.

 Jack Black's support turn as a record-shop fascist in the forthcoming High Fidelity looks to have shoved him into the million dollar bracket. The rotund, hyperactive actor has just signed to play Mike Myers's sidekick in the monkey-business comedy Dieter for an estimated $1m. This comes just a few weeks after Black pocketed a cheque for a similar figure on signing to the Columbia comedy Saving Silverman. In High Fidelity, Black's hilarious know-all, music-bore antics threaten to steal the show from star John Cusack, while his climactic spot of on-stage singing sends the film off with a flourish. In addition to his acting day-job, music is clearly a passion for Black, who forms one half of the rising rap duo Tenacious D.

webTitle: George Lucas to direct Stars Wars shock!

fields.headline: George Lucas to direct Stars Wars shock!
fields.trailText: Lucasfilm announced this week that - to no one's great surprise - George Lucas would be taking the director's chair for the forthcoming Star Wars: Episode 2
fields.body:
Lucasfilm announced this week that - to no one's great surprise - George Lucas would be taking the director's chair for the forthcoming Star Wars: Episode 2. But this is not so obvious a statement as it first appears. After dazzling the world with Star Wars in 1977, Lucas handed over the director's reins to Irvin Kershner for the Empire Strikes Back in 1980 and to Richard Marquand for Return of the Jedi in 1983, and in fact did not direct another movie until the Phantom Menace in 1998.

More revered as a director than writer, Lucas has also penned Episode 2 himself although Jonathan Hales, whose film credits include the 1980 Agatha Christie adaptation of The Mirror Crack'd, will give it a final polish.

Meanwhile in Australia, where the film begins shooting this summer, the stunt co-ordinator has been scouring Sydney for some rough and ready stuntmen. Considering that such stunt-laden outings as The Matrix and Mission: Impossible 2 were filmed there, he shouldn't have too much trouble finding them.

webTitle: Matt Damon to replace Brad Pitt in The Bourne Identity

fields.headline: Matt Damon to replace Brad Pitt in The Bourne Identity
fields.trailText: Following the last-minute exit of Brad Pitt, Matt Damon is top choice to star in The Bourne Identity, a paranoid thriller to be directed by Doug (Go) Liman
fields.body:
Following the last-minute exit of Brad Pitt, Matt Damon is Universal's top choice to star in The Bourne Identity, a paranoid thriller to be directed by Doug (Go) Liman. Damon is currently in final negotiations with studio executives, and insider sources report that the picture is scheduled to begin shooting in September or October.

The Bourne Identity, is based on the bestselling yarn by king of the airport novels, Robert Ludlum. The story follows the misadventures of an amnesiac man who finds himself washed up on a beach riddled with gun-shot wounds. Before long, our hero is being hounded cross-country by assassins, while simultaneously trying to figure out who he is.

The presence of respected left-field director Liman behind the camera suggests that The Bourne Identity may well adopt the same tack as The Talented Mr Ripley in converting an essentially pulp-thriller source book into a weightier, more high-brow picture. The identity problems of Bourne's central character echo that of the blank and predatory character that Damon played in Ripley.

The Bourne Identity has been regarded as one of Universal's most prestigious projects for over a year. Pitt pulled out of the movie earlier this week due to a schedule conflict with his starring role in Tony Scott's Spy Game. Damon has recently completed work on the Robert Redford-directed drama The Legend of Bagger Vance, and is currently collaborating with director Jim Sheridan (My Left Foot) on a treatment of the Wally Lamb novel I Know This Much is True.

webTitle: MacLaurin claims match-fixing inquiry is 'tip of the iceberg'

fields.headline: MacLaurin claims match-fixing inquiry is 'tip of the iceberg'
fields.trailText: England cricket chief Lord MacLaurin has claimed the Pakistani match-fixing inquiry is just the "tip of the iceberg" and hinted at mafia involvement in the game.
fields.body:
England cricket chief Lord MacLaurin has claimed the Pakistani match-fixing inquiry is just the "tip of the iceberg" and hinted at mafia involvement in the game.

Former captain Salim Malik and former Test bowler Ata-ur-Rehman were banned for life yesterday by the Pakistan Cricket Board (PCB) for match-fixing. But MacLaurin, speaking on Radio 4 earlier today claimed: "I don't like to say this really but I think this might be just the tip of the iceberg."

"I believe there are other problems which we have to unearth. I do know there are a number of investigative journalists looking at this problem throughout the world. I know police forces are looking at it. Although we have had this result so far, watch this space because this is not the end of it."

When asked if he thought it was administrators or just players involved, he added: "I'm uneasy. I have a feeling that it can be both. It could be a mafia-type organisation and the players are just pawns in this.

" I'm very pleased these findings are coming out. We have to pursue it to the end to clean the game."

MacLaurin said it was possible the International Cricket Council could intervene further in the Pakistan cases. "I think the ICC have the authority to ask the parent board to look again at the fines or suspensions that they are going to impose," he said.

"If they are not satisfied they would ask a third party to look at it, so this is by no means an open and shut case."

Meanwhile Malik has claimed he will go to court to challenge the life ban imposed by the Pakistan Cricket Board.

"I am being made the scapegoat. I haven't done anything wrong and I continue to plead by innocence," Malik said from Lahore. "I have been cleared by two previous investigations. But now I find myself victimised again. Every time a probe is carried out, my name is dragged in despite having served the country with distinction and pride.

"I am in consultation with my legal advisers and will challenge the decision in the court," he continued. "I don't accept the ban and will continue to fight to get my name cleared, because no matter if my cricket is finished I have a life ahead of me and can't live with the reputation of being a gambler."

fields.headline: Rubbish
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about refuse, rejects and other castoffs on the net
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about refuse, rejects and other castoffs on the net
fields.body:
1. Britain's waste is out of control and we may have to start burning more of the 414m tonnes we produce a year, the government warned today.

2. Until now, we've dumped 80% in landfill sites; of the rest, two-thirds is incinerated and the remainder recycled.

3. Environmentalists such as Friends of the Earth object to incineration because they believe it adds to air pollution and is a waste of potentially valuable resources.

4. Their unlikely allies are the Tories who want to halt incinerator building until independent British scientific evidence proves they are safe.

5. England and Wales trail Europe on recycling: Germany, Sweden and Finland all manage more than 30%, while Austria and the Netherlands reach 45%. Switzerland comes top with 52%.

6. Carelessly deposited rubbish was for centuries a source of disease through the infected water supplies and a breeding ground for flies, rats and other vermin.

7. For example, pigs that fed on rubbish tips caught diseases such as trichinosis, which they readily passed on to humans. Today, we know that carcinogens emanate from toxic waste.

8. Not everyone thinks rubbish is rubbish. Garbologists simply love to rifle through the dustbins of the rich and famous, find out what they had for dinner, and what they were thinking.

9. Wombles too are great fans of the things that everyday folk leave behind.

10. In truth, landfill's a gas. Methane produced by decomposing organic matter across the country would, say the experts, generate enough electricity to power a city the size of Leeds.

fields.headline: Government backs burning waste
fields.standfirst: Eurotrash: Britain scrapes barrel in waste leagues
fields.trailText: More rubbish will be burned in incinerators under the government's new strategy for waste management unveiled today.
fields.body:
More rubbish will be burned in incinerators under the government's new strategy for waste management unveiled today.

Environment minister Michael Meacher will urge the public to make more use of local council recycling facilities for paper, metal and glass. But environmentalists' attention will invariably be focused on the government's recommendation of an extended "role" for incinerators to prevent so much of the country's rubbish being dumped in the ground.

Mr Meacher insisted that the government strategy prioritised waste reduction and increased recycling, with only a "small increase" in incineration, where concerns over the health risks of burning waste were "enormously exaggerated".

"The government is for the first time setting statutory targets for local authority recycling and composting which will double recycling in three years," he told the Today programme.

"It is at a pathetically low level of about 9% at the present time. We will be requiring local authorities to take action on recycling, and to achieve these targets, local authorities will have to start or step up doorstep collection of recyclable waste. We intend to treble the rate of recycling and composting of household waste within the next decade, to achieve a recycling rate of 30% by 2010."

A spokesman for the Department of the Environment confirmed the "role for incineration" in the government's waste strategy.

"The older generation of more polluting incinerators were shut down, or refurbished to meet new standards, in 1996. Modern waste-to-energy incinerators are tightly regulated to protect human health and the environment," he said.

Labour's plans received a critical reception from Conservatives and Liberal Democrats, which also set out their waste management plans this week.

Liberal Democrat environment spokesman Don Foster called on the government to use the tax system to tackle the problem of waste.

"We have heard too often over the last three years the government talking about targets. There need to be targets, but they need to be backed up by clear action," he said.

"We need to start taxing firms if the amount of packaging they use is more than a certain amount. We could stop people looking at the easy option of burying waste by taxing it.

"If we are not careful, we are taking too big a risk. The incinerator route really is a very risky route. There is a recent leaked report from the US Environmental Protection Agency that would make anybody stop and think before they agreed to go ahead with new incinerators."

Conservative environment spokesman Damian Green promised a Conservative government would halt the building of new incinerators until they had been proved safe.

"There are not just concerns about the safety of incinerators, there are also severe worries over the amount of heavy duty traffic that will occur as a result, damaging the environment of our towns and countryside," he said. "We will introduce a moratorium on new incinerators until independent British scientific evidence proves they are safe."

The government also faces the challenge of meeting European Union targets to cut the proportion of waste going into landfill sites from 85% to 35% by 2016 - an extra 33 million tons a year. Regulations would be introduced over the next two or three years to penalise wasteful packaging, said Mr Meacher.

fields.headline: Ethiopia declares victory over Eritrea
fields.trailText: Ethiopia declared victory in its border war against Eritrea today after the Eritrean government agreed to withdraw from the territories it occupied at the start of fighting two years ago.
fields.body:
Ethiopia declared victory in its border war against Eritrea today after the Eritrean government agreed to withdraw from the territories it occupied at the start of fighting two years ago.

Ethiopia's government said its army had routed enemy positions on the central front of the war over the last two days, with the Ethiopian army chasing fleeing Eritrean troops.

"After the Ethiopian blitzkrieg of the last two days, the Eritrean army was demolished at midnight," said government spokeswoman Selome Taddesse. "Those few troops that managed to survive the thrashing are being chased and destroyed by the heroic Ethiopian forces as they run for their lives."

Eritrea had earlier announced it would pull back troops from the territories it seized at the outbreak of the border war, in accordance with a request from the Organisation of African Unity.

"Eritrea has decided, for the sake of peace, to accept the appeal OAU's appeal for de-escalation," Eritrea's foreign ministry said in a statement issued by its UN mission late yesterday. Resorting to euphemisms to describe its military reverses, the statement said: "Eritrea has decided to redeploy its forces to positions held before May 6 1998."

Withdrawal would start in the Zalambessa area, Eritrea said, stressing it was not surrendering to Ethiopia .

Ethiopian state radio played patriotic songs and said the country's flag was again flying over the small mountain-town of Zalambessa, the focus of fighting on the central front.

The war has dragged on for two years but Ethiopian forces made big battlefield gains in the past two weeks, driving across the border deep into western Eritrea and then attacking along the Zalambessa front on Tuesday.

Ethiopia claimed that the Eritrean president, Isayas Afewerki, was pulling back not because of diplomatic pressure but because his army was falling apart.

"It is about time he faced reality," said the spokeswoman for the Ethiopian government. "The reality is he was kicked out. He has been destroyed, thrashed."

She said Ethiopia's army would continue to attack Eritrea until its forces totally withdrew from the border. Eritrea two years ago seized border land it claimed under old colonial-era boundaries. Since then, fighting over their disputed 620-mile border has claimed the lives of tens of thousands of soldiers and civilians on both sides. webTitle: The Scotsman who led England in Test cricket

fields.headline: The Scotsman who led England in Test cricket
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your question.
fields.trailText: Which Scotsman captained England at cricket? asks Mick Crabtree
fields.body:
Which Scotsman captained England at cricket? asks Mick Crabtree

There have been quite a few Scottish-born England Test players - among them Ian Peebles, David Larter, Gregor MacGregor, Peter Such and, most recently, Gavin Hamilton - but only one has captained England. That was Mike Denness, who took over from Ray Illingworth for the 1973-74 tour of West Indies, and continued as captain until the first Test of 1975, when he was sacked after England lost heavily to Australia. In all Denness, who was born in Ayr, captained England in 19 of his 28 Tests, winning six, losing five and drawing eight. Douglas Jardine, England's captain on the infamous Bodyline tour of Australia in 1932-33, was of Scottish stock, but he was actually born in India.

What is Zimbabwe's lowest Test score? asks Ian Lansdale

Zimbabwe went 39 Tests without being dismissed for under 100 - but now they've done it twice in their last three matches. At Port-of-Spain in Trinidad in March, Zimbabwe needed only 99 to win their inaugural Test against West Indies. But West Indies' fast bowlers dismantled them for 63, and pulled off an improbable victory. And now it's happened again: at Lord's, in their first Test in England, Zimbabwe were shot out for 83. They were nearly dismissed for less than 100 in their second innings too, but Bryan Strang's late flourish at least took them into three figures.

Has a team which was forced to follow on ever won the match? asks Dan Ward

It has happened twice in Tests, most famously at Headingley in 1981 in what has become known as 'Botham's Match'. After Australia made 401, England were shot out for 174 and followed on 227 runs behind. On the fourth morning the England players all booked out of their hotel, expecting an early finish. Not long afterwards they were 135 for 7 in their second innings, still 92 behind. But Ian Botham's majestic 149 not out, helped by useful contributions from tailenders Graham Dilley (56) and Chris Old (29), meant that England managed to reach 356, which still left Australia only 130 to win. Bob Willis roared down the hill at Headingley to take 8 for 43, Australia collapsed to 111 all out, and England went cricket-mad. The other occasion also involved England beating Australia: it was at Sydney in December 1894. Australia made 586 (Syd Gregory 201, George Giffen 161) and England replied with 325. Following on, England made 437 (Albert Ward 117), then bowled Australia out for 166 (Bobby Peel 6-67) to win by 12 runs.

I work in the museum at the Wanderers ground in Johannesburg. One of the items in our collection is a bat autographed by members of a private tour captained by Lord Tennyson and including Joe Hardstaff, Arthur Wellard and Norman Yardley. Unfortunately there's no date on the bat and I am trying to identify the other signatures. Can you tell me more about the tour? asks Alison Tetley

This was a tour of India (not, as you may have thought, South Africa) in 1937-38, sponsored and led by Lord Tennyson, who as Lionel Tennyson had captained England in 1921. It was a strong side, not far below Test-strength and containing several current or future internationals, which won a series of unofficial Tests against India 3-2. The full side was: Lord Tennyson (capt), WJ Edrich, PA Gibb, AR Gover, J Hardstaff, TO Jameson, James Langridge, NT McCorkell, IAR Peebles, GH Pope, TPB Smith, AW Wellard, TS Worthington and NWD Yardley. In all they played 24 matches, winning eight, losing five and drawing 11. The 1939 Wisden Cricketers' Almanack says the team had a lot of trouble with injuries and illness - Tennyson himself went down with dysentery. Overall Bill Edrich (Middlesex and England) was the leading batsman, with 876 runs at an average of 46.10, and George Pope (Derbyshire and England) was the top bowler, with 58 wickets at 15.93.

Rudra Singh, the former Indian international, is now my captain at Blackpool Cricket Club. Can you tell me about his Test record? asks Donald

Rudra Pratap Singh, who was born in Lucknow on Jan 6, 1965, played two one-day internationals for India as a right-arm fast-medium bowler. Both games were in the 1986-87 series against Australia. He didn't take a wicket in the first one, at Hyderabad, but did dismiss Dean Jones in the second, at Rajkot. That was his only international wicket, at an overall cost of 77 runs. He didn't bat in either match. Rudra Singh had a long first-class career for the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh: starting in 1982-83, he scored 1413 runs, with one century, and took 150 wickets in 59 matches up to 1995-96. He's now a leading coach in England.

I am an ardent cricket fan and am planning to see a match at Lord's. What is the best place to view and enjoy the match: the Grand, Mound, Edrich or Compton Stands? asks Deepak Malik

It depends on whether you like to watch from sideways-on or end-on, and whether you want to be at ground level or higher up. If you want to be behind the bowler's arm - the sort of view you generally get on TV - the Edrich and Compton Stands are the best bet. If you're ordering a ticket over the phone, then tell them you want to be behind the arm, as both stands stretch round quite a long way and you might find yourself looking over mid-on or mid-off. I would go for the upper tier, because the lower ones can get a bit cold. Of course, you might get wet in the upper tier, as they're not covered! The Mound Stand is more sideways-on, and the back part is covered. The Grand Stand gives a good side-on view too. It's the newest of the stands - and also the most expensive. That's for international matches: if you go to a county game at Lord's you should be able to wander around and have a look at all the stands to see which one you prefer.

Who has taken the most hat-tricks in first-class cricket? asks Ben Spivey

Doug Wright took seven hat-tricks in his first-class career, all of them for Kent, although he also took 108 wickets in 34 Tests for England. He was a quickish legspinner, who played either side of the Second World War, and had a distinctive bounding approach to the wicket. He was sometimes erratic - his Test wickets cost nearly 40 runs apiece - but on his day he was deadly. He made his debut for Kent in 1932, when he was only 17, captained them from 1954 to 1956, and retired in 1957. He died in November 1998, aged 84.

I was confused by your answer to last week's question regarding the "hit ball twice" law. If someone is allowed to hit the ball again in order to protect his wicket, what is the point of the law? asks GR Young

The law does permit the batsman to hit the ball a second time (for the sole purpose of guarding his wicket), for example if the ball is trickling backwards towards the stumps. He also wouldn't be out if he was returning the ball to a fielder. What he's not allowed to do is deliberately hit it again and look for a run. Otherwise he could legally flick the ball up, a bit like a tennis serve, and smash it away wherever he liked. The full law can be found in Wisden Cricketers' Almanack (this year the Laws start on page 1426), or on the Lord's website (click here).

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly.

fields.headline: Dando: chronology of an investigation
fields.trailText:
How was Jill Dando killed?
The 38-year old BBC presenter was shot with a single bullet outside her home in a west London street just before noon on April 26 last year. Few thirty-something women are ever killed in such circumstances, let alone a high-profile, inoffensive TV personality.
fields.body:
How was Jill Dando killed?
The 38-year old BBC presenter was shot with a single bullet outside her home in a west London street just before noon on April 26 last year. Few thirty-something women are ever killed in such circumstances, let alone a high-profile, inoffensive TV personality.

If it was a shooting in broad daylight, there must have been a lot of witnesses
Strangely, no. The police had very few clues to go on. A man was seen talking on a mobile phone near her home before the shooting. There was another sighting of a man "sweating" afterwards by a bus stop. And then there was a metallic, blue Range Rover seen speeding across a nearby bridge.

Who fell under suspicion initially?
There was an incredible array of possible suspects, starting with her fiance or a former lover. Then attention turned to a stalker or an underworld hitman, perhaps someone aggrieved by a case on her TV programme Crimewatch. There was even talk that a pro-Serb sympathiser might have targeted Dando because she had helped to highlight the plight of ethnic Albanian refugees in Kosovo where war was raging.

Did these lines of investigation bear fruit? No one was charged. The police concluded the murder was probably the work of a loner, but their investigation proved slow and pain. A team of nearly 50 police officers sifted through Dando's private life, reading thousands of her e-mails and letters. The police studied video surveillance tape from around the area and analysed thousands of mobile phone calls made in the neighbourhood on the morning of the murder, but with no breakthroughs.

Did the police ever consider closing the case? No. On the first anniversary of Dando's death last month, police said they had identified at least 140 people who had an "unhealthy interest or obsession" with her. And Hamish Campbell, the officer in charge of the investigation, told The Guardian: "He will be caught. Don't ask me when. It could be this month, it could be next month. If it is an ex-lover somewhere from her past who has arranged for this to happen, someone will eventually break the silence. If it is a loner, it will come out eventually. I'm a great believer. I really am."

fields.headline: The Irish over the water
fields.standfirst: Former Northern Ireland correspondent Derek Brown on the key American players who, although remote, play a significant role in the Ulster conflict
fields.trailText: Thursday, 12.45pm: Former Northern Ireland correspondent Derek Brown on the key American players who, although remote, play a significant role in the Ulster conflict
fields.body:
There are 40m Americans of Irish descent, ten times more than Ireland's population. That single astounding statistic says more than any amount of political analysis about the key role of the US in the current Northern Ireland peace process.

The Clinton administration, which did so much to transform the Good Friday deal from distant dream to wobbly reality, still has an enormous stake in its success. So too, for that matter, would a Republican or any other brand of president.

That explains, to some extent, why President Clinton so brusquely rejected Tony Blair's pleas for help in the ongoing row over the proposed change of name for the Royal Ulster Constabulary.

As revealed in today's Guardian, the prime minister twice asked Clinton, his close friend, to lean on the Irish government and Sinn Fein to compromise over the name change.

The president rebuffed the suggestion. Bowing to Ulster Unionist demands for the royal title to be retained, he said it "would be like leaving Alabama and Georgia under all-white cops".

The bluntness of the language underscores the exasperation of the White House with the latest attempts by unionist hardliners to scupper the power-sharing accord. And that exasperation is in turn the result of the enormous political clout of the various Irish lobbies in Washington.

British and northern Irish critics of the US government's stance often mistakenly attribute it to the brazen propaganda of Noraid, the best-known republican front organisation in America. Noraid has indeed raised the republican profile, as well as many millions of dollars in so-called humanitarian aid.

It has also happily exploited the profound ignorance of many Americans about events in Northern Ireland. One widespread fallacy, for example, is that Ulster Catholics have no vote.

But Noraid is a bit-player on the raucous stage of Irish-American lobbying. Much more important are the Dublin government and the Irish business community, both of which have benefited enormously from US investment and goodwill.

Nationalist politicians too have assiduously cultivated the White House, none more successfully than the Social Democratic and Labour Party leader John Hume. Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein president, may have notoriously broken down the invisible barrier against republicans, but it is Hume who has quietly, firmly, ensured that successive presidents keep Northern Ireland near the top of the agenda.

As the rival factions of Ulster Unionists square off for their showdown on Saturday, President Clinton has fired off an unmistakable warning against any attempt by the British government to temporise on the issue of police reforms.

The Americans understand, perhaps better than the spin doctors of Whitehall and Stormont, that changing the name of the Royal Ulster Constabulary to the Police Service of Northern Ireland is much more than petty symbolism. It is the key to making a revamped police force acceptable to nationalists and republicans - and to Washington as the main peace-broker.

What President Clinton has done, in effect, is to underline that where Northern Ireland is concerned, he is less of an ally of the Blair government than an arbiter of the accord.

webTitle: The best crooner scene:  Man on the moon

fields.headline: The best crooner scene:  Man on the moon
fields.trailText: An Italian restaurant. Night. A small band set up their instruments on an equally small stage. As the lights dim, a coarse Brooklyn accent crackles over the PA.
fields.body:
An Italian restaurant. Night. A small band set up their instruments on an equally small stage. As the lights dim, a coarse Brooklyn accent crackles over the PA.

"And now, Mama Roma's is proud to present international singing sensation... a man who has sold more records than Elvis and the Beatles combined... ladies and gentlemen, Mr Entertainment... TONY CLIFTON!"

A drum roll. A spotlight. Nothing. Finally, the announcer returns.

"Ladies and gentlemen, out of respect for Mr Clifton's vocal demands, could everyone please extinguish your cigarettes and cigars."

The crowd complies, grumbling.

webTitle: Passenger jet hijacker escapes via parachute

fields.headline: Passenger jet hijacker escapes via parachute
fields.standfirst: Hear Guardian correspondent John Aglionby on the hijacking
fields.trailText: A Philippine Airlines jet with 290 people on board was hijacked today by a man who took the passengers' money and then parachuted to the ground outside Manila, authorities said.
fields.body:
A Philippine Airlines jet with 290 people on board was hijacked today by a man who took the passengers' money and then parachuted to the ground outside Manila, authorities said.

The Airbus 330 later landed at Manila's airport and the passengers were let off safely.

The jet left Davao City, in the southern Philippines, for the 90-minute flight to the capital, Manila, with 278 passengers and 12 crew on board, the airline said.

The hijacker, wearing a blue ski mask and carrying a handgun and a grenade, ordered the pilot of Flight PR812 to return to Davao City, about 600 miles from Manila. But the pilot said he did not have enough fuel, Manila airport general manager Antonio Gana said.

Later, the plane was depressurised to permit the hijacker to jump with a parachute while it circled 13 miles from Manila at 6,000ft.

The jet landed at Manila airport after about two-and-a-half hours after its departure. It was not clear if the hijacker who jumped from the plane had any accomplices aboard.

Passenger Ida Marie Bernasconi, a reporter for a Manila television channel, said the hijacker carried ropes and appeared to have prepared for his mid-air exit. He used the ropes to get out of the plane, she said, but did not describe how.

"Before he left, he collected all the money he could from the passengers," she said. After the plane landed, the pilot said to her, "This is our second lease on life."

Police were hunting for the hijacker in the area where he landed with his parachute.

Security was tightened at all airports in the southern Philippines after the hijacking, southern command Lt Gen Deomedio Villanueva said.

"We are still investigating how the hijackers were able to board the plane despite strict security in Davao airport," Lt Gen Villanueva said.

The military is battling Muslim guerrillas fighting for a separate Islamic state in the impoverished southern Philippines. One group of rebels is holding 21 foreign hostages there.

fields.headline: Enigma variations
fields.standfirst:
Hollywood's latest blockbuster U-571 shows Americans grabbing Germany's Enigma code machine. But in fact U-110 was the crucial sub, and it was captured by the British. Hugh Sebag-Montefiore talks to the survivors of what George VI called 'perhaps the most important single event in the whole war at sea'

Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Hollywood's latest blockbuster U-571 shows Americans grabbing Germany's Enigma code machine. But in fact U-110 was the crucial sub, and it was captured by the British. Hugh Sebag-Montefiore talks to the survivors of what George VI called 'perhaps the most important single event in the whole war at sea'
fields.body:
The film U-571, which is released in Britain next week, is currently one of the top-grossing films in America. However, it has achieved its success in spite of the fact that, or perhaps because, it has tampered with history. The film shows the Americans, rather than the British, capturing an Enigma cipher machine, a factor which, not surprisingly, makes the film much more likely to do well in the US. However, the real-life story of the British capturing an Enigma from the U-110, on which the film is based, is, if anything, even more dramatic and moving than the action shown in the movie. This leads one to question whether the director of U571 might have done better to have dramatised the true story.

The British hunt for the German submarine U-110 began shortly after midday on May 9 1941. That was when Joe Baker Cresswell, the commander of the British destroyer HMS Bulldog, one of the group of warships protecting a convoy heading from Britain to America, looked on with horror as the U-boat drew blood for the first time.

He could not see the submarine itself. All he saw were two tall towers of water shooting up into the air on the right side of two merchant ships. That was enough to tell Baker Cresswell that the ships had been torpedoed by a U-boat lurking on the convoy's right flank.

But even as the two ships sank he knew that a trap he had set was about to snap shut on the unsuspecting enemy. He had placed the British corvette HMS Aubretia on the convoy's right flank to provide for precisely this eventuality. It now charged towards the spot from where the torpedoes appeared to have been fired, and, having identified the U-boat on its asdic sonar equipment, dropped the first pattern of depth charges.

The U-boat was the U-110. It might have sunk a third ship had it not been for an accident. The final torpedo fired had remained stuck inside the tube. This was to have fatal consequences for many of the crew. Normally, after a torpedo was fired from the U-boat's bow, water was pumped into the tanks in the bow to compensate for the departure of the missile. However, given that the torpedo on this occasion never left the U-boat, the pumped-in water merely unbalanced it for just long enough to stop it diving out of harm's way. By the time its 28-year-old commander Fritz-Julius Lemp was able to give the order to dive, it was too late.

Lemp's crew winced as HMS Aubretia's depth charges exploded and the whole U-boat vibrated. There was a scraping, creaking sound, as the metal deck plates rubbed together and bent, until it seemed inevitable that the deck itself would be torn in half under their feet.

When the extinguished lights came on again, all eyes in the control room were fixed on Lemp. Leaning nonchalantly against the periscope, with his cap pushed on to the back of his head, he murmured soothing words of reassurance to those around him. "It's OK. We're all going to be fine," he said, followed by the grim joke: "You don't think I'm going to let them catch me and shoot me, do you?" This encouraged one of the veteran submariners to advise Helmut Ecke, the 23-year-old journalist who was supposed to be covering the action on the U-boat for the German armed forces propaganda unit, to mention the men's terrified faces in one of his propaganda articles. Ecke, who is still living in Germany today, will never forget the terror he experienced as the depth charges went off.

But after the men in the U-110's control room had heard the damage reports coming in, even Lemp's jokes wore a little thin. The damaged batteries were giving off a whiff of chlorine gas, none of the depth meters were working, so it was impossible to tell whether they were sinking or rising. A loud hissing sound suggested that the pressurised air, which was supposed to be held back in reserve so that it could be used to blast the U-boat to the surface in an emergency, was escaping.

Lemp was eventually forced to announce to his men that he could not control the U-boat, and there was nothing more he could do. "We must wait and see what happens," he muttered, and to anyone still listening, he added: "I want you all to think of home, or of something beautiful."

Herbert Langsch, one of three Enigma operators still alive in Germany, resigned himself to death. As he pictured the U-boat tumbling into the abyss where it would soon be crushed by the growing pressure, he thought of his childhood sweetheart, and tried to imagine how she would feel when she knew he had died.

But then the men felt the submarine rocking from side to side and the word came down the line that they had managed to make it to the surface after all. They were saved. Or so they thought. For the scene which greeted the German crew, as they climbed onto the deck outside, was like something out of Dante's inferno. Two large warships were steaming towards the crippled U-boat, as if intent on ramming it. At the same time, guns were firing on them from all sides. They were surrounded.

Some of the crew jumped into the water immediately. Others hung around on deck, hypnotised by the sight of the destroyers bearing down on them. Radio operator Heinz Wilde, who still lives in Germany, climbed up the conning tower ladder to ask Lemp whether he should destroy the Enigma machine and code-books. Lemp merely shouted back at him to get out, so Wilde followed the other crew members into the sea.

The engineers opened up the vents so that the diving tanks would be flooded. They then jumped overboard with Lemp, mistakenly believing the U-boat would sink in a matter of minutes. It was only when it failed to sink that Lemp called out to another officer that they should try to climb back on board to see what could be done. But, at that moment, the U-boat was swept beyond their reach. That was the last time anyone saw Lemp.

Lieutenant David Balme, who was in charge of the Bulldog's boarding party, sent over to the U-110 in a whaler decided that he should be the first to climb down the conning tower. It takes a particular kind of courage to venture inside a captured submarine. For all he knew, scuttling charges set by the Germans might explode at any minute. As he stepped into its control room, he suddenly felt very lonely and isolated. The interior was tinged with blue by the emergency lighting. Apart from the sound of his own breathing, all Balme could hear was a faint hissing, and the sound of the Atlantic waves lapping against the hull. To his relief, he soon discovered he was alone, and he shouted to the rest of the boarding party to follow him down.

While Balme was arranging his men into a human chain so that they could pass all the code-books and charts up the conning tower and into the whaler waiting for them outside, his telegraphist tapped him on the shoulder and said: "Come and look in the radio room. There's something rather interesting I want to show you." On the table in the radio room was a machine like a typewriter. The telegraphist proceeded to show Balme how, when he pressed one letter key on the keyboard, another letter was highlighted on the display panel. Balme instructed the telegraphist to use the screwdriver in his toolbag to undo the four screws securing the machine to the table. Then it, too, was passed up to the deck outside.

It took the men about an hour and a half to clear all the books, papers and machinery out of the U-boat. Then Baker Cresswell sent over some sandwiches. Balme settled down to eat his while sitting at Lemp's roll-top desk. Inside the desk, he found an Iron Cross, some pictures of Lemp's family, and a sealed envelope. Balme, who now lives in the south of England, carefully put all three items into his pocket before returning to the Bulldog. The next morning the U-boat sank.

Two days later, HMS Bulldog docked in Scapa Flow, the British naval base in the Orkneys. Baker Cresswell was greeted by Allon Bacon, an intelligence officer who was supposed to take the documents down to Bletchley Park, the code-breaking centre. "Never mind about losing the U-110," Bacon said. "From our point of view, it was a good thing, as we can now keep all this quiet. For God's sake never breathe a word about this to anyone." Baker Cresswell replied that he would have to tell the commander-in-chief of the home fleet. "Yes, of course," said Bacon, "but no one else."

Bacon was down in London by 6pm on May 13. Three hours later, he was driven through the gates into Bletchley Park. As he walked into the naval intelligence section, he triumphantly held his briefcase containing the most important captured papers over his head, like an athlete who had just won a gold medal.

Later that night, as Baker Cresswell sailed back to Iceland, he received the following signal about the operation which had been code-named "Primrose" from Sir Dudley Pound, the first sea lord: "Following from first sea lord. Hearty congratulations. The petals of your flower are of rare beauty." He and the rest of the crew were to receive further congratulations from King George VI, who stated that the operation was "perhaps the most important single event in the whole war at sea."

The documents and Enigma machine seized from the U-110 did not, in spite of what is stated in the U-571 film and in the TV documentary Station X, recently repeated on Channel 4, help the British code-breakers to break the main naval Enigma code for the first time. That was achieved thanks to the capture of Enigma code-books from a series of German trawlers. Even the capture of the Enigma machine was no help. Other Enigma cipher machines and apparatus had already been captured by the British. But in the envelope seized by David Balme there was something almost as valuable: the settings and procedure to be used for "Offizier" Enigma messages, the especially important doubly enciphered messages sent to officers in U-boats while they were at sea. These crucial messages might never have been read by the British had it not been for the capture of the U-110.

Hugh Sebag-Montefiore's book Enigma: The Battle for the Code, is published by Weidenfeld & Nicolson today, price £20. The author lectures on Enigma at the British Library bookshop at 1pm on June 2

fields.headline: Bafta award-winning British cameraman dies
fields.trailText: Mike Roberts, the distinguished British cameraman, who worked extensively with Alan Parker, Neil Jordan and Roland Joffe, has died aged 62
fields.body:
Mike Roberts, the distinguished British cameraman, who worked extensively with Alan Parker, Neil Jordan and Roland Joffe, has died aged 62, writes Fiachra Gibbons.

He died yesterday in Bath where he was shooting a film called Chocolat for the director Lasse Halstrom.

Roberts, who had already shot the Disney production 102 Dalmatians earlier this year, was the only British cameraman to have been awarded a Bafta lifetime achievement award.

fields.headline: Spielberg hopes for UK revival
fields.trailText: Steven Spielberg yesterday said he wanted to see the British film industry "get back on its feet" and become as great as it was in the 1940s and 1950s.
fields.body:
Steven Spielberg yesterday said he wanted to see the British film industry "get back on its feet" and become as great as it was in the 1940s and 1950s.

In the world's first cyber seminar yesterday, the Hollywood director told students at John Moores University in Liverpool: "Britain had a great film industry under Ealing, Rank and Korda.

"But everyone left the UK and came to America and made more money, fame and fortune in the States. I would love to see the British film industry get back on its feet again."

He added: "It is up to the Commonwealth to do what Australia has done, coming to America to make a picture and then going off to make more pictures back home."

Connected by ISDN lines from Hatfield, Hertfordshire, where he is filming, he told media students that the British film industry needed a great leader to do what had been done in Britain many years ago.

Spielberg said that he had made 11 films in England and would return to the country to make more. "I have made almost as many films in England as I have in America," he said.

"I will come back to England again and again. You have great art directors, cinematographers, chippies and sparks. I think I've done my share in keeping as much work in the UK as I can."
