webTitle: Josef von Sternberg: The Scarlet Empress

fields.headline: Josef von Sternberg: The Scarlet Empress
fields.trailText: The film remains, like all Sternberg's best work, beautiful, ironic, disturbing and erotic. And that is rather more than camp. Actually, it made the rest of Hollywood look camp, or at least banal
fields.body:
"The hallmark of camp is the spirit of extravagance. Camp is a woman walking around in a dress made of three million feathers. Camp is the outrageous aestheticism of Sternberg's American movies with Dietrich" - Susan Sontag

If you read Josef von Sternberg's Fun in a Chinese Laundry, his vastly entertaining autobiography, you would think the director a control freak to end all control freaks.

For instance, he insists that in all the seven films he and Marlene Dietrich made together, he created her every gesture, expression and movement. She was merely a little German puppet. It was not quite true, though she never had the same feeling for any of her other directors.

Susan Sontag was right in essence to say that Sternberg and Dietrich combined to produce camp, but The Scarlet Empress is so much more than that - it is great cinema. Sternberg once said that he would not mind showing his films upside down because their justification was not the story, the screenplay or the acting but "the phenomenon of visual style". You could say that he wrote with the camera - and he often achieved poetry.

The Scarlet Empress can certainly be termed the work of a visual poet. And though no one would claim this tale of Catherine the Great, child and woman, is historically accurate, its mixture of legend, romance and fairytale leaves camp far behind.

In the film, nothing is quite what it seems, to either Catherine or us. Her kindly doctor turns out also to be the public hangman. Innocent little Catherine asks: "Can I become a hangman some day?" He then reads to her about terrible tortures that Sternberg illustrates as if turning the pages of a book. In the last image, the hangman pulls on a bell rope, and the clapper is a naked man, dangling by his feet.

The film is full of Sternberg's obsessive, and often malicious, melancholy. There seems to be nothing in this world that is not corruptible. Catherine's fate pursues her, making her ambition fruitless and her attempts at love impossible. No matter how banal the dialogue, there is a constant sense that Sternberg's purpose is not just to tell a story but to decorate it so that its meaning becomes crystal clear.

Of course Dietrich looks superb, as she always did for Sternberg - he knew he had found someone the camera loved. It was indeed what he called "a dramatic encounter with light", illustrating the life and times of a woman who had to become ruthless, even compared with the men around her.

Some think the film an allegory about Hollywood - about a woman groomed for stardom by her mother, given a new image, presented to the public, and finally dehumanised, imprisoned by her own image. And by associating Catherine with a white horse, Sternberg may have had in mind the legend of her death, attempting intercourse with a stallion.

But this is mere conjecture. The film remains, like all Sternberg's best work, beautiful, ironic, disturbing and erotic. And that is rather more than camp. Actually, it made the rest of Hollywood look camp, or at least banal.

fields.headline: Real reveal Spain's upper class
fields.trailText: A wonderful goal from Steve McManaman helped Real Madrid to their eighth European Cup triumph in a final of stunning pace and audacious skills here in the Stade de France.
fields.body:
A wonderful goal from Steve McManaman helped Real Madrid to their eighth European Cup triumph in a final of stunning pace and audacious skills here in the Stade de France.

After Fernando Morientes had put Real ahead shortly before half-time Valencia found their best efforts to draw level frustrated by excellent defending. Then in the 67th minute the ball was cleared to McManaman, who from the penalty arc drove a right-footed shot inside the right-hand post to distinguish still further an already outstanding performance.

Seven minutes later the contest was finally put beyond Valencia's reach by Raul, who with the opposition crowding forward gathered a pass from Savio, one of the substitutes, and dashed two-thirds of the length of the pitch to score Real's third.

Last night's match broke new ground. Never before had teams from the same country contested the European Cup final and Real Madrid and Valencia were not even Spanish champions, either last season or this.

The Champions League, in effect, was on trial. A routine fixture had been plucked from the Spanish League and asked to turn itself into a masterpiece. The Spaniards pouring into the Stade de France just wanted to see their side win, but the rest of Europe demanded a spectacle to reflect the undoubted quality which lay in both teams.

Certainly Real had little doubt where the route to victory lay. From the outset Vicente del Bosque had Michel Salgado and Roberto Carlos breaking quickly on the flanks from a five-man defence while up front Raul, watched closely by Javier Farinos, tucked himself into pockets of space behind Nicolas Anelka and Fernando Morientes.

They also depended on the Argentine might of Fernando Redondo dominating the central areas much as he had done against Manchester United at Old Trafford.

Yet a mistake by Redondo, who sold himself in the tackle to let Claudio Lopez through, might have cost Real a goal in the 17th minute. His fellow Argentine set up Mendieta for a low shot which Iker Casillas in the Real goal blocked.

Just before that Raul's centre from the left had found the head of Anelka, who nodded the ball goalwards only to see Santiago Canizares touch it over the crossbar. With both teams fully committed to attacking and getting numbers forward chances at either end were always likely.

Valencia, if anything, were more inclined to pull players back once they had lost possession. And on their quicker breaks they tended to find more space in the Real half.

McManaman, busy, alert and frequently involved in Real's more threatening movements might have provided a goal just past the half-hour. From a throw by Roberto Carlos, Morientes hooked the ball to the former Liverpool forward, McManaman's shot was aimed inside the left-hand post but Canizares kept it out at full stretch.

Since Real were pressing home their attacks with greater conviction it was no surprise when they took the lead six minutes before half-time with a cleverly improvised goal which began with a free-kick from Roberto Carlos.

For the first time the Brazilian attempted one of his thunderbolts from 35 yards. The shot rebounded to Anelka, who kept possession tenaciously on the right before feeding Salgado, who scooped it towards the far post where Morientes was waiting to head the ball down past Canizares.

In anticipation of a Valencia onslaught, Real began the second half defending in depth. Yet when Gerardo failed to control a clearance from Iker Casillas in the 49th minute Anelka was on to the ball in a trice, forcing Canizares to concede a corner in keeping out his shot at the near post. This was a match unforgiving of errors and the mere presence of Anelka was enough to panic Valencia's defenders.

Shortly before the hour Mendieta attempted to take on a clutch of opponents in the Real penalty area but was dis possessed by a well-judged sliding tackle from McManaman. That moment summed up the spirit and organisation of Real's performance, not to mention the amount of ground covered by McManaman.

Still Real looked the more likely scorers. In the 63rd minute Raul unleashed a dipping shot from 30 yards which Canizares did well to keep out.

Goalscorers : Morientes 39, McManaman 67, Raul 75.

Real Madrid (5-2-2-1): Casillas; Salgado (Hierro, 85min), Ivan Campo, Helguera, Karanka, Roberto Carlos; McManaman, Redondo; Raul, Morientes (Savio, 73); Anelka (Sanchis, 81).

Valencia (4-4-2): Canizares; Angloma, Djukic, Pellegrino, Gerardo; Mendieta, Farinos, Gerard, Kily Gonzalez; Claudio Lopez, Angulo.

Referee: S Braschi (Italy).

webTitle: What is poetry? Ask a poet

fields.headline: What is poetry? Ask a poet
fields.standfirst: A Guardian reader sent a poetical poser to the Notes & Queries section. Acclaimed poet Michael Rosen replied...
fields.trailText: Can anyone tell
fields.body:
Can anyone tell

Me if this

Is a poem or

not?

Doyle Cross, Dagenham, Essex

Michael Rosen writes: The problem with definitions of poetry is that they are either too limiting or too general. At the end of the day, it's poets, publishers and audiences who decide. As the questioner implies, this means that there are areas of great disagreement. Chaucer's Canterbury Tales is written in "verse" and yet we don't usually call the whole cycle, or even one of the individual tales, a "poem".

Proverbs, aphorisms, slogans and formulaic jokes such as riddles often display the characteristics we associate with poetry: pattern, rhythm, compression, musicality and the like, but are rarely called poems. Ever since people started writing free verse there have been some readers who thought that these poets had indeed written poetry while other readers were sure that it wasn't.

Interesting problems arise with the 1611 Authorised Version translations of the Psalms and the Song of Solomon. Nowadays, many readers would regard these as poetry. They can be contrasted with John Donne's sermons, including the famous "bell tolls" piece, or Martin Luther King's "I have a dream", both of which have the rhythms one might associate with free verse poetry and yet few would call these poems.

This said, it is quite possible to take up a non-categorising position on all this: "I don't care what it's called, do I like what I'm reading or hearing?" After all, when we're in conversation with people not many of us ask ourselves if we had just heard an example of irony or sarcasm, litotes or hyperbole, ellipsis or deixis and the like. If we can avoid getting stuck in the "what is it?" position, it's perhaps easier to enjoy the way all kinds of language users create patterns with words that intrigue us. The questioner has written what is a classic self-referential sentence and laid it out on the page according to the tradition of free verse. Nice one, but not worth sweating over whether it's a poem or not.

fields.body:
Leeds manager David O'Leary has offered Sunderland £20m for Kevin Phillips, according to the Sun. Peter Reid will do all in his power to keep the 30-goal striker, however, arguing that the Black Cats need Phillips more than they need the money.

Liverpool are set to make a shock move for out-of-contract Internazionale star Roberto Baggio, reports the Star. The Italian legend would command £50,000-a-week wages, but as he would be available on a Bosman free Gerard Houllier is ready to meet his demands.

Kenny Cunningham has pledged his future to relegated Wimbledon, despite interest from Everton.

Martin O'Neill will only take over at Celtic if director of football Kenny Dalglish leaves the Parkhead club. The Leicester manager is said to be ready to enter formal talks but will not budge on this pre-condition.

Turkish club Besiktas have bid £5m for Liverpool defender Rigobert Song. Bayer Leverkusen are also interested in the player.

Hibernian are interested in Raith's Canadian international defender Paul Fenwick, according to Planet Football.

webTitle: Rhetoric cannot hide it: Bush's project is insane

fields.headline: Rhetoric cannot hide it: Bush's project is insane
fields.standfirst:
The American national missile defence system challenges our alliance

Special report: Bush's America
fields.trailText: The American national missile defence system challenges our alliance: Come what may, Dubya insists, the US must build its infamous national missile defence system, NMD, to which Russia, not to mention China, or for that matter all of Europe, are rootedly opposed.
fields.body:
Unilateralism can cut both ways. George W Bush, president presumptive, proposes to do something good with it. He said on Tuesday that the US should make big reductions in its nuclear arsenal, if necessary unilaterally. It didn't matter what Russia did or didn't do alongside.

This was a striking novelty from the Republican right. But it was the sweetener for a parallel assertion that would work to opposite effect, which also says that Russia doesn't matter. Come what may, Dubya insists, the US must build its infamous national missile defence system, NMD, to which Russia, not to mention China, or for that matter all of Europe, are rootedly opposed.

There's a further sweetener. Europe and Israel, Bush said with a sweep of rhetoric, would be protected as well. It would be an allied matter. Japan could be under cover too. All God's children. This is meant to deflect the widespread affront that Clinton's embryonic version of NMD has given the allies.

Bush proposes multilateral benefits. But he doesn't address arguments that persuade sane people this is an insane scheme. Nationalism, not globalism, may be pushing the US towards a misbegotten 21st century destiny. As Europe's custodian of the special relationship, Tony Blair will soon be facing a special challenge to his powers of persuasion, and his courage to dissent.

Clinton has been quite slow to push NMD forward. The reasons are hard even for pre- election Democrats to overlook. The technical capacity of the system - one bullet guaranteed to hit another, with no forewarning of its firing, at a closing speed of 10,000mph - is unproven.

Star Wars worked only in the movies. So far one test failed, another half-succeeded, a third, serially postponed, is due at the end of July. On this single test hangs Clinton's possible decision, guided entirely by electoral thoughts on behalf of Al Gore, to approve NMD deployment. There are reputable scientists who believe the technical reliability of NMD will never, repeat never, be sufficient to justify the costs.

The costs come in two parts. The financial projection, at $60bn, is so immense as to raise serious issues about better means of national, let alone global, defence. Could there not be more potent bangs for the buck? But the diplo-strategic cost is greater still.

Seen from Moscow, and indeed from London, NMD bids to be deeply destabilising of the delicate existing architecture of nuclear deterrence. Merely by deciding to deploy - even if the technical capabilities of the system are as fanciful as many serious people believe - Washington will play a dangerous game with the peace of the world.

This is the hazard posed by W, or, if you prefer, his novelty. He suggests not only that peace will be better protected against a host of potentially missile-wielding new enemies (North Korea, Iran, Iraq), but that the old enemy can be ignored. The cold war is finished, and with it the thinking that defined Russia as the threat and Soviet-American treaties as the bulwark of peace.

Russia, he says along with Richard Perle, is finished. So the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty should be no impediment to NMD. A meticulous article in the new issue of Survival, the journal of the Institute for Strategic Studies, exposes both the illegality and the probable diplomatic aftermath of busting the ABM treaty. But Dubya, backed by Henry Kissinger, Colin Powell and the rest of the old Reagan-Bush galere, is moving on from that tired analysis into a brave new world where the former treaty partner can be dictated to by the American hegemon.

This doctrine, the product of ideological triumph and political opportunism, underrates Russian pride and fear alike. Russia's deepest sense of security remains dependent on nuclear deterrence. It would perceive this as being imperilled by an NMD system that could one day, as Vladimir Putin must reckon, be thickened to black out the Urals as well as North Korea, and thus weaken the premise at the heart of the deterrent deal: each side's be lief in its vulnerability to a strike from the other side. Even Zbigniew Brzezinski, no dove he, attacks NMD for the false assumptions its defenders make about Russia, in the name of converting the US into "an internationally gated community", building exclusive protection against threats that derive a lot from paranoia.

To defend himself against that charge Bush now says he wants to include all allies under the umbrella. This notion doesn't appear to have been any more deeply thought out than the wider implications of NMD itself. It is of a piece with the casual opportunism which, in the context of the presidential election, leaves a great and complex issue vulnerable to many transient pressures. Maybe, whoever gets to the White House in November, a few reality-checks, of the technology, the finance and threats, will test NMD to destruction. But it would be unwise to count on this, in America's present mood of self-centred anxiety and vast budgetary optimism.

The allies, therefore, must continue to express their puzzlement and scepticism. The first Nato discussion of NMD, at the foreign ministers' meeting in Florence yesterday, rightly maintained that tone. Britain, the most faithful ally, has a particular responsibility. While certain not to criticise NMD in public, Blair sees a British role as mediator between the White House and his new special friend, Mr Putin.

Clinton's coming visit to Moscow is very unlikely to secure the crowning deal he wants, for Russian compliance in a modest NMD. With a future president, Blair sees himself as perfectly placed to get the parties round a table to make a sensible arrangement: the typical British middle-man, hoping to tame Bush (or Gore) and at the same time keep them sweet.

Something tougher is needed. Here is a project born of US domestic politics, with help from the military-industrial complex, assisted by congressional merchants of pork-barrel, pushed along by analysts who have lost their sense of proportion in face of the theoretical possibility that the land-mass of the US could be attacked. Serious risk-assessment is overwhelmed by game-players gripped by enchanting hypotheses about a North Korea mad enough to launch a putative missile against California or - the lure offered by a recent Pentagon visitor to Whitehall - Iran to do the same to London. Disruptive though it will be to 20th century alliances, the lures must be resisted.

To Europe, the billions don't matter much. The dollars are America's business. But global stability counts for everything. Washington is being drawn to disturb it radically, underrating the consequences with an insouciance that is a measure of US difficulty these days in maintaining an international perspective. If NMD should divide the alliance, that would be regrettable. But Europe should not quail before explaining to America that it will.

hugoyoung@compuserve.com

So the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty should be no impediment to NMD. A meticulous article in the new issue of Survival, the journal of the Institute for Strategic Studies, exposes both the illegality and the probable diplomatic aftermath of busting the ABM treaty. But Dubya, backed by Henry Kissinger, Colin Powell and the rest of the old Reagan-Bush galere, is moving on from that tired analysis into a brave new world where the former treaty partner can be dictated to by the American hegemon. This doctrine, the product of ideological triumph and political opportunism, underrates Russian pride and fear alike. Russia's deepest sense of security remains dependent on nuclear deterrence. It would perceive this as being imperilled by an NMD system that could one day, as Vladimir Putin must reckon, be thickened to black out the Urals as well as North Korea, and thus weaken the premise at the heart of the deterrent deal: each side's be lief in its vulnerability to a strike from the other side. Even Zbigniew Brzezinski, no dove he, attacks NMD for the false assumptions its defenders make about Russia, in the name of converting the US into "an internationally gated community", building exclusive protection against threats that derive a lot from paranoia. To defend himself against that charge Bush now says he wants to include all allies under the umbrella. This notion doesn't appear to have been any more deeply thought out than the wider implications of NMD itself. It is of a piece with the casual opportunism which, in the context of the presidential election, leaves a great and complex issue vulnerable to many transient pressures. Maybe, whoever gets to the White House in November, a few reality-checks, of the technology, the finance and threats, will test NMD to destruction. But it would be unwise to count on this, in America's present mood of self-centred anxiety and vast budgetary optimism. The allies, therefore, must continue to express their puzzlement and scepticism. The first Nato discussion of NMD, at the foreign ministers' meeting in Florence yesterday, rightly maintained that tone. Britain, the most faithful ally, has a particular responsibility. While certain not to criticise NMD in public, Blair sees a British role as mediator between the White House and his new special friend, Mr Putin. Clinton's coming visit to Moscow is very unlikely to secure the crowning deal he wants, for Russian compliance in a modest NMD. With a future president, Blair sees himself as perfectly placed to get the parties round a table to make a sensible arrangement: the typical British middle-man, hoping to tame Bush (or Gore) and at the same time keep them sweet. Something tougher is needed. Here is a project born of US domestic politics, with help from the military-industrial complex, assisted by congressional merchants of pork-barrel, pushed along by analysts who have lost their sense of proportion in face of the theoretical possibility that the land-mass of the US could be attacked. Serious risk-assessment is overwhelmed by game-players gripped by enchanting hypotheses about a North Korea mad enough to launch a putative missile against California or - the lure offered by a recent Pentagon visitor to Whitehall - Iran to do the same to London. Disruptive though it will be to 20th century alliances, the lures must be resisted. To Europe, the billions don't matter much. The dollars are America's business. But global stability counts for everything. Washington is being drawn to disturb it radically, underrating the consequences with an insouciance that is a measure of US difficulty these days in maintaining an international perspective. If NMD should divide the alliance, that would be regrettable. But Europe should not quail before explaining to America that it will. hugoyoung@compuserve.com

webTitle: Road charges are crucial, mayor tells assembly

fields.headline: Road charges are crucial, mayor tells assembly
fields.standfirst:
Mayor calls road charges at top of assembly agenda

Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone yesterday declared congestion charging the make-or-break issue for his London mayorship, as defeated Liberal Democrat mayoral candidate Susan Kramer accepted a job in his administration and Industrial Society director Will Hutton agreed to report on the tube funding controversy.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone yesterday declared congestion charging the make-or-break issue for his London mayorship, as defeated Liberal Democrat mayoral candidate Susan Kramer accepted a job in his administration and Industrial Society director Will Hutton agreed to report on the tube funding controversy.

Facing his first Greater London assembly question time as mayor, Mr Livingstone said that "getting the congestion charge right" was the single biggest issue facing London's new government.

Although the first of what will be monthly sessions was billed as a grilling, the man Tony Blair warned would be a "disaster for London" exuded benign consensus and dominated proceedings effortlessly. Continuing to deploy his powers of patronage to draw potential critics into his administration and put opponents on the back foot, the mayor used his report to assembly members to announce the appointment of Ms Kramer to the board of Transport for London, which will oversee bus, tube and train services from July.

He also revealed that Mr Hutton, former editor of the Observer and a consistent critic of the government's use of private finance initiative schemes in the public services, will head the planned inquiry into the relative merits of John Prescott's and his own rival proposals for funding tube modernisation.

Mr Hutton will take the place of journalist and rail expert Simon Jenkins, and report in September on whether the government's public-private partnership or Mr Livingstone's bond-financed public sector scheme offers Londoners a better deal.

Throughout the two-hour meeting in a church hall in Westminster, Mr Livingstone exchanged quips with Labour GLA chair Trevor Phillips, while continually emphasising the common ground with government ministers and between the assembly's political groups.

After listening to his explanations about early budgetary decisions, Tory GLA member Elizabeth Howlett told the mayor: "That all seems terribly prudent".

"That's me," replied Mr Livingstone, to widespread laughter from members of the public and GLA workers listening to the debate.

fields.headline: Man arrested over Dando murder
fields.trailText: Police today arrested a man on suspicion of the murder of Crimewatch presenter Jill Dando.
fields.body:
Police today arrested a man on suspicion of the murder of Crimewatch presenter Jill Dando.

The suspect was detained at about 6.30am and taken to a police station in London, Scotland Yard said.

Police said in a statement: "Officers investigating the murder of Jill Dando this morning arrested a man on suspicion of murder.

"The man was arrested at approximately 6.30am and was taken to a police station in London."

The spokesman added that no further details were being released at this time.

Today's arrest is the first since May 27 last year, when funeral director James Shackleton was questioned but released without charge.

He resembled the e-fit of the "sweating man" seen at a bus stop close to the 37-year-old's home minutes after the murder.

Detectives leading the hunt have always remained confident that they would arrest someone for the murder and a total of £250,000 in rewards has been put on offer.

Officers in the year-long inquiry have though been frustrated by the lack of significant breakthroughs from a series of public appeals and the unwillingness of people who were in the area at the time to come forward to clear their names.

fields.headline: Bundesbank alarm over misvalued euro
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Europe's monetary chiefs have blamed financial markets for the weakness of the euro, highlighting concern that public faith in the currency is being sapped.
fields.body:
Europe's monetary chiefs have blamed financial markets for the weakness of the euro, highlighting concern that public faith in the currency is being sapped.

Euro frailty could lead to political problems before the introduction of notes and coins in 2002 and has promoted an effort to talk it higher. Portugal hit out at markets for pressing the currency to levels that it said substantially undervalued it.

Earlier yesterday the Bundesbank issued an unusually strongly worded report, warn ing that the euro's exchange rate had become so misaligned that its credibility was at stake.

It said the euro was 20-30% undervalued and that "such misvaluations are not good".

The report stepped up the rhetoric of recent weeks with warnings notably from German and French officials that the currency's depreciation was totally unjustified.

Economists said the comments displayed increasing frustration among European policymakers not only at the euro's weakness but at their own inability to prevent it. One senior finance ministry official, speaking earlier this week, said the main problem was that the euro's fall against the dollar had not taken place in an orderly way.

"In a year and a half, the political question is what is going to be the public reaction [to the weak euro] ... A weak euro means increased inflation and increased interest rates."

He said a European Union finance ministers' (Ecofin) statement on May 8, outlining its policy towards the euro, may not have been forceful enough. The statement said Ecofin shared a "common concern" about the euro level, which it said did not reflect the strong economic fundamentals.

Intervention to support the euro has been effectively ruled out from lack of support from the US, while a raft of positive economic data and a steady official mantra that the currency "has room to appreciate" has not stopped the drop.

Economists see a danger that public concern over the currency becomes reflected in higher inflation expectations.

"This is a problem, because the public will ask who is responsible for the weakness of the currency and that is the central bank rather than politicians," said Jörg Krämer at Invesco Asset Management in Frankfurt.

In Germany it is a more acute problem as the Bundesbank is no longer sole guardian of the currency.

"The mark saw swings in the past but no one questioned the Bundesbank's inflation fighting credentials. The ECB does not have a track record," Mr Krämer said.
Reuters

webTitle: Euro route backed to save steel jobs

fields.headline: Euro route backed to save steel jobs
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Thousands of jobs are at risk in the steel industry because of the strong pound and the government's failure to join the euro, union leaders will tell MPs and members of the Scottish parliament and Welsh assembly later today.
fields.body:
Thousands of jobs are at risk in the steel industry because of the strong pound and the government's failure to join the euro, union leaders will tell MPs and members of the Scottish parliament and Welsh assembly later today.

The unions will also urge Corus, the country's main steel producer, to reverse its recent decision to halve the number of shifts at its Workington plant and axe 168 jobs despite winning a £120m order for rails from Railtrack - the bulk of which will go to Corus's new French plant because of sterling's strength.

The AEEU, which claims to be Britain's biggest metals union, is urging government action to secure British steel production and says the strong pound cut the country's steel demand by 10% last year, posing a threat to Corus plants, notably Llanwern and Port Talbot in south Wales.

Bob Shannon, the union's national organiser for metals, said last night: "Steel is a vital industry, employing 60,000 people, but it is under threat from the strong pound. Steel is losing £60m each month in lost export revenue and that means jobs are on the line." He added: "Joining the euro will give steel the stability it needs to invest and plan ahead. We can't afford to wait forever."

Union sources said the aim of the lobby was to give steel the same high profile recently awarded by ministers to the car industry.

Corus, formed from the merger of British Steel and Dutch rival Hoogovens last October, has said that its British operations may have to be "reconfigured" if sterling remains so strong. Analysts estimate that every 10 pfennig rise in the pound compared to the German mark costs the group £80m in lost profits each year.

In the six months before the merger British Steel lost £167m, largely because of the pound, but company officials insisted there was no immediate threat to the two Welsh plants which employ 6,500. Corus employs 34,000 in Britain but has shed 9,000 jobs in the past three years to counteract sterling's rise.

Mick Leahy, leader of the Iron and Steel Trades Confederation, the main steel union, condemned the decision to transfer the five-year Railtrack work to France as "absolutely crazy" and insisted Workington could complete the full order.

He insisted the medium-term prospects for the steel industry were more positive than the picture painted by the rival AEEU. "Our view is that Corus should keep output up to levels before the merger, producing 20m tonnes a year, and should ride the storm, putting pressure on their competitors."

webTitle: PM urged to set euro timetable

fields.headline: PM urged to set euro timetable
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair faced renewed pressure yesterday to step up Britain's preparations for the European single currency when a senior Labour backbencher called on the prime minister to set out a timetable for British membership.
fields.body:
Tony Blair faced renewed pressure yesterday to step up Britain's preparations for the European single currency when a senior Labour backbencher called on the prime minister to set out a timetable for British membership.

Voicing the frustration of pro-European cabinet ministers, Martin O'Neill said that Mr Blair should "clear the air" at this year's Labour conference and provide a "definitive statement" outlining his position on the euro.

Mr O'Neill, chairman of the Commons trade and industry committee, said: "There could be a problem if, in about six months from now, there has not been a definitive statement by the Labour leadership as to what the government's attitude is going to be on the issue.

"If we don't clear the air in the run-up to a general election, we will find that this will be an issue which will assume a significance that it doesn't merit."

His remarks, at a press conference organised by the pro-European Britain in Europe group, highlight the growing frustration among pro-European members of the cabinet at Downing Street's failure to take a lead on the euro.

The prime minister has said he is in favour in principle of joining a successful euro, but will wait until after the next election to decide whether Gordon Brown's five economic tests have been met.

Mr O'Neill said that business could not wait that long and the government should make clear this autumn whether the British economy is beginning to meet the tests.

"There is a point where governments have nowhere else to hide, and they have to come out and state their position in relation to the next phase of the European project," he said. "It is the prerogative of politicians to duck and dive and that has happened in the Labour party."

Mr O'Neill's intervention came amid signs of a growing cabinet rift over British preparations for the euro.

The pro-European Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, last week said that nothing could be done to help exporters hit by the high level of the pound until Britain joined the euro.

Stephen Byers, the pro-European trade and industry secretary, waded into the row when he said the government should guard against a drift back to a "wait and see" position.

fields.headline: Journalists killed in ambush
fields.standfirst:
Sierra Leone: special report
Interactive guide
fields.trailText: Two western journalists were ambushed and killed by rebel forces of the Revolutionary United Front outside the Sierra Leone capital, Freetown, yesterday. Three soldiers of the Sierra Leone army were also killed in the attack and two other journalists, a South African and a Greek, were injured.
fields.byline: Chris McGreal  in Freetown and  Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
Two western journalists were ambushed and killed by rebel forces of the Revolutionary United Front outside the Sierra Leone capital, Freetown, yesterday. Three soldiers of the Sierra Leone army were also killed in the attack and two other journalists, a South African and a Greek, were injured.

According to colleagues who identified the bodies, the dead journalists were an American working for the Reuters news agency and a Spanish cameraman working for the Associated Press. Their names have not yet been released.

They and the two journalists who were wounded were travelling in two vehicles when they were attacked four miles east of Lunsar. The wounded were treated at a hospital run by UN peacekeepers. Their injuries were not believed to be life-threatening.

News of the deaths came as the British government was plunged into new controversy over Sierra Leone by reports that British weapons were being used by child soldiers.

Officials admitted that British self-loading rifles could have got into the hands of boys in the Sierra Leone army, despite assurances by President Ahmed Kabbah that they would only be used by regular soldiers, in accordance with "human rights standards".

The reports that youngsters were arming themselves with British guns are acutely embarrassing to a government that has condemned the use of child soldiers in Africa.

The issue is doubly sensitive for ministers who agreed on Tuesday to supply the Kabbah government with a further consignment of weapons, including 10,000 ex-British army self-loading rifles.

The weapons were intended for training but are being used in combat, and not always by those for whom they were they were intended. Kamajor militiamen have often taken the guns of regular soldiers.

Controlling a shipment of 10,000 rifles, particularly in the middle of a war, will prove very difficult. Ultimately, if there are children on the front line they will end up with British guns in their hands.

The UN estimates that there are about 5,000 child combatants in Sierra Leone. The bulk of them were conscripted by the rebels after being ab ducted and introduced to powerful drugs, but there are many hundreds fighting with the government forces.

They were among the first to be demobilised when the country's peace accords were signed in July. They appear to have been among the first to pick up a gun again when the war rekindled. Of the 1,600 child soldiers sent to 10 UN camps for reintegration into civilian life, well over half are back in the war.

The new Sierra Leone army says it is screening out children. But other pro-government forces - particularly the Kamajor militia and the army loyal to the deposed military ruler Johnny Paul Koroma - have no such qualms. The aid agency Cafod warned yesterday that the new supply of British rifles could mean more children being given weapons.

Amnesty called for safeguards to ensure that he British equipment was not used to commit human rights violations.

Ministry of Defence officials insisted that the new weapons consignment would be subject to "controlled release under the supervision of British officers" leading the new military training mission.

fields.headline: Tory vow to scrap tagging
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The Conservatives will scrap the home detention curfew scheme under which more than 20,000 prisoners have been released early from jail on electronic tags, the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, said last night.
fields.body:
The Conservatives will scrap the home detention curfew scheme under which more than 20,000 prisoners have been released early from jail on electronic tags, the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, said last night.

She announced that the election of a Tory government would spell the death knell for the early release scheme, after citing figures showing that 400 of those released under the scheme - fewer than 2% - had gone on to commit a total of 700 new offences between them after release from prison.

"We will scrap completely the early release on tagging scheme," she said in the Commons to cheers from her own side. "Under Labour, the message is clear - if you get six months, you'll get out in six weeks."

She claimed that total cost of the extra prison places needed for the Tories' new crime initiative would be no more than £260m and denied Labour claims that the true figure would be nearer £1.5bn.

However, addressing the Conservatives, the Liberal Democrats' home affairs spokesman, Simon Hughes, said: "How do you explain that when you and your party were in government we had rising prison numbers and falling convictions, and that in 1992, after 13 years of the Tories, we had record crime?"

fields.headline: Leo slows Labour's poll slide
fields.standfirst:
Blairs' baby: special report

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour's slide in the opinion polls was checked by the birth of Leo Blair, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
Labour's slide in the opinion polls was checked by the birth of Leo Blair, it emerged last night.

A Mori poll for today's Times, undertaken last weekend, shows that Labour support has fallen three points to 48% - their lowest level for six years - while the Tories have jumped five points to 32%, their highest level since November 1996. That shift would have been greater but for the birth of Leo early on Saturday.

Just under half the interviews for the poll were done on Thursday and Friday, before the birth. Pre-Leo, Labour support fell more sharply to 46%, against 34% for the Tories.

fields.headline: Ask Jack
fields.standfirst: Send your questions and comments to Jack.Schofield@guardian.co.uk. Published letters will be edited for brevity but please include full details with your original query
fields.trailText: Script cue | USB for all
fields.body:
Script cue
What is this Scripting Host I read about? I don't find anything about it in the Help of my Windows 98. How can I turn it off if I can't find it? Roger Giles
rogermg@lineone.net

Jack Schofield: The Love Bug virus that swept the world exploited a feature of Windows insecurity that most people didn't know they had. It arrived as a Visual Basic Script (.vbs file), and any computer that runs VB scripts was and is potentially vulnerable, whichever email software is installed. The obvious response is to remove the software that runs VB scripts, and Roger Giles is not the only reader who asked how to do this.

Although removing the Windows Scripting Host (WSH) software is a good idea for most people, it also removes the program's benefits as well. For example, the synchronisation programs that enable handheld computers to update desktop PCs (and vice versa) may be affected.

WSH is installed as part of Microsoft Windows 98 and Internet Explorer 5, and can also be downloaded from Microsoft's website.

To disable WSH in Windows 98, select Start|Settings| Control Panel and double-click the Add/Remove Programs icon. Click on the tab for Windows Setup, select Accessories, and double-click to expand the section. Find the entry for Windows Scripting Host and click the check box so that it is not selected. Then click OK.

If you have installed WSH with Internet Explorer 5 or downloaded it, you can simply disable VBS scripting. Double-click the My Computer icon to open a window on your desktop and select View|Options. Click on File Types in the resulting tabbed dialogue box, then scroll down to the bottom. Select the VBScript Script File entry, and click on the Remove button. If there isn't an entry, don't worry about it. This approach should also work with other versions of Windows, including Windows 98.

Please note that disabling WSH and/or VBS will not prevent any email program from downloading viruses sent as attachments, and it will not stop you from running them.

In fact, it just makes it more likely that the next virus will use a different type of file instead. But while disabling VBS will not protect you fully, it will help protect other people: viruses will no longer be able to run a VB script that exploits the Microsoft Outlook address book to email themselves to everyone you know.

This week, Microsoft is also releasing a patch that makes Outlook 98 and 2000 (not Outlook Express) more secure, and users should now be able to download it from http:// officeupdate.microsoft.com The patch blocks the operations of a huge number of different types of file, not just VBS.

However, Microsoft Office users who want the extra security also have to install the large Office Update SR-1a service pack, which is perhaps best obtained from a computer magazine cover disc. They will also need their original copy of Microsoft Office.

Incidentally, the Outlook patch increases the default setting of the security zones within Outlook from "trusted" to "restricted", and this disables most automatic scripting. People who don't download the patch should do this manually by selecting Tools|Options and clicking the tab for Security.

USB for all
My computer with Windows 98 does not have a USB port. Is there any way one can be installed as many new devices seem to require this? Dr Donald Gau
DGau335533@aol.com

JS: In theory it should be easy to add two or four USB ports on a PCI expansion card, which can be plugged in to your PC after opening the case. Suppliers include Busby, Belkin and Entrega. Some USB cards will work with later versions of Windows 95 but Windows 98 works much better. (The need for USB is one reason for upgrading to Windows 98 or to Windows Millennium, which should arrive in a few weeks.)

Apple Mac users who lack USB ports can often add them via PCI expansion cards too.

Off messages
I signed up for various newsletters and reports which all have methods of unsubscribing - upfront and obvious until you try to use them. I am now having problems with Oprah Winfrey's Oxygen2. Where's the secret button that will free me from Oprah's clutches? Mary Wilde
wilde@kt66lw.freeserve.co.uk

JS: When you subscribe to a newsletter or mailing list, you should always get a welcome message that tells you how to unsubscribe, so file that away for later use. The main problem with getting off mailing lists is that subscribe and unsubscribe commands have to be sent to a different email address from messages - they have to be sent to the server computer, not the list owner or the entire readership. It's easy to send unsub message to the wrong address.

However, many mailing lists and publications now have websites where readers can subscribe and unsubscribe more easily. Oprah has one at www.oxygen.com/newsletters/unsubscribe.html

Download
Small irritating problem: when downloading some software from the net, my Windows 95 presents a choice of where I want to file it. If the software is to be used by a program, how can I find out where to store the software so it can be found by the program? Eliot Wright
100756.3352@compuserve.com

JS: I always download things to a folder called Downloads, otherwise I wouldn't know where to find them. Once downloaded, the file can be checked for viruses then copied to an empty directory such as C:\temp

If the download is actually several files combined into one package, use Winzip or something similar to look inside for Install.txt, which should tell you how to install the program. If that doesn't tell you to run the installation from somewhere specific, it should be OK to run it from C:\temp

Once the program has been installed, you can delete the contents of the C:\temp directory and remove any subfolders.

fields.headline: UFF rules out disarmament
fields.standfirst: Full statement
fields.trailText: The IRA's offer to put its arms beyond use does not represent an intention by the republicans to disarm, loyalist paramilitaries claimed today.
fields.body:
The IRA's offer to put its arms beyond use does not represent an intention by the republicans to disarm, loyalist paramilitaries claimed today.

The Ulster Freedom Fighters (UFF) insisted they remained committed to the peace process, but ruled out any move towards decommissioning their own guns.

A statement after a leadership meeting today declared: "The UFF does not consider the verification of selected IRA arms dumps as a step it is required to reciprocate."

UFF representatives have held two meetings with General John de Chastelain, head of the international decommissioning body, as part of the government's disarmament process.

More talks are likely and even though the IRA has pledged to keep their guns and explosives buried for good, the loyalists made it clear today they will make no moves at this stage.

Together with the Ulster Defence Association, the UFF is the largest of the loyalist paramilitary groups in Northern Ireland.

Meanwhile, police in the Irish Republic today seized bombmaking equipment belonging to dissident Republican paramilitary group the Real IRA.

The special detective unit recovered more than 1lb of Semtex, four electrical detonators and a timing power unit during raids on several houses in West Dublin this morning. A man in his late 40s was also arrested.

It is feared that the Real IRA is planning terrorist attacks in Northern Ireland in the run up to Saturday's crucial vote by the Ulster Unionist council.

A police spokesman said the searches were part of a continuing investigation into the Real IRA, and tests were being carried out on the recovered material.

webTitle: Eurotrash: Britain scrapes the barrel in waste league

fields.headline: Eurotrash: Britain scrapes the barrel in waste league
fields.standfirst: Government backs burning rubbish A government target to recycle 25% of household waste by the year 2000 will not be met with Britain consistently bottom of European leagues in recycling prowess
fields.trailText:
Targets
It became a cliché in the 1980s to say that Britain was the dirty old man of Europe. So much so, that the government felt compelled to set a goal of 25% of household waste being recycled by the year 2000 - a target it will not meet.
fields.body:
Targets
It became a cliché in the 1980s to say that Britain was the dirty old man of Europe. So much so, that the government felt compelled to set a goal of 25% of household waste being recycled by the year 2000 - a target it will not meet.

A decade on, the government continues paying lip service to recycling while stuffing every available crevice in the country with rubbish. If anything it is getting worse: a government waste report says we produce around 27 million tonnes of municipal waste each year, and this is growing by around 3% annually.

Household recycling in Europe and America
According to 1998 figures compiled from government data by Friends of the Earth, national household recycling rates were 52% in Switzerland, 45% in the Netherlands, 34% in Norway and 28% in Denmark. Across the Atlantic, the US recycled 31.5% of its waste, while in parts of Ontario many areas achieved rates over 60%.

In England and Wales, government figures confirm that just 8% of household and other waste collected by local authorities was recycled or composted. In Scotland, a mere 5.7% was recycled. The vast majority of Britain's rubbish was dumped in landfills.

Bottom of the league
This is not an isolated figure. Britain is consistently bottom of the league in all measures of recycling prowess. In terms of aspirations, England and Wales' new target is to recycle 30% of household waste by 2010. The Netherlands aims to recycle twice that, 60%, this year. Denmark hopes for 40 - 50% in 2000.

The UK is rooted to the bottom of the European glass recycling league, reusing just 24% of its glass in 1998. Switzerland recycles 91%, Sweden 84%, German 81%, and even France, with its notoriously cavalier attitude towards its countryside, recycles 55% of its glass.

The UK is second worst for steel recycling, with only tiny Luxembourg returning poorer percentage figures. In aluminium can recycling, Britain is doing better - it is third from bottom with 38% recycling figures, ahead of Spain and France, but still a (dirty) world away from Switzerland on 89%, Sweden on 87% and Germany on 86%.

Local rubbish
Within Britain, the enthusiasm of local authorities for recycling varies hugely. The best local authority for recycling in 1998/99 was Bournemouth, which recycled 37% of its waste, according to the audit commission. Only two other councils, Castle Morpeth and Dorset, recycled more than 30% of their waste.

The worst local authority was Wansbeck, which recycled 0.9% of its waste. Durham and Corby only managed to recycle 1% and 1.3%, while Sedgefield, Tony Blair's constituency, managed just 1.4%. Twenty four local councils in England and Wales recycled less than 2.5% of their rubbish.

fields.headline: Ofsted fails three councils
fields.standfirst:
Private sector to remedy 'serious weaknesses' in local authorities

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government is to send private consultants into three more "failing" local education authorities, it said yesterday, in an extension of its schools privatisation programme.
fields.body:
The government is to send private consultants into three more "failing" local education authorities, it said yesterday, in an extension of its schools privatisation programme.

The school standards minister, Estelle Morris, said consultants would be sent into the authorities in Bradford, Rochdale and Waltham Forest, north-east London, to advise on how improvements could be made after government inspectors uncovered "serious weaknesses" in their work.

The office for standards in education yesterday published its findings. It rated all three councils as poor but singled out Bradford as requiring the most urgent action.

Chris Woodhead, chief inspector of schools, said the inspections had revealed "an ingrained culture of failure and hopelessness" in all three areas.

The Yorkshire council - a hung council with a Conservative leader - now faces virtually all of its services being handed over to the private sector. Its problems were attributed mainly to "poor political and professional leadership ... over many years".

Consultants will also be sent in over the coming weeks to Waltham Forest and Rochdale, in Lancashire, both Labour controlled. All three authorities said yesterday they would work closely with the contractors to bring about progress.

Ofsted started statutory inspections of all local authorities in England two and a half years ago as part of Labour's drive to raise school standards, and has now inspected around half of them, 75 in total. Yesterday it published six reports on individual authorities.

Conservative run Kensington and Chelsea in west London received a glowing verdict. In central London, Conservative controlled Westminster was found to have "more weaknesses than strengths", with particular problems turning around standards in its secondary schools. At the same time, Labour led Luton in Bedfordshire was described as having made "uneven" progress.

Ms Morris yesterday defended the government's decision to take action "quickly, firmly and urgently" in the case of the three failing authorities.

"In Bradford we are not prepared to accept an option that leaves the LEA in charge of education services," she said. "The Ofsted report makes clear that the education services in Bradford are failing children and not supporting schools. The council is performing many of its responsibilities unsatisfactorily."

She admitted that "most, if not all" of Bradford's education services were likely to be contracted out to the private sector.

Mr Woodhead said that he was surprised and disappointed that there were still so many town halls letting down their local schools and communities.

The latest action by the government brings to 15 the number of authorities in which ministers have recommended intervention. Last week the government announced that it had extended its list of approved consultants and providers in anticipation of the demand for further inverventions.

Ms Morris said: "We are not in this for the short term or the quick headlines. What we want is irreversible change, and we will not leave any of these LEAs until we have got that. There will be no slipping back when we have finished."

webTitle: Clare Short's brother quits as school stress takes toll

fields.headline: Clare Short's brother quits as school stress takes toll
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The brother of Clare Short, the outspoken international development secretary, has resigned as headmaster of a struggling rural junior school "weighed down" by red tape and the daily grind of toiling in an under-resourced system.
fields.body:
The brother of Clare Short, the outspoken international development secretary, has resigned as headmaster of a struggling rural junior school "weighed down" by red tape and the daily grind of toiling in an under-resourced system.

After 28 years of teaching, and five years after being brought in to turn around the most socially deprived school in Somerset, Kevin Short has left to pursue a commercial publishing career.

"I just wanted to do something else," he admitted last night. "This battle has consumed my life for the last five years - and it's brick wall stuff.

"I've just turned 52 and I'm getting weighed down by it. Being a head is hard and I don't think it's something you should sacrifice your life to."

Mr Short's decision comes despite his having revolutionised exam results at the 280-pupil Hamp junior school - where the number of 11-year-olds passing the government's standard assessment tasks (Sats) in English, maths and science has soared from 18% on his arrival to 46% last year.

But his achievement has meant working more than 70 hours a week while struggling to balance the needs of his pupils - over a third of whom have special needs - with the constraints of the national curriculum.

"It's very frustrating because, although there's an atmosphere of change, there just aren't the resources or time to do it," Ms Short's brother, explained from his home in the village of Kilve, near Williton, last night.

"You have so many initiatives pouring in from everywhere - from the government, from your local education authority, and ideas you'd like to pursue yourself - but there's no conduit to control how much arrives unless you're very ruthless and bin lots of it.

"And of course you can't do that with government ideas, and you shouldn't with the local education authority's."

But, in a school where the majority of children come from single parent families and 40% are regarded as socially inadequate, other issues are equally important, Mr Short believes.

"We need to spend time dealing with low expectations, lack of role models, feelings of inadequacy and not just thinking: right, we're going to do some more English, or some grammar, or maths.

"The problem is, how do you create time for this - and how do you find the balance? It's very, very hard."

Mr Short, who previously worked as a head in Deptford, south-east London, spoke of the demands on his time, including helping to paint the school on Sundays and in the holidays. "It's something that can consume your life," he said.

He also criticised the severe underfunding of rural schools. "Inner city schools get a third more money, irrespective of need, because the problems are recognised more - but poverty in Bridgwater is similar to parts of London.

"But Somerset also has to spend millions on bussing children to schools, and on keeping small schools going. So we have 36 children in each class, even though over a third are special needs. That's not how you deal with learning difficulties - but how do you overcome it?"

Mr Short, who asked his older sister's advice before resigning, has few regrets about leaving his profession.

"It can be a daily grind. You have to have a burning passion and if you start to doubt you have that energy, you shouldn't be doing that job.

"What's needed are people who are positive. And I don't want to turn into someone who's no longer like that."

"I've just turned 52 and I'm getting weighed down by it. Being a head is hard and I don't think it's something you should sacrifice your life to." Mr Short's decision comes despite his having revolutionised exam results at the 280-pupil Hamp junior school - where the number of 11-year-olds passing the government's standard assessment tasks (Sats) in English, maths and science has soared from 18% on his arrival to 46% last year. But his achievement has meant working more than 70 hours a week while struggling to balance the needs of his pupils - over a third of whom have special needs - with the constraints of the national curriculum. "It's very frustrating because, although there's an atmosphere of change, there just aren't the resources or time to do it," Ms Short's brother, explained from his home in the village of Kilve, near Williton, last night. "You have so many initiatives pouring in from everywhere - from the government, from your local education authority, and ideas you'd like to pursue yourself - but there's no conduit to control how much arrives unless you're very ruthless and bin lots of it. "And of course you can't do that with government ideas, and you shouldn't with the local education authority's." But, in a school where the majority of children come from single parent families and 40% are regarded as socially inadequate, other issues are equally important, Mr Short believes. "We need to spend time dealing with low expectations, lack of role models, feelings of inadequacy and not just thinking: right, we're going to do some more English, or some grammar, or maths. "The problem is, how do you create time for this - and how do you find the balance? It's very, very hard." Mr Short, who previously worked as a head in Deptford, south-east London, spoke of the demands on his time, including helping to paint the school on Sundays and in the holidays. "It's something that can consume your life," he said. He also criticised the severe underfunding of rural schools. "Inner city schools get a third more money, irrespective of need, because the problems are recognised more - but poverty in Bridgwater is similar to parts of London. "But Somerset also has to spend millions on bussing children to schools, and on keeping small schools going. So we have 36 children in each class, even though over a third are special needs. That's not how you deal with learning difficulties - but how do you overcome it?" Mr Short, who asked his older sister's advice before resigning, has few regrets about leaving his profession. "It can be a daily grind. You have to have a burning passion and if you start to doubt you have that energy, you shouldn't be doing that job. "What's needed are people who are positive. And I don't want to turn into someone who's no longer like that."

fields.headline: Musical politics
fields.standfirst:
Elsewhere

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: There is something curiously un-Blunkett-like about the proposal that the time-honoured children's game of musical chairs should be banned on the grounds that it encourages aggression.
fields.body:
There is something curiously un-Blunkett-like about the proposal that the time-honoured children's game of musical chairs should be banned on the grounds that it encourages aggression. For Mr Blunkett has consistently conveyed the message that aggression is exactly what he wants to encourage in our children. He clearly believes that, without a bit of early elbow work, they are unlikely to become the boardroom buccaneers and global tycoons which New Labour wants to create.

Yet the thumbs down for musical chairs came from a semi-official quango linked to Mr Blunkett's own department. Indeed, the booklet in which the barmy recommendation is made was launched this week at a function addressed by that ultimate model of ministerial pushiness, Margaret Hodge. She made it clear that she certainly didn't want to ban musical chairs - unsurprisingly, since I bet she was a ruthless success at it when she was a girl. You don't pole-vault straight from leading a loony-left council to being a rock-solid Blairite apparatchik without having sharp elbows.

But no children's game - save perhaps for pass the parcel - provides a better foundation for a career in politics than musical chairs. Its essential nature is almost laughably close to such quintessential features of life at Westminster as the traditional cabinet reshuffle and the annual elections for the constituency section of Labour's national executive committee.

Even as I write, the tinkling piano music has already struck up inside the cabinet room, and the participants in this festival of push and shove have begun to circle the table. Soon the tempo will quicken, though it may be some time before the music stops. Or it may stop quite soon. And, as most of us remember from childhood, it is the suddenness of the silence which gives the game its thrill.

But when the music finally stops there will be a frenzy of childlike aggression exactly like the one condemned in this week's wimpish booklet. When the shrieking eventually dies down, some ministers will find themselves without a chair and will have to wipe their eyes, gather up their going-home presents. Like the children's version, it can indeed be cruel. So it's better to be prepared.

The ultimate example of cruelty was Harold Macmillan's notorious "night of the long knives", when he yanked out almost half the available chairs and thus left a formidable segment of his school chums and in-laws without a job. It moved the matchlessly witty Jeremy Thorpe to remark: "Greater love hath no man than that he lay down his friends for his life." But a subsequent Harold - Wilson - was more soft-hearted.

True, the music played in Wilson's reshuffles, and the participants circled the table in traditional fashion. But when the music stopped it often became apparent that not a single chair had actually been removed; everyone had simply moved round the table one or two places. "Yes," explained Barbara Castle after one such exercise, "but some of them are nearer the door than they were."

New Labour is not so squeamish - least of all at party HQ where another gold-medalist in elbow work, Margaret McDonagh, is in charge. Ms McDonagh not only yanks out the chairs when the music stops - she has hit upon a striking new wheeze: you don't put out the chairs in the first place.

Thus the promised ballot of party members for Labour's mayoral candidate was scrapped when it became obvious that Ken Livingstone would win it. And this month Millbank found a new wrinkle to cope with the elections to the party's national executive. They didn't scrap the ballot, they simply saw to it that members either didn't get a ballot paper, or fixed it so most of them didn't realise they had one before it was too late to cast their vote. This trick was accomplished by concealing the paper inside a so-called "magazine" which is so boring that virtually no one opens it, let alone reads it. Worse, the information that the package contained a voting form wasn't on the cover of the magazine, it was on the back of the see-through plastic wrapper.

The result has been highly satisfactory from Millbank's point of view. Having fielded a TV star to mop up as any votes as possible - and he delivered in spades - they managed to secure the defeat of most of the leftwing candidates by achieving a record low turnout: all down to what looks very like a con trick with the ballot papers.

A harsh verdict? Well, the alternative is that the "fix" on the London mayoralty and the "rigging" of the NEC vote are really the result of massive incompetence. I'm not sure which verdict Ms McDonagh would prefer, but I'm pretty sure which is the more plausible. If that's politics, give me a children's party any day, aggression and all.

David McKie is elsewhere

fields.headline: Alternative schooling
fields.standfirst: Ofsted strikes another council down
fields.trailText: Schools inspector Chris Woodhead has once again come down hard on councils. On his prompt, the government instructs Rochdale and Waltham Forest to bring in consultants.
fields.body:
Schools inspector Chris Woodhead has once again come down hard on councils. On his prompt, the government instructs Rochdale and Waltham Forest to bring in consultants. Schools minister Estelle Morris says she is not prepared to leave the elected councillors of Bradford in charge of schools; their management, as in Islington, will pass to a private firm or, conceivably, some other public agency. Ofsted's inspection of local education authorities is only half completed. By its end a good number of other elected councils will have seen their responsibility for schools' management removed. Local democracy is on the run. But even the most passionate advocate of diversity and ballot box choice must accept the hard facts of educational under-attainment and children's ruined life chances; alternatives to the town hall are worth trying, at least temporarily.

The accuracy of Ofsted's harsh judgement of Bradford and the other councils is difficult to assess, though it is noticeable how few heads and teachers, let alone parents and governors dispute them. But what next? Money plays a large part in explaining failure but Ofsted's charges pose a wider question. Are multi-member councils in the Labour- dominated cities inherently unable to provide a good services? If not education, can councils be trusted on child care and social work?

Labour, in thrall to its growing army of inspectors, has made councils more marginal. Meanwhile the local dimension to delivering public services and councils grows ever more complex. Alongside zones and specialist committees we now have private firms running services. It is going to be hard to evaluate let alone coordinate them.

Perhaps councils can evolve into the "strategic" bodies described in government papers. Under elected mayors or streamlined cabinets they might, in theory, be better able to supervise services for the delivery of which they are not themselves responsible. But that model depends on high-quality local leadership. A smaller number of councillors will have to be better paid. Elected councils are not just a vital element in democratic culture. They are often the only agency capable of kick-starting social and physical regeneration. Bradford may have failed to run its schools adequately, but an elected local authority with a substantial budget remains essential in ensuring Bradford has a future.

webTitle: A tale of two inner-city classrooms

fields.headline: A tale of two inner-city classrooms
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Bradford: Fight against 'culture of hopelessness'
fields.body:
Bradford: Fight against 'culture of hopelessness'

Alan Hall, headmaster at Belle Vue girls' school in Bradford, and his fellow heads across the city made the mistake of asking their local education authority nicely for some changes. Changes Ofsted has now demanded in acid terms.

The fact that everyone now knows of the "culture of hopelessness" under the former Labour council - turfed out in this month's elections - is no pleasure to Mr Hall, who fights a permanent battle against misconceptions about his own prospering comprehensive.

His coffee table uses a laminated upbeat local press cutting ("Belle Vue is Bradford's Best School") as a coaster for parents - 93% of them of Asian-origin - who come to grumble when standards do not seem as high as they would like.

With 55% of his 700 pupils on free school meals, 28% classed as special needs and 85% speaking English as a second language, Mr Hall needs all the help he can get from the LEA.

Instead, he says, he has had to batter his head against a befuddled attitude to funding, a sense of lethargy and an attitude of "we know what schools want better than you do".

The inefficiency has cut hardest in the LEA's allocation of resources, made worse by the council holding on to a much greater share of government funding than any comparable LEA.

While ministers talk about schools controlling over 90% of their budgets, the figure in Bradford is 77.6%. Mr Hall says: "We've been hoping for that extra control since 1988."

He says politicians seemed unable to ask schools: what do you need to help you do your job better?

Instead, the inspiration that has seen Belle Vue raise its A-level rates to the national average has had to come in part from private sector initiatives like the Teacher of the Year award. Mr Hall's deputy Jan Lee was a Yorkshire regional winner last year.

The prospect of private consultants moving into parts of the LEA also has backing from the heads, who reluctantly agree the authority is incapable of turning things round on its own.

Kensington: Council's great expectations aid success

When Chris Woodhead said that Kensington and Chelsea showed what it was possible to achieve in "very difficult urban circumstances", his words would have raised eyebrows among those who had only seen the borough's very visible affluence.

But the elegant stuccoed terraces and streets crammed with BMWs and four wheel drives can be misleading.

Just over half the borough's children are educated privately, removing at a stroke most of the wealthiest parents from its state schools.

Jan Bentley, head of the 270-pupil Fox primary, said hers is a very mixed school. "There are 30% of pupils who are entitled to free school meals. About 30% are bilingual. There are children who come in here at ages five to 11 with absolutely no English at all - some may be refugees, some from the local embassies.

"Another thing that's important is mobility. We have pupils moving in and out; it might be because they are refugees, or because when families expand they can sometimes no longer afford to live here."

Nevertheless, the school's character is broadly middle class and around a quarter of Fox primary's children go on to be privately educated, said Ms Bentley.

Ofsted yesterday praised Kensington and Chelsea for showing "strong, clear and efficient leadership" and for having high expectations of their schools.

Ms Bentley agreed. The LEA, she said, provided "a strong lead from the top; saying what needed to be achieved".

Ofsted also approved of the LEA's "excellent" training of school staff. Again, the head said the key to her school's success was "the quality of the teaching in the classrooms, the training and support that's given."

In most classes there is more than one adult so the teacher has help dealing with special needs pupils.

Envious rival LEAs note that the council can concentrate resources on its primaries because, unusually, the borough has only one secondary school.

The school has no uniform "because we believe that we are all individuals with something to contribute as an individual," Ms Bentley said.

fields.headline: Riots threaten pro-GM conference
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: Ringed by Italian riot police, disowned by city authorities, dumped by the government and besieged by protesters, the biotechnology industry's campaign for European hearts and minds crashed before it began yesterday.
fields.body:
Ringed by Italian riot police, disowned by city authorities, dumped by the government and besieged by protesters, the biotechnology industry's campaign for European hearts and minds crashed before it began yeste'

Hundreds of companies and institutions gathered in Genoa to organise a counter-attack against environmental critics, but were left stranded after the Italian authorities sided with thousands of protesters. The minister of agriculture, Alfonso Scanio, withdrew sponsorship of the three-day conference and sent a symbolic £30 to the estimated 400 pressure groups mobilising last night.

Genoa's council voted to join a group of municipalities which have banned genetically modified food, and will send its mayors to today's demonstrations. About 5,000 armed riot police, backed by helicopters, patrolled the seafront congress and exhibition centre as delegates arrived for the Tebio conference.

Biotechnology representatives from 21 countries had hoped to use Genoa as a showcase to reclaim the propaganda initiative, but the event appeared to have backfired amid claims that the programme had ben rigged.

The police are afraid that the scuffles and vandalism outside the centre will grow into street battles today when mainstream environmentalists are joined by anarchists and militants.

Claiming that the technology is dangerous and untested, the protesters have united under the slogan Rebellion is Natural. Britain's Reclaim the Streets group vowed to attend what some protesters billed a "mini-Seattle", threatening a sequel to the riots at the World Trade Organisation's summit last December. Greenpeace and Friends of the Earth have pulled out of the rallies for that reason.

The Italian prime minister, Giuliano Amato, sent a telegram of support to the conference, but several cabinet ministers backed the decision of Mr Scanio, a Green, to withdraw sponsorship.

Many newspapers and the nobel laureate Dario Fo also backed the protests.

The atmosphere of hostility was fed by a consumer watchdog's discovery of food products not carrying GM warning labels.

"The industry was trying to send a signal that genetically modified food was part of the wider biotechnology research into medicine and other good things but it failed," said Fabrizio Fabbri of Greenpeace

The conference organisers accused the protesters of hijacking a genuine attempt to engage in dialogue. Renalto Dulbecco, a Nobel-winning scientist and president of Tebio, admitted that controls were needed for potentially dangerous technologies, but pleaded for the benefits to be recognised.

Plants resistant to dehydration and rice with added vitamin A were just two of many breakthroughs that could be of huge benefit to developing countries, he said.

Speakers assured the audience that the future of GM technology was bright. Japan and the US were forging ahead in research, and laggards like Portugal, Spain and Italy were catching up, they said.

Doug Yarrow, of the British Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council praised the Government for spending an extra £1bn on the industry over three years. The UK was benefiting from improved "knowledge transference" between universities and firms, he said. Repeating a conference mantra about the need for public relations, he urged scientists to spend at least 2% of their time explaining their work to the public.

Academics and executives clustered around a stand offering tips on handling the media. The advice included: "Be as open as possible and never lie", "Show concern if there is a genuine problem", "Be as positive as possible without sounding callous and uncaring", and "Beware of admitting liability".

Secondary-school children were agog as John Schollar, of the national centre for bioethic education at the University of Reading, demonstrated how to create electricity from yeast. He said: "Children come with fresh minds, they are more open.

"If you can engage them in the science then they are in a better position to make ethical and moral choices about the science. Unlike some people outside."
