webTitle: Seeds supplied by France and US may be tainted

fields.headline: Seeds supplied by France and US may be tainted
fields.standfirst:
Crop crisis: GM contamination widespread

GM food: special report
fields.trailText: International seed suppliers and scientists last night admitted that contamination of crops by genetic modification was probably widespread, threatening to further undermine the government's claim that it is in control of the spread of the new technology.
fields.body:
International seed suppliers and scientists last night admitted that contamination of crops by genetic modification was probably widespread, threatening to further undermine the government's claim that it is in control of the spread of the new technology.

French suppliers of seed for Britain's maize crop have said they cannot guarantee it is free of GM material, while US testers warned that much of the American conventional seed supply may have been contamination by GM pollen.

Greenpeace, the environmental campaigners, raised the stakes further by claiming that 5% to 15% of the European maize crop might be contaminated - an allegation denied by seed companies.

An article in today's New Scientist reports that low level contamination of seeds sold to Europe appears widespread. Pioneer Hi-Bred, the world's largest supplier of GM and conventional seeds, acknowledged that a low level of mingling between the types was "inevitable".

"In 1998 the UK imported 491,000 tonnes of soya beans from North America. If 1% was GM, roughly 5,000 tonnes of GM soya beans were imported", says New Scientist.

A spokesman for the Brussels-based European Seed Association said yesterday that there had been one or two incidents last year when conventional maize had been found to be contaminated with GM.

"Everyone knew about it", said a spokesman, Garlich von Essen."There was no legal provision for this so French growers guaranteed there was not more than 1%. The guarantee does not mean there is GM, but it guarantees there is not more than 1%." France supplies most of the UK's maize seeds, said Mr Essen. He denied Greenpeace's claim of up to 15% contamination.

webTitle: Clinton refuses to back Blair's deal for RUC

fields.headline: Clinton refuses to back Blair's deal for RUC
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The famously close relationship between Bill Clinton and Tony Blair came under strain last night, as it emerged that the US president had refused, point blank, two successive pleas for help from the prime minister over the Northern Ireland peace process.
fields.body:
The famously close relationship between Bill Clinton and Tony Blair came under strain last night, as it emerged that the US president had refused, point blank, two successive pleas for help from the prime minister over the Northern Ireland peace process.

In what one high-placed source described "as an extraordinary and unprecedented event" Mr Clinton rebuffed Mr Blair twice in a day during two phone calls to the White House.

On May 10, just days after the IRA had promised to open its arms dumps to outside inspection, the prime minister contacted the president asking him to lean on both the Irish government and Sinn Fein, urging them to compromise on the proposed name change of the Royal Ulster Constabulary. Unionists want the RUC name to stay: Mr Blair was seeking White House help in extracting a republican concession on the issue.

"Clinton told Blair straight: not every issue is negotiable," the official, closely involved in the peace talks, told the Guardian last night. "He's about the only person who could have stood up to Blair on the issue and he did."

The president explained to the prime minister that, while the US had sympathised with unionist demands for IRA disarmament, it had no patience with subsequent unionist demands on the RUC and the flying of the union flag on public buildings on Northern Ireland.

Mr Clinton, who has remained in day-to-day, direct contact with the Ulster peace process, stressed his belief that the Patten report on police reform should be implemented in full "as it was printed."

The revelation comes as the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, is due to announce the government's final decision on the RUC name, possibly today. He is understood to be poised to make one final move to woo unionist doubters.

The decision will be watched closely for its impact on waverers within the Ulster Unionist party. The UUP's ruling council is due to vote on Saturday on whether to re-enter devolved government with Sinn Fein, with many unionists saying they will vote no unless the RUC name stays.

Party officials yesterday fore cast an extremely close vote, with as many as 400 of the council's 871 members already claimed by the No camp. But that cut little ice with the White House.

According to US officials, Mr Clinton regards the notion of an overwhelmingly Protestant force in Northern Ireland as the equivalent of the mainly white police forces that ruled black areas of the United States before the civil rights era. He believes that to bow to unionist demands on the RUC "would be like leaving Alabama and Georgia under all-white cops."

The president's rebuff of Mr Blair came after an all-out effort by the British embassy in Washington to persuade US opinion-formers to understand the unionist case on the RUC. Most American political and editorial opinion had earlier sided with unionism on disarmament.

But Mr Clinton stepped in with a lobbying effort of his own, making it clear that the onus was on unionism to compromise.

The episode is the first known clash between the two leaders, who have made much of their closeness. Mr Blair stood at Mr Clinton's side throughout the Monica Lewinsky scandal in 1998, and the president has seen the prime minister as his main ally in the search for a new third way in centre-left politics.

But his involvement in Northern Ireland has been so intense for so long that Mr Clinton now has strongly held - and highly informed views - of his own. Many observers say he has often read the process more shrewdly from Washington than have his counterparts in Dublin and London.

The government hopes that the focus on the RUC may be enough to bring John Taylor, the unionists' deputy leader, back onside, which would be a vital development in the push to restore devolution next week. Mr Taylor, at present in the Far East on parliamentary business, is opposed to a return to government with Sinn Fein.

Concessions would anger nationalists and republicans who say there are already as many as 44 differences between Chris Patten's recommendations for RUC reform and the Policing bill published last week.

Sinn Fein sources warned this week that the IRA initiative could be removed altogether if there were further concessions.

Mr Trimble also poured scorn on the plans of Jeffrey Donaldson, the Ulster Unionist MP for Lagan Valley and a critic of the Good Friday agreement, to forward his own proposals at the Saturday meeting.

Mr Mandelson indicated last week that he would back incorporation of the RUC's name in the "title deeds" of the new service. And he may accept an Ulster Unionist amendment before the debate on the bill.

webTitle: Politics, race and the fight to inherit

fields.headline: Politics, race and the fight to inherit
fields.standfirst:
Tottenham Labour party will today pick its candidate for MP. Will it be Grant's white widow or a young black barrister?

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tottenham Labour party will today pick its candidate for MP. Will it be Grant's white widow or a young black barrister?
fields.body:
Shortly before he was elected MP for Tottenham in 1987, the late Bernie Grant was interviewed in the presence of his partner, Sharon. Bernie said the most important message his victory would send to black people around the country was one of "self-respect. Young blacks need somebody they can look up to as a black."

"They're thirsting for a figurehead," added Sharon.

More than a decade later, following Grant's sudden death in March, Tottenham is once again looking for a "figurehead" to send to Westminster. And once again race is high on the agenda.

Of the four candidates shortlisted for the Labour ticket there are two frontrunners. On one side stands Grant's widow, Sharon - a white woman with whom he worked closely and who wishes to continue and build on her husband's legacy.

On the other is one of the "young blacks" to which Bernie Grant was referring - a 27-year-old barrister called David Lammy who grew up in Tottenham and went to Harvard, via a boarding school.

The ramifications go far beyond north London. At stake is the shape of any future debate on black representation in parliament and arguably the political legacy of one of the nation's most popular MPs.

Supporters of both camps say the decision, which will be made by Labour party members in Tottenham this evening, will be close. Transfers from the other two candidates - Shahid Malik, a Haringey council policy officer, and Sabena Khan, who comes from outside the borough - could prove crucial.

Mr Lammy, who was elected to the Greater London Authority earlier this month, is expected to emphasise his youth, his roots in the area and argue that it is time for change. Ms Grant will stress her track record in working alongside Bernie Grant and her ability to follow through on the work he started.

Mr Lammy's detractors have attempted to brand him a "Millbank stooge" - a slick, media-friendly candidate who will represent the interests of the Labour party leadership rather than the people of Tottenham. But while he is certainly the candidate favoured by the Labour party hierarchy, they have been keen not to be seen to interfere.

"There's no doubt that they want Lammy to win," said one senior Labour source. "But they know that if they make their support too obvious or look heavy-handed that it will be counter-productive. They've learned their lesson with Frank Dobson."

Ms Grant's critics say she is too leftwing and lacks the personal following that Bernie Grant built up over many years. "We do not inherit seats in the Labour party, we fight for them," said one local member.

Track record

"Bernie Grant had a lot of fine qualities and was very popular but we still have the bad housing and high unemployment here that we've always had. We need someone that ministers are going to listen to."

But despite her left-leanings, Ms Grant reportedly outshone the other candidates at the interview stage. "She's been in the party long enough to know how to play the game," said one Labour insider. "She was well-rehearsed and they couldn't point to any disloyalty in her track record."

While the votes will not divide on strictly racial lines, anecdotal evidence suggests that Ms Grant has attracted considerable backing from black and Asian members of the party, while Mr Lammy is expected to receive the support of a large section of white members.

Stafford Scott, a black community worker who was heavily involved in the Broadwater Farm Defence Campaign, says he is supporting Ms Grant "after a lot of soul searching".

"We've argued the need for black representation but many of the arguments being put forward in favour of Lammy are tokenistic," he said. "We're more worried about the quality of representation than the colour of it. Lammy's a nice bloke but he's as different to me as any white, middle class candidate."

But others insist that to elect Ms Grant would be to dwell on the past rather than look to the future. "Bernie was a great MP but we should not be trying to find a new Bernie," said Alan Stanton, a local councillor and former constituency secretary who is white and supporting Mr Lammy.

"David is bright, determined, energetic. We do need a black MP. They don't just have to be black, they have to be good as well. But we do need someone who is going to represent the multicultural nature of our community and provide role models for kids."

With almost 40% of the population belonging to ethnic minorities, Tottenham remains one of the most racially diverse constituencies in the country. It is home to a large Cypriot community as well as a significant proportion of people of West African origin.

The Broadwater Farm estate, notorious after the uprisings of 1985, shows just how much has changed and how much remains the same. The estate, which houses 3,500 people from 39 different nations, is enjoying a £33m facelift and was recently singled out in a government report on neighbourhood management. A huge mural of a waterfall greets you as you enter and concierges on many of the blocks.

It used to be branded the "estate of death"; last year the News of the World hailed its "astonishing turnaround" as a "miracle". But unemployment, at 40%, remains high and buses refuse to go there, preferring to stop at the top of the road.

Representative

Pastor Kweku Frimpong-Mason, the chairman of the tenants' association, says the race of the MP who follows Bernie Grant is irrelevant. "We don't talk about black and white here," he said. "We talk about people who can serve the people. We need someone who can represent the whole community."

Elsewhere in the constituency racial tensions remain acute. "Bernie represented us because he was black and he knew how we felt," said Nigel Taylor. "I don't know anything about his wife but if she's white then she doesn't know what it's like being black in London."

Those who back Mr Lammy say that the failure to replace Bernie Grant with another black candidate in a constituency like Tottenham would represent a significant setback in the Labour party's professed desire to see more black MPs.

There are only nine black and Asian MPs (eight Labour and one Tory) - a quarter of what there should be if the Commons were to be truly representative. And in the newly devolved bodies the story is even bleaker, with no ethnic minorities in the Scottish and Welsh assemblies and only two in London, where a quarter of the electorate is black or Asian.

"Our new democracies have been ethnically cleansed," wrote the Labour chairman of the GLA, Trevor Phillips, in the Observer this week.

But even these small numbers represent a significant improvement on 1987 when Bernie Grant, Diane Abbot, Keith Vaz and Paul Boateng became the first black MPs in Britain for more than 60 years.

Bernie Grant inherited a majority of 9,936 and doubled it in 10 years. He is referred to simply as "Bernie" and all, white and black, say he stood up for Tottenham. "What we need," said one resident of Broadwater Farm who refused to be named, "is someone who will put their career on the line if necessary. Bernie stuck his neck out for us."

Bernie Grant shot to prominence two years before his election in the wake of the murder of PC Blakelock. Famously mis quoted as saying "the police got a bloody good hiding" (he actually said "the youth think they gave the police a bloody good hiding"), he immediately became tabloid fodder: Barmie Bernie of the loony left.

In the last interview that he gave he described his struggle to be nominated MP for Tottenham as the "most stressful part of my life. My biggest problem was that the white structures in the Labour party didn't consider me to be a serious enough candidate even though I was leader of the council. They considered a black candidate as an anathema. Once I was selected, getting elected was a piece of cake."

The battle to replace him has been no less fraught although the battle lines could not be more different. This time the Labour leadership wants a black candidate and the Left is supporting a white one.

The constituency

Population: 45.5% black and minority ethnic; 54.5% white

Multicultural community numbers about 110,000

45.8% of residents own their homes

Unemployment: 13.5%

Most famous landmark: White Hart Lane stadium, home of Tottenham Hotspur football team

Covers approximately six square miles of north London

1997 election result

Labour 25,309

Conservative 13,341

Lib Dem 5,120

Majority 11,968

The Tottenham rivals

David Lammy

Age 27

Born Haringey, north London

Education A Haringey primary school, then King's school in Peterborough. Law degree from University of London, masters from Harvard law school

Work Barrister in London

Strengths Young, gifted and black. Favoured by the Millbank machine. Able public speaker and skilled campaigner with strong roots in the area

Weaknesses Favoured by the Millbank machine. Flown too high too fast - within a month of being elected to the GLA he wants to be MP for Tottenham. Born in the area but moved away at a young age

Sharon Grant

Age 47

Born Kent

Education School in Tonbridge, Kent, degree in social administration from Birmingham University, masters in comparative social administration

Work Lecturer until 1987, then personal assistant to Bernie Grant. A Haringey councillor 1984 to 1990

Strengths History of campaigning alongside Bernie Grant in Tottenham and is best placed to claim her husband's mantle. Proven credentials of standing up against Millbank

Weaknesses A white candidate replacing a black MP in an ethnically diverse seat. Represents more of the same, a leftwinger who might be alienated from ministers

Born in the area but moved away at a young age Sharon Grant Age 47 Born Kent Education School in Tonbridge, Kent, degree in social administration from Birmingham University, masters in comparative social administration Work Lecturer until 1987, then personal assistant to Bernie Grant. A Haringey councillor 1984 to 1990 Strengths History of campaigning alongside Bernie Grant in Tottenham and is best placed to claim her husband's mantle. Proven credentials of standing up against Millbank Weaknesses A white candidate replacing a black MP in an ethnically diverse seat. Represents more of the same, a leftwinger who might be alienated from ministers

fields.headline: Pinochet immunity revoked by Chile
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: A Chilean court has stripped Augusto Pinochet of his immunity from prosecution, raising expectations that the senator may face trial charged with human rights abuses.
fields.body:
A Chilean court has stripped Augusto Pinochet of his immunity from prosecution, raising expectations that the senator may face trial charged with human rights abuses.

Santiago's appeal court ordered that their landmark decision be kept secret for at least a week, but Chile's newspapers yesterday reported that the judges voted by 13 to 9 to lift the immunity which Gen Pinochet accorded himself when he changed the country's constitution in 1980.

For years Gen Pinochet, who overthrew President Salvador Allende in a bloody coup in 1973, has been seen as untouchable in Chile. The military continues to put pressure on the country's courts to retain that immunity.

President Ricardo Lagos has refused to comment on the court decision until it is made public, but he warned the military and their rightwing allies that the country would not tolerate interference in the affair.

The decision lifts the legal barriers to investigation of the former dictator's role in the disappearance and presumed murder of more than 1,200 opponents of military rule.

"Now we are opening the path of truth and justice," said Carmen Hertz, a human rights lawyer who lost her husband to Pinochet's security forces.

Gen Pinochet, 84, learned of the decision at his residence on the outskirts of the capital. It may take up to two weeks for the vote to be formalised, after which his lawyers will have five days to appeal to the Chilean supreme court.

Without immunity, Gen Pinochet could be prosecuted for 108 different criminal complaints lodged against him.

The state defence council, which participated in the effort to remove Gen Pinochet's immunity, has begun to investigate several high profile murders committed during the 1973-1990 dictatorship.

The cases include the mur ders of the labour leader Tucapel Jimenez in 1987 and the investigative reporter Jose Carrasco in 1986. The most advanced case against Gen Pinochet is that of the "Caravan of Death" in which 72 political activists were hauled from their jail cells and executed.

Before any inquiries can proceed, however, there are numerous hurdles. The former dictator's lawyers are expected to argue that he is too sick to mount a responsible and effective defence.

The decision to strip Gen Pinochet of immunity was made after growing pressure on a frail Chilean justice system. After showing little interest in human rights cases for 27 years the judiciary was forced to take the case seriously after the general returned from London in March.

The vote, called by Ruben Ballesteros, president of the Santiago appeal court was widely interpreted as pre-emptive move against the right wing and the military, both of which have been making public noises about the "the mistaken and unjust" treatment of Gen Pinochet.

On May 19, military leaders issued a communique reminding the public that the constitution cedes them the right to be "the guarantors of the country's institutional order". The declaration also asked the state and the public to work with "even-handedness" in civilian military issues.

President Lagos viewed the statement as a threat against a government decision to let the courts resolve the case of Gen Pinochet and other human rights issues.

Just hours before the leaked announcement of the court vote, President Lagos said in a national radio interview: "We are in a democratic country and the decisions of the courts are going to be respected and adhered to - by everyone."

webTitle: Last troops slam the gate on Lebanon's party

fields.headline: Last troops slam the gate on Lebanon's party
fields.standfirst:
Barak warns against cross-border attacks: Beirut declares national holiday: SLA militia floods into camps

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Barak warns against cross-border attacks: Beirut declares national holiday: SLA militia floods into camps
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg  at the Good Fence border crossing
fields.body:
Blaring their horns, a cavalcade of Lebanese guerrillas in purloined Mercedes cars roared up to the border yesterday, stopping within spitting distance of the Israeli soldiers who had lorded it over them only hours before.

And so, after 22 years of occupation and the deaths of 1,000 Israeli troops and many thousands of Lebanese, a new order was born at the perversely named Good Fence border crossing yesterday afternoon.

"The Israeli government has changed the situation in Lebanon," Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, told a press conference in Jerusalem last night. "Today there are no Israeli soldiers in Lebanon."

Amid the victory din from the Lebanese village of Kafr Kila, a scant half-mile from the crossing, Israeli soldiers glared at the enemy who had punctuated every step of their retreat from southern Lebanon with mortar fire and machine-guns.

Dozens plunged into the apple orchards along the border, inching closer to their sworn foes. But, in accordance with the new rules of engagement that Israel hopes to impose on the last active war zone on its borders, they did not open fire.

They were also powerless to prevent the wholesale theft of vehicles abandoned at the Good Fence during the headlong flight of Israel's proxy militia, the South Lebanon Army (SLA). With the evacuated security zone entirely under the control of Hizbullah, members of the militia face reprisals for collaborating with the occupier. As night fell yesterday, they were still streaming towards the border.

But for Hizbullah the party was in full swing. Although the whoops of joy floating across the frontier must have infuriated the Israelis, they were determined that the first day of the new order would not descend into bloodshed.

"It is Lebanese territory, where there is Lebanese sovereignty," said Major Oliver Rafowicz, spokesman of the army's northern command. "Until someone fires on us or kills Israeli citizens, if they want to have yellow Hizbullah flags or shout slogans and fire guns in the air, it is an internal affair."

It seemed a high-minded sentiment for what has been a most ignoble retreat.

At 6.42am, when the giant steel gates were padlocked shut behind the last tank to trundle out of south Lebanon, Israel was still finding comfort in the fact that it had extricated its 600 men and most of its weaponry without a single casualty.

Final retreat

A war so soul-destroying it was called Israel's Vietnam was over. But the last rites were a sombre affair.

"I have two feelings: great happiness, and great heartache," said soldier Shai Mor. As his Mercedes approached Gate 93 for the last exit, he unfurled a Lebanese flag, with its cedar crest.

Behind him came Brigadier Benny Gantz, night goggles slung around his neck and ear fused to his mobile phone. He too acknowledged that the end was painful, and that Israel had badly misjudged the staying power of the SLA.

Asked whether Israel had suffered a humiliating defeat, as Hizbullah and its supporters claim, he lifted his shoulders in an elaborate shrug before replying no.

"The Hizbullah are very well trained guerrillas," he said. "When it comes to fighting against a regular army, I am not sure too many armies would have done as well as Israel."

But the broader circumstances of the withdrawal are worrying. With the rapid demise of the SLA, and a refugee influx of 5,000 that has confounded all expectations, Israel is entering an era of great uncertainty.

At the Good Fence yesterday, the only missiles coming across were melons, lobbed by Hizbullah fighters, which splattered against an army vehicle.

Then a journalist asked the Hizbullah fighters about the rockets which have terrorised Kiryat Shmona, reduced to a ghost town in the past few days. "Their day will come," replied one.

But Mr Barak warned of the perils of any cross-border attacks. A statement issued by the Israeli cabinet said he "stressed that firing on soldiers or civilians within our borders will be considered an act of war that will require an appropriate response against any such action."

Meanwhile, Israel's army chief, Lieutenant-General Shaul Mofaz, threatened to strike Syrian targets in Lebanon if Israel came under attack.

"If there is an attempt to hit the northern residents or [Israeli] soldiers we will hit all the power-holding elements in Lebanon including Syrian targets in Lebanon," he told a press conference in Metulla. "The pilots are in a heightened state of readiness."

In Beirut Lebanon's prime minister, Selim al-Hoss, said Israel's generals were in no position to issue threats. He said the army had exited "terrified and defeated, wagging behind him the tails of a crushing defeat", and declared today a national holiday - "the Day of the Resistance and Liberation".

For their part in hastening the collapse of the SLA, Hizbullah guerrillas also received the blessings of the Hamas spiritual leader, Sheikh Ahmed Yassin.

From the Palestinian-controlled territory of Gaza, the disabled cleric said the past 48 hours had been an inspiration for Hamas's rejection of a negotiated peace with Israel.

"We in the Hamas Islamist Movement in Palestine look to this victory as a victory for Islam and Muslims in Palestine and everywhere," he said in a letter to the Hizbullah leader, Sheikh Hassan Nasrallah.

But some still seemed to be oblivious to the change in circumstances.

Yesterday, the erstwhile commander of the SLA, General Antoine Lahad, immaculate in a freshly starched periwinkle blue shirt, dawdled over lunch in the restaurant of the Cedars Hotel in Metulla while a bodyguard kept back reporters.

Refugees' anger

He did condescend to raise a glass of Pepsi in a toast, but was perhaps still unaware that in the town of Marjayoun, Hizbullah guerrillas were sifting through the detritus of his looted home.

Forty miles down the road, his countrymen could not afford to be so sanguine. At Korazim, a second tent camp for the influx was going up on a huge car park built for the papal visit in March.

Many of the new arrivals were bristling with fury. "How dare Israel put us in camps like this," said one. "We are not Palestinians."

webTitle: Hizbullah savours victory as defeated foe looks on

fields.headline: Hizbullah savours victory as defeated foe looks on
fields.standfirst:
President tours liberated area: No bloodshed amid celebrations: Struggle continues, says guerrilla chief

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: For the first time in 25 years Lebanon has become whole again. To celebrate, President Emile Lahoud himself went down to the restored southern strip which had been occupied by the Israelis and their surrogate forces for 22 years.
fields.byline: David Hirst  at Kfar Kela, on the Israeli frontier
fields.body:
For the first time in 25 years Lebanon has become whole again. To celebrate, President Emile Lahoud himself went down to the restored southern strip which had been occupied by the Israelis and their surrogate forces for 22 years.

But it was not the Lebanese army that accomplished this feat. It was nowhere to be seen. It was the Iranian-backed Hizbullah, the most successful resistance movement Israel has ever faced. The guerrillas were everywhere, with a vast camp-following of ordinary citizens who had come on a pilgrimage to the various improvised shrines the liberated territory had to offer.

Some climbed up to Beaufort castle, a spectacular legacy of the Crusades, which was abandoned by the Israelis in the middle of Tuesday night. Some crowded into the joint headquarters of the Israeli oc cupation forces and their proxy militia, the South Lebanon Army, in Marjayoun. They found the Israelis had stripped it of almost anything worth taking. Some tried to loot the nearby house of the SLA commander, General Antoine Lahd, but militiamen forced them to yield up the carpets they had seized.

For many the most important shrine was the Fatima Gate. There for the first time in their lives they peered down into the territory of the "Zionist enemy" which had visited such havoc on their country.

They were all good-humoured. But for the Israelis who watched the festivities from the other side of the fence, there could be no escaping the fact that, after the withdrawal from Lebanon without guarantees or agreements, Israel and Hizbullah are eyeball to eyeball along the length of the frontier. The potential for conflagration is immense.

Asked what the future held, Hizbullah's chief for south Lebanon, Sheikh Nabil Kaouk, said "more victories" against the enemy. There were still the so-called Shebaa farms to liberate - about 40 square miles of territory at the junction of Israel, Syria and Lebanon, on which Israel has built a ski resort and a settlement for Ethiopian Jews.

But one of his colleagues, Sheikh Hussein Yahya, was more cautious. For the time being, he implied, Hizbullah would digest its victory.

Throughout the former Israeli security zone teams of guerrillas were collecting a rich haul of military trophies which the SLA had left behind. Between the former crossing point, near the market town of Nabatiyah, there were at least six abandoned tanks, scores of armoured cars, jeeps, and other vehicles.

Hizbullah was also imposing a new moral order. In a first symbolic gesture, the guerrillas pulled down a statue of Saad Haddad, the first commander of the SLA and dragged it through the streets.

The neighbouring village of Qleia, peopled almost exclusively by Christian Maronites, some of whom were among the first to collaborate with the Israelis, was almost deserted. Many of the inhabitants are believed to have fled to Israel. The Hizbullah seized Israeli goods in the shops.

But the takeover has been almost bloodless. When Israel staged its long, slow withdrawal from its 1983 invasion of the country as far as Beirut, the process triggered intercommunal bloodshed.

It will be a weighty decision, some inhabitants say, for Hizbullah to resume its armed struggle against Israel. For most of them - those who were there during the occupation and those now returning to their abandoned arms and orchards from the congested slums of Beirut - the victory is complete.

fields.headline: Mugabe legalises land grab
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The president of Zimbabwe, Robert Mugabe, stepped up pressure on the British government yesterday by formally announcing a change in law that will allow him to confiscate white-owned farms.
fields.byline: Andrew Meldrum  in Harare and  Ewen MacAskill
fields.body:
The president of Zimbabwe, Robert Mugabe, stepped up pressure on the British government yesterday by formally announcing a change in law that will allow him to confiscate white-owned farms.

The land grab, which effects up to 841 white farms worth £108m, could come as early as next week unless Britain offers an improved compensation package.

The attorney general, Patrick Chinamasa, said the list of farms slated for seizure might be released tomorrow.

The Commercial Farmers Union, which represents Zimbabwe's 4,500 mainly white farmers, also put the onus on Britain when it appealed yesterday to the international community, especially Britain, to make funds available so farmers would be compensated for properties seized.

But the Foreign Office was uncompromising yesterday, insisting there will be no more cash and that it did not intend being held hostage.

The Foreign Office minister Peter Hain, who has been an outspoken critic of Mr Mugabe, said: "This act is calculated to raise the temperature. It is in nobody's interest.

"We are extremely concerned that President Mugabe may be preparing to take land quickly and without compensation under this act."

Mr Mugabe's latest move came amid increased violence in the run-up to parliamentary elections on June 25 and 26. The opposition Movement for Democratic Change claimed yesterday death squads had been set up to eliminate its candidates, and there were reports of election monitors being beaten up.

The MDC secretary general, Welshman Ncube, alleged that members of Mr Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party had been given special paramilitary training at Zimbabwean army headquarters in Harare and deployed for "Operation Tsuro" - the systematic elimination of the opposition party's candidates.

Operatives had been told "if you get the opportunity to kill them and you can get away with it, you should do so," said Mr Ncube.

Mr Mugabe, who claimed Britain has reneged on promises to fund land com pensation schemes, used his sweeping powers to amend the Land Acquisition Act, giving his government the authority to seize white-owned farmland for redistribution to poor blacks. The alterations were published in a special government gazette, the presidential press secretary, Munyaradzi Hwengwere, confirmed yesterday.

The new law was made possible by a constitutional amendment pushed through parliament on April 6.

Mr Mugabe is hoping the seizure of the white-owned farms will help his Zanu-PF party regain the support of the country's poor rural blacks. Mr Mugabe's backers have already invaded more than 1,300 farms and are claiming them as their own.

The official confiscation of 841 farms will make them government properties. Mr Mugabe could then move poor blacks onto the seized farms before the parliamentary elections.

The president of the Commercial Farmers Union, Tim Henwood, said his organisation opposed the seizure of the 841 farms, but he appealed to the international community for help with funding.

"The international community could make funds available for a proper resettlement programme, in which farmers would be fully compensated for their land," he said. "It would be helpful if Britain were to come to the table and participate."

webTitle: Prescott shoots from the hip to escape mob

fields.headline: Prescott shoots from the hip to escape mob
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Bob Dylan sang "They're selling postcards of the hanging" - a reference to the pictures which Americans who'd attended lynchings mailed to each other early in the 1900s. The last time John Prescott performed at prime minister's questions, more than a year ago, it did seem like frontier justice, if without as much legal punctilio.
fields.body:
Bob Dylan sang "They're selling postcards of the hanging" - a reference to the pictures which Americans who'd attended lynchings mailed to each other early in the 1900s. The last time John Prescott performed at prime minister's questions, more than a year ago, it did seem like frontier justice, if without as much legal punctilio.

The Tories turned out in party mood yesterday, looking forward to a twitching dangle and a slow, painful death. David Willets was wearing a vivid salmon tie, and Anne Widdecombe was glorious in jet black and pink. With her legs sticking out, she looked like a gigantic dancing liquorice allsort from an old TV sweetie ad.

But the victim refused to be strung up. The necktie party went on without the guest of honour. Mr Prescott wasn't brilliant, but he was a thousand times better than last time, and he left the chamber to riotous applause from his own side and slaps on the back from his colleagues.

Oh, he got plenty of things wrong. Apparently the dome will have "seven limmion visitors" which is "almost as many people as voted Tory at the last election" - a fact which he liked so much that he told it to us twice.

He spoke about "integrated tranning, er transport planning." When Alan Beith picked him up on the miserable 75p a week offered to old age pensioners, he said "he mustn't berate us for simply giving what he calls the 78p on pensions."

Challenged by Sir George Young, the shadow leader of the house (some weird protocol prevents Mr Hague from squaring up to a mere deputy prime minister) he rattled off all the ways in which the Tories had ground down Britain's hard-pressed pensioners: "They stopped the earnings link, which with pensioners is one of the major complaints," he yelled, oblivious to the fact that Labour hasn't restored the link in three years. The Tories collapsed in mirth at that, but Mr Prescott pulled the noose off his neck and hurled it into the dust.

For these were minor errors, mere stumbles compared to the terrible crash of April 1999. Mainly, it's because he has realised that a tiny drop of humour goes a long way in the Commons, like tabasco sauce on an oyster.

So, answering the formula question about the prime minister's engagements for the day, he said: "He has been working throughout the night on exhausting domestic matters." The whole country would congratulate him and Cherie on the birth of baby Leo. "Six pounds, 12 ounces - now there's a killer fact!"

This reference to last week's Blair parade of killer facts ("Tories sucked the brains out of 2m old age pensioners and sold them to space aliens - killer fact!" and similar nonsense) was wildly applauded.

When Sir George Young raised the topic of the state pension, Mr Prescott pointed out that Mr Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, had shown a lack of enthusiasm for Mr Hague's policy on this matter.

"It's clear that Hugh Grant and Liz Hurley aren't the only ones going through a separation!"

Topical or what? I like the idea of prime minister's questions as a David Letterman-style comedy monologue. "The hon. gentleman's speech directly contradicted his party's policy on this. Seems like actor Amanda Holden isn't the only one who's been fooling around behind the old man's back!" Or, "this white paper resembles Carol Vorderman's dress at the Baftas. What it reveals is fascinating, but what it conceals is crucial!"

Whatever. Mr Prescott had triumphed over the mob, and rode away from the lynching to astonished cheers.

webTitle: Flight from border zone turns spotlight on Syria

fields.headline: Flight from border zone turns spotlight on Syria
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Israel's withdrawal from southern Lebanon has brought Syria back to centre-stage in the Middle East. So far, it's not a speaking part.
fields.body:
Israel's withdrawal from southern Lebanon has brought Syria back to centre-stage in the Middle East. So far, it's not a speaking part.

President Hafez al-Assad is a famously cautious man and he will need a little time to weigh up the dynamics of the new situation.

Israel, meanwhile, has lost no time in warning of the consequences if he fails to restrain the Hizbullah guerrillas in Lebanon.

On the Syrian side, a statement in yesterday's issue of Tishreen, the official daily, sounded ominous. "There will be no peace with Israel until it pulls back its troops to the [pre-war] June 4 1967 line."

This is standard fare and "no peace" does not necessarily mean war: since the military disengagement of 1973, Syria and Israel have not exchanged a single bullet.

More significantly, the statement went on to say: "The Israeli retreat and defeat in Lebanon came as a result of the Syrian-Lebanese struggle." In other words, Syria is treating the withdrawal as a partial victory - which probably means that it sees no need for immediate action.

As the last Israeli troops moved out, Syria pointedly announced that its foreign minister, Farouq al-Shara, had spoken to Madeleine Albright, the US secretary of state, by telephone and that both had "affirmed the necessity of assuring citizens in south Lebanon and avoiding military escalation".

One view of Syria's position is that it now faces a serious dilemma because, with the Israeli withdrawal, it has lost its best bargaining chip.

According to this view, Syria's bargaining power with Israel rested until this week mainly on its hegemony in Lebanon, which it could have used, in the context of a broader deal, to help Israeli forces leave the south and guarantee border security afterwards.

Probably in the hope of nudging President Assad towards the negotiating table, Ehud Barak, the Israeli prime minister, announced that his forces would leave Lebanon with or without Syrian cooperation. Syria was not to be stampeded, so Israel withdrew unilaterally.

One of the attractions of the missed deal was that Mr Barak might have found it relatively easy to sell to the Israeli public. The war in Lebanon was unpopular, and the return of the Golan Heights would not have appeared an unduly high price to pay for peace on the northern border. The question now is what, if anything, can Israel get in exchange for the Golan Heights?

The Syrian and other Arab governments take a more sanguine view. That is Mr Barak's problem, they say. But there can never be a comprehensive peace in the Middle East while Israel continues to occupy Syrian territory.

It is also clear that Israel's unilateral withdrawal from Lebanon will probably not bring border security - in which case there will still be something to negotiate about with Syria.

This makes the current situation extremely dangerous. Syria's interests lie in making Israel feel that its northern border is still insecure, but at the same time it cannot risk a direct conflict with Israel.

Eyal Zisser, an expert on Syrian affairs at the Tel Aviv University Dayan centre for Middle East studies, said yesterday: "Syria doesn't want escalation; it doesn't want a war. What they will try to do is to copy the situation that we had along the security zone to the border itself."

Syria, he said, would probably encourage the activity of individual groups against Israeli troops. "They will try to check and test Israeli intentions and to create new rules of the game that will enable them to continue and use this pressure card against Israel."

Israel, in turn, cannot afford to let Syria get away with that - hence its threat to hit Syrian targets as reprisal for attacks by other groups.

Israel, now that it has no troops in Lebanon, is also likely to draw increasing attention to the presence of 35,000 Syrian troops there. This will be seen by some Arab leaders as an Israeli attempt to drive a wedge between Syria and Lebanon.

It may, however, prove impractical to call on Syria to withdraw its troops while keeping Hizbullah on a short leash. Last month a Lebanese newsletter, ad-Diplomasi, suggested that Syria had been working on a plan to move its forces into the border area - which Israel might prefer to eyeballing Hizbullah across the fence.

webTitle: Mugabe gangs strip and beat school staff

fields.headline: Mugabe gangs strip and beat school staff
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: They arrived with lists of schools, businesses and individuals suspected of supporting the opposition Movement for Democratic Change and began hunting them down.
fields.byline: Andrew Meldrum in Chimanimani, eastern Zimbabwe
fields.body:
They arrived with lists of schools, businesses and individuals suspected of supporting the opposition Movement for Democratic Change and began hunting them down.

They took over the town's secondary and primary schools and dragged the teachers from their classrooms. Some teachers accused of being MDC supporters were stripped naked in front of their students. Many were beaten, some unconscious. Several teachers were hospitalised and three headmasters are still missing.

By the standards of Zimbabwe's increasingly brutal election campaign, Chimanimani got off lightly at the weekend. But the hit squad trained and funded by President Robert Mugbe's ruling Zanu-PF had done its job.

Today, Chimanimani, a quiet, prosperous town on Zimbabwe's eastern mountains is half deserted. Most people avoid speaking to outsiders.

The campaign is called "Operation Tsuro" after the rabbit or hare, which Shona people believe to be a particularly intelligent animal. The hit squad has been trained to burn, bludgeon, torture and kill to get Zimbabweans to support Zanu-PF.

Next stop on the gang's tour was the Border Timbers estate and lumber mill. After several workers were beaten and management was threatened, the company decided to close down all operations. Border Timbers employs 3,500 people and had export orders worth US$18m (£11m) last year. The company has since re-opened.

Mr Mugabe's men also in vaded the farm of the MDC parliamentary candidate for Chimanimani, Roy Bennett. In response to death threats, Mr Bennett said he would rather give up his farm than his allegiance to the MDC. But he left Chimanimani with his wife, Heather, after the war veterans had held her hostage for several hours.

Mr Bennett tried to return to his farm yesterday, but he was warned by police that the occupiers were armed and would shoot him dead. His once prosperous coffee farm is now a shambles from looting and destruction. Many of his 600 workers have been badly beaten.

"The war veterans intimidated everyone in the town," said a local woman."Tellers at the bank, workers at Zesa [the state electric power company], the post office and the PTC [the phone company] were all threatened and followed when they went home from work. Some were beaten and their homes ransacked."

The police have promised to protect people from violence, even if it comes from visiting thugs from Zanu-PF, but things have not returned to normal in Chimanimani. There are no tourists and the normally popular hotels and lodges are empty.

At the weekend people were told to attend a rally for the Zanu-PF parliamentary candidate, Munacho Mutezo. About 2,000 showed up, many in vehicles commandeered from Mr Bennett's farm.

Mr Mutezo, the chairman of Time Bank in Harare, made a big show of the MDC T-shirts and membership cards, which he said had been "surrendered" by people at the rally.

"There are hundreds here who have rejoined Zanu-PF," Mr Mutezo said. "People are deserting the MDC for Zanu-PF out of free choice."

The intimidation of Chimanimani is not an isolated incident. Zanu-PF has sent squads to Kariba, Mutoko, Murehwa and Masvingo and other provincial centres. In Harare and Bulawayo, the townships have been brutalised by gangs who go door to door.

"We are afraid and we hope things will get back to normal soon," said a man in Chimanimani. "But people still want change. We hope that if we are quiet now, we will be able to vote for change when the time comes."

fields.headline: Empty gestures
fields.standfirst:
The new Tory pension plans are phoney

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Beware of snake-oil salesmen carrying second-hand goods. One balding member of this fraternity went to the London School of Economics yesterday having already got his proposals on the front pages of three broadsheet newspapers. William Hague is promising to provide increases in pensions ranging from £5.50 for single people to £10 a week for retired couples over 75.
fields.body:
Beware of snake-oil salesmen carrying second-hand goods. One balding member of this fraternity went to the London School of Economics yesterday having already got his proposals on the front pages of three broadsheet newspapers. William Hague is promising to provide increases in pensions ranging from £5.50 for single people to £10 a week for retired couples over 75. What has happened to the party which believes in cutting taxation, broke the link between pensions and earnings (losing retired couples over £30 a week), scrapped free eye tests and promoted a private pension strategy which lost 2.4m people some £11bn? Humility would be more appropriate than yesterday's hubris from the Tory leader. As Steve Webb, a social security specialist and Liberal Democrat spokesman noted, all but 70p of the Tory money was already heading towards pensioners.

The good news for the nation's 11m pensioners is that belatedly their cause is now being taken seriously by politicians. No group saw such a widening of inequality between its members during the Tory years - a fivefold variation between the top and bottom 10%. Below an ever-rising average - £240-a-week in 1997 - a wide phalanx of poverty persisted. Labour has rightly concentrated on this poorest 40%, some 4m people who only survive on means-tested benefits. Much welcome targeted help has been funnelled to this group through an earnings-related minimum earnings guarantee. By next April this will have helped lift the income of single pensioners over 75 by £950 a year and couple's income by £1,350. But the party of spin has failed to find a way of selling this redistributive programme. Worse still, it has not been rigorous enough in tracking down the 500,000 eligible people who decline to claim the increases. There is nothing wrong with its policy, but a lot wrong with its politics in failing to recognise the row that a mere 75p on the basic state pension would generate.

fields.headline: No more excuses
fields.standfirst:
Unionist no vote will leave peace in tatters

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Not for the first time the fate of Northern Ireland lies in the hands of 870 or so members of the Ulster Unionist Council. On Saturday they will vote whether or not to re-enter devolved government with Sinn Fein.
fields.body:
Not for the first time the fate of Northern Ireland lies in the hands of 870 or so members of the Ulster Unionist Council. On Saturday they will vote whether or not to re-enter devolved government with Sinn Fein. If they vote yes, their party leader, David Trimble, will resume as Northern Ireland's first minister. The province's grand experiment in self-rule will begin once more. If they vote no, Mr Trimble's leadership will be in tatters and the Northern Ireland executive will be nothing more than a memory. According to Seamus Mallon, the ever-wise deputy leader of the Social Democratic and Labour party, the outcome will be even bleaker: the peace process itself will be sidelined "for at least a decade".

So the stakes are high. In the past Unionists had to ponder the risks of power-sharing with Sinn Fein while the IRA refused to give up its weapons. Now that has changed. The IRA has found a way to disarm in its own terms: by offering to open up its arsenals to independent, international inspection. That offer came in a statement at the start of the month which almost everyone involved could see was a huge breakthrough. Indeed, that was the word used by the Ulster Unionists' deputy leader, John Taylor - who predicted at the time 95% backing among Unionists for a return to the executive. In other words, the major obstacle that used to stand between them and power-sharing has been removed. The decommissioning problem has been solved.

And yet the no camp within the UUP remains as adamant as ever. They claim to have wooed at least 400 council members over already, although some suggest their strength peaked last weekend - when Mr Trimble wisely put off a vote which he might well have lost. Which way that human weather vane, deputy leader John Taylor, jumps will be crucial. The rejectionist case no longer centres on decommissioning. Instead, the rejectionists have shifted their complaint. Now they say they cannot re-enter government with Sinn Fein unless the Royal Ulster Constabulary is allowed to keep its name - in defiance of the recommendations of Chris Patten's independent report. They also want to wave the Union flag from public buildings. For that they are prepared to spurn the best chance of peace in a generation.

This is a demand that should not be indulged. As we report today, Bill Clinton understood that - and said as much to Tony Blair. For this demand is not meant sincerely. Most of those making it are using it as an excuse to refuse, once again, to reach an accommodation with republicanism. Jeffrey Donaldson and his chums do not want to share power with Sinn Fein. When decommissioning ceased to be a good excuse not to, they found something else. Proof of that came when Mr Donaldson told the BBC on Sunday that he did not want his two daughters to be taught in schools controlled by Martin McGuinness as minister of education. There was something refreshingly honest in that remark. For what Mr Donaldson was admitting was that arms, names and flags are not the core problem: the heart of the matter is that he does not want to see Sinn Fein anywhere near power, no matter how much it or the IRA changes. It has taken some time to reach this degree of clarity. But now that it is there, we should use it: and understand that Saturday's vote is a straightforward choice between Mr Trimble's acceptance of the necessity of power-sharing and Mr Donaldson's refusal of it. It is a choice between reality and fantasy. We hope Ulster's Unionists know which way to jump.

fields.trailText: Ministers were yesterday forced on to the defensive over the troubled Millennium Dome as anger mounted among Labour backbenchers, peers and opposition parties.
fields.body:
Ministers were yesterday forced on to the defensive over the troubled Millennium Dome as anger mounted among Labour backbenchers, peers and opposition parties.

Conservatives in the Lords attacked government handling of the Dome as a "fiasco that is rapidly becoming a scandal", while the Liberal Democrats called for the attraction to close early, and the number of mainly Labour MPs demanding a public inquiry into the project's funding rose to 64.

But the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, standing in for Tony Blair at prime minister's questions, hailed the Dome "a success" as Tories dubbed it a "monument to the vanity and emptiness of New Labour".

Amid continuing claims that the former British Airways chief, Bob Ayling, forced to quit as chairman of the New Millennium Experience Company board on Tuesday as a condition of another emergency lottery grant, had been made a scapegoat to protect ministers, his successor, David Quarmby, tried to put the attraction's troubled past behind him.

A member of the board since February 1997, he said the Dome team was doing a "terrific job".

Meanwhile, MPs homed in on the culture secretary, Chris Smith's role in granting emergency funding to the Dome.

Mr Smith's shadow, Peter Ainsworth, and the Labour MP for Medway, Bob Marshall-Andrews, both claimed the culture secretary's position as head of the Dome's sponsoring department - the Department of Culture, Media and Sport - and chairman of the millennium commission, which funds and oversees the project, represented a conflict of interest.

The Conservatives demanded an explanation after it was confirmed that Mike O'Connor, director of the commission, advised members that - according to the narrow criteria on which he was allowed to make a judgment of value for money - he could not recommend the granting of the latest emergency lifeline of £29m to the Dome.

He told commissioners that they could still opt to make the grant if they considered other factors such as the cost of shutting down the attraction, estimated at between £100m and £200m.

Mr Smith then wrote to Mr O'Connor on behalf of the commissioners authorising him to issue the grant.

The Tories' deputy leader in the Lords, Lord Mackay of Ardbrecknish, raised the issue of millions of pounds of extra funding in an emergency question.

He said: "This is a fiasco that is rapidly becoming a scandal."

Lord Falconer, whom Tories and Labour critics argue should take much of the flak for the Dome fiasco, defended the "worthwhile" project and said it was necessary to "rejig plans" because of an original overestimate on the numbers of visitors.

The Dome was still achieving higher visitor numbers than any other paying attraction in the country, he said.

The minister, who cancelled a Sky TV appearance today on which he was scheduled to answer questions about the Dome, repeatedly stressed the "independent" nature of the millennium commission.

Government sources claimed that it was one of the independent commissioners who had first suggested that the latest £29m grant should be conditional upon Mr Ayling's departure, and that the plan had been backed unanimously by the others, who include the former Conservative deputy prime minister and original Dome enthusiast, Michael Heseltine.

The government is anxious to repel claims from Labour backbenchers and opposition parties that his sacking was a political manoeuvre by the government to shield ministers from blame.

Suggestions by the New Millennium Experience Company that the commission had withdrawn its condition, allowing Mr Ayling technically to resign without being pushed, were denied by the commission yesterday.

There were no signs that ministers were prepared to offer any olive branches to those MPs expressing concern, who include the former defence minister, Peter Kilfoyle, and the former deputy chief whip, George Mudie.

Mr Blair's spokesman disclosed that the prime minister had spoken to Mr Ayling on Tuesday, after the former British Airways chief's resignation, to thank him for the work he had done on the Dome project.

Dome winners _

Residents of Greenwich. House prices up 10%

Pierre Yves Gerbeau. £100,000 salary at the Dome

Thames Water. Won award for innovative toilet design

Employees. Up to 5000 new jobs over the year

Local businesses. They have have secured £11m worth of new contracts

_ and losers

Jennie Page and Bob Ayling, both forced to resign

The black redstart, Britain's rarest bird, which lost its nesting ground

New Millenium Experience Company, harshly criticised over handling of lottery funds

Sponsors who have had their names associated with a huge "white elephant"

webTitle: Trimble's rival prepares for day of destiny

fields.headline: Trimble's rival prepares for day of destiny
fields.standfirst:
Profile: Jeffrey Donaldson detests division - but opposes his leader

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Profile: Jeffrey Donaldson detests division - but opposes his leader
fields.body:
The landmarks in Lisburn to Molyneaux House, party HQ, are a road map to Ulster Presbyterianism. Pass the Orange Hall, go left after the Gospel Hall and just before the Y club, and there it is, with union flag flying, on the right just alongside the British Legion.

Jeffrey Donaldson, who replaced former party leader James Molyneaux as Ulster Unionist MP for Lagan Valley three years ago, is late. Time enough to flick through A Day in the Life of Ireland, photographs from all 32 counties, and Many Cultures: One Nation, marking Nelson Mandela's presidential inauguration six years ago. The reading material might surprise the prejudiced outsider.

Donaldson, 37, infuriates many, British liberals included. But nothing angers him more than the suggestion he is one of those don't-want-a-Fenian-about-the-place unionists that Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams harps on about. All he wants, he says, is democracy.

David Trimble, the party leader, is likewise hardly his biggest fan. That may be prompted more through fear than anything else, for Donaldson has proved a formidable opponent and, despite his protestations, is waiting in the wings should Trimble fall.

He has until now managed successfully to ride both horses. He sees himself as a constructive critic of the Good Friday agreement and, consequently, the party leadership, while simultaneously regarded within the more hardline anti-agreement camp as one of them.

Northern Ireland may have changed forever on April 10 1998, the date the agreement was sealed. But Donaldson's career too was transformed, walking out at the last minute after playing a key role shoulder to shoulder with Trimble in the all-party talks.

As Trimble assented to the agreement, Donaldson was departing Castle Buildings, unable to back the deal because IRA decommissioning was never pinned down. Party spin doctors suggested he was leaving on a family holiday. It rang hollow even then.

Before then Donaldson was heir apparent, the party's rising star. He was steeped in the Ulster Unionist party, working as Enoch Powell's agent at 18, was assistant grand master of the Orange Order, and was an impressive media performer.

Donaldson, late yesterday because of meetings with party delegates to draw up alternative proposals to put to Saturday's meeting of the ruling Ulster Unionist Council, says: "There was no opportunism involved. I simply in all conscience would have been unable to look people in the eye and tell them this was a good deal. I was heavily punished, prevented from standing for the assembly. While I enjoy my work as an MP, it has left me sidelined."

Trimble brought him in again at Castle Buildings last July, signalling to Sinn Fein he was no soft touch on decommissioning. He also asked him to join a review committee after the suspension of the devolved institutions in February.

Donaldson denies feeling used. But he points out the review committee, set up in February to look at the circumstances in which the party might return to an executive, last met two months ago.

Even his critics within the party concede Donaldson was right. Tony Blair turned somersaults to pull him back on side during the referendum campaign, adding his hand-written pledges on the issue to the side letter he gave Trimble on Good Friday. Donaldson dismissed them all as meaningless fudge, enraging Blair.

Donaldson knows his plan, which he refuses to unveil now, must appeal to a broad base of delegates, who have different reasons for opposing a return to government. One argument playing well is that a yes vote means Martin McGuinness as education minister.

But he says he had other objections at the time to the agreement. He cites the policing issue, and believes that Chris Patten's later recommendations on the RUC vindicated him. One of his formative experiences was when his cousin, Sam Donaldson, was the first policemen to be blown up in the troubles. Sam's brother, Alec, also became an IRA victim, murdered in a mortar attack on the RUC station in Newry, which killed nine.

Many see Saturday's decision as the defining moment in Northern Ireland politics. Wrapped up into it, they say, is Trimble's future, the realignment of unionism, the fate of the agreement, and maybe even the survival of the loyalist and IRA ceasefires.

Donaldson says: "I don't subscribe to this being Armageddon. It is an important day, but I don't believe everything is settled on Saturday, whatever happens. But it is vital the Ulster Unionist party stands up as the custodian of democracy and good government."

Donaldson, married with two daughters, Claire, nine, and Laura, eight, still ducks questions about his ambitions. But whereas he used to deny he had a burning drive to be top dog, he says now: "I am in no hurry to become leader."

That may be wise. Ulster Unionists seem to be heading for electoral setbacks next year, and the race may be to be the next leader but one.

Leadership questions prompt his only hesitancy. He would, he finally says, prefer this were about issues rather than a beauty contest. He detests this division.

fields.headline: Redstone's hopes of raising £1bn dashed
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Telecommunications operator Redstone admitted that falling technology share prices have dashed its chances of raising £1bn towards financing expansion plans.
fields.body:
Telecommunications operator Redstone admitted that falling technology share prices have dashed its chances of raising £1bn towards financing expansion plans.

As the company yesterday announced increased pre-tax losses of £10.4m, chief executive Graham Cove admitted market conditions mean Redstone will not be able to raise the cash it needs by the first quarter of next year to complete a national telecoms network.

Mr Cove said Redstone, which leases capacity from other operators and resells it to small businesses, plans to connect to 300 BT local exchanges by the time they are opened to competitors in July 2001. But he admitted that plans to raise £500m to £1bn within 10 months to take Redstone to 3,000 BT exchanges could not proceed under present market conditions.

Mr Cove said that Redstone still has sufficient funds to double its previous short-term expansion target.

Redstone is also contemplating buying an internet service provider, he said. The share price fell as much as 20% after the announcement of figures for the year to March 31, which compared with a £3.2m loss the previous year, and finished the day down 15.5p at 227.5p. Redstone floated at 120p a share last October.

The pre-tax loss was in line with forecasts and traders said the falling share price was more due to a general weakness in the sector. Redstone said it had appointed UBS Warburg as a joint broker alongside existing adviser Peel Hunt.

fields.headline: Microsoft break-up hint
fields.standfirst:
Judge's comments point to split after breach of monopoly laws

The future of Microsoft: special report
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The US judge presiding over the Microsoft anti-monopoly trial gave the first indication that he is considering breaking up the software group.
fields.body:
The US judge presiding over the Microsoft anti-monopoly trial gave the first indication that he is considering breaking up the software group.

In his first public remarks since finding Microsoft guilty of breaking US anti-trust laws, Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson asked lawyers for the US government and 17 US states why they had not proposed breaking the company into three rather than two.

He praised an "excellent brief" submitted by two industry associations which proposed dividing Microsoft into three companies.

The justice department and states had proposed turning Microsoft into an applications company and a company to sell Windows, the operating system used on more than 90% of the world's computers

David Boies, government senior counsel, said yesterday that a two-way split would be "quicker and more effective than a horizontal divestiture".

Judge Jackson asked if the government's proposals would not "simply create two separate monopolies which have no incentive to interfere with each other's profitability".

In a sign that the judge would like the trial, which started more than two years ago, to be over quickly, he said when offered further legal disclosure that he "did not want to see any more briefs".

John Warden Microsoft's chief counsel, said the company "fully expected to prevail on appeal wherever that appeal will be held".

The judge commented: "It is somewhat ironic that if you think you will prevail when you get to the court of appeal, you nevertheless, are asking to spend more time in this court."

Mr Warden continued to argue that the government's break-up proposals were "extreme" and "punitive", which is not allowed under the relevant anti-trust laws.

He said: "There is absolutely no precedent for what is proposed here. The court has long understood that splitting up unitary companies is an enormously complicated and disruptive process and one which neither the court nor the justice department has any natural inclination."

In a heated exchange Mr Warden and the judge discussed the consequences of Microsoft's conduct, which the judge had ruled to be unlawful.

In a typically dramatic presentation, Mr Warden argued that the government was siding with Microsoft's corporate rivals. He described a group of them, including some micro systems, and Novel, as "corporate pygmies".

Mr Warden also described the economic benefits created by Microsoft and said that a break-up could harm the future developments of the economy. "The court is thus presented with a situation in which benefits of the existing organisation are substantial and known and the benefits of busting it up are speculative and unknown and may be negative."

In presenting its argument, the government criticised Microsoft's proposals for a remedy based on business constraints as inappropriate. An email sent by Bill Gates after an earlier so-called consent decree had been agreed read: "This anti-trust thing will blow over and we haven't changed our basic business practices at all except it may change our e-mail policy."

fields.headline: A class act
fields.trailText: May I add a personal memory of Sir John Gieldud from the other side of the stage door. As a theatre-mad teenager in the 50s, I and my school friends were introduced to his varied talents in A Day by the Sea, the "Japanese" Lear - later The Ages of Man. We were, alas, too young to have seen his Hamlet or Richard. We used to dash round to the stage door for autographs afterwards; some of the cast would go past ignoring us.
fields.body:
May I add a personal memory of Sir John Gieldud from the other side of the stage door. As a theatre-mad teenager in the 50s, I and my school friends were introduced to his varied talents in A Day by the Sea, the "Japanese" Lear - later The Ages of Man. We were, alas, too young to have seen his Hamlet or Richard. We used to dash round to the stage door for autographs afterwards; some of the cast would go past ignoring us.

Sir John, immaculately dressed, trilby at a modish angle, cigarette elegantly attached to his lower lip, always came and talked to us, signed everything, listened patiently to our girlish praise, thanked us and said good night. Forty years on I wrote to him to thank him in retrospect for all the enormous pleasure he had given me - I received a handwritten response by return. Goodnight sweet prince, and flights of angels sing thee to thy rest.
Alison Turner
Tunbridge Wells, Kent

fields.headline: Misogynists in the house
fields.trailText: Just days after Oona King's article (Male members, May 19), sitting in the Commons, I listened to seven references to "Blair's babes" and other rude remarks from Conservatives, implying Labour women MPs elected in 1997 are not interested in the legislative process, want to work only from nine to five and are frightened of making speeches.
fields.body:
Just days after Oona King's article (Male members, May 19), sitting in the Commons, I listened to seven references to "Blair's babes" and other rude remarks from Conservatives, implying Labour women MPs elected in 1997 are not interested in the legislative process, want to work only from nine to five and are frightened of making speeches.

I used to think the Tories who promote these views did so by accident, reflecting a kind of institutional misogyny. But now I realise that this is a determined attempt to drive people who do not fit the old male, macho mould out of the house. The presence of women threatens their smug complacency. The gasbags who this week prolonged debates until after 2am on matters where there was no disagreement and no vote, have a padding of self-importance which insulates them from contact with real life and increases with each year of continuing service.

They want to drive out the new women because they don't want the diversity of British society to be properly represented in parliament. They recognise that the best ally of reactionary Conservatism is cynicism about politics which the continued under-representation of women and black and Asian people in parliament will create. Opinion polls show that Tory support is at rock bottom, yet in the local elections they demonstrated that they can win when people don't bother to vote. Few people vote when they feel excluded from political life and debate.

I hope to continue representing the people of Slough out of a determination to help this place to catch up with modern society. Last week a number of Slough employers described to me their policies to help parents balance work and family life. It makes good business sense and I have no doubt that legislators with better balanced lives will make better laws.
Fiona Mactaggart
MP

webTitle: Cheap jibes at Roger Lyons' expense

fields.headline: Cheap jibes at Roger Lyons' expense
fields.trailText: The article by David Hencke (The all-expenses lifestyle, May 23) was a disgraceful commentary on the operations of a modern democratic union. The so-called expenses attributed by Hencke to our general secretary, Roger Lyons, include major costs of hotel accommodation and meals for union conference delegations, press conferences, meetings with our unions etc. The fact that a credit card has been used does not mean that all, or even a majority of the purchases benefit the cardholder. Maybe Hencke should have checked? The general secretary invited him to check his "facts" in detail but he refused the offer.
fields.body:
The article by David Hencke (The all-expenses lifestyle, May 23) was a disgraceful commentary on the operations of a modern democratic union. The so-called expenses attributed by Hencke to our general secretary, Roger Lyons, include major costs of hotel accommodation and meals for union conference delegations, press conferences, meetings with our unions etc. The fact that a credit card has been used does not mean that all, or even a majority of the purchases benefit the cardholder. Maybe Hencke should have checked? The general secretary invited him to check his "facts" in detail but he refused the offer.

Among the many inaccuracies in the article was the allegation that there are "disputed expenses". There are not. Investigations in April 1999 by accountants HW Fisher, and a report of July 1999 by the government's certification officer, charged with ensuring correct use of union funds, confirmed that previous allegations "were untrue and without foundation".

Expenditure on "sustenance" was confirmed as principally Sunday, Bank Holiday and late-night expenditure. There is no claim by staff "for thousands of pounds of unpaid overtime". That is simply untrue. Refreshments are not "usually provided" on news programmes by radio and TV stations as claimed by Hencke. It is however true that some limited refreshments have been purchased on occasion by MSF for journalists - as certain Guardian staff can verify!

The union does not insure officers on business abroad, as Hencke asserts, unless specifically arranged - as has been done by the general secretary. Nor was any family meal or petrol claimed in France. The union's 1998 Christmas NEC reception was paid for on the general secretary's card, and 75 lay elected members had a Christmas drink. Doesn't this happen at the Guardian?

The only "extraordinary" feature of Hencke's article was your decision to give it a full page. Every penny of the general secretary's expenses has been checked and verified by independent inquiry. But why let the truth spoil a nasty anti-union dig at our general secretary and our campaigning union?
Brenda Warrington
President, MSF

fields.headline: Stood up
fields.trailText:
The Tories' "money back if you stand for 20 minutes" scheme (Tories stand up for rail commuters, May 24) for commuters would be expensive and probably make things worse. I try to avoid peak travel times. But if I knew I could travel for free by making my journey at the busiest times, I might be tempted to join the crush.
Iain Forsyth
London
