fields.headline: Words with the warden
fields.trailText: Philosophers are supposed to be good at expressing their views clearly and succinctly, and Alan Ryan fully lived up to this expectation (Oxford blues, G2, May 24).
fields.body:
Philosophers are supposed to be good at expressing their views clearly and succinctly, and Alan Ryan fully lived up to this expectation (Oxford blues, G2, May 24).

Mr Ryan was given a whole page to defend Oxford University's rejection of Laura Spence as a medical student, but he could have stopped three-quarters of the way down his first column, the point at which, startlingly, the warden of New College conceded the worst suspicions of critics of Oxford's selection system.

The interview process, he admitted, "gives ... middle-class bullshitters a flying start". Indeed, it might have been better if he had stopped there. Then he would have spared Ms Spence, his readers and perhaps himself as he rereads it, his gratuitous and patronising swipe at her in his final sentence. "With any luck," he wrote, "she will ... learn [at Harvard] the sort of respect for the complexity of the truth that will make her a good doctor ..."

Most people, glancing at Ms Spence's achievements, would assume that she has this respect already.
Donald Mackinnon
Yardley Gobion, Northants
donaldmackinnon@yahoo.com

 As the warden of New College, Oxford, is apparently unable to write good English, perhaps it is a good thing that Laura Spence is going to Harvard: "...it wasn't them that....", for goodness sake!
Dr John Baker
Cambridge

 Alan Ryan is right to distinguish between qualification and entitlement, and also to note that private schools tend to supply candidates en masse. But, unlike the finals of the Olympics, selection for university is not a measurable, objective process and there are clear biases at work.

The reason state school teachers are resentful when their candidates fail is not because of their reaction to the individual event, as Alan Ryan suggests, but because of the disproportionate success of the private schools overall: with under 10% of pupils, they supply more than 50% of Oxbridge undergraduates.

Oversubscribed institutions such as Oxbridge and the medical schools have a choice: they can smugly recruit in their own image, or they can acknowledge a duty to devise recruitment procedures which recognise the full range of talent and potential in the society which supports them.

I do not write as a chippy outsider: 25 years ago, I achieved my Oxford place as a result of a selection process which discriminated in favour of state school applicants, a brave and imaginative decision which clearly would not be made now.
Liz Fuller
London

 Why did the Guardian give Alan Ryan a full page to justify the blatantly inequitable Oxbridge entry system? Why did you not ask Wheen to write instead? Why do so few candidates from northern comprehensives achieve Oxbridge places? We still have yet to be told.
Alan and Lesley Fowler
Wadsworth, W Yorks

 Alan Ryan may be right that admission standards are lower at Harvard than at Oxford, but it's not because Americans leave school a year earlier - they don't. They generally start a year later, aged six, but presumably that's not the explanation either.
David Voas
Liverpool
voas@liv.ac.uk

 Why are thousands of perfectly good applicants being turned away from medical schools each year? I thought we were short of doctors, and that's why junior doctors had to work such long hours.
Dave Hill
Tonbridge, Kent

fields.headline: Further education
fields.trailText: Roy Hattersley's evidence (Comment, May 22) is questionable. Grammar school pupils are selected at age 11. If a comparison is to be made between the results of grammar school pupils and the most able 25% in comprehensives, then the latter group must also be selected on the basis of tests done at that age. A rather better point of comparison would be the GCSE point score, which then gives some idea as to how all the pupils are faring rather than just an underperforming few.
fields.body:
Roy Hattersley's evidence (Comment, May 22) is questionable. Grammar school pupils are selected at age 11. If a comparison is to be made between the results of grammar school pupils and the most able 25% in comprehensives, then the latter group must also be selected on the basis of tests done at that age. A rather better point of comparison would be the GCSE point score, which then gives some idea as to how all the pupils are faring rather than just an underperforming few.

A recent review of the literature on grammar schools by David Crook et al concluded there is no strong evidence one way or the other as to whether children will achieve higher results in a comprehensive or a grammar school. Since the onus must be on proponents of grammar schools to show the value of them for the children who attend, this rather unglamorous result is all the ammunition Roy Hattersley needs.
Geoff Tennant
London

 The main argument of the Campaign for State Education against grammar schools has always been "creaming": the education of the majority is allegedly being damaged by taking out the top tier of ability. But if the top 25% at comprehensives are doing better than the creamed children, none of the presumed causes of poor achievement by less able children can in fact be true. Logic should now dictate that the pressure will be off grammar schools. Having proved conclusively that comprehensives are doing better without the creamed children, let us make the choices we want to make, depending on what our children are like and where we happen to live.
Charles Owen
Birmingham

 Perhaps now it has been shown that there are no educational reasons for keeping grammar schools, proponents will admit that they really wish for social selection for their children.
Mary Blake
Campaign for State Education

fields.headline: An Ayling pound
fields.trailText:
Now Bob Ayling is looking for employment (New Dome chairman chosen, May 24), I suggest the government puts him in sole charge of the strength of the pound. Given his recent track record, it will not be long before exporters are happy again.
Michael Wilson
Newark, Notts
fields.body:

Michael Wilson
Newark, Notts

 We have just had a lottery application refused; this was for £5,000, to tarmac and light a path to provide suitable wheelchair access to the church for the disabled and the old. Obviously I should move to the south-east and apply for £50m.
Revd Mike Dixon
Alnwick, Northumberland

 Perhaps the £29m for the dome explains why our town will not receive the £1.25m asked for in a lottery bid for a new swimming pool and sports centre.
Cllr Lawrence Ross
Otley, W Yorks

 I gave my collection of junk pens (Letters, May 23) to a friend visiting India. They're hugely popular with the local children - and of course better for them than sweets.
Andrew McCloy
Youlgrave, Derbys
McRamble@compuserve.com

 I write with the junk pens that I receive, but I suppose dnort@thirdagepress.co.uk doesn't have much occasion to do so.
Tony Black
Sevenoaks, Kent

 Of course money grows on trees (Letters, May 19). Ever heard of European Money-tree Union?
Doug Meredith
Manchester

 Has anyone else noticed that the initials of the Blair children's first names can now be arranged to spell Ken L? Further evidence for the mystic powers of London's mayor?
Andrew Platt
Sutton Coldfield, W Mids

webTitle: Dyson follower aims to clean up

fields.headline: Dyson follower aims to clean up
fields.standfirst: City provides some lather for a new-concept washing machine
fields.trailText: That big white machine lurking in your laundry room or kitchen could be in for some changes. A multi-millionaire entrepreneur is doing the rounds of the City with plans to revolutionise the way we do our washing. Martin Myerscough is chairman of Monotub Industries, an Aim-listed company with a radical new washing machine called Titan.
fields.body:
That big white machine lurking in your laundry room or kitchen could be in for some changes. A multi-millionaire entrepreneur is doing the rounds of the City with plans to revolutionise the way we do our washing. Martin Myerscough is chairman of Monotub Industries, an Aim-listed company with a radical new washing machine called Titan.

He wants to follow in the footsteps of James Dyson, the inventor who introduced the successful bagless vacuum cleaner, in injecting a little style and imagination into household appliances. "I'm not arrogant enough to say we've got the answer to everything. But we're different and if you're different, you get noticed," he says.

Since flotation in October, Monotub's market capitalisation has risen from £18.5m to £47m, valuing Mr Myerscough's 37% stake at £19m. Not bad for a venture which began as little more than a sideline - Myerscough's day job is as finance director of KS Biomedix, the soaraway biotech firm.

So what is all the fuss about? The Titan is certainly smarter than the average washing machine - it is slimmer, with a large orange-tinted window on the front. The model has a tilted drum, so it can be opened during a cycle without water spilling out, and it has a removable basket which can be filled with dirty washing, then put inside. The Titan can take 40% more clothes than the average machine but uses 75% less water. It is likely to cost between £500 and £600.

Myerscough says: "Dyson proved that if you've got a product which has benefits over existing technology, if the benefits are what people want, people will overlook the unknown brand and buy it."

He has persuaded Currys to stock the machine exclusively for four months from its launch - a sign that the industry is beginning to take Monotub seriously.

The Titan's take-off leaves Myerscough, 57, with a bizarre dual career. He still works full-time at KS Biomedix, a stockmarket success now worth £240m which specialises in developing drugs from sheep antibodies.

Originally from Lancashire, Myerscough is from a family of vets and doctors. He went to Newcastle University, then became an engineer. In the late 1980s, he worked on the design of oil rigs but became frustrated with heavy industry and joined Arthur Andersen in 1990 to train as an accountant. Within three years, he was a manager but again, he became restless: "I was 36 - I was quite an old manager and I was looking at another five or six years to get a partnership."

Myerscough began searching for a way to "break away" and put feelers out to see if he could find a new line of work. Among the people he met through Andersens was Jeffrey Wright, then chairman of KS Biomedix, which was a small business with a promising treatment for rheumatism.

"Jeffrey told me he was looking for a finance director," recalls Myerscough. "I said I didn't know anything about pharmaceuticals - I was an engineer."

Myerscough eventually agreed to join KS but he warned that he had one or two other irons in the fire, which he was keen to progress with in his spare time. One was his washing machine project, which had begun when a colleague from Andersen's had lunch with the niece of a washing machine repair man. The repair man, it emerged, had been working on prototypes for new machines, without a great deal of success: "He had a few crude ideas - he's quite a practical chap - he'd been making things in his workshop."

Myerscough pooled his engineering experience, together with his commercial know-how, with the repair man. Myerscough says: "The concept of wild flashes of brilliance is completely wrong. You actually have phenomenal setbacks. Some of our earlier models turned out to be fantastically noisy."

They finally came up with a machine which worked and trawled round manufacturers such as Bosch to see if they were interested. Few were enthusiastic so they decided to go it alone, with help from a few private backers. Myerscough says: "Talking to big organisations can be frustrating for a small company. They don't want to take it until it's been launched and it's proven that consumers like it."

Myerscough's new-found wealth is unlikely to impress his colleagues at KS Biomedix - its value rocketed earlier this year, as hi-tech shares surged. Chief executive Kim Tan, who owns 67%, is worth more than £200m.

In addition to his two jobs, Myerscough is building his own 68ft wooden boat, named "Madam" after his wife. Sitting in Monotub's temporary office in Covent Garden, the company is yet to find a permanent base, Myerscough admits he has a hyperactive streak. He says much of his drive comes from the death of a young relative in 1996 from cancer: "It made me sit down and list all the things I wanted to do."

The Titan will be in the shops this autumn but Myerscough already knows he has made a success of his life - he boasts that he has been interviewed by Johnny Vaughan on Channel Four's Big Breakfast, alongside Trevor Bayliss, inventor of the clockwork radio.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: It was another poor day for technology shares. But what's bad for the hi-techs and the dot.coms, has been good for the old economy. Yesterday it was the turn of the banks to post splendid gains.
fields.body:
It was another poor day for technology shares. But what's bad for the hi-techs and the dot.coms, has been good for the old economy. Yesterday it was the turn of the banks to post splendid gains.

While the Techmark, down 53.9, is worth less than half its record high of March 6, the FTSE 100 managed a 31.8 point rise to 6,118.6. though it had dipped below 6,000 during the morning.

Lloyds TSB was a big gainer, up 8% or 52.5p at 716.5p. Barclays rose 84p to £17.35, supported by positive broker comments following yesterday's e-commerce presentation. Abbey National gained 26.5p to 862.5p and Bank of Scotland rose 39.5p to 620p. Prudential rallied 29.5p from the previous day's falls to 973p. This was credited to the group's announcement that the flotation of its online operation Egg is proceeding as planned. The previous day it had said it was reviewing the flotation daily.

Not all tech stocks fared badly. Baltimore rose 9.5p to 374p, Misys gained 19p at 516p and Logica was 59p higher at £15.30. But technology issues dominated the FTSE 250 fallers. Fibernet Group fell a whopping 242.5p to £12.82.5p, Imagination Technologies was down 23p at 214.5p with continued concerns about the future of Sega's Dreamcast, DCS Group dropped 100p to 800p and Kewill Systems lost 65p to 795p.

Redstone Telecom re ported a reasonable set of full-year results, but admitted that the market sentiment against technology may hit its expansion plans. It closed 15.5p down at 227.5p.

The high-profile world of the net stock was again on the receiving end of negative market sentiment: Eidos fell 38p to 260p, Durlacher was down 6.5p at 56.5p, 365 Corp down 7p at 82.5p and Scoot.com 7p lower at 82.5p.

QXL.com also continued its decline, down a further 8p at 109p, as the chances of a predatory takeover bid from US rival E-Bay receded.

In the slightly older world of television, Carlton Communications added 16.5p to 760.5p despite admitting the burden placed on its profitability by its digital roll-out.

Carlton's prospective partner, United News & Media , gained support on increasing hopes that their planned merger could succeed, rising 17p to 802p. BSkyB had a good day, rising 80p to £11.20.

Elsewhere, Cadbury Schweppes rose 9.25p to 449p after revealing it is in talks with Philip Morris unit Kraft Foods to buy its chewing gum and sweet business.

British Airways fell 10.5p to 356p as the market worried about the prospect of increased competition following reports that United Airlines could acquire US Airways.

fields.headline: Chancellor stands by his man
fields.standfirst: Committee snubs Brown's choice | Off the mark
fields.trailText: Committee snubs Brown's choice | Off the mark
fields.body:
Oxford economist Chris Allsopp must be considering his position carefully today after the treasury select committee rejected his candidacy for the vacant position on the Bank of England's key rate-setting body. Although the chancellor is standing by his man and the committee has no constitutional right of veto, Mr Allsopp may feel his credibility has been so dented that he should retire gracefully.

But before he rushes to fall on his sword, he should remember we have been here before. St DeAnne Julius of Threadneedle Street was savaged by the committee at her confirmation hearing for her links to the CIA - a brief spell spent working for them as an analyst after graduation. She survived to be canonised by the manufacturing sector for her robustly dovish views.

More justifiably, the committee took exception to hedge fund guru Sushil Wadhwani's answers to their questionnaire when it became apparent he had simply cribbed them from answers given by other monetary policy committee members. He received a sharp rap over the knuckles from the backbenchers and had to apologise for trampling on parliamentary dignity. Mr Wadhwani went on to make an influential contribution on the MPC by pointing out that they had been forecasting a fall in the pound for the past three years without it happening, and it might be better to base their interest rates decisions less on what theory suggested would happen to the pound and more on the undoubted irrationality of the market.

Ms Julius and Mr Wadhwani have both proved to be assets to the MPC, and there is no reason to suppose that Mr Allsopp will not be as well. Granted, he does not produce the kind of theoretical papers which earn the respect of other academics and baffle the rest of us. But the treasury select committee is fond of complaining that the MPC is too academic and divorced from the real world. The real world is Mr Allsopp's metier - he has a track record as a pragmatic economist who has advised governments around the world. He also edits the Oxford Review of Economic Policy, which readers will find to be a practical rather than theoretical journal.

There is a serious point behind the committee's complaints. Mr Allsopp did not give an impressive account of himself at their hearing on Monday. Part of the MPC's job is to be able to explain to the public why they have made their decisions. If he stays, he needs to redeem himself with some better performances.

That said, showmanship is only part of the job - and a small part at that. Mr Allsopp should hold his nerve, and Gordon Brown should stand his ground.

Off the mark

One byproduct of the recent dot.com shake-out has been to illustrate to the general investing public that the fortunes of the markets are no longer spelt out by that supposed barometer of British corporate health, the FTSE 100 index.

The constituents committee has worked hard to modernise the top 100 list, bringing in a slew of new economy favourites at the last constituents' meeting in March. And, yes, there will be plenty of chuckling early next month when the committee meets again and slings the likes of Thus - down by two-thirds in three months - and Baltimore Technology - off almost 70% since winning Footsie status - back out of the blue chip index.

But there are much more intractable problems with the make-up of the Footsie - problems which carry and actually reinforce investment risk. Anyone looking for evidence as to how and why too much of the nation's pension and insurance money is injected into the country's biggest companies need look no further than Vodafone AirTouch. To be frank, by little ol' British standards, this mobile telephone group, commanding a market capitalisation of £158bn, is just too big for the parochial Footsie - and that is after the recent slump in the new economy stocks.

To put this heavyweight share issue in context it is first worth noting that for every penny movement in Vodafone's share price, up or down, the Footsie moves by three points. So when the Nine O'Clock News announces a "good" day on the stock market, it means our premier mobile phone company has gone up, or vice versa. Yesterday, almost half the 31.8-point gain on the top 100 could be attributed to one company.

To bang on further: from a March 6 high of 399p to the recent low of 240p set last week, Vodafone had fallen just a fraction under 40% - or the equivalent of 477 Footsie points.

Coincidentally or otherwise, the top 100 fell 530 points during this period - suggesting along the way that the other 99 top British companies have been riding out the past two months of crisis in the markets rather well.

webTitle: Union membership shows first rise in 20 years

fields.headline: Union membership shows first rise in 20 years
fields.standfirst: Monks says recruitment is going well in non-traditional employment areas
fields.trailText: Official confirmation that the generation-long decline in the number of trade unionists in Britain is over was given yesterday as the unions gear up to take advantage of the new legal right to recognition, which comes into effect next month.
fields.body:
Official confirmation that the generation-long decline in the number of trade unionists in Britain is over was given yesterday as the unions gear up to take advantage of the new legal right to recognition, which comes into effect next month.

Membership of all unions, including those which are not affiliated to the Trades Union Congress, rose for the first time since 1979, according to the certification officer for trade unions' annual report, bearing out other evidence that the two-decade-long union cull is over.

The latest figures from the government's union watchdog showed a 50,581 increase last year, to more than 7.8m, reflecting a more favourable political and industrial climate for trade unionism as well as the overall rise in employment.

That is still a long way from the 13.2m peak reached in Margaret Thatcher's first year as prime minister, and the increase is a modest 0.6%, but it was welcomed as good news by the TUC's general secretary, John Monks.

He said: "Unions are now recruiting outside their traditional areas, and our campaigns on behalf of all employees - such as our efforts to get the government to extend parental leave - show that we have as much to offer to employees in new industries as where we have been traditionally strong."

The upturn reported by the certification officer reflects increases in the number of trade unionists recorded last year in the government's labour force survey and in the TUC's own membership figures.

That trend is likely to be given a significant boost in two weeks when the key provisions of the Employment Relations Act come into effect, giving unions the right to get access to non-union companies and negotiate with employers where more than 50% of a workforce are members of the union.

Nevertheless, unions still face a formidable challenge rebuilding their strength in the emerging industries and some employers are preparing to adopt American-style union-busting techniques to see off new recognition claims.

Last week the law firm Eversheds began a series of trade union regional "roadshows" with employers, addressed by US lawyer Alan Lips, warning of the likely impact of the legislation and how to use American experience to "disincent" workers from "considering the need for union representation".

fields.headline: Somerfield
fields.trailText: Times keep going from bad to worse for Somerfield. A couple of years ago the management was contemplating how to break into the Gang of Four.
fields.body:
Times keep going from bad to worse for Somerfield. A couple of years ago the management was contemplating how to break into the Gang of Four.

But the plan to challenge Tesco, Asda, Sainsbury and Safeway backfired more spectacularly than anyone might have believed possible.

Yesterday the supermarket chain admitted it performed badly, again, in the fourth quarter of the financial year. Like-for-like sales were down 9.8%. The trend was bad enough in own-fascia stores, down 5.1%, but worse in Kwik Save shops bought as part of expansion plans. Here store sales deteriorated by 16%.

"It is important to understand that there is a huge amount to be done over the next two years," recently appointed executive chairman John von Spreckelsen said in the trading statement. He's not kidding.

The new managers, headed by erstwhile Punch Taverns boss Alan Smith, intend to keep all 756 Kwik Save stores and operate under two fascias.

Pre-tax profits fell 44% to £63.9m in the 28 weeks to November 6 and the dividend was cut to 1.5p from 4.5p.

The group's troubles have attracted bid interest, but this has led nowhere. Somerfield expects to make a "sizeable writedown" on the Kwik Save assets and the loss will only be partly offset by £130m profit from disposals already completed. The group is now valued at just £267m, or a third of the book value of its assets.

The wretched supermarket group delivered a further blow to its shareholders yesterday, warning that full year profits would be at the bottom end of analysts' expectations. Analysts had estimated the pre-tax profit figure to come in at between £73m and £103m compared with a pre-exceptional profit of £218.4m a year earlier.

But disappointment is nothing new to Somerfield's investors, having seen their shares shrink to around a tenth of their value over the past year and half. Yesterday the shares fell 2p to 51.75p. The stock once traded around the dizzy heights of 450p.

webTitle: Accountants start fourth inquiry into TransTec

fields.headline: Accountants start fourth inquiry into TransTec
fields.trailText: A fourth official inquiry was launched yesterday into TransTec, the collapsed engineering group founded by the former paymaster-general, Geoffrey Robinson. This latest investigation is being held by the disciplinary branch of the accountancy profession.
fields.body:
A fourth official inquiry was launched yesterday into TransTec, the collapsed engineering group founded by the former paymaster-general, Geoffrey Robinson. This latest investigation is being held by the disciplinary branch of the accountancy profession.

Inquiries will focus on TransTec's former auditors, the accounting firm PriceWaterhouse Coopers (PwC), and TransTec's former chief executive, Richard Carr, and former finance director, Bill Jeffrey, both chartered accountants.

Heading the inquiry is former serious fraud office senior assistant director Christopher Dickson, who is in charge of the accountancy profession's joint disciplinary scheme.

DTI inspectors are already investigating the £200m collapse just before Christmas of TransTec, with special reference to the concealment of a £12m claim against the company from car group Ford and to the reasons for the company's slide into insolvency.

Meanwhile the west midlands fraud squad is investigating claims that, between 1986 and 1988, claims for subsidies for technical innovation were falsified to inflate the amount TransTec was spending to develop a new electric spark drill. Former accountant May Ayris said that nearly £500,000 of the £1.3m in DTI grants TransTec received was fraudulently obtained.

In Northern Ireland, the industrial development board has been reviewing files relating to grants totalling £6.9m for TransTec's plant at Campsie in the west of the province.

Mr Dickson said yesterday the JDS had authority only over individual accountants and accountancy firms. He said the JDS had hired Mazars Neville Russell to supply "forensic" auditors.

Bankers pulled the plug on TransTec after it emerged the firm had concealed from investors both the £12m Ford claim and the fact that £8m of this claim had been secretly paid to the car company.

Mr Robinson, Labour MP for Coventry north-west, resigned from the company in May 1997 when he entered office as a government minister and the concealment of the claim took place after that date.

PwC said last night: "[No-one] has complained to the Institute [of Chartered Accountants] about PwC or our members". It pledged co-operation with the inquiry.

fields.headline: Carlton chief criticises Granada tactics
fields.standfirst: Green scoffs at demerger plan
fields.trailText: Carlton Communications chairman Michael Green yesterday launched a broadside against rival ITV company Granada over its ambition to break up his planned merger with United News & Media.
fields.body:
Carlton Communications chairman Michael Green yesterday launched a broadside against rival ITV company Granada over its ambition to break up his planned merger with United News & Media.

Mr Green scoffed at Granada's statement in January that it was minded to bid for either Carlton and United and said it was simply a reaction to being "caught on the hoof".

All three possible combinations are now being scrutinised by the Competition Commission which is due to give a response in July.

Mr Green described the planned demerger of Granada Media to create a bid vehicle as a piece of "financial engineering" which shareholders had seen through.

"I would need to know what their bid is and what they would plan to do to make a sensible reposte. I like to see the rabbit before I shoot it," Mr Green said of the putative bid from Granada.

The proposed merger between Carlton and United is the only combination of ITV companies that would work under present legislation, he said.

"We have dotted the Is and crossed the Ts and said what we would dispose of - we've done our homework. With Granada, one minute it seems they are buying British Airways, another its Whitbread and they won't say whether they want Carlton or United. I would be surprised if they know what they are doing.

Hs said: "Gerry Robinson, [Granada's chairman] who is described as the architect of all this is on his way out. Could you really see Steve Morrison [chief executive designate of Granada Media] running a combined Granada/Carlton?"

Carlton was announcing half year pretax profits of £171m, up marginally from £164.9m the previous year and before the £98m cost of its stake in pay TV platform OnDigital.

Mr Green said that OnDigital remained on course for flotation "within the next 12 months".

The business, which has 673,000 subscribers, would be ready when it reached 1m, he said. Carlton shares were marked 16.5p higher at 760.5p.

At the same time, Carlton announced a clutch of new media investments including a deal with Sainsbury which will see the supermarket group take a half share in the company's pay television channel Carlton Food Network. The channel will be rebranded SimplyFood and users will be able to order groceries online.

Other investments included a pan-European alliance with Germany's Kirch, Italy's Mediaset, Spain's Telecino and France's TFI to invest in internet and interactive projects. Each partner will put up around €50m (£31m) although the announcement was later muddied when Mediaset put out a statement saying it was "premature" to say a deal had been struck.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Figures counter economic view
fields.body:
Figures counter economic view

Government figures yesterday contradicted the common view of the economy by showing exports growing despite the strong pound and domestic demand slowing sharply.

According to the office for national statistics the trade deficit with the rest of the European Union shrank to £110m in March, contributing to a better than expected global deficit of £1.9bn. The non-EU balance for April, also released yesterday, widened to £2.3bn.

Ciaran Barr, chief UK economist at Deutsche Bank, said that, the figures were likely to ease Bank of England worries about excessive domestic demand but were not to signal a significant slowing in growth.

OFT reviews BT ad rate caps

The office of fair trading said yesterday it was reviewing a cap on the rates BT can charge for Yellow Pages advertisments in light of competition from internet-based directories.

Lloyd's of London insurance market is to admit foreign brokers for the first time. The move alters a system which has been in place since the 1980s which required Lloyd's brokers to be based in London and directly regulated by Lloyd's.

webTitle: Job fears as Ford seals deal for Land Rover

fields.headline: Job fears as Ford seals deal for Land Rover
fields.standfirst:
Nasser wants profit in two years

Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Ford plans to return Land Rover to profitability by 2002, Jac Nasser, the US car group's global president, said yesterday.
fields.body:
Ford plans to return Land Rover to profitability by 2002, Jac Nasser, the US car group's global president, said yesterday. He called the company "truly one of the world's great brands" after signing a €3bn (£1.8bn) deal to buy it from BMW and take on its 13,000 British employees.

But union officials, reeling from the shake-up of the British car industry in the past few weeks, demanded urgent talks over job security, investment and new models at Land Rover and the Gaydon design centre Ford takes on under the deal.

Their concern was heightened by news that Daewoo, the troubled Korean car maker likely to be taken over by Ford or arch-rival General Motors, could sack hundreds of the 750 staff at its Worthing research and development centre.

Ford's premier automotive group, including Jaguar and Aston Martin in Britain, will take over Land Rover on June 30 after two months of tough negotiations which finally led BMW to take on all the sports utility manufacturer's debts - estimated to be DM1bn.

Ford said it would pay €2bn upfront and €1bn in 2005 for Land Rover, long regarded as the jewel in the crown of the Rover group BMW bought in 1994 but which made "modest" losses in 1998 and 1999.

Duncan Simpson, a senior AEEU official, welcoming the deal, said: "We will be seeking urgent talks with Ford about Land Rover's Solihull plant. We need to know what the deal means for job security, in vestment and new models. But there are no indications of any redundancies and I'm confident we can have constructive, amicable relations with Ford -certainly different to the acrimonious ones with BMW."

The US group is taking on the Discovery, Freelander and Defender models while BMW will complete development for it of a new Range Rover. Mr Simpson said the greatest concerns rested on Solihull's powertrain business which produces engines, axles, transmission systems and gear boxes, given that Ford is to boost output of these at Bridgend and Dagenham where it is to cease car production from early 2002.

But Gaydon - now shared by Ford, BMW and the Phoenix consortium which has taken on the bulk of Rover's car output - faces an uncertain future. An array of British component suppliers are also likely to be squeezed out as Ford imports parts from other, cheaper countries.

Joachim Milberg, BMW chairman, said the deal was, after the sale of Rover, "the second decisive step for carrying out the strategic development of the BMW group".

It is meant to put to rest continued speculation that the Bavarian car maker is itself at risk of take-over - from Ford, GM or, more likely, Volkswagen.

Phoenix, given a £500m sweetener by BMW to take over Rover's Longbridge operations, said Kevin Howe, a former managing director at the Birmingham plant, would be the car company's new chief executive.

Mr Howe, who left for Rolls-Royce last year, said: "There's a lot of hard work ahead of us but I would not be returning unless I was convinced that we can become a very successful business."

webTitle: Connex rival fights 'dirty' in battle for commuter franchise

fields.headline: Connex rival fights 'dirty' in battle for commuter franchise
fields.standfirst:
Trains would be kept clean and staff sent to a charm school.

Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Connex, the private rail operator, was last night accused of running "a disgraceful operation" with dirty toilets and an uncaring attitude to commuters, by a rival company determined to win one of its train franchises.
fields.body:
Connex, the private rail operator, was last night accused of running "a disgraceful operation" with dirty toilets and an uncaring attitude to commuters, by a rival company determined to win one of its train franchises.

The calculated remarks were made by Keith Ludeman, the managing director of Govia, which owns Thameslink, another London commuter service.

He said that one in six Connex trains failed to run "and that is as bad as you can get".

Mr Ludeman, who is in the final bidding for a new 20-year franchise for Connex South Central, the most congested and most criticised part of the London commuter network, said:

"For a variety of reasons, the South Central franchise has been run down to such a degree that nothing short of a radical plan will bring it round quickly."

Mr Ludeman backed commuters who have regularly complained about short and dirty trains to Connex management. He said that "they have suffered for a long time with staff shortages and a poor response to their inquiries".

He promised a £1.5bn investment programme over the lifetime of the franchise and competition with Connex - on the South Eastern franchise - with a price war.

Mr Ludeman said he was proposing a two-year experiment to reduce off-peak fares by up to 50%. If the experiment was successful and it attracted people out of their cars, the cut-price fares could become permanent.

Peak fare increases would be pegged to inflation minus 1% as at present, until the company completed the introduction of new trains and fares. That might take seven years.

Mr Ludeman's remarks on the eve of the delayed national rail summit, which will be chaired today by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, show that the industry faces severe problems over its commitment to a public service and a lack of understanding of its role.

Mr Ludeman said passengers would be invited to join "a stakeholder board" which would give them a real voice in the running of the railway. The South Central franchise would be renamed Southern Railway.

French-owned Connex has put in its £1bn bid to the Strategic Rail Authority - the quango making the final decision. Its plans include increased capacity for the network with 100mph trains between London and the Sussex coast.

fields.headline: Government remains 'too secretive'
fields.standfirst: Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: Government officials remain too secretive when releasing information to the public, the parliamentary watchdog said yesterday as the Scottish executive and the Welsh assembly challenged Jack Straw's plans for a restricted freedom of information bill.
fields.body:
Government officials remain too secretive when releasing information to the public, the parliamentary watchdog said yesterday as the Scottish executive and the Welsh assembly challenged Jack Straw's plans for a restricted freedom of information bill.

Scottish and Welsh politicians said they planned to press ahead with a much broader definition of what information could be released than that allowed in England.

Michael Buckley, the parliamentary ombudsman, demanded that the home secretary take a more liberal view of the release of information on crime prevention and national security, areas where the release of documents faces a blanket ban under the freedom of information bill, now going through the Lords.

In three judgments Mr Buckley rebuked the Home Office and the Ministry of Defence for failing to release relatively harmless information - on the grounds that it could reveal operational data on fighting crime or be a threat to national security.

The ombudsman's finding against the Home Office is the third within a year.

Mr Buckley said: "The number of complaints coming to me about the refusal to release information remains low. If any lessons are to be drawn from so few investigations, it is, perhaps, that some information in sensitive areas such as crime prevention and national security can be released safely if departments take a realistic view of potential harm in relation to the public interest in disclosure."

Mr Buckley's report found the Home Office had wrongly with held sections of The Internet Detective, a guide to online crime for criminal investigators.

Sections that had already been released to the press were censored, he said, although it was right to withhold those parts that had not already been published.

The MoD was the subject of two complaints. In one, it was right to withhold information about nuclear capabilities, security and intelligence matters, but should have issued less sensitive material.

In the other, officials who had refused to release information on UFOs relented after the ombudsman intervened and the man making the request agreed to pay for the cost of collating it.

In Wales Rhodri Morgan, the first minister, published a consultation document on the freedom of information code, announcing that in Wales government departments would have to prove "substantial prejudice" if they wanted to withold information from the public. This will immediately make it more difficult for Welsh departments to withold information than their English counterparts, who merely have to demonstrate "harm or prejudice" to stop information being published.

The Scottish executive yesterday received widespread backing for a similar decision.

Maurice Frankel, the director of the Campaign for Freedom of Information, said the announcements in Wales and Scotland "promise a remarkably powerful right of access".

He said Mr Buckley's criticisms "are significant as crime prevention is covered by class exemption in the bill. The ombudsman is saying this information can realistically be released but the bill does not say that, it simply exempts it."

fields.headline: Shot by both sides
fields.standfirst:
We've all heard about the murdered children and the mob violence. But what if the UN is largely to blame? Fiachra Gibbons reports on a shocking documentary about Sierra Leone

Sierra Leone: special report

Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Never again will I be able to watch Michael Buerk on the Nine O'Clock News give the customary warning "Scenes you are about to see may disturb some viewers" without a pang of anger.
fields.body:
Never again will I be able to watch Michael Buerk on the Nine O'Clock News give the customary warning "Scenes you are about to see may disturb some viewers" without a pang of anger.

After watching New World Order (Somewhere in Africa) at Cannes, a gut-wrenching documentary about Sierra Leone in which the hypocrisy of Britain and the United Nations turns the stomach as much as the barbarity on the streets, you cannot but think that our dinners are not disturbed half often enough.

French director Philippe Diaz insists that when he went to Sierra Leone with the charity Action Against Hunger it was to make a "little humanitarian film" about how famine and politics are often entwined. "I had no intention of making a film about changing the world. It just happened," he says. "We found a terrible situation made worse by the UN. It was being presented as a war between democracy and barbarian, diamond-hungry rebels who were chopping civilians' hands off; this was not what we found. What we did find shocked us so much it was hard to believe."

Watching the film unfold is not an easy experience. The opening credits roll over a casual murder on the streets of the capital Freetown by a government militiaman patrolling with the UN-backed Nigerian Ecomog troops. What passes for the UN in this part of the world, we soon discover, doesn't just allow cold-blooded murder, but actively takes part.

The civilian is wearing shorts and white vest and you can feel his panic. The militiaman looks like a cross between a voodoo witch doctor and Davy Crockett. You just catch the cutlass in his belt, and the barely raised rifle. It is all over in a second.

The bizarre get-up is the uniform of the Kamajors, a strange pro-government army of religious fanatics who go through an initiation ceremony that is supposed to make them invulnerable to bullets.

Later in the film we see the coup de grace delivered by someone well out of shot. A Nigerian gun doing its humanitarian duty as part of the UN mandate probably put the poor guy out of his misery. Brains do not pour out on to the ground like this in Hollywood. It is messier and more unsettling than you can possibly imagine, as if someone had spilled a blancmange. This is not a film, however, that relies on gore to shock. It is those nice familiar UN men and women, the dashing, recently recalled British high commissioner Peter Penfold in his colonial white suit, and the mealy-mouthed rebel propagandists that are really scary.

Diaz's film tells how in nine years Sierra Leone descended into a bloody pit of anarchy and despair, not through the usual flashy jump-cuts of action footage, but through eerily still talking-head interviews. Decisions taken in London and New York that mean horror and starvation on the ground in Sierra Leone are elided with practised ease: President Kabbah talks about combating hunger with a $150m bridge to the airport; rebels behind massacres and mutilations talk haughtily about illegality and injustice. It is soon clear that nothing big ever happens without Britain and the UN's say-so.

Only when he has painstakingly shown how Britain in particular, and the international community in general, scuppered a peace agreement four years ago because it did not conform to the small print of that year's big global push for democratisation does Diaz confront us with the results of that high-handedness in the most brutal fashion.

A man shot by the Ecomog/UN troops slowly splutters his last alone on a pavement, a corpse burned beyond recognition twitches with life, amputation victims come bearing their hacked limbs, a man is battered to death by a mob, his head impaled on a stick, and then later his penis. Dead children lie rotting in the ruins of their homes, killed by cluster bombs allegedly paid for by Britain and dropped from Ecomog jets. In Africa, it seems the niceties of peacekeeping need not be observed.

These scenes, shot by Sorious Samura, a cameraman who worked for the Sierra Leone government until he could no longer square himself with their actions, represent a tiny fragment of the 70,000 people who have died since the UN killed off the last hope that Sierra Leonians might make peace between themselves. Sorious has since fled to London.

"My assistant Michele got sick when he first played the tape," says Diaz. "I thought, I can't let people see this. But then I thought, they must."

When I saw New World Order in a small municipal theatre in a village high in the hills above Cannes, its impact was stunning. No one in the audience moved for a few minutes. Then everyone wanted to speak. The debate lasted longer than the 120 minutes of the film. No one, as Diaz feared, felt the scenes of graphic suffering excessive and, lest his compatriots feel smug, Diaz pointed out, "It is France that is the real neocolonial villain in Africa."

Diaz has become used to this first incredulous and then impassioned reaction. "We always want to think the best, that if the UN is involved it will be OK and we can forget everything. Sometimes though, as in Sierra Leone, that is when the problems really begin."

One woman, however, refused to let him go without an explanation. "How can this be? The UN - how could they? Why have the journalists not told us of this?" Indeed.

webTitle: Parties battle over rival pension pledges

fields.headline: Parties battle over rival pension pledges
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague's eye-catching plans to raise basic pensions by £5 to £10 a week last night imploded under heavy government fire as ministers insisted that the proposed Tory upheaval could give pensioners as little as 42p extra a week.
fields.body:
William Hague's eye-catching plans to raise basic pensions by £5 to £10 a week last night imploded under heavy government fire as ministers insisted that the proposed Tory upheaval could give pensioners as little as 42p extra a week.

Throughout a day of intense briefing and counter -briefing, reminiscent of a general election campaign, both sides scored points at the expense of their rivals' blueprints for courting the nation's 11 million "grey votes" before polling day.

The furore produced one Tory gain. The former social security minister, Labour maverick Frank Field, confirmed that few "Labour members want to go into the election without a very important rethink of what our pensions strategy is".

Ministers deny their 75p rise in basic pensions (plus targetted rise for the poorest) are wrong. But they grabbed the Hague-inspired chance to publicise Gordon Brown's complicated pension package.

Hague aides explained that, contrary to overnight assurances, their figures - £5.50 for a single pensioner at 65, £10 to a couple over 75 - include the inflationproofing element of £2-£3 a week which the law would give them automatically.

In addition to a huge shift of resources from such major ticket items as the £1bn a year winter fuel allowance and free TV licences - worth £360m - which Mr Hague would move across to the basic pension, it emerged that just £320m of extra funds will be added to the pension budget, the Tory social security spokesman, David Willetts, confirmed.

Most of that will come from other social payments, £90 m from the social fund - which provides emergency loans - a similar sum from scrapping the "failed" New Deal for lone parents, £40m from alleged administrative savings, and £100m from winter fuel payments made to men aged 60-64 under a controversial ruling by the European Court.

webTitle: Activists demand better race balance in Commons

fields.headline: Activists demand better race balance in Commons
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Black and Asian activists within the Labour party yesterday joined forces with aspiring women politicians to press their shared demand for a Westminster parliament that accurately reflects the ethnic and gender balance in British society.
fields.body:
Black and Asian activists within the Labour party yesterday joined forces with aspiring women politicians to press their shared demand for a Westminster parliament that accurately reflects the ethnic and gender balance in British society.

On the eve of tonight's selection of a Labour candidate to succeed Bernie Grant in the Tottenham byelection, the new grouping known as EQ - for equality - attracted prominent elected politicians to its launch at Westminster, despite the hostility to the venture of senior Labour officials at Millbank.

Paul Boateng, who as Jack Straw's deputy at the Home Office is Britain's highest ranking black politician, turned up to showsupport.

He told the seven other black and Asian MPs that it was their collective duty to help "the next generation" in ways which had been denied to them when they were first elected in 1987.

Diane Abbott, MP for Hackney North, warned that previous campaigns had made "tremendous progress" but mainly for the benefit of white women - the bulk of the 122 women MPs, 101 of them Labour, elected in 1997.

Of the 659 MPs there are eight from ethnic minorities, including two women, Ms Abbott and Oona King.

But it is widely assumed that the numbers will fall back again if Labour loses marginal seats at the next election.

Neither Tories nor Lib Dems have made the same efforts that Labour has to ensure better gender and ethnic balance, in the face of stiff opposition within its own ranks and a legal action which resulted in all-women lists being ruled illegal.

At yesterday's meeting, close to the Commons, there were heated calls for quotas, for more working class candidates, and for older candidates - "This party is saying 'young, young, young'," complained an Asian barrister - as well as warnings that, unless black youths could be drawn into the political process, they would drift into apathy or into Muslim fundamentalism.

"Party bosses should remember that the number one reason black people don't get involved in politics is because there are so few black MPs," said Simon Woolley, the co-ordinator of Operation Black Vote.

Trevor Phillips, chairman of the new Greater London assembly, said that he was against targeting seats or quotas, but he was in favour of ensuring that black and Asian people could compete fairly, so that the best candidate would win.

fields.headline: Minister of sound
fields.standfirst:
He can hear expressions on people's faces. He digests tapes at Pinky and Perky speed. And he has an extraordinary memory for figures. In a rare interview about his blindness, David Blunkett talks to John Carvel

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: He can hear expressions on people's faces. He digests tapes at Pinky and Perky speed. And he has an extraordinary memory for figures. In a rare interview about his blindness, David Blunkett talks to  John Carvel
fields.body:
David Blunkett seldom discusses his blindness. Politics is not a handicap race and he is anxious to avoid being patronised by commentators or colleagues thinking they can judge him against standards below those they set for sighted cabinet ministers. So there has been little on record until now to answer the obvious questions about how he manages to stay on top of his job when other ministers over the years struggled to keep up with the flow of reading matter in their departmental red boxes.

Yet, to most voters, blindness is Blunkett's most noticeable characteristic, helping to make him one of the most recognised politicians on the front bench. He uses his dog, Lucy, as the foil for many a political joke, interpreting her sleepiness, agitation or chewing of the lead as a response to the inadequacies of opponents' speeches.

Blunkett's reticence about his blindness has left untold an important story about the mechanics involved in running his department. However, he gives for this interview a frank assessment of the consequences of holding high office without being able to see. "Probably my failing is that I feel I need to be on top of things too much," he said. "I've never wanted anybody to say I don't know the facts, or I'm not on top of the portfolio because I can't see. That involves me spending a lot more time on work than I ought to at weekends. It probably makes me a bit antisocial." The problem is practical. Blunkett uses Braille for taking notes, sometimes typing them out on his own portable machine. That and Lucy's dog box are among the few personal features in his office on the seventh floor of Sanctuary Buildings, his departmental headquarters in Westminster. If he is making an important policy speech or answering questions where he wants to use particular words or figures, his officials will provide a Braille text. A Braille version of Labour's 1997 manifesto has pride of place on his desk.

However, Braille is an unwieldy medium. More than two large cardboard sheets are needed to hold the information that could have been printed on a single side of thin A4 paper. Blunkett would find it hard to carry the number of documents he needs to digest on journeys between London and his Sheffield constituency - let alone find things - if they were all in Braille.

The medium is also impractical for speed-reading and does not allow for emphasis by underlining or use of different typefaces. Blunkett has to tear the side of the cardboard sheet as a marker to a passage he may want to refer to during a speech.

As a result he chooses to receive most of his information through the earpiece of a tape recorder. Three sets of staff - in the department, his parliamentary office and constituency - have been trained to condense material so that he hears only what he needs to know. He tells them repeatedly that he can always ask for more, but gets no benefit from being given too much.

Blunkett listens to these tapes at twice the normal speed. He says the sound he hears when he takes in Cabinet agenda papers, departmental initiatives or constituency casework resembles the soundtrack from an episode of Pinky and Perky, the children's television classic. The minister switches to normal speed only when there are figures he wants to memorise or points he wishes to consider at a slower pace.

But even tapes played at double the normal speed are a slow way to assimilate information. He estimates that a reasonably fast reader could take in the same number of words in about a third of the time. The prime minister, who has the speed-reading techniques of the barrister he used to be, is a lot quicker than that.

The consequence for Blunkett is an extended working week. He says he is blessed by an ability to take in material as well on a train or car journey as in his office. If, like some of his colleagues, he got travel sickness trying to work on the move, he thinks he would struggle to cope.

Such are the downsides of blindness. The upsides lie in the heightened development of other faculties. Ministerial colleagues envy his excellent memory for facts and figures, particularly during public spending negotiations. Relying less on notes, he is better able to marshal arguments when he is required to think on his feet. Blunkett says the technique is job specific. "It's not that my memory is better than anyone else's. If you asked me to learn a Shakespeare sonnet before cabinet in 30 minutes' time, I wouldn't be able to recite it any better than you. But if you give me a set of figures for presenting at cabinet, I have learned to do that."

Sir Michael Bichard, his permanent secretary, says that plenty of other ministers and senior officials have good memories. But, however well briefed they are, they take notes into meetings as a "comfort blanket". And that may diminish their ability to order arguments. "Maybe some of us would benefit if the papers were taken away from us," he says.

Another heightened faculty is Blunkett's sensitivity to the mood of a meeting. Sir Michael says that the minister picks up vibes from changes in the tone of voices which can remain hidden behind facial expressions. Blunkett says he can get it wrong. "But sometimes I can detect what I call a shuffling silence and can tell people aren't happy."

At the end of a meeting, Sir Michael might tell Blunkett about a facial expression that would have added to his understanding of a speaker's point of view. "But almost invariably he will have picked up the point already."

The good relationship between the two men is clearly pivotal to the department for education and employment's effectiveness and the high regard the prime minister has for its performance. Sir Michael dates it back to their first encounter, lasting one and a half hours when Blunkett made him laugh more than at any other first meeting in his life.

They both still dine out on the story of Blunkett's first ministerial presentation to Tony Blair after the election, when the department rushed over notes produced using its newly acquired Swedish Braille software. None of the officials could read what they were sending and it was not until after the meeting had started that Blunkett discovered the computer had translated it into Swedish.

Another feature of Blunkett's style of political management is a willingness to delegate to junior ministers and not steal all the limelight when their policies come to fruition. There is more of a sense of teamwork at the DfEE than some other departments and in three years there has been no known example of the juniors rubbishing their boss.

Delegation may help to reduce Blunkett's reading overload, but Sir Michael is convinced that it has nothing to do with his blindness. "His grasp of detail is such that he doesn't have to do it," he says. Similarly, the minister's preference for taking lots of decisions at relatively short meetings with a small number of relevant officials has more to do with management style than personal circumstances. "If he and I sit down for half an hour, we go through a lot of business. That develops a better relationship than exchanging elegantly crafted minutes."

There may be lessons in all this for other departments that could benefit from more delegation, fewer meetings and cutting down paperwork by more careful summarising. "He talks about his blindness as an inconvenience rather than a disability," says Sir Michael. "That is what it is. I don't think you could have a secretary of state who is more demanding and more on top of his job. After a while, you don't regard his blindness as a problem, certainly not a disability. We all work hard but he works smart and we have all learned by watching him . . . I think he could do any job in government."

Blunkett tells jokes about his blindness. He says the great benefit is being able to read in bed without the light on. A favourite story to break the ice at a conference is the one about a visit to a primary school when he sat down to let the children stroke his dog. "I reached out to touch the one sitting next to me and said: 'How old are you, my dear?' She said, 'I'm 28 and I'm their teacher'."

Blunkett is thriving on power, but behind the good humour such a workload must be taking its toll. After a long week in London, he heads off to Sheffield with his specially adapted red boxes - enlarged to provide a compartment for Braille notes on one side and tapes on the other. One Saturday, a box was delivered at 8am, with 23 tapes to be dealt with before the start of the following working week. He says he manages. As his career has progressed, the support has improved although there was a dreadful year after he moved from the leadership of Sheffield council to become a Labour MP in 1987 when he struggled without the necessary back-up.

He says the financial cost to the DfEE is limited to some computer software, a Braille embosser and a couple of staff in his private office to read material on to tape. The cost to him personally may be greater. He says he tries to keep some degree of balance in his life and make time for his sons. "But I know I'm spending time on work rather than doing things that would refresh me as a man."

webTitle: Concession on RUC to woo Unionists

fields.headline: Concession on RUC to woo Unionists
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The government is believed to be poised to make one final move to woo Ulster Unionist doubters ahead of Saturday's critical meeting of the party's ruling council, by spelling out how the renamed police service in Northern Ireland will be linked to the RUC's title.
fields.body:
The government is believed to be poised to make one final move to woo Ulster Unionist doubters ahead of Saturday's critical meeting of the party's ruling council, by spelling out how the renamed police service in Northern Ireland will be linked to the RUC's title.

The focus on the Royal Ulster Constabulary may be seen as enough to bring John Taylor, the Unionists' deputy leader, back onside, which would be a vital development in the push to restore devolution next week.

Mr Taylor, at present in the far east on parliamentary business, is opposed to a return to government with Sinn Fein despite the IRA's unprecedented offer on arms.

But the development would outrage nationalists and republicans - they list 44 differences between Chris Patten's recommendations for RUC reform and the policing bill published last week. Sinn Fein sources warned this week that the IRA initiative could be withdrawn if there were further concessions designed to reassure Ulster Unionists.

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, indicated last week that he would back incorporation of the RUC's name in the "title deeds" of the new service. And he may accept an Ulster Unionist amendment before the debate on the bill.

Mr Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, was upbeat despite the news that at least four of his assembly team would vote against an early return to government with Sinn Fein. Those intending to vote against a return to devolution now include assembly members Derek Hussey, Roy Beggs junior, Peter Weir and Pauline Armitage.

Mr Trimble also ridiculed the plans of Jeffrey Donaldson, the Ulster Unionist MP for Lagan Valley and a critic of the Good Friday agreement, to forward his own proposals at the Saturday meeting.Yesterday, Mr Donaldson refused to divulge his proposals, but said they were designed to unify the party. He believes the IRA offer fails to address the decommissioning issue.

But Mr Donaldson's reluctance to specify his plans boosted the Trimble camp which felt that the Lagan Valley MP was highlighting a hole in the strategy of the "no camp" but failing to plug it.

As the canvassing continued Mr Trimble called on the 860 delegates, who will meet at the Waterfront Hall, Belfast, to take a reality check, emphasising how much had been achieved since the agreement was sealed two years ago. He said that politics was about operating in the real world.

He accused anti-agreement Unionists of making the task of his party's leadership more difficult in securing progress on decommissioning. Had they backed him instead of saying there was no requirement on the IRA to do so, progress would have been much faster.

Mr Trimble pleaded with those opposed to the IRA deal to rally round after Saturday's vote. Against yesterday's defections, he has the support of assembly member Billy Armstrong, who was opposed to going into government with Sinn Fein in November.

webTitle: Watchdog steps up criticism of ITV

fields.headline: Watchdog steps up criticism of ITV
fields.standfirst: Coverage of current affairs is lightweight, says report
fields.trailText: The battle between the Independent Television Commission and ITV has intensified with a condemnation by the regulator of the channel's current affairs and entertainment shows.
fields.body:
The battle between the Independent Television Commission and ITV has intensified with a condemnation by the regulator of the channel's current affairs and entertainment shows.

A week after it rejected ITV's plans to revive flagging ratings for its news programmes, the commission has turned its sights on the rest of the network's output.

In its annual review of ITV's performance, published today, the regulator criticises Tonight with Trevor McDonald for relying too heavily on celebrity interviews and lightweight social affairs issues, and says the network's arts and entertainment schedules would have looked thin without the hit game show Who Wants to be a Millionaire?

The ITC says the channel "failed to hit top form" with new arts, comedy and entertainment shows in a year of "dramatic change" following the scrapping of News at Ten. The new current affairs show, Tonight, had not yet achieved flagship status, and there was a danger that factual programmes have begun to look the same.

After demanding last week that ITV should come up with new ideas to arrest the decline in news audiences, the ITC's second set of stern words is another indication that it is keen to flex its muscles to counter criticism that it has been unwilling to use its powers strongly enough.

The commission urges ITV chiefs to maintain high levels of cash investment if they are to reverse failed attempts to find "new, potentially long-running bankers".

But it is positive about ITV's overall strategy: "Bold steps were taken, supported by an increased programme budget and increased deployment of marketing techniques to arrest years of audience decline," the review says.

Sport, children's programmes and drama are highlighted for praise in the report, but the commission expresses dismay at the network's failure adequately to cover major events such as the eclipse and the millennium eve celebrations.

ITV's factual programming relies principally on human interest stories, CCTV footage, consumerism and lifestyle shows, such as Parking Wars, Motorway Life and the "... from hell" series, resulting in a "sameness in tone", the commission says.

The distinction between features, documentaries and current affairs had become blurred, it says and it goes on to warn ITV against depriving viewers of variety.

ITN's news coverage had, however, remained of high quality.

ITV welcomed the broad thrust of the review. "We are pleased that the ITC has acknowledged that ITV delivered increased range and diversity in its programming last year," it said in a statement.

"As the ITC has said, 1999 was a year of dramatic change for ITV when bold steps were taken, supported by an increased programme budget. The ITC recognised in particular much that was new, high quality and wide-ranging in drama, strengthened factual programming, and marked improvements in sport, education, social action and religion."

The statement added: "Following the introduction of the new ITV schedule in 1999, ITV increased its peaktime audience share for the first time in seven years.

"An additional £64m was invested in peaktime programming and it is gratifying that the ITC has recognised many of the achievements of ITV's new evening schedule."

The performance review also assesses each of the 15 regional ITV broadcasters. It expresses dismay that Carlton, which holds three ITV franchises - for London weekday, the midlands and south-west - has imposed its corporate image on each.

The loss of the strong local identities built up by Central and Westcountry is disappointing, the report says.

Grampian television, owned by the Scottish Media Group, is criticised for failing to mirror the needs of its local audience.

The regulator expressed astonishment at the failure to broadcast a separate hogmanay show for the region last year, and said that too many co-productions with the parent company were classed as local programmes.

This was not acceptable, and Grampian had agreed to improve its performance this year.

News While the fall in ratings was unsatisfactory, the "quality of the ITN service remained undiminished".

Current affairs There is praise for Tonight with Trevor McDonald: a "genuine attempt to inject new life into mainstream current affairs programming". But there is "too great a concentration of lighter treatments and the focus on celebrity interviews tended to provide insufficient depth".

Factual The "caught on camera" genre - cheap and easy television - is criticised. But there were a "a small number of outstanding films". This Morning remains "commendably consistent", and the new daytime talk show Loose Women was praised.

Children's programmes The success of the Saturday morning strands SM:TV Live and CD:UK is highlighted, as is strong showings in children's drama, entertainment shows, and pre-school output.

Religious ITV made a "real effort in 1999 to bring fresh ideas to its religious programming".

Drama The new flexibility in the schedule led to more variety, but new series were in familiar settings. There were hits in short series of contemporary drama - Forgotten drew the best debut rating (12m) for such a series, the report said. "The emergence of some new talent to ITV in terms of writers and actors was welcome."

Entertainment Millionaire was a hit again. But Give Your Mate a Break and Would I Lie To You? were failures. Comedy was problematic.

Sport "Sport is now one of ITV's strongest programme categories having recovered well from the doldrums of four or five years ago."

Arts "ITV's arts policy in 1999 was muddled and lacked sufficient forethought." Some programmes were labelled arts shows when they were entertainment. "The ITC expects to see ITV overhauling its arts policy to meet fully the definition of arts programming."

webTitle: Taiwanese pop star incurs China's wrath

fields.headline: Taiwanese pop star incurs China's wrath
fields.standfirst: Taiwan and China: special report
fields.trailText: The Taiwanese pop singer Chang Hui-mei, whose popularity once transcended the tension between China and Taiwan, has become a casualty of the dispute between the island and the mainland.
fields.body:
The Taiwanese pop singer Chang Hui-mei, whose popularity once transcended the tension between China and Taiwan, has become a casualty of the dispute between the island and the mainland.

Television, newspaper and billboard advertisements for the soft drink Sprite, featuring Chang, were banned after she sang at the Taiwanese president's inauguration on Saturday, Chinese media executives said yesterday.

A spokeswoman for Coca-Cola, which makes Sprite, said that the company would not contest the decision. "We respect it, and we'll have alternative arrangements."

The ad ran for at least a month on China Central Television before being pulled after Chang sang the anthem of the Republic of China - Taiwan's formal name - at Chen Shui-bian's inauguration.

Chang is an unlikely victim of the political tension. Last summer, when China was threatening to go to war with Taiwan, she packed stadiums in Shanghai and Beijing.

Advertisements featuring Hong Kong pop stars are among those being used as replacements.
AP, Beijing

webTitle: Sierra Leone children carry British guns

fields.headline: Sierra Leone children carry British guns
fields.standfirst:
Sierra Leone: special report
Interactive guide
fields.trailText: The government was plunged into renewed controversy over Sierra Leone yesterday by reports that British weapons were being used by child soldiers.
fields.byline: Richard Norton-Taylor,  and  Chris McGreal  in Freetown
fields.body:
The government was plunged into renewed controversy over Sierra Leone yesterday by reports that British weapons were being used by child soldiers.

Officials admitted that British self-loading rifles could have got into the hands of young boys in the Sierra Leone army, despite assurances by President Ahmed Kabbah that they would only be used by regular soldiers, in accordance with "human rights standards".

The reports that youngsters were arming themselves with British guns are acutely embarrassing to a government that has repeatedly condemned the use of child soldiers in Africa.

The issue is doubly sensitive for ministers who agreed on Tuesday to supply the Kabbah government with a further consignment of weapons, including 10,000 self-loading rifles.

After the UN dropped its embargo on arms supplies to Mr Kabbah's forces, Britain shipped £10m worth of weapons to Freetown last year. They included 132 general purpose machine-guns with 2m rounds of ammunition, more than 2,000 mortars, and 7,500 rifles, with 800,000 rounds of training ammunition.

They were intended as training weapons but are being used in combat, and not always by those they were intended for. Kamajor militiamen have taken the guns off regular soldiers on some occasions, saying they will put them to better use as more experienced fighters.

Controlling a shipment of 10,000 rifles, particularly in the midst of a war, will prove very difficult. Ultimately, if there are children on the front line they will end up with British guns in their hands.

The UN estimates that there are about 5,000 child combatants in Sierra Leone. The bulk of them were conscripted by the rebels after being abducted and introduced to powerful drugs, but there are many hundreds fighting with the government forces.

They were among the first to be demobilised when the peace accords were signed last July. They also appear to have been among the first to pick up a gun again when the war rekindled. Of the 1,600 child soldiers sent to 10 UN camps for reintegration into civilian life, well over half have apparently gone back to war.

The new Sierra Leone army says it is screening out children. But other pro-government forces - particularly the Kamajor militia and the army loyal to deposed military ruler Johnny Paul Koroma - have no such qualms. Anyone willing to fight is welcome and teenage boys are apparent at roadblocks. Most of the children in uniform are in their mid-teens and above. Occasionally they are younger.

Sierra Leonean soldiers dismiss suggestions that 15-year-olds are too young to fight. There is a consensus that if they are old enough to work and father children, then they are old enough to defend their families from the rebels.

The aid agency Cafod warned yesterday that the new supply of British rifles could mean more children being given weapons and being drawn into the fighting.

Amnesty called for safeguards to ensure that he British equipment was not used to commit human rights violations, and said that Sierra Leonean personnel given weapons should be trained in international law.

Ministry of Defence officials insisted that the new weapons consignment would be subject to "controlled release under the supervi sion of British officers" leading the new 90-strong military training mission.

Child soldiers "are obviously something we condemn". a Foreign Office official said. "We've worked hard to eradicate the practice wherever we come across it.".

But British officials said the risk that the weapons would get into the hands of children remained.

Defence sources in London expressed confidence that Revolutionary United Front rebels were "in a degree of retreat", though they remained in force in two areas: the diamond-producing region in the east of Sierra Leone and west and north-west of Freetown.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook said the Government favoured an African peace force for Sierra Leone, with the west in a supporting role behind the scenes. "European troops in the frontline are not necessarily helpful in achieving reduction in tension," he said.

"It is better if the frontline is provided by African troops facing African situations," he told the BBC yesterday.
