fields.headline: Regan cooperates
fields.standfirst: Monaco businessman on £1m bail
fields.trailText: Andrew Regan, the Monaco-based entrepreneur who tried to take over the Co-operative Wholesale Society three years ago, yesterday returned to Britain to face a criminal charge of stealing £2.4m.
fields.body:
Andrew Regan, the Monaco-based entrepreneur who tried to take over the Co-operative Wholesale Society three years ago, yesterday returned to Britain to face a criminal charge of stealing £2.4m.

Mr Regan flew to London and gave himself up at Charing Cross police station, where he was arrested and charged with theft. He later appeared in court and was released on £1m bail.

Mr Regan, pictured yesterday, has been wanted by the serious fraud office since October. He is accused of stealing money five years ago from Hobson - a food company of which he was then chief executive.

The case revolves around an agreement under which Hobson supplied products to the Co-operative Wholesale Society. This contract was extended in 1995 in return for a payment by Hobson of £2.85m.

At Bow Street magistrates' court, Mr Regan spoke only once - to confirm his name and his address in Monte Carlo. He was granted a highly unusual bail condition allowing him to return to Monaco until June 20.

His lawyer, Julian Bevan, said that he wanted to tie up his business affairs and attend the confirmation of three of his six children in the principality.

Beyond June 20, he was told to surrender his passport and stay in London, within the M25.

Mr Regan was told to sleep every night at a designated address in south London, and he was also ordered not to contact any potential witnesses in the case.

Mr Regan has provided a surety of £500,000, and his father, former Spring Ram kitchens chairman Roger Regan, has lodged a further £500,000 security with his law firm.

A warrant for Mr Regan's arrest was issued after three other people were charged in September with corruption offences. The three were Allan Green and David Chambers - both former Co-op employees - and Paul Thomas, a former solicitor for Hobson.

Mr Regan tried to institute a £1.7bn takeover of the Co-operative Wholesale Society through a vehicle called Galileo. The attempt failed before he had even tabled a formal bid.

Mr Regan is represented by Burton Copeland, a law firm which has worked on a series of high profile City cases including the Maxwell affair and the collapse of Blue Arrow.

webTitle: Sorry, I'll confess that on the telly again

fields.headline: Sorry, I'll confess that on the telly again
fields.trailText: Regular viewers of confessional talk shows on television could be forgiven a sense of déjà vu, since almost half those who bare their souls are serial guests of up to seven or eight appearances, research published yesterday finds.
fields.body:
Regular viewers of confessional talk shows on television could be forgiven a sense of déjà vu, since almost half those who bare their souls are serial guests of up to seven or eight appearances, research published yesterday finds.

The broadcasting standards commission says that some producers are calling on proven guests, in a phenomenon described as "repeat performer syndrome".

The study, entitled Consenting Adults, also found wide differences among programme makers as to how they gained the consent of the participants. The commission called on them to rethink their practices, and it may strengthen its own code.

With the expansion of daytime TV and the proliferation of cable and satellite channels, talk shows and docu-soaps have been a cheap way of filling the schedules lists. The talk show Kilroy was the first incarnation on BBC1, and it spawned others, such as Vanessa - axed after it was discovered using "fake guests" - and Trisha, and Esther.

The other popular genre relying on "real people" is the television docu-soap, a formula also cheap for programme makers.

The commission said that guests on such shows should be made more clearly aware of the implications of appearing on screen and told how the footage might be used. Sometimes material is put to different use. In one case the commission received a complaint about footage from a documentary-style programme on teachers ending up in the ITV comedy show In Bed with Medinner. One docu-soap participant claimed people became "puppets on the editing room floor".

For the study, 40 people who had appeared in shows were interviewed. The researchers discovered that 19 had appeared in two or more programmes. One of them confessed to taking part in "seven or eight" shows, including programmes that featured personal issues, as well as documentaries about collections and variety shows.

"They have gone from amateur to semi-professional status," said Philip Schlesinger, a professor at Stirling university's media research institute, which compiled the study. "You can see the attraction for programme makers because they know [the guests] are probably kosher, there's no question about their genuineness and they already know how to do an interview."

Pressures on programme makers meant that often guests had to be found at short notice, so researchers turned to people already listed in their contacts books and possessing a track record.

The research sample was small, but the commission believes the findings are accurate. Its view was supported by programme makers involved in the study, who were not surprised by the discovery.

Most of those taking part in shows were happy at the way they were treated by TV companies, which in many cases sought the consent of people connected with the participants. But in one case a woman felt "hurt" by her daughter's revelations on television. In another a woman who featured in one show to seek revenge on her estranged husband had supplied footage of him and his children, but later she complained about the impact it had on the youngsters and their experiences at school.

The commission is now hoping programme makers will pay more attention to the feelings of show participants.

fields.headline: Train murder suspect loses appeal
fields.trailText: The Portuguese supreme court ruled yesterday that Sid Ahmed Rezala could be extradited to France to stand trial for the murders of British student Isabel Peake, who was pushed to her death from an express train last October, and two young French women.
fields.body:
The Portuguese supreme court ruled yesterday that Sid Ahmed Rezala could be extradited to France to stand trial for the murders of British student Isabel Peake, who was pushed to her death from an express train last October, and two young French women.

The court, which could have refused to extradite the 20-year-old Algerian on the grounds that he faces a stiffer prison sentence in France than the 25-year maximum allowed in Portugal, said only that it had upheld a lower court's decision in March to grant France's extradition request.

Lawyers for Mr Rezala, who last week confessed to the killings in an interview with a French news magazine, made no immediate comment on whether they would appeal to Portugal's constitutional court.

France, embarrassed by a bungled investigation that allowed Rezala to flee the country last December, had already asked Interpol to issue an international arrest warrant in case extradition was denied.

Rezala, arrested in Lisbon in January, is wanted in connection with the murders of Ms Peake, a Birmingham student, Corinne Caillaux, who was stabbed in the toilets of an express, and Emilie Bazin, a former girlfriend.

fields.headline: Retired colonel on secrets charge
fields.trailText: A former army officer awarded the Queen's Gallantry Medal for his work defusing bombs in Northern Ireland was yesterday committed for trial at the Old Bailey on secrets charges.
fields.body:
A former army officer awarded the Queen's Gallantry Medal for his work defusing bombs in Northern Ireland was yesterday committed for trial at the Old Bailey on secrets charges.

Nigel Wylde, a retired colonel, who pleaded not guilty, was arrested in December 1988 with Tony Geraghty, a defence journalist who wrote a book describing how army computers secretly monitor the activities of two thirds of the population of Northern Ireland.

His book, The Irish War, was published in October 1988. No attempt has been made to withdraw it. Secrets charges against Mr Geraghty were withdrawn by the attorney general, Lord Williams.

Colonel Wylde, who is on unconditional bail, is charged with making damaging disclosures without authority in his role as a government contractor.

He faces the prospect of a two year jail sentence.

He said yesterday: "I challenge the prosecution to prove there was any damage to national security as a result of the book. The Official Secrets Act is oppressive, violates the presumption of innocence and consequently my human rights."

He added: " It was clearly a political decision to remove the journalist from this case designed to try and reduce the publicity his prosecution would attract".

fields.headline: Struggle renewed
fields.standfirst: Old foes in tussle over Westminster plinths
fields.trailText: Sylvia Pankhurst and David Lloyd George are to posthumously renew their struggles of the early part of the last century.
fields.body:
Sylvia Pankhurst and David Lloyd George are to posthumously renew their struggles of the early part of the last century.

The socialist feminist best known as a suffragette, and the Liberal leader remembered for introducing old age pensions, face a "battle of the plinth". Rival groups are vying to erect a statue to their heroine or hero on the same plot of land across the road from the Palace of Westminster.

The tussle over the College Green spot promises to revive the clashes of more than 80 years ago when Sylvia Pankhurst led protests to win women the vote. Lloyd George was a member of the Liberal administration that initially opposed the right and passed the notorious "Cat and Mouse Act" to force feed her and other hunger strikers.

When suffragettes disrupted a debate, he declared: "I see some rats have got in; let them squeal. It does not matter."

Lloyd George became prime minister during the first world war, a conflict opposed by Pankhurst, but eventually agreed to limited suffrage in 1918.

Sylvia Pankhurst's radicalism saw her expelled from the Women's Social and Political Union, and she was left off an earlier memorial near the House of Lords. Her case is championed by a committee backed by more than a dozen MPs, including Margaret Beckett and Glenda Jackson, the Liberal Democrats' women's group and unions.

It plans to raise £30,000 for a lifesize bronze by Ian Walters who has sculpted statues of Harold Wilson and Nelson Mandela.

The Lloyd George campaign is chaired by Michael Heseltine and supported by a cross-party coalition of peers. It intends to raise £400,000 for a bigger figure and favours the College Green site if, as expected, a bid for Parliament Square is rejected.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Kray associate arrested
fields.body:
Kray associate arrested

A former associate of the Kray twins has been arrested after claiming on television he was involved in two murders. Freddie Foreman, 68, was arrested on suspicion of perjury and perverting the course of justice. He claimed he had been involved in the deaths of Frank Mitchell and Tommy "Ginger" Marks.

Signalman cleared

A rail signalman was yesterday found not guilty by Wakefield magistrates of being drunk while operating a signal box. Andrew Westmoreland, 36, of Normanton, was found slumped in the box and when later breath-tested at his home was more than four times the legal limit for driving. He told the court he had drunk brandy after he got home from work feeling ill.

Rough deal for Irish

One in 10 of the people sleeping rough on the streets of London are Irish, according to a report published today by housing charity Shelter.

Transfusion refused

A Jehovah's Witness injured in a road crash died in hospital after refusing to have a blood transfusion, an inquest at Huntingdon heard yesterday. A verdict of accidental death was recorded on James Titcombe, 53, of Sudbury, Suffolk.

Spike sets world record

Spike, a ginger and white tomcat, has celebrated his 30th birthday at his home in Bridport, Dorset. A Guinness Book of Records spokesman said: "Spike holds the record for being the oldest cat in the world."

fields.headline: Yesterday day, bad day
fields.trailText: Ken Clarke. The former chancellor, a notorious technophobe, was renowned for trusting to pencil and paper at 11 Downing Street.
fields.body:
Good day

Ken Clarke. The former chancellor, a notorious technophobe, was renowned for trusting to pencil and paper at 11 Downing Street. When forced to take a laptop to European meetings the cigar chomping Clarke said he only ever used it to find out the football scores. But now he has embraced the 21st century and bought himself a mobile phone - the latest miniature model, in raspberry pink.

Good day

Bob Marshall-Andrews. The scourge of the Dome has a very own dome of his own in Pembrokeshire national park. His bizarre underground home - shortlisted for an award - has been nicknamed the Tellytubby House by locals.

Today

Commons:Lords amendments to electronic communications bill. Whitsun recess adjournment debate.Lords: Regulation of investigatory powers bill, second reading. Parliament rises for the Whitsun recess and returns on June 5.

fields.headline: Surgeons criticise cancer ops delay
fields.standfirst:
Diagnosis target is 'undermined'

The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The government's target of specialist diagnosis within two weeks for women with breast cancer will not save lives because operations are routinely cancelled, surgeons warned yesterday.
fields.body:
The government's target of specialist diagnosis within two weeks for women with breast cancer will not save lives because operations are routinely cancelled, surgeons warned yesterday.

Robert Mansel, a cancer surgeon and professor of oncology at the University of Wales college of medicine, said yesterday that two of his operations on women with breast cancer at University hospital Cardiff had already been cancelled this week due to staff shortages and lack of beds.

"They will have to be rescheduled but we're booked up for two to three weeks ahead," he said. "There may be a delay."

Professor Mansel said there was great strength of feeling among the cancer surgeons gathered yesterday for the annual meeting in Cardiff of the Association of Surgeons of Great Britain and Ireland.

"Cancer surgeons are very committed. They see the agony for the patient, who knows that there is a cancer sitting in their body and that they have to wait for treatment," he said. "There is tremendous psychological pressure for the patient. The worst thing we ever have to do is to tell a patient who has been waiting all day that their operation has been cancelled."

The Royal College of Surgeons has written to the government's "cancer tsar", Mike Richards, saying it is "surprised and concerned at how little attention is given to the role of surgery in the management of cancer". Although most cancers are initially diagnosed and operated on by surgeons and although for many people with solid tumours surgery represents the only chance of survival, far more attention is paid to drug treatment and to radiotherapy, they claim.

Most surgeons who operate on cancer are general surgeons. Many more specialist cancer surgeons are needed, the letter argues. "If we are to improve the prognosis following the treatment of cancer, we need to ensure there are surgical specialists in the treatment of cancer in numbers at least equal to those in Europe."

The letter points out that Britain is lagging behind Europe and the US in surgical outcomes. In England and Wales the five year survival rate for cancer of the rectum is 37% after surgery, while in Europe generally it is 47% and in the US 64%.

Prof Mansel said a variety of problems caused cancellation of operations. There were serious shortages of hospital beds, nurses and theatre staff. "If one member of staff is missing, the whole thing breaks down," he said.

He said if, for instance, operating theatre assistants were absent, the anaesthetists could not do their job because they could not leave the patient to get the drugs. Hitches of this sort meant some theatres stood empty much of the time.

"The beds are a major issue and Alan Milburn [the health secretary] has recognised that. The latest report acknowledged that beds have been cut too far. We need spare beds for people who need routine surgery. That could be done by opening up closed wards," said Prof Mansel. More flexibility was needed in the appointments system, he said, so that patients with cancelled operations did not go to the back of the queue but were slotted in as soon as possible.

fields.headline: Geoff Goddard
fields.standfirst: Innovative song-writer in an era before the Beatles
fields.trailText: In the early 1960s, Geoff Goddard, who has died aged 62, was the soul, in-house composer, general factotum and eminence grise of record producer Joe Meek's RGM Sound.
fields.body:
In the early 1960s, Geoff Goddard, who has died aged 62, was the soul, in-house composer, general factotum and eminence grise of record producer Joe Meek's RGM Sound. Operating out of a tiny flat-cum-studio in north London's Holloway Road, RGM was a cauldron of other-worldliness, funfair vulgarity, tunes drenched in echo and technical innovations that changed studio procedures forever.

It was Goddard who, in the middle of the night, fingered the keyboard melody on the Tornados' multi-million selling Telstar in 1962 - for which he was uncredited. It was Goddard who wrote the melodramatic Johnny Remember Me (1961) for singer and actor John Leyton.

Apart from music press coverage and an outing on Harpers West One, an ITV drama series, the disc featured in Psychic News, since Goddard had claimed that his muse had resulted from an interest in spiritualism dating from his spell in the army. Thus, during one of the twice-weekly Holloway Road seances, contact had been made with Buddy Holly who, via the tumbler, had affirmed the record's hit potential.

Goddard's later hits for Leyton included Wild Wind and Son This Is She. A perpetrator of the death disc par excellence, Goddard also specialised in tribute songs such as Mike Berry's BBC-banned Tribute To Buddy Holly, and Just Like Eddie, an Eddie Cochran homage from sometime Tornado guitarist Heinz Burt (obituary April 11).

Born and bred in Reading, Berkshire, Goddard was a chorister in a local church before studying viola and piano at the Royal Academy of Music in London. Following national service, he made inroads into pop music, and met Meek. He performed as a pianist, optimistically projected by Meek as "Anton Hollywood", complete with candelabraed concert grand - even if he more resembled a saturnine Harpo Marx. "I was seen," he told me, "as a sort of mixture of Russ Conway and Liberace".

One of Goddard's first published compositions was Lone Rider, an instrumental to which he added lyrics - about a ghostly motorcyclist cautioning the living against "taking risks for kicks". In 1962 that too was recorded by Leyton.

Two years later the Meek-Goddard partnership shattered forever. Goddard lost a legal battle over whether the Honeycombs' Have I The Right chart-topper infringed the copyright of his own Give Me The Chance. Meek meanwhile, in the wake of the success of the Beatles and a new musical era, was facing increasing commercial and mental disintegration. Goddard quit RGM Sound and Holloway Road.

Weary of the shabbier aspects of the music industry, his withdrawal into anonymity was of his own choosing. The artistic motivation seemed to have gone out of his life. The most notable post-Meek ripple he made was in writing My Head Goes Round for Cliff Richard's Tracks And Grooves album (1969).

Later the once vastly successful songwriter took a job in Reading University's catering department. He just did the clearing up, he told me, he was nobody of any importance, he thought - although once in a while he did get recognised.

Yet he was not a recluse, neither did he renege on his past. Last year I gave a talk at Reading University's sociology faculty on "mortality in the popular song" - and there he was, with his sometime RGM colleague Lord Sutch (obituary June 19 1999). And he was always pleased by public attention, as when Just Like Eddie, transformed, became the (mildly lucrative) Just Like Shreddies for a television commercial. As for Johnny Remember Me, it was frequently revived - by anyone from Showaddywaddy to Dave Vanian and his Phantom Chords.

By the mid-1980s the royalties had been drying up. Then his London music publisher got in touch, asking Goddard to drop by. The songwriter went down to Reading University's students' union, found a telephone and rang the publisher. Thus was he told that he had a platinum disc waiting for him; Bronski Beat and Marc Almond's medley of Donna Summer's I Feel Love and Johnny Remember Me had sold more than 300,000. Goddard, completely out of touch with the modern music business, had never heard it. However, its success prompted him to resume song-writing.

In 1991 he was interviewed on a Channel 4 documentary on his sometime collaborator Joe Meek, who, finally deranged, had committed suicide after murdering his landlady in 1967. In the 1990s Goddard was heard on piano at various university functions, notably at end-of-term Christmas celebrations where students could wonder why the clearer-up inserted ancient pop songs like Johnny Remember Me and Just Like Eddie in among the carols.

fields.headline: Michael Langford
fields.standfirst: Influential tutor whose best-selling books became standard texts for generations of photographers
fields.trailText: Influential tutor whose best-selling books became standard texts for generations of photographers
fields.body:
As a writer, teacher and practitioner, Michael Langford, who has died aged 67, was a major influence on British photography. Joining the Royal College of Art as a photography tutor in 1967, he retired three decades later as a fellow of the RCA. His bestsellers, Basic Photography (1965) and Advanced Photography (1969), are standard texts, still used today, bibles for generations of photographers who owe their careers to his work.

He became an RCA senior tutor in 1973, departmental head 12 years later and from 1994 to 1997 he was course director. In the late 1960s I was one of the first half-dozen students recruited on to what was then a new course. With his gentlemanly, silvery ele gance, Langford was an excellent foil for John Hedgecoe, now emeritus professor of photography at the RCA, who founded the photography school in 1965.

In those times feminism was no more than a murmur, and the photographic industry a male domain, yet on that unconventional course there were equal numbers of women and men. We were drawn from the disparate worlds of commercial and fine art, and it was testimony to Langford and Hedgecoe that most of us went on to success.

Once I anxiously asked Langford how I might metamorphose from graphic design graduate to professional photographer within a two-year course. He smiled graciously. I would soon pick up the technique, he reassured me. "That," he went on, "is the easy part." He conducted us into a darkened studio overlooking Cromwell Road. Facing a window blind pierced by a tiny hole was a white screen, on which the traffic outside appeared, upside-down. "The principle," observed Langford, simply, "of photography. The pinhole camera."

Gradually our motley crew became fledgling photographers, but my first colour pictures were a failure. "Just go back and do it again," said Langford. "That's what we were told in the Royal Air Force when things went wrong. Just try again, please." I reshot. All was well.

Langford was educated at Portsmouth Grammar School and started his career in Bournemouth aged 16 as a local photographer's apprentice. Two years later, on national service, he was assigned to the RAF photographic section. Then, after a brief spell with a press photography firm, he worked as an industrial photographer while teaching evening classes.

In 1959 he took up a fulltime teaching post at Ealing Technical College (now Thames Valley University). Five years later he moved to Birmingham College of Art. Then, in 1967, came the RCA.

With hindsight I can see the benefits of disparity in the teaching methods we experienced at the college. Students quickly became tough. It took a degree of resilience to withstand, let alone appreciate, the contrast between Langford's polite phone calls to Harrods to reserve fashion accessories for our studio work and Hedgecoe tearing up prints in the interests of demonstrating "what really counts in a pitcher!"

Langford never espoused a teaching method, he thought students should develop their own ideas - intuition always taking precedence, perhaps even over rationality. Thirty years after seeing his Cromwell Road go silently by, upside-down in that darkened studio, I am preparing an exhibition of my photographs, just trying again, as he would have appreciated.

Langford's 17 books were translated into many languages, and are texts in schools and colleges across the world. He was finishing the seventh edition of Basic Photography - a book originally drawn from his Ealing lectures - just before he died.

He leaves his wife Pamela and two daughters.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Hunchback Of Notre Dame
fields.body:
The Hunchback Of Notre Dame

(William S Dieterle, 1939)

4pm, Sky Cinema

An exemplary screening of Victor Hugo's Gothic classic: aside from the beauty-and-beast romantic horror story, there's a tangible sense of a grotesque medieval world. The film is brilliantly conceived by Dieterle, and beautifully acted by Cedric Hardwicke as Frollo, Maureen O'Hara as the gypsy girl, Esmeralda, and best of all Charles Laughton - who somehow manages to express the selfless nobility of the misshapen Quasimodo through all that monster make-up.

The Graduate

(Mike Nichols, 1967)

8.10pm, FilmFour

Dustin Hoffman's Benjamin arrives home with his degree and is now majoring in disgust at the complacent lifestyle of his affluent parents. Their friend Mrs Robinson (the glorious Anne Bancroft,) begins a cynical affair with him, until true love turns up in the shape of her daughter (Katharine Ross). It could hardly fail; and with its final, joyful act of youthful rebellion, it captures the mood of the decade.

Some Came Running

(Vincente Minnelli, 1958)

9pm, TCM

When a blocked writer (Frank Sinatra) rolls into his home town after a 15-year absence, you pretty much know what to expect: sulking and drinking to excess, while upsetting the applecart with his smart mouth. Ol' Blue Eyes finds his seemingly idyllic town full of two-faced people, and hooks up with the only honest folk he can find - cardsharp Dean Martin and stupid but well-meaning good-time girl, Shirley MacLaine.

Breakdown

(Jonathan Mostow, 1997)

10pm, Sky Premier

Married couple Kurt Russell and Kathleen Quinlan's Jeep breaks down in the middle of nowhere, USA. Passing trucker JT Walsh gives her a lift to a diner while Kurt fixes the car. When he reaches the meeting place, Walsh and assorted rednecks deny ever seeing his wife. Mostow's unsettling thriller builds an air of taut menace around the disappearance; but lurking underneath Russell's east coast sophisticate is an action hero, and a violent reckoning approaches.

fields.headline: Lord Mackenzie-Stuart
fields.standfirst: Scots lawyer dedicated to European ideal became president of the Court of Justice
fields.trailText: Scots lawyer dedicated to European ideal became president of the Court of Justice
fields.body:
Among the fine portraits at the Faculty of Advocates in Edinburgh is a memorable one of Lord Mackenzie-Stuart, who has died aged 75. The sitter, painted by Alberto Morrocco, wears the robes of a judge of the European Court of Justice, and so the painting commemorates his achievements as a judge of that court from 1972, and as its president, 1984-88.

Born in Aberdeen, Jack Mackenzie Stuart (the hyphen came when he was created a life peer in 1988) was the son of the professor of Scots law at the city's university. He was educated at Fettes College, Edinburgh; in 1942 he enlisted in the Royal Engineers. A study of bridge-building was put into effect in France, Holland and Germany. Promoted to temporary captain in 1946, he was posted to Burma, and then cleared mines in Northumberland before demobilisation in 1947.

After obtaining law degrees at Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge, of which he became an honorary fellow, and at Edinburgh University, he was called to the Scots Bar in 1951. He became a QC in 1963. In June 1972 he was elevated to the bench, but resigned four months later, on his nomination as the first British judge on the European Court of Justice. His study and knowledge of European Community law led in 1977 to the publication of his book, The European Communities and the Rule of Law. His talents came in due time to make a formidable impact on his fellow judges at Luxembourg.

His work as a judge of the Court of Justice was marked by his deeply-held convictions about the way forward in Europe, derived not only from his wartime experiences, but also from his sense of a legal and historical communion between the law of Scotland and other European systems of law. These convictions were reflected in his views about the manner in which judgments should be sought within a court comprised of members from different jurisdictions, and accorded with the courtesy of manner which always marked his conduct as a judge.

That same sense of history and legal communion was also to drive his efforts within the court to look outside its legal boundaries and, in particular, to lead it into debate with members of the Supreme Court of the United States. This was to a Scots lawyer like Mackenzie-Stuart a rational extension of the principles of the age of enlightenment with which Scotland and Scots lawyers had been associated. He considered that in holding the balance between collective law-making through Brussels and the laws of the member states, especially in the areas of freedom to trade and work, the best way for the Court of Justice to secure that balance lay in a community-wide rule of law rather than the "subsidiarity" of the Maastricht treaty. In 1996, he warned that the court functions as "a bulwark against the Balkanisation of western Europe, and we undermine it at our peril".

But the portrait in the Faculty of Advocates also speaks about the private man. The sitter looks out from the frame, slightly withdrawn, apparently hesitant and even enigmatic, but still implying that sense of fun which was Jack Mackenzie-Stuart's hallmark. With Anne, his wife, he extended friendship and generous hospitality to all who came into contact with them, whether at their homes in Edinburgh, in Luxembourg or in France. Their marriage created a partnership of minds dedicated to working for the European ideal, as well as the focus for a happy family life.

His interests and research lay in many directions beyond the law. His account of the stay in Edinburgh after the French Revolution of the Comte d'Artois, later the Bourbon King Charles X, entitled A French King at Holyrood, was published in 1995. To those who worked with him he showed the same quiet courtesy and reasoning that he employed in court. I had the privilege to "devil" paperwork on behalf of Jack Mackenzie-Stuart before I was called to the Bar. On many evenings, after discussion of his forthcoming cases, came the moment when Anne entered with the tea-tray. In its train came wide-ranging debate over a multitude of topics, legal gossip and laughter. The flat already showed the signs of Jack's penchant for collecting - paintings, gilt candlesticks or antique furniture. The duties of a "devil" in the Mackenzie-Stuart household came to encompass baby-sitting and dressing-up as a butler for a Victorian party.

Even in the dark days of his final illness, that same welcome, width of conversation and willingness to share his library of learning were still to be found.

He is survived by his wife Anne and four daughters.

Alexander John Mackenzie Stuart, Lord Mackenzie- Stuart of Dean, lawyer, born November 18 1924; died April 1 2000

fields.headline: Appreciation: Sir John Gielgud's films
fields.trailText: While not surprisingly the tributes for Sir John Gielgud (obituary May 23) concentrated on his stage career, he appeared in some 80 films plus a number of memorable television productions. He worked for directors ranging alphabetically from Richard Attenborough to Andrej Wa jda and in talent from Orson Welles to Michael Winner.
fields.body:
While not surprisingly the tributes for Sir John Gielgud (obituary May 23) concentrated on his stage career, he appeared in some 80 films plus a number of memorable television productions. He worked for directors ranging alphabetically from Richard Attenborough to Andrej Wa jda and in talent from Orson Welles to Michael Winner. He won an Oscar for his role as the acerbic butler in Arthur (1981) and was seen by millions more people in that comedy than in all his stage appearances combined.

Not that he ever became a popular screen actor. The camera did not particularly love him. His angularity and exquisite diction lent distance, and his best roles on television in Brideshead Revisited or on screen as Lord Raglan in The Charge Of The Light Brigade (1968) or on several memorable occasions as butlers, showed that he excelled playing aristocrats and their betters. Both groups are feared and respected by the general public, but neither is liked.

There was an attendant cruelty to his best roles, whether dismissing the lower orders to their deaths (Oh! What A Lovely War) or being supercilious about their inarticulateness (Arthur). There might be a twinkle in his eye, but it noted waspishness not the merriment of John Mills or the charm of Alec Guinness. In the pantheon of British actors his status is unquestionable, but the screen exposed an incapacity to be rather than act a part.

His screen debut was in the forgotten Who Is That Man? (1923) although his first memorable film character was Inigo Jolliphant a decade later in JB Priestley's The Good Companions, directed by Victor Saville - probably the best British director of the period next to Alfred Hitchcock. He acted for Hitchcock as the eponymous Secret Agent in 1936, playing Ashenden in a film taken from two Somerset Maugham stories and a play by Campbell Dixon. Gielgud professed himself disappointed in the role, and it is possible that part blame for his distant persona was Hitchcock's, who preferred his actresses aloof and his actors forceful.

These films dominate a scarce filmography until he was tempted to America in 1953 to play Cassius in a bizarrely cast, although brilliantly successful, version of Julius Caesar, directed by Joseph L Mankiewicz. He was the only classical actor in the cast, which included James Mason as Brutus and Louis Calhern as a memorable Caesar (a role Gielgud took in the poor 1970 version) and Marlon Brando as Mark Antony. Reputedly Sir John and Brando were equally in awe of each other.

He returned home to play Clarence in Olivier's Richard III, then a steely Warwick in the Graham Greene-adapted film of Shaw's St Joan. Numerous films followed: some memorable like Orson Welles's Chimes At Midnight, in which he played Henry IV, and some ludicrous such as the 1972 Lost Horizon.

Alongside the duds were notable cameos in Attenbororough's Gandhi and as the unfeeling administrator in David Lynch's The Elephant Man. He responded to the challenge when cast opposite Britain's best screen actor Trevor Howard in the anti-war The Charge Of The Light Brigade, and saw off a similar challenge playing Dirk Bogarde's father in Alain Resnais's Providence (1977). Gielgud's portrayal of the alcoholic dying writer pinning his family to his pages like butterflies is a melancholy vision of a lonely, hollow man.

Increasingly, he found cinema rewarding both financially and emotionally, averaging a couple of films a year; these included such experiments as Prospero's Books, where Peter Greenaway immortalised a free version of his great performance in The Tempest. Few films offered such challenging roles, although Shine (1996) was a late highlight in a career which braved working for both Michael Winner and Otto Preminger twice - showing, as film historian David Thomson noted, that he latterly "plunged into film with magnificent, indiscriminate zest".

webTitle: Work in progress: Tony Bennett, singer

fields.headline: Work in progress: Tony Bennett, singer
fields.trailText: I'm thrilled to be doing the Elizabeth Taylor concert at the Royal Albert Hall. It's one of my favourite venues, and I performed at their 100th anniversary concert. This time it's for such a wonderful cause - and such a lady: she's the empress of the entertainment world.
fields.body:
I'm thrilled to be doing the Elizabeth Taylor concert at the Royal Albert Hall. It's one of my favourite venues, and I performed at their 100th anniversary concert. This time it's for such a wonderful cause - and such a lady: she's the empress of the entertainment world.

I'm doing a number of other concerts while I'm in the UK, including a big one outside Leeds Castle on the 29th to salute the history of the BBC. I'm doing this one with Diane Krall, a fantastic young jazz vocalist and pianist with whom I'm currently doing the Two For The Road Tour.

The tour will also take us to Manchester, Dublin and Edinburgh in late June, and then on to a number of European cities before we return to the US for two nights at the Hollywood Bowl. That will be fantastic - in front of an audience of 18,000. Other venues will also be outside, and I'm really looking forward to that, as the public always love to be outside in the summertime, and the atmosphere is very relaxed.

Before I leave Britain, however, I'll also be in Hampstead for the opening of a show of my paintings. I went to art school in Manhattan and have painted all my life, and still paint every day - in fact, it's my second career. In the US my paintings have done very well and, when the brochure for the UK show was launched, I gather that four were sold even before it had opened.

It's going to be an extremely busy summer. But after this series of concerts are over I'm off on holiday to Italy, where I plan to do some painting in Tuscany and Venice. After that it'll be back to thinking some more about an album I'm planning with Diane Krall.

Interview by Meg Carter

Tony Bennett performs in Elizabeth Taylor: A Musical Celebration on Sky Premier at 8pm on Sunday 4 June. His album Bennett Sings Ellington: Hot And Cool is now on release

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Music Live, the five-day musical jamboree spanning the BBC's national and local channels, gets under way when Sean Rafferty surveys the festival's classical components for In Tune (5.0pm, Radio 3). Then Performance On 3 (7.30pm, Radio 3) relays a Handel concert from Westminster Abbey, and a rather more eclectic mixture emerges with Steve Lamacq hosting United Nations (8.0pm, Radio 1), a four-hour bash bringing live performances from around the UK.

Music Live, the five-day musical jamboree spanning the BBC's national and local channels, gets under way when Sean Rafferty surveys the festival's classical components for In Tune (5.0pm, Radio 3). Then Performance On 3 (7.30pm, Radio 3) relays a Handel concert from Westminster Abbey, and a rather more eclectic mixture emerges with Steve Lamacq hosting United Nations (8.0pm, Radio 1), a four-hour bash bringing live performances from around the UK.

Chris Bowlby looks back this week on one of the 20th century's most controversial medical treatments to ask Why Did We Do That? (8.0pm, Radio 4). His question implies that electroconvulsive therapy has vanished into history: in reality it's still given to thousands of patients suffering severe depression or schizophrenia. They hailed it as a miracle cure when it began in the 1940s. Then came the side effects - mental confusion, severe loss of memory, and even coronaries.

fields.headline: One for the road
fields.standfirst: Before The Beatles, Abbey Road was just another recording studio - afterwards, it was a rock'n'roll shrine. And on Monday it hosts the finale for a BBC music extravaganza.  Paolo Hewitt  pays tribute
fields.trailText: Before The Beatles, Abbey Road was just another recording studio - afterwards, it was a rock'n'roll shrine. And on Monday it hosts the finale for a BBC music extravaganza. Paolo Hewitt pays tribute
fields.body:
Still they come from all over the world to scrawl their messages of devotion to The Beatles on the wall outside Abbey Road studios. They do so because they are slightly mad and because in the mind of the world Abbey Road will forever be linked to the Fab Four. The group recorded most of their work here and indeed named their last album after the studio.

Meanwhile, inside Abbey Road, staff are preparing themselves for the BBC's Music Live season, which is due to culminate here on Monday. Confirmed acts include Moby, Ian Brown, Death In Vegas, Ocean Colour Scene, Paul Weller, The Move, Ravi Shankar and possibly, I say possibly , an ex-Beatle or two. The day's proceedings will be transmitted in the capital by London Live radio, and BBC1 will broadcast highlights throughout the day. The idea of presenting such a popular selection of artists at Britain's most famous studio belongs to Jim Le Hat, a producer at London Live.

"We had a meeting last November," he explains, "and as a colleague was talking about the Music Live season, I had Abbey Road appear in front of my eyes. Think of a place where so much great music has been made, you have to think Abbey Road. I've been there before so I knew we could set the bands in three different studios and cut between them."

Ironically, although Abbey Road is indeed the most famous studio in the land, Neil Aldrich, who has worked there for 30 years, says that many people think the studio, following the demise of The Beatles, is now a dusty museum. Nothing could be further from the truth, he insists.

Most of its three studios are booked for the year, reflecting the "quality of the technicians here and their understanding of what people want". And famous acts who have recorded here recently include Oasis, The Spice Girls, Spiritualized, Dr John and Paul Weller. And, adds Aldrich, a sizeable number of Hollywood film scores have emanated from studios one and two, including the recent Star Wars film, Braveheart, Raiders Of The Lost Ark, The Talented Mr Ripley and Sleepy Hollow.

It hasn't always been thus. Built by EMI Records in 1931 to provide a suitable environment in which to record their artists, the studio was never christened Abbey Road. It was only 15 years ago that they officially changed their name from EMI Recording Studios to Abbey Road studios. By then, of course, The Beatles had made the place a landmark. But even they, during their time there, had to put up with an often antiquated and fairly strict regime.

Studios which were booked for a certain time-slot rarely allowed bands to go over, let alone miss a day through excessive behaviour the night before. When John Lennon dropped an acid tab one night and started freaking out, producer George Martin quietly ushered him onto the roof to see off the effects of the drug. Meanwhile, downstairs, the engineers wore suits, and the technicians and porters were distinguished, respectively, by obligatory white and brown coats. Everyone had to pay for their tea and biscuits in the canteen, including The Beatles.

"In the early 60s there were very few recording studios," Aldrich points out. "It was a music factory, and certain guidelines were laid down. Many places had executive toilets and the like. Nothing strange, that's how businesses were run. Nowadays those guidelines have been relaxed. Certainly, throughout the 60s, life became far less informal here."

Indeed, it did. The Sex Pistols mixed their legendary Never Mind The Bollocks here, providing potent symbolism of the new sweeping away the old. Not surprising then that Oasis - Noel Gallagher once joked that they should have been called The Sex Beatles - began recording their third album, Be Here Now, in studio two. Shades of yesteryear occurred when an irate conductor barged into their studio and asked them to, please, keep the noise down. The group decamped to a country studio the very next day.

On Monday the proceedings will begin at the distinctly impolite hour of 7.30am and will, hopes Aldrich, display the wide talent that makes up contemporary British pop. The day will end with a 40-minute concert by Paul Weller, tickets for which are to be given away through the radio station. One curious matter is the inclusion of 60s popsters The Move, the only band ever to be sued by a British prime minister, when then manager, Tony Secunda, created a promotional postcard depicting the Labour leader Harold Wilson and his secretary Marcia Falkender in a compromising position. The band were unaware of the card and were mortified when Wilson sued.

Thirty years later and The Move are still with us, influencing the likes of Weller and, according to Carl Wayne, glad to be employed.

"It's amazing that we're still going and that the music we made then is still finding favour with people," he says. "It's a great honour for us to go into Abbey Road. I've always wondered if someone as talented as Paul McCartney ever recognised the worth of what we were trying to do."

Come Monday, and Carl may just be able to find out in person.

Highlights from BBC Music Live at Abbey Road, Monday, 6pm, BBC2

Think of a place where so much great music has been made, you have to think Abbey Road. I've been there before so I knew we could set the bands in three different studios and cut between them." Ironically, although Abbey Road is indeed the most famous studio in the land, Neil Aldrich, who has worked there for 30 years, says that many people think the studio, following the demise of The Beatles, is now a dusty museum. Nothing could be further from the truth, he insists. Most of its three studios are booked for the year, reflecting the "quality of the technicians here and their understanding of what people want". And famous acts who have recorded here recently include Oasis, The Spice Girls, Spiritualized, Dr John and Paul Weller. And, adds Aldrich, a sizeable number of Hollywood film scores have emanated from studios one and two, including the recent Star Wars film, Braveheart, Raiders Of The Lost Ark, The Talented Mr Ripley and Sleepy Hollow. It hasn't always been thus. Built by EMI Records in 1931 to provide a suitable environment in which to record their artists, the studio was never christened Abbey Road. It was only 15 years ago that they officially changed their name from EMI Recording Studios to Abbey Road studios. By then, of course, The Beatles had made the place a landmark. But even they, during their time there, had to put up with an often antiquated and fairly strict regime. Studios which were booked for a certain time-slot rarely allowed bands to go over, let alone miss a day through excessive behaviour the night before. When John Lennon dropped an acid tab one night and started freaking out, producer George Martin quietly ushered him onto the roof to see off the effects of the drug. Meanwhile, downstairs, the engineers wore suits, and the technicians and porters were distinguished, respectively, by obligatory white and brown coats. Everyone had to pay for their tea and biscuits in the canteen, including The Beatles. "In the early 60s there were very few recording studios," Aldrich points out. "It was a music factory, and certain guidelines were laid down. Many places had executive toilets and the like. Nothing strange, that's how businesses were run. Nowadays those guidelines have been relaxed. Certainly, throughout the 60s, life became far less informal here." Indeed, it did. The Sex Pistols mixed their legendary Never Mind The Bollocks here, providing potent symbolism of the new sweeping away the old. Not surprising then that Oasis - Noel Gallagher once joked that they should have been called The Sex Beatles - began recording their third album, Be Here Now, in studio two. Shades of yesteryear occurred when an irate conductor barged into their studio and asked them to, please, keep the noise down. The group decamped to a country studio the very next day. On Monday the proceedings will begin at the distinctly impolite hour of 7.30am and will, hopes Aldrich, display the wide talent that makes up contemporary British pop. The day will end with a 40-minute concert by Paul Weller, tickets for which are to be given away through the radio station. One curious matter is the inclusion of 60s popsters The Move, the only band ever to be sued by a British prime minister, when then manager, Tony Secunda, created a promotional postcard depicting the Labour leader Harold Wilson and his secretary Marcia Falkender in a compromising position. The band were unaware of the card and were mortified when Wilson sued. Thirty years later and The Move are still with us, influencing the likes of Weller and, according to Carl Wayne, glad to be employed. "It's amazing that we're still going and that the music we made then is still finding favour with people," he says. "It's a great honour for us to go into Abbey Road. I've always wondered if someone as talented as Paul McCartney ever recognised the worth of what we were trying to do." Come Monday, and Carl may just be able to find out in person. Highlights from BBC Music Live at Abbey Road, Monday, 6pm, BBC2

webTitle: The price is right: What will be the most popular baby's name next year?

fields.headline: The price is right: What will be the most popular baby's name next year?
fields.body:
Leo 25/1

Ewan 50/1

Freddie 100/1

Brooklyn 250/1

This last week has been baby week (unofficially). The Blairs' Leo roared into public life, and despite Tony's father being the namesake, the Blair baby will undoubtedly be more often paired with the glamorous Leo DiCaprio than an unknown family member.

"It is interesting that out of the 330,000 boys born in the UK every year, film stars', pop stars' and footballers' names have cropped up higher in the lists in recent years", Ed Nicholson, Ladbrokes' entertainment odds compiler says.

So will the nation's fondness for naming babies after celebrities push out the Jacks and Thomases in the next few years?

"In 1998 a new entry at 44 was Owen (after Michael Owen). Interestingly enough, Liam (as in Gallagher of Oasis) had dropped 10 places so, yes, there is a strong correlation between high-profile names and those new-born baby names. In 1994 Ryan and Luke were in the top ten."

Nevertheless, Jack is still odds-on favourite to be the most popular name in 2001, says Ed. "Of the four runners here, Leo has the strongest chance of beating Jack. Obviously we have Tony and Cherie's newborn and Mr DiCaprio. It could become the Jack of the 21st century."

With Ewan McGregor and the athlete Ewan Thomas's recent publicity, Ewan stands a good chance. "Ewan has always been a popular name", says Ed.

Another fad is for unisex names like Posh 'n' Beck's Brooklyn. "As a name from famous parents his breeding is exemplary", says Ed. "Parents who enjoy football and pop may follow their lead. But form suggests the most popular names are still traditional. Over 25,000 boys are named Jack, Thomas or James each year."

"Freddie is an interesting name. It has classic connotations (Frederick) as well as modern icons such as Freddie Prince Jr. But it won't beat Jack or James."

Interview by Jennifer Rodger

fields.headline: Suburban nightmare
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: There are many things we can't choose in this life - our neighbours, for instance. However, when the people of Sherwood, a residential suburb of Nottingham, discovered last year that they were about to welcome two of Britain's most notorious child-killers into their community, they tried, understandably, to put their collective feet down.
fields.body:
There are many things we can't choose in this life - our neighbours, for instance. However, when the people of Sherwood, a residential suburb of Nottingham, discovered last year that they were about to welcome two of Britain's most notorious child-killers into their community, they tried, understandably, to put their collective feet down.

Inside Story followed the increasingly ugly process of public protest and government indifference, proving once again that you only have to scratch the surface of modern British life to discover deep currents of hatred and fear. Nothing whips up communal blood-lust like paedophilia: at the drop of a hat the merry men and women of Sherwood turned from peaceful bourgeois into a placard-wielding mob. "They should bring back hanging or the electric chair", announced one protestor, while the group chanted the hastily composed "What do we want? No paedophiles! Where don't we want them? Nottingham!"

They had a point, though. Lenny Smith and Robert Oliver are not only paedophiles, but killers. Smith murdered a six-year-old boy; Oliver killed 14-year-old Jason Smith during an orgy. As bogeymen go, they don't get much more terrifying or disgusting than this. The problem is, though, that they've both served their sentences and are now free men. Accommodation has been provided within the walls of Nottingham prison, and the men are free to come and go as they please, albeit with a police escort.

The theory may have been sound, but in practice it was a disaster. The flats are 200 yards from an infant school; there's a scout camp just up the road. It's hard to imagine the ideal location for Smith and Oliver to begin a new life in the community, but it couldn't be any worse than this. Concerned residents set up a tent outside the prison gates and began collecting signatures for a petition. Sadly, but inevitably, it all fell to pieces within weeks. The Home Office ignored the petition; the protesters fell out, divided between those who believed in the democratic process and those who preferred screaming in the streets and pushing their children in front of cameras. The frenzy reached a peak with a prison picket, where police broke a car's windows and showered a toddler with glass. "My fucking daughter's in that car - he could have got glass in her fucking face", shrieked a mother.

From this point irony piled on painful irony. Neighbour fell out with neighbour. Property prices in the area plunged, leaving Sherwood residents unable to move out. Objections to the scheme became confused and ridiculous: "They're not from round here", said one woman, veering straight into League Of Gentlemen territory. "Hasn't Nottingham got enough to cope with with its own dirty gits?" And, of course, when Smith and Oliver finally moved into their new homes, they stayed put - aware, no doubt, that the uniformed escort that would accompany them during any outing would make them an easy mark for local vigilantes. "We didn't achieve anything", concluded the protestors, who returned home to count the cost in fragmented families and soured relationships.

Nick London's film let nobody off the hook: neither the haughty Home Office nor the hysterical residents. The local MP was conspicuous by his or her absence, and indeed the whole democratic process emerged with egg on its collective face. (The film was originally scheduled for the eve of the local council and London mayoral elections and was moved, understandably, because of the dim light in which it showed local politics.) A special booby prize, however, must go to the prison governor, who commemorated his "victory" in getting the two paedophiles comfortably settled by producing a souvenir tie for his officers.

In Channel 5's Urban Gothic, a 21st-century Nosferatu through the rain-washed cliché-strewn streets of Soho. Rex (Keith-Lee Castle) swished around, swore profusely and mingled with a group of similarly unlovely mortals. Every so often he had to feed, so we were treated to the sight of a woman having her face carved up with a razor. Horror-queen Ingrid Pitt made a cameo looking bemused, as well she might.

webTitle: Robertson tries to avert US rift with Europe

fields.headline: Robertson tries to avert US rift with Europe
fields.standfirst: EU defence plans would also benefit America, says Nato chief
fields.trailText: Plans to beef up the European Union's defence capability should not worry the United States and will not undermine the western alliance, Nato's secretary general, Lord Robertson, declared yesterday.
fields.body:
Plans to beef up the European Union's defence capability should not worry the United States and will not undermine the western alliance, Nato's secretary general, Lord Robertson, declared yesterday.

As the US urged Nato's European members to do more to help keep the peace in Kosovo, Lord Robertson sought to assuage America's fears that the EU might be striking out on its own.

"The Americans appreciate that what is happening here is a rebalancing of the alliance and a strengthening of European capabilities," he said, at the opening of a Nato ministerial meeting in Florence.

Brussels, which is trying to give the EU some military muscle to match its economic weight, has had to focus much of its efforts on keeping the Americans happy.

On Monday the EU political committee approved a framework for future relations with Nato. That document will be presented to the EU summit in Portugal next month.

In Helsinki last December EU leaders promised to develop rapid-reaction capability so that by 2003 up to 60,000 troops could be swiftly deployed and kept in place for up to a year. But fears have been expressed in the United States that the end result could undermine Nato.

On two committees now up and running in BrusselsEU diplomats and soldiers are looking at military matters for the first time. Both are directly answerable to the EU's foreign and defence policy supremo, Javier Solana, himself a former Nato chief.

"If the Europeans strengthen their capabilities, that would be a win-win situation ... because the alliance will get the benefit of these capabilities and the US will not be dragged into every tiny conflict or crisis that the Europeans could handle for themselves," Lord Robertson said.

But mutual frustrations were underlined in Florence when Madeleine Albright, the US secretary of state, urged her European colleagues to send more personnel to the under-strength police force in Kosovo.

Mrs Albright said she knew the Europeans were doing their fair share, but the Clinton administration needed their help to prove this to Congress, which has threatened to make funding for Kosovo conditional on European contributions.

The US covered most of the costs of last year's Nato bombing campaign against Yugoslavia, but the European allies have taken the lead in paying the cost of reconstruction and civilian administration.

Meanwhile the Americans have been working hard on another contentious transatlantic issue - trying to persuade the Europeans of the need for the new national missile defence programme, which is aimed at knocking down incoming missiles launched by rogue states.

Russia and China strongly oppose the programme, and many of the allies also remain unconvinced that it is needed.

Frosty exchanges were predicted with the Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, who is resuming talks with Nato after a year-long gap because of tension over Kosovo.

Nato is angry because of Russia's recent decision to hold formal talks with General Dragoljub Ojdanic, the Yugoslav defence minister, who was indicted last year by the Hague war crimes tribunal, like President Slobodan Milosevic and other senior officials.

Under binding UN security council resolutions, Russia should arrest any indictees who enter its territory.

The European Commission has approved plans to spend up to 22m euros (£13.5m) to help clear the river Danube of debris and unexploded shells from Nato's bombing of Yugoslavia.

The money will be used to clear the debris of three bridges destroyed in the northern Serbian city of Novi Sad, but not to pay for rebuilding the bridges.

fields.headline: Fur flies
fields.standfirst: Vogue editor's former nanny sues for injuries from graffiti clean-up
fields.trailText: A former nanny for Vogue's British editor, Anna Wintour, claims to be an innocent victim of the "fur wars" between animal rights protesters and the editor
fields.body:
A former nanny for Vogue's British editor, Anna Wintour, claims to be an innocent victim of the "fur wars" between animal rights protesters and the editor

She says she was left with "permanent neurological injuries" in the wake of a graffiti attack by anti-fur militants on Ms Wintour's New York home.

Lori Feldt is suing the publisher of Vogue, Condé Nast, for $50m (£31m), claiming that the cleaners the firm sent to remove the graffiti in December 1997 used highly toxic chemicals and failed to evacuate her from the house, where she was employed to look after Ms Wintour's children.

The nanny was found unconscious and taken to hospital, and according to her lawyer, Carl Lustig, she has never recovered.

"She has numbness in her face and hands, multiple neurological problems, vision problems, headaches [and] swelling of the joints," Mr Lustig said.

He said that Ms Feldt lost her job six months later "because she was not capable of performing her duties", and was now in a low-paid "cashier-like" job.

A Condé Nast spokesman refused to comment on the suit yesterday.

If Ms Feldt, 27, is able to prove her case, she may emerge as the most serious human casualty so far of the bitter guerrilla conflict over use of fur by the fashion industry.

Nowhere is the battle fought with more aggression than in New York, where women wearing furs have frequently been attacked and splattered with paint by anti-fur groups such as the Paint Panthers.

Furs virtually disappeared from the fashion scene in the 80s and early 90s, but in recent years they have staged something of a comeback. The industry lobby, the Fur Information Council, claims that 200 designers used animal fur in their collections this season, compared with 45 in 1985.

Vogue and the London-born Ms Wintour have been at the vanguard of fur's rehabilitation. As one of the arbiter's of style, she has been unapologetic about her meat-eating lifestyle.

An animal rights militant once flung a dead racoon at her, but she succeeded in turning the incident into yet another publicity coup for the magazine, which she had edited since 1988. On another occasion she sent plates of rare beef to protesters outside Condé Nast's offices.

On December 2 1997 the Paint Panthers spray-painted a trail of red paw-prints leading to her house, ending in a pool of animal "blood" on the doorstep.

According to the case filed by Ms Feldt's lawyer, Ms Wintour asked Condé Nast to remove the paint, and it sent a team of cleaners. Ms Feldt was in the house at the time and was not told to leave, the case says.

The fumes found their way into the house, apparently through the drains, and inflicted "a serious and severe shock to her brain and to her nervous system".

Celebrity and animal rights collided in another Manhattan court room on Tuesday, when Chrissie Hynde, the lead singer of the Pretenders, answered charges for taking part in an attack on a leather clothing display at a New York branch of Gap.

Ms Hynde said the leather had come from cows which had been mistreated.

The charges were dismissed.

webTitle: Mocked Canada finds hope and glory in a beer ad

fields.headline: Mocked Canada finds hope and glory in a beer ad
fields.trailText: To some people it is nothing more than a beer advert. But to a lot of Canadians Jeff Douglas's 60-second Molson beer spot has become an unofficial anthem of national allegiance. What is beyond doubt is that it is the most talked about cultural phenomenon of the year north of the 49th parallel.
fields.body:
The Rant that is rocking the nation begins quietly. "I'm not a lumberjack. Or a fur trader. I don't live in an igloo, eat blubber or own a dogsled."

Then the distant strains of Land of Hope and Glory kick in, and a steady crescendo begins. "I have a prime minister, not a president. I speak English and French, not American."

The voice becomes more excited. "I can proudly sew my country's flag on my backpack. I believe in peacekeeping, not policing; diversity, not assimilation. And that the beaver is a truly proud and noble animal. A tuque is a hat, a chesterfield is a couch. And it's pronounced zed. Not zee. Zed."

Now comes the defiant climax. "Canada is the second largest land mass, the first nation of hockey - and the best part of North America." Then a slight pause, followed by the big, shouted finish: "My name is Joe. And I am Canadian."

To some people it is nothing more than a beer advert. But to a lot of Canadians Jeff Douglas's 60-second Molson beer spot has become an unofficial anthem of national allegiance. What is beyond doubt is that it is the most talked about cultural phenomenon of the year north of the 49th parallel.

Molson first aired it on Oscar night in March - along with Superbowl Sunday the most watched television night in North America. It provoked a volcanic response from watching Canadians.

Within weeks Mr Douglas, 28, was being invited to perform the Rant in public, especially at big ice-hockey games. Last month, at a key game between the Toronto Maple Leafs and the Ottawa Senators, it brought 20,000 fans to their feet in a raw display of fist-pumping excitement.

The opinion and letters columns of Canadian newspapers have spent weeks analysing the meaning of the ad and interpreting the intensity of the public's response.

"There are people doing their theses on nationalism wanting to talk to me about the maturity of Canadian nationalism - from a beer ad," says Brett Marchand of Molson's marketing department. "We knew it would sell beer. We didn't expect to touch such a nerve."

"This speaks to every stupid question that Americans always ask Canadians, the former Ontario premier Bob Rae says.

"There is a very strong element of nationalism in Canada that never goes away. The closer we get economically, the more we like thumbing our noses. And it's a lot of fun."

The opinion and letters columns of Canadian newspapers have spent weeks analysing the meaning of the ad and interpreting the intensity of the public's response. "There are people doing their theses on nationalism wanting to talk to me about the maturity of Canadian nationalism - from a beer ad," says Brett Marchand of Molson's marketing department. "We knew it would sell beer. We didn't expect to touch such a nerve." "This speaks to every stupid question that Americans always ask Canadians, the former Ontario premier Bob Rae says. "There is a very strong element of nationalism in Canada that never goes away. The closer we get economically, the more we like thumbing our noses. And it's a lot of fun."

fields.headline: Not fade away
fields.standfirst:
With their androgynous, innocent eccentric looks, the Rolling Stones helped to define Britain in the swinging 60s. But who carved that image? Adam Sweeting talks to former manager Andrew Loog Oldham, while Will Hodgkinson meets photographer Gered Mankowitz

Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: With their androgynous, innocent eccentric looks, the Rolling Stones helped to define Britain in the swinging 60s. But who carved that image? Adam Sweeting talks to former manager Andrew Loog Oldham, while Will Hodgkinson meets photographer Gered Mankowitz
fields.body:
Andrew Loog Oldham, former manager of the Rolling Stones, is one of the most committed self-publicists the rock'n'roll business has ever seen, but even he couldn't describe himself better than Nik Cohn did in his book Awopbopaloobop Alopbambom. "Oldham, without doubt, was the most flash personality that British pop has ever had, the most anarchic and obsessive and imaginative hustler of all," Cohn wrote. "He loathed slowness and drabness, age and caution and incompetence, mediocrity of all kinds, and he could not stand to work his way up steadily like anyone else. Instead, he barnstormed, he came on quite outrageous. I think his talent and impact have been very, very underestimated."

Oldham quotes this admiring passage in his new autobiography, Stoned. How could he have resisted? The book arrives as Oldham is attempting a mini-renaissance, after alcohol and fast living dragged him close to the brink in the mid-90s. It is a speedy, quick-witted read - and part of its intrigue lies in trying to decide whether Oldham was really as significant as he thinks he was.

He only takes the story as far as 1964, by which time he had led the Rolling Stones up the British charts and was beginning to eye up the vast potential of the US. Although those expecting epic yarns of rock'n'roll debauchery will have to wait for the projected sequel (which will also cover Oldham's years running his pioneering indie label, Immediate), the story he tells is fascinating. Andrew Oldham is at its centre, but equally it is a portrait of British society in transition: a drab, grey nation suddenly whisked up in the swirling cloud of the 60s.

"England was never shitty," argues Oldham, who now lives in Colombia. "It was what you made of it, and my book acknowledges and gives thanks to that."

Oldham was brought up by his Australian-Jewish mother Celia in London, and learned a curiously English mixture of arrogance, rebelliousness, gender confusion and good manners at Wellingborough public school. "In the late 50s, my school would put on Gilbert & Sullivan romps such as HMS Pinafore, in which young men dressed as young girls and looked very pretty," he remembers. "This could be very confusing to a 13-year-old boy." These notions of role-playing would later emerge in the camp androgyny exploited by Mick Jagger and Keith Richards. The idea of the Stones as Oldham's identity-by-proxy was central to the way he handled their career, from the way they dressed onstage to their sound in the studio, where Oldham directed the recording sessions like a mad maestro hearing apocalyptic sounds in his head.

It sounds comical now, but what triggered Oldham's lust for the pop business was the stage musical, and later the movie, of Expresso Bongo. He was mesmerised by the show's fictional pop manager, Johnnie Jackson. "This was the first ever British dramatisation of the 50s rock'n'roll scene and the revolution in the streets it was fomenting," Oldham writes in Stoned. "It signalled a coming of age for the new music, the new style, the new hustle."

And Oldham intuitively grasped what he needed to steal to create his distinctive personal style. "I felt like a thoughtful French New Wave movie," he writes, "so I rolled the credits and appeared on location in Hampstead Village's thriving beatnik scene."

Later, he gravitated to Chelsea, where he turned up at Mary Quant's Kings Road boutique, Bazaar, and talked himself into a job. "At first fashion was the fashion, then fashion became music," he explains. His moment of epiphany came in 1963 when he saw his first Rolling Stones gig at the Crawdaddy Club in Richmond. Since clothes loom even larger in Oldham's narcissistic recollections than the pop stars he circulated among, he had made sure he was dressed for the part: "broadcloth, blue, tab-collared shirt, jet-black wool tie, three-piece suit complete with cuffs on jacket and trousers, flair-waisted jacket à la Bunny Roger with inverted vent, spit and polished side-laced black booties".

As the pop potentate he must have been insufferable, not least when he was swanning around town in his blue Chevrolet Impala, driven by his rent-a-thug Reg "the Butcher" King. Former Decca promotion man Tony Hall catches Oldham in a nutshell with his observation that he "looked like a white English equivalent to a Blue Note record sleeve".

Oldham's arch, self-mythologising tone would grate on the reader a lot sooner than it does, were it not for the inclusion of such comments from a broad cross-section of eye-witnesses. Vidal Sassoon, Pete Townshend, Gene Pitney, Lionel Bart, Mary Quant, Marianne Faithfull and future Led Zeppelin bass player John Paul Jones all lob in their half-a-crown's worth, along with a swarm of friends, publicists and journalists.

The book's overriding impression is of the unbearable excitement of British pop's first brilliant dawn, when you could meet everybody who mattered in the Green Room on a Friday evening at the TV pop show Ready Steady Go! The knowledge that it was a fleeting moment, with many of the protagonists doomed to an early exit, merely intensifies the buzz.

If Oldham were entering the music industry afresh today, how would he do it? "With a hit song, a follow-up and a law degree," he spiels. "But if I was starting out with a lead singer who put me at one with the world and a guitarist who was at one with the world, I'd still jump into a swimming pool with no water. Stoned is not a cautionary tale - it's a celebration and carries the hope that any self-respecting impassioned young 19-year-old of today would do the same."

Stoned is published by Secker & Warburg, price £16.99. The Immediate Singles Collection will be released by Sequel Records next month.

'They liked my ignorance'

Gered Mankowitz is as integral to the 60s as dolly birds and Purple Hearts. As a 16-year-old in 1963 he had his own studio in the heart of the most swinging of London scenes - Mason's Yard, SW1, over the road from the Scotch of St James nightclub and next to the Indica art gallery, where John met Yoko. By the age of 17 he was shooting Marianne Faithfull for her mercurial manager, Andrew Loog Oldham. A year later Oldham commissioned Mankowitz to photograph what became the album cover for the Rolling Stones' Out of Our Heads, and to take their American visa photographs while he was at it. For the next three years Mankowitz's images of the band were to be burned onto the public's retina: Brian Jones as a Prince Regent gone to seed, Mick Jagger as the naughty boy bourgeois-in-waiting, Charlie Watts as an unruffled smoothie, Bill Wyman as a dirty old man and Keith Richards as an innocent waiting to be corrupted.

"I was terrible at school," says Mankowitz of his precocious success, "but I showed an interest in photography. My dad, Wolf Mankowitz, was famous in the 50s and 60s as a writer and a personality, so as a family we had been photographed quite a lot, in particular by a wonderful man called Tom Blau who owned the photo agency Camera Press. He liked my work and offered me an apprenticeship, so I was out of school at 15 and into a sweatshop, where I learned everything. Eventually Tom sent me to the zoo to shoot Guy the Gorilla. In 1964 I shot the singers Chad and Jeremy, who were appearing on a television show with Marianne Faithfull; Marianne was having a hit with As Tears Go By so everyone was talking about her. We all went out to dinner that night. I thought she was wonderful, started photographing her, and then Oldham asked me if I could photograph the Stones. That's pretty much it."

Soon after Mankowitz first shot the band, Oldham asked him to join them on their US tour in 1965. "It was a dream come true for me, and it was a novelty for them to work with a photographer who was younger than they were - Bailey, who had worked with them previously, was well into his 20s and heading into middle age, even then. They liked my ignorance, and felt that I had caught whatever it was that they wanted to be seen at that time. Also, because of being used to famous people at home I wasn't intimidated - as a boy I had been shouted at by Charles Laughton and Elsa Lanchester to turn my music down. I was playing Stay by Morris Williams and the Zodiacs and they didn't go for it."

In the American photographs, the band have an innocence not yet eclipsed by an excess of indulgence and success. "They just had a naughty aspect back then. Mick wiggled his bum and Brian Jones wore check trousers and people were shocked. And they didn't perform; unlike the Beatles they had nothing to do with the all-round entertainer tradition. But by not performing, we created a performance - that sullen, unsmiling, irregularly dressed gang was a new look. It was a great image made from what was within the band themselves."

All of the Stones looked eccentric; Brian Jones looked downright weird. "He was a very odd chap, and certainly the standout one in the early days. He had this extraordinary hair on a big head, small neck, wide shoulders, no hips, Rupert the Bear trousers, rollneck sweaters - a look that was quite unique." In Mankowitz's photographs, Jones seems alienated from the rest of the band. "He was capable of fantastic charm, then his dark side would emerge. He was the first to experiment with acid, and it was beginning to have an effect. In Miami he said to me, 'I've got two tabs of acid - have one with me.' I said thank you but no, and he said, 'OK, I'll take both of them and you write down everything I say.' 'No thanks, Brian.' "

In Chicago Jones jumped out of the limo in a traffic jam and disappeared for four days; in Texas he sulked in the car while the others ate burgers in a diner, waiting until they returned to the car to go to the restaurant himself. "Oldham sent the record plugger in to get him, and he grabbed Brian with hamburger in mouth and threw him into the car," remembers Mankowitz.

Mankowitz's most celebrated shoot was taken on an icy morning on London's Primrose Hill in November 1966, and became the album cover for Between the Buttons. "We had been working all night, and the look of the band was fantastic - baggy and craggy. I had this idea of distorting the image by making a home-made filter out of black card, glass and vaseline to make the boys dissolve into the landscape. Brian was lurking in his collar; I was frustrated because it felt like we were on the verge of something really special, and he was messing it up. Andrew said to me, 'Don't worry about Brian.' And he was absolutely right - the way that Brian appeared not to give a shit is exactly what the band was about."

Between the Buttons marked a high point of Mankowitz's relationship with the band; it soon went downhill. Unwilling to move with the Stones into a new area of experimentation, he was usurped by Michael Cooper, and by mid-'67 the innocence was gone. Brian Jones was lost, Jagger and Richards had been charged with drug offences, and the band fell out with Oldham. Mankowitz went with him. He's still doing portraiture today, having shot everyone from Jimi Hendrix and the Small Faces to the Verve and Oasis for Mojo magazine, but it's the Rolling Stones whose image he really captured and, to an extent, created. "It was the peak of their initial success and it was a great adventure," he says now. "We were amazed when it went on for another year. Nobody thought it would go on for 35 years."

Gered Mankowitz's exhibition, The 60s + One, is at Focus Gallery, London WC1 (020-7242 7191), till June 17.
