fields.headline: Jungle fever
fields.standfirst:
Deep in the forest, something is stirring: women making a life's work of mixing with monkeys. Carole Jahme has been watching the watchers

Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Deep in the forest, something is stirring: women making a life's work of mixing with monkeys.  Carole Jahme  has been watching the watchers
fields.body:
Civil war waged around Jo Thompson. Bands of lawless soldiers passed through the outskirts of her research project, wiping out the mission station and leaving behind a trail of destruction. Thompson was the only white woman in a 23,908km area of the Congo. She was working alone, studying the rainforest and its inhabitants, and she did not want to leave. But when the bush pilot service she used to travel to Kinshasa was grounded and she got word that rebel activity was hotting up, she knew she had no choice but to go. The only way to escape was to get aboard the last powerboat willing to make the gruelling seven-day journey down the Congo River. "After weeks of mental and emotional conflict, I chose to be on it. But I was already planning my return."

Primatology is essentially about the discovery of how ape-like we are, or how human-like animals are - and it is the only area of science in which women outnumber men. But while the theories and methods of women primatologists like Thompson have grown to dominate the discipline, it took a man to set this agenda. Louis Leakey was a maverick palaeoanthropologist, a scientific outsider of radical ideas who decided the best way to breathe life into the fossils of the early ape-men he'd dug up was to make a behavioural study of contemporary apes.

He believed a woman would be best suited to living with them because he felt women were innately fluent in non-verbal communication (a mother will intuitively know what her infant wants), while men were tongue-tied. Women have evolved to understand the intentions of others, even if no words are spoken, and it is the desire for this intimacy, rather than for academic success, that seems to motivate women primatologists.

In 1957, Jane Goodall, a secretary from Bournemouth, introduced herself to Leakey while visiting Kenya. An adventurer and an animal lover, Goodall was also 23 and beautiful. Leakey was a womaniser; on the spot, he offered her a job as his assistant. Three years later, he had raised enough financial support to set her up in Gombe, a stretch of forested hills by Lake Tanganyika in Tanzania, to study the chimpanzees there.

No one had ever tried to habituate a colony of wild chimps before and it was believed to be impossible - a view that, in her first few weeks, Goodall began to share. The chimps were hostile, charging at her screaming and breaking big branches. And when they weren't threatening her, they were silently disappearing into the trees.

But when Goodall had been at Gombe for three months, an amazing thing happened. She saw a chimp do something no one had ever seen before, something that would change our appreciation of evolution for ever. She saw a chimp she'd called David Greybeard pick a long stem of grass, peel off its leaves and insert it into a termite hole; when the angry termites bit it, he pulled it out and ate them.

This sent shock waves through the scientific establishment for two reasons: until that point, the human lineage had been thought the only tool-using ape - and the discovery had been made by a woman and "amateur". Leakey was thrilled and organised the National Geographic to film her work. Miss Goodall and the Wild Chimpanzees (1965), narrated by Orson Welles, was the first documentary of its kind; it made Goodall a star and effectively gave birth to the women-dominated science of primatology.

Leakey set about finding more women to study apes - Dian Fossey for gorillas and Biruté Galdikas for Asian orang-utans. National Geographic filmed these women at work, too, playing shamelessly on the image of "lone women at one with nature". But there was a troubling side to their existence that was not shown in the films. Civil war and poachers threatened their lives; malaria, snakes and scorpions were a common hazard; they faced searing heat by day, freezing nights and relentless parasites that burrowed in through their skin.

Only pure love could keep these women there and, isolated with the apes, they turned to them as a romantic thread. For Fossey, estranged from her own relatives, it was easy to idealise the gorillas and make them family. Friends in the US would be rewarded with the first stool of a new-born gorilla, carefully gift-wrapped.

Such intimacy with the apes has brought criticisms of subjectivity and anthropomorphism - a scientific sin. Jane Goodall said of David Greybeard that she grew to love him more than any other chimp she'd ever known, while fellow primatologist Janis Carter so loved Lucy - an American-born captive chimp who had been taught to "speak" in sign language, to eat burgers and to drink gin - that she rescued her and took her "home" to Africa.

For seven years, Carter lived with Lucy in a forest and tried to teach her how to behave as a wild chimp is meant to. This experience affected Carter deeply; she withdrew from humans altogether and moved, grunted and ate as an ape would. The boyfriend she had left in America would sporadically visit, but each time he found her more ape-like. Only after an attack by a male chimp did she return to civilisation.

This closeness between women and apes can have a more dangerous downside. Male orang-utans have raped women working at Biruté Galdikas' research site in Borneo and at Gombe, primatologist Barbara Smuts has found similarities between the sexually aggressive behaviour of male apes and men. Smuts (a fan of Goodall's whose research was cut short when she was kidnapped by Congolese rebels) noticed that female chimps were beaten by males when they were not sexually receptive; later, when the female became receptive, she would mate with her aggressor rather than risk another beating. Smuts reasoned it was in the female's interest to mate with a strong male, just as, through history, women have aligned themselves with powerful men who could protect and provide for them and their children. Similarly, sitting near a 400lb silver-back gorilla and gaining this powerful creature's acceptance may give women primatologists a dangerous frisson.

While female primates were almost ignored by men, they have proved fascinating to women, who have discovered not only that many species are matriarchal but that a modern woman's concerns have grown with her in evolutionary terms. Primatologist Jeanne Altmann was fascinated by the way nursing baboons manage their time, instinctively weighing up the costs and benefits of each task and therefore how much time to dedicate to it: how much to suckle the baby, how much to forage for food, how much to groom powerful friends or be groomed, how much to search for a good sleeping site. Just as human mothers are presented with a clash of interests, so are primate mothers.

There are other links, too: women primatologists find their periods adjust from 28 days to apes' 32-day cycle. Amy Parish, who experiences this while studying bonobos, theorises that menstrual synchronicity between apes means they are reproductively equal, so no female will be especially sexy at any one time, leaving the others feeling jealous and excluded, and no one female will bear the brunt of male sexual interest alone.

The female orgasm is a phenomenon women also share with their primate sisters and its evolution has been theorised on by primatologist Sarah Hrdy. Male primates often show hostility towards infants that are not their own and Hrdy concluded that female sexual pleasure evolved to motivate females into taking a series of male partners, thus confusing paternity. That way, when an infant is born, at best a series of males should provide for it, as it could be theirs; at worst the males shouldn't kill it, again because it could be theirs.

For bonobos, both sexual pleasure and bonding come through lesbianism: females have pronounced clitorises and rub their genitals together to elicit mutual orgasms. There is no violent sexual coercion in the lives of female bonobos because sisterhood protects them; no male, no matter how powerful, can play off one female against another the way male chimps and men sometimes do.

Paradoxically, while uncovering the essence of womanhood and female bonding, women primatologists have become jealous of each other's successes; they have competed at conferences and even gone so far as to murder another's favourite ape. They are an obsessed, passionate, brave and individualistic breed, and the influence they have had on our self-perception is immense.

Beauty and the Beasts by Carole Jahme is published by Virago on June 8 at £18.99.
fields.bodyText: Civil war waged around Jo Thompson. Bands of lawless soldiers passed through the outskirts of her research project, wiping out the mission station and leaving behind a trail of destruction. Thompson was the only white woman in a 23,908km area of the Congo. She was working alone, studying the rainforest and its inhabitants, and she did not want to leave. But when the bush pilot service she used to travel to Kinshasa was grounded and she got word that rebel activity was hotting up, she knew she had no choice but to go. The only way to escape was to get aboard the last powerboat willing to make the gruelling seven-day journey down the Congo River. "After weeks of mental and emotional conflict, I chose to be on it. But I was already planning my return." Primatology is essentially about the discovery of how ape-like we are, or how human-like animals are - and it is the only area of science in which women outnumber men. But while the theories and methods of women primatologists like Thompson have grown to dominate the discipline, it took a man to set this agenda. Louis Leakey was a maverick palaeoanthropologist, a scientific outsider of radical ideas who decided the best way to breathe life into the fossils of the early ape-men he'd dug up was to make a behavioural study of contemporary apes. He believed a woman would be best suited to living with them because he felt women were innately fluent in non-verbal communication (a mother will intuitively know what her infant wants), while men were tongue-tied. Women have evolved to understand the intentions of others, even if no words are spoken, and it is the desire for this intimacy, rather than for academic success, that seems to motivate women primatologists. In 1957, Jane Goodall, a secretary from Bournemouth, introduced herself to Leakey while visiting Kenya. An adventurer and an animal lover, Goodall was also 23 and beautiful. Leakey was a womaniser; on the spot, he offered her a job as his assistant. Three years later, he had raised enough financial support to set her up in Gombe, a stretch of forested hills by Lake Tanganyika in Tanzania, to study the chimpanzees there. No one had ever tried to habituate a colony of wild chimps before and it was believed to be impossible - a view that, in her first few weeks, Goodall began to share. The chimps were hostile, charging at her screaming and breaking big branches. And when they weren't threatening her, they were silently disappearing into the trees. But when Goodall had been at Gombe for three months, an amazing thing happened. She saw a chimp do something no one had ever seen before, something that would change our appreciation of evolution for ever. She saw a chimp she'd called David Greybeard pick a long stem of grass, peel off its leaves and insert it into a termite hole; when the angry termites bit it, he pulled it out and ate them. This sent shock waves through the scientific establishment for two reasons: until that point, the human lineage had been thought the only tool-using ape - and the discovery had been made by a woman and "amateur". Leakey was thrilled and organised the National Geographic to film her work. Miss Goodall and the Wild Chimpanzees (1965), narrated by Orson Welles, was the first documentary of its kind; it made Goodall a star and effectively gave birth to the women-dominated science of primatology. Leakey set about finding more women to study apes - Dian Fossey for gorillas and Biruté Galdikas for Asian orang-utans. National Geographic filmed these women at work, too, playing shamelessly on the image of "lone women at one with nature". But there was a troubling side to their existence that was not shown in the films. Civil war and poachers threatened their lives; malaria, snakes and scorpions were a common hazard; they faced searing heat by day, freezing nights and relentless parasites that burrowed in through their skin. Only pure love could keep these women there and, isolated with the apes, they turned to them as a romantic thread. For Fossey, estranged from her own relatives, it was easy to idealise the gorillas and make them family. Friends in the US would be rewarded with the first stool of a new-born gorilla, carefully gift-wrapped. Such intimacy with the apes has brought criticisms of subjectivity and anthropomorphism - a scientific sin. Jane Goodall said of David Greybeard that she grew to love him more than any other chimp she'd ever known, while fellow primatologist Janis Carter so loved Lucy - an American-born captive chimp who had been taught to "speak" in sign language, to eat burgers and to drink gin - that she rescued her and took her "home" to Africa. For seven years, Carter lived with Lucy in a forest and tried to teach her how to behave as a wild chimp is meant to. This experience affected Carter deeply; she withdrew from humans altogether and moved, grunted and ate as an ape would. The boyfriend she had left in America would sporadically visit, but each time he found her more ape-like. Only after an attack by a male chimp did she return to civilisation. This closeness between women and apes can have a more dangerous downside. Male orang-utans have raped women working at Biruté Galdikas' research site in Borneo and at Gombe, primatologist Barbara Smuts has found similarities between the sexually aggressive behaviour of male apes and men. Smuts (a fan of Goodall's whose research was cut short when she was kidnapped by Congolese rebels) noticed that female chimps were beaten by males when they were not sexually receptive; later, when the female became receptive, she would mate with her aggressor rather than risk another beating. Smuts reasoned it was in the female's interest to mate with a strong male, just as, through history, women have aligned themselves with powerful men who could protect and provide for them and their children. Similarly, sitting near a 400lb silver-back gorilla and gaining this powerful creature's acceptance may give women primatologists a dangerous frisson. While female primates were almost ignored by men, they have proved fascinating to women, who have discovered not only that many species are matriarchal but that a modern woman's concerns have grown with her in evolutionary terms. Primatologist Jeanne Altmann was fascinated by the way nursing baboons manage their time, instinctively weighing up the costs and benefits of each task and therefore how much time to dedicate to it: how much to suckle the baby, how much to forage for food, how much to groom powerful friends or be groomed, how much to search for a good sleeping site. Just as human mothers are presented with a clash of interests, so are primate mothers. There are other links, too: women primatologists find their periods adjust from 28 days to apes' 32-day cycle. Amy Parish, who experiences this while studying bonobos, theorises that menstrual synchronicity between apes means they are reproductively equal, so no female will be especially sexy at any one time, leaving the others feeling jealous and excluded, and no one female will bear the brunt of male sexual interest alone. The female orgasm is a phenomenon women also share with their primate sisters and its evolution has been theorised on by primatologist Sarah Hrdy. Male primates often show hostility towards infants that are not their own and Hrdy concluded that female sexual pleasure evolved to motivate females into taking a series of male partners, thus confusing paternity. That way, when an infant is born, at best a series of males should provide for it, as it could be theirs; at worst the males shouldn't kill it, again because it could be theirs. For bonobos, both sexual pleasure and bonding come through lesbianism: females have pronounced clitorises and rub their genitals together to elicit mutual orgasms. There is no violent sexual coercion in the lives of female bonobos because sisterhood protects them; no male, no matter how powerful, can play off one female against another the way male chimps and men sometimes do. Paradoxically, while uncovering the essence of womanhood and female bonding, women primatologists have become jealous of each other's successes; they have competed at conferences and even gone so far as to murder another's favourite ape. They are an obsessed, passionate, brave and individualistic breed, and the influence they have had on our self-perception is immense. Beauty and the Beasts by Carole Jahme is published by Virago on June 8 at £18.99.

webTitle: Heaven has nothing to do with it

fields.headline: Heaven has nothing to do with it
fields.standfirst:
Irrational talk by Charles did not help environmental scientists

GM food: special report
The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: It is not hard to see why Prince Charles's solution to the environmental crisis is spiritual transformation, rather than political awakening. It is harder to see why those environmentalists who have less to lose have chosen to follow him.
fields.body:
It is not hard to see why Prince Charles's solution to the environmental crisis is spiritual transformation, rather than political awakening. It is harder to see why those environmentalists who have less to lose have chosen to follow him.

His Reith lecture was certainly a bold speech for the heir to the throne to make, and there is no question that the prince, unlike some of his predecessors, truly wants to make the world a better place. But the views he expressed were beset with such blatant contradictions that I can't understand why anyone should wish to subscribe to them.

Prince Charles correctly asserted, for example, that current measures to reduce the production of greenhouse gases are "insufficient", and that there is "plenty of evidence" that farming which uses a diversity of crops and few chemicals makes more sense than monoculture. Both of these statements are, and can only be, drawn from science. Yet he used them to advance the argument that only through "an understanding of the sacred" can we truly determine where natural limits lie.

He praised Socrates's definition of wisdom - "knowing that you don't know" (which is, incidentally, a pretty good description of the scientific model) - but in the same paragraph he suggested that "an instinctive, heart-felt awareness" is "the most reliable guide" to whether or not we are doing the right thing. We already know, in other words, all that we need to.

Yet this chaotic thinking has received nothing but praise from people whose cause it undermines. Writing in the Guardian on Saturday, for example, Sir Jonathon Porritt insisted that "every one of the world's major religions" contains "an environmental ethic". Maybe his copy of the Bible differs from mine. The one I've read keeps insisting that God granted man dominion over nature.

Dr Mae-Wan Ho argued in the Guardian yesterday that "the prince is more in touch with the common people than our elected government." This may be true, but it doesn't mean he is right. Environmentalists are in danger of allowing their critics to define them: as backward-looking and anti-intellectual.

To me, the need to protect the environment springs not from "a sense of the sacred", but from social justice. It can be defended with the help of arguments every bit as rigorous and scientific as those expounded by the people Prince Charles attacks.

The genetic engineering of crop plants, for example, is dangerous not because it is "usurping God" or "tampering with Nature", but because it grants big business monopolistic control over the foodchain, with devastating consequences for both the poor and the eco-system.

Damaging the ozone layer is harmful not because it troubles Heaven, but because it exposes us to malignant melanomas.

Jonathon Porritt complains that scientists have taught us to see ourselves as "random, purposeless bipeds". This is precisely why science is liberating. It shows us that humankind is not the purpose and pivot of the universe, that man has not been cast in the image of God to control the rest of creation. Science teaches us humility. It tells us that we emerge from the natural world, and remain subject to its laws and limitations. Only through the demolition of creation myths can an ecological worldview be sustained.

The problem arises not from science itself, but from the political and economic context in which it operates. Whether science is used for or against us depends upon who controls the purse strings. Interestingly, while Prince Charles attacked scientists, he went out of his way to praise Sir John Browne, the chief executive of BP. Through its university funding programme, BP has done more than any other British corporation to ensure that science meets its needs, rather than those of humanity as a whole.

None of this is to suggest that we must become coldly calculating robots. While human life, resulting from a series of evolutionary accidents, is arguably meaningless, individual human lives are not. Those accidents have bequeathed an extraordinary degree of consciousness, which in turn has granted us an enhanced capacity for both sympathy and suffering. Using the one to relieve the other invests our lives with a purpose which surely requires no celestial justification. Nor do we need God to tell us to protect other species and beautiful landscapes: we can do so simply because we love them.

Prince Charles has dug a hole, into which many of our most prominent environmentalists have felt obliged to fall. They can hardly complain if those who wish to profit from destruction characterise them as the enemies of reason.

fields.headline: The bottom line
fields.standfirst: What do recent photos of All Saints tell us about modern female friendships?  Anita Chaudhuri gets to grips with girls who grope
fields.trailText: What do recent photos of All Saints tell us about modern female friendships?  Anita Chaudhuri gets to grips with girls who grope
fields.body:
Every picture tells a story, even those over-hyped post-premiere shots that inevitably find their way into the pages of the Sun. Thus it is worth giving some serious consideration to the hidden symbolism in a picture that appeared in that newspaper yesterday, featuring three members of the girl band All Saints. Shot from the rear, it depicts Melanie Blatt flanked by Nicole and Natalie Appleton. Two of them are slyly squeezing each other's, ahem, posteriors, while the third demurely clasps her friend's hand.

All of a sudden, physical demonstrations of intimacy between female friends has become a sort of code that indicates that the protagonists are fun-loving, cheeky, good-time girls. Artist Tracey Emin is often seen with her arm around friend Sarah Lucas, as is Kate Moss with Jade Jagger. Broadcaster Mariella Frostrup always seems to be photographed holding hands with her more famous friend Patsy Kensit.

Women touching each other in order to express their feelings for each other is nothing new; what has changed is that such displays have become not merely socially acceptable but virtually de rigueur - whether you are comfortable with it or not. And like all social trends, what is acceptable within the parameters of close relationships has inevitably begun to spill over into the corporate world.

Personally, I often find myself linking arms with a close girlfriend. It can feel very comforting, particularly when wearing new shoes and trying to cross a perilous shopping thoroughfare. Walking along joining hands with two or more friends can feel unexpectedly liberating, taking me back to those heady teenage days when joining hands with members of an identically dressed gang, walking five abreast, was a mark of belonging, of safety in numbers.

In the grown-up world, things are more complex, the boundaries less clearly defined. Last week, following a business dinner, my host, a woman I had never met before, encased me in a goodbye clinch worthy of Gone With The Wind. I found myself pulling away abruptly enough to cause minor offence. Still wiping lipstick off my cheek on the train home, I marvelled at the strength of my reaction. It wasn't that I construed the gesture as sexual. Rather that I felt outraged by the assumption that any kind of intimacy was appropriate after so short an acquaintance.

"It's interesting that there are some friends I choose to kiss, cuddle and generally embrace, while there are others I don't do that with," says Gemma Harrison, a designer. "There is an unwritten rule among some friends: we simply don't do kissing and hand-holding. No doubt a psychologist would try to tell me that I have a fear of becoming intimate with those women, but to be honest I feel just as close to them as to the women I touch. "

She points out that boyfriends often find this degree of physical contact between herself and friends to be fascinating, occasionally vaguely titillating. "The notion that there could be anything sexual at play is frankly absurd, but men just don't get it. They wouldn't touch their friends like we do because they are scared of the homosexual connotations, so they think that if we do, there must be something going on."

Another friend observes that she is far more likely to be physically affectionate with women who remind her of her sister. "When I find myself stroking a friend's hair or putting my hands on her waist, it's a playful, protective gesture that comes naturally from the way my sister and I relate to each other. Often with friendships I am trying to replicate that very free and easy relationship that one can have with a sibling."

This bond between sisters is perhaps what we are all trying to recreate through such public shows of affection. It is certainly an idea that's part of the zeitgeist. Recent films such as The Virgin Suicides and Hanging Up both explore the complex and alluring bonds that exist between female siblings - and the extent to which men misunderstand those bonds. No surprise, then, that two of the girls in the All Saints photo are sisters, or that they are almost identically dressed. They may not have convinced us with their combats and pregnancy power, but a bit more public groping might win us over yet.

fields.headline: Runaway trains
fields.standfirst:
John Prescott had a year to get the rail industry right. Well, he failed

Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: John Prescott's loose remarks at the close of last year's rail summit have come back to haunt him with a vengeance.
fields.body:
John Prescott's loose remarks at the close of last year's rail summit have come back to haunt him with a vengeance. Launching an appeal for the industry to pull together, he frankly admitted that ministers had a year to get it right, or the public would start to blame the government for rail's continuing poor performance. Labour would no longer be able to hide behind the cloak of privatisation, the fragmented legacy of the Tories.

Well it's happened. Mr Prescott will today open the summit delayed since February because the government has nothing positive to say about rail. Last year he managed to lean on the prime minister to suggest that transport had not slipped down the government's agenda when it clearly had. This year, it is lucky for Mr Prescott that the Blair baby has left him in charge. He is expected to make only the ghost of an appearance at the meeting and then leave the field to his deputy, Lord Macdonald, to answer any difficult questions.

Even the choice of venue (the Queen Elizabeth conference centre just off Parliament Square), is an extraordinary example of inept planning. It overlooks the Central Hall, where harrowing accounts of the Paddington rail crash are becoming a daily source of embarrassment to the industry and the government. Lord Cullen's mammoth inquiry is, in effect, a series of three separate investigations into first, the cause of the Paddington crash last October; then into its links with the Southall accident two years earlier; and finally on the state of the industry and the management of safety.

Over the course of the next nine months and in the lead up to the election, he will therefore be giving the first independent view of what has happened to rail since privatisation, and his verdict will almost certainly be damning.

Even without the Paddington inquiry, today's summit is condemned before it begins. Since last year, the industry can boast of little cheer, except that the public, forced to use what should be an efficient alternative means of transport, is flocking to rail. In the past four years, passenger usage has soared by more than 25%, better than at any time since the second world war.

The industry's most striking deficiency is a dearth of investment. The government has been locked into the legacy it inherited from the Tories, a series of seven to 15-year-long franchises, underpinned by gradually diminishing subsidies from the taxpayer, some of it going into the pockets of the train operating companies. It could and should have made sure that the subsidies were being injected directly into the industry. And it could have found ways of making Railtrack improve the infrastructure, but it has not. Belatedly, the rail regulator has started to exert his authority, after his predecessor sat on his hands for five years.

Instead, the government has looked to the privatised monopoly to see through important capital projects, such as the building of the Channel tunnel rail link. The first stage of the link is ahead of schedule, but Railtrack still has to reach a decision on the more expensive stage into central London, guaranteed by Mr Prescott if the Railtrack deal collapses.

The west coast mainline project between London and Glasgow is in a mess. Railtrack has bungled the scheme, allowing its costs to burgeon out of control from £2bn two years ago to more than £5bn, putting at risk the timing of Richard Branson's adventurous scheme to introduce 140mph tilting trains on the potentially lucrative London to Manchester route. Railtrack is bristling at persistent inquiries from the rail regulator, who understandably wants to know what is going on, while the company is openly pleading with the deputy prime minister for more money.

But there has been very little, a dribble, actually spent on the railway, apart from the London Underground, which is in constant need of cash transfusions. As the election approaches, Mr Prescott is becoming a very worried man. Clearly there could be more money available for transport. But that is a matter primarily for the chancellor, not Mr Prescott, and Mr Brown is not due to reach a final decision until the end of July. In the meantime, Mr Prescott has been promising the earth to Sir Alastair Morton, the former boss of Eurotunnel and chairman of the Strategic Rail Authority (SRA), who has the responsibility to distribute the cash on behalf of the government.

Nothing is mentioned officially but Mr Prescott has indicated to Sir Alastair that he could have at least £2bn for the railway if he could show immediate results which would win the government bonus points before the election. The problem is that Sir Alastair can't, even if Mr Prescott can squeeze the money out of Mr Brown's wallet. What Mr Prescott wants should have happened long ago, but successive governments have been too mean.

Caught in the midst of the political infighting, the travelling public is exasperated and defenceless. It does not believe what it is told: that the railway is getting better. Official figures can be made to prove anything. The truth is that punctuality and reliability has hardly improved in the past year, some services have been quietly withdrawn, and overcrowding on some routes is an outrage. The fares structure is long overdue for reform. It remains unnecessarily complicated, and the window of opportunity for cheaper travel at off-peak times keeps closing.

The one body which might bring some influence to bear on this sad state of affairs, the SRA, is a disappointment. Far from producing a bright new panacea for the industry, and trying to make the railway more comfortable and responsive to the needs of passengers, it has largely immersed itself in a frantic search for new franchise operators. The SRA's attention is almost solely concentrated on rolling out three new rail franchises. But will they be more passenger friendly than the first lot, desperately hammered out in the last months of John Major's government?

It would be far more appropriate if the SRA was commanded by a full-time chairman, not the part-timer, Sir Alastair Morton, handpicked by Mr Prescott. Sir Alastair is energetic, sharp, and works longer than his official hours permit, but the extra work load carried by the SRA demands greater concentration in an industry which has been failing for too long.

Today's participants have been instructed by Mr Prescott to sing from the same hymn sheet. They will. But events across the road in the Central Hall mean they will be signing the song of the absurd, the sound of an industry oblivious to real events and the cries of real people.

It could and should have made sure that the subsidies were being injected directly into the industry. And it could have found ways of making Railtrack improve the infrastructure, but it has not. Belatedly, the rail regulator has started to exert his authority, after his predecessor sat on his hands for five years. Instead, the government has looked to the privatised monopoly to see through important capital projects, such as the building of the Channel tunnel rail link. The first stage of the link is ahead of schedule, but Railtrack still has to reach a decision on the more expensive stage into central London, guaranteed by Mr Prescott if the Railtrack deal collapses. The west coast mainline project between London and Glasgow is in a mess. Railtrack has bungled the scheme, allowing its costs to burgeon out of control from £2bn two years ago to more than £5bn, putting at risk the timing of Richard Branson's adventurous scheme to introduce 140mph tilting trains on the potentially lucrative London to Manchester route. Railtrack is bristling at persistent inquiries from the rail regulator, who understandably wants to know what is going on, while the company is openly pleading with the deputy prime minister for more money. But there has been very little, a dribble, actually spent on the railway, apart from the London Underground, which is in constant need of cash transfusions. As the election approaches, Mr Prescott is becoming a very worried man. Clearly there could be more money available for transport. But that is a matter primarily for the chancellor, not Mr Prescott, and Mr Brown is not due to reach a final decision until the end of July. In the meantime, Mr Prescott has been promising the earth to Sir Alastair Morton, the former boss of Eurotunnel and chairman of the Strategic Rail Authority (SRA), who has the responsibility to distribute the cash on behalf of the government. Nothing is mentioned officially but Mr Prescott has indicated to Sir Alastair that he could have at least £2bn for the railway if he could show immediate results which would win the government bonus points before the election. The problem is that Sir Alastair can't, even if Mr Prescott can squeeze the money out of Mr Brown's wallet. What Mr Prescott wants should have happened long ago, but successive governments have been too mean. Caught in the midst of the political infighting, the travelling public is exasperated and defenceless. It does not believe what it is told: that the railway is getting better. Official figures can be made to prove anything. The truth is that punctuality and reliability has hardly improved in the past year, some services have been quietly withdrawn, and overcrowding on some routes is an outrage. The fares structure is long overdue for reform. It remains unnecessarily complicated, and the window of opportunity for cheaper travel at off-peak times keeps closing. The one body which might bring some influence to bear on this sad state of affairs, the SRA, is a disappointment. Far from producing a bright new panacea for the industry, and trying to make the railway more comfortable and responsive to the needs of passengers, it has largely immersed itself in a frantic search for new franchise operators. The SRA's attention is almost solely concentrated on rolling out three new rail franchises. But will they be more passenger friendly than the first lot, desperately hammered out in the last months of John Major's government? It would be far more appropriate if the SRA was commanded by a full-time chairman, not the part-timer, Sir Alastair Morton, handpicked by Mr Prescott. Sir Alastair is energetic, sharp, and works longer than his official hours permit, but the extra work load carried by the SRA demands greater concentration in an industry which has been failing for too long. Today's participants have been instructed by Mr Prescott to sing from the same hymn sheet. They will. But events across the road in the Central Hall mean they will be signing the song of the absurd, the sound of an industry oblivious to real events and the cries of real people. keith.harper@theguardian.com

fields.headline: The power of two
fields.standfirst:
Alone, he was an inoffensive actor and she was, er, who knows? Together, they became Britain's premier supercouple. So can Hugh and Liz survive the split? Polly Vernon on why two stars are better than one

Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Alone, he was an inoffensive actor and she was, er, who knows? Together, they became Britain's premier supercouple. So can Hugh and Liz survive the split? Polly Vernon on why two stars are better than one
fields.body:
Stop all the clocks, the presses, GMTV's showbiz segments. Liz and Hugh have split, and a nation is trying to work out whether or not it saw it coming.

We should be horrified that the demise of the Chelsea Fabulous Grant 'n' Hurley ensemble has dominated our headlines, bumped stories of real-life atrocity and screaming injustice from our front pages, overshadowed civil war and other such things, but naturally, we're not. We are, in fact, fascinated by the whole deal, as obsessed, intrigued and pleasantly appalled by them on the occasion of their split, as we were throughout the latter, most public stages of their relationship. (To be entirely truthful, the break up isn't proving as messy or emotionally bloody as we may have wished - no public screaming matches, no undignified splurgings to the press, no evidence of heavy objects being thrown. Then again, these are early days and with the whiff of infidelity hanging round Liz like something rather pungent, chances are it'll all kick off nicely within a fortnight.)

But while speculation about the catalyst behind the split runs riot, another issue is raising its head. Can Liz's celebrity survive without Hugh, and will Hugh find anything sparkly enough to detract from his wholly pedestrian wardrobe without Liz? Will we ever hear from either again?

For the past six years or so, Liz and Hugh have defined contemporary supercoupledom. Theirs was a sparkly union, launched publicly in the midst of a premiere with the aid of an outré Versace dress, rocked and yet curiously, "cemented" with a glorious, sleazy, sexy scandal, and trimmed with all sorts of pretty aristos, bizarre diet regimes, and extravagant rumours about their sexual proclivities. Posh and Becks might be more famous, Zoe and Norman might be more Ibiza, but Liz and Hugh were "Hollywood" in the way that proper power couples should be. They were our Tom and Nicole, with the added bonus of being British and thus more accessible. But more than this, before we acknowledged them as a double act, they were nothing. Before Liz, Hugh was an arguably attractive, essentially inoffensive posho actor. Before Hugh, Liz was - well, who knew? That they were so truly trifling separately, and yet so utterly, instantly mesmerising together, lies at the heart of their significance as a supercouple.

Never before has the notion of the supercouple held such currency. It's hardly a new concept (Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor, I am led to believe, had a certain claim on public interest levels in their day), yet it's growing increasingly relevant with every passing moment of the 21st century. In an age when celebrity obsession rages unchecked, the idea that two famous people could cop off, date, and even set up home together titillates us beyond belief. What do they talk about? What do they do ? How can they bare the giddiness of so much specialness in one place at one time? It's hard to imagine how they keep from exploding.

What is it about the pairing off of two celebrities that earns them infinite cachet? What is it about taking up with another member of the fame pack which not only compounds and confirms your fame, but multiplies it infinitely? Why are these individuals so much greater as a double act than the sum of their parts would suggest?

Take the Beckhams. Independently, she was a scowling, talentless harridan who claimed she was posh when she obviously wasn't, and who flaunted her recently acquired wealth in a terribly gaudy manner. Without her, he flashed thigh prettily enough on the edges of our consciousness, but was basically one of a number of dull enough footballers and it was very difficult to distinguish between them. Sometimes it was difficult to care. But together, they make a truly majestic package. With him, Tor transformed into a delightful, smiling, chatty thing with a lovely sense of humour (she was sending up her own social pretensions all along - now we see) and an open delight in her newly confirmed celebrity. With her, Beckham got himself highlights and a look that shot him straight into cultural icon territory, not to mention an entrée onto the front pages of every newspaper. Oh, the foul football chants in her honour, oh, the surreptitious winks she shot into the VIP area after performing a solo in yet another packed out arena, oh, the leaked phone calls, the retrieved shopping lists (pickled onions and cakes! Imagine!), the extravagant gifts. They were just like us, only much, much better!

The phenomenon of the contemporary supercouple is, surprisingly, not that rigidly defined. Strictly speaking, it should involve two people of equally matched celebrity. One should be blonde, the other brunette. They should be, if not equally pretty, then matched in other respects. Intelligence, for example, can compensate for looks. Their wardrobes should work well together. They should have a slightly different claim on sections of the press, so that they might spread news of their fame to those who were formerly ignorant of their existence. They should spend their entire lives whirling about socially, attending charity launches, endorsing the right appeals, going to the right weddings. They should be sparkly, smiley, smug, and ever so slightly aloof. Think AA Gill and Nicola Formby.

But, as the past five years have proved, supercoupledom is actually very much open to interpretation. Zoe Ball and Norman Cook, for example, were an odd combo on the face of things. She was so terribly Radio One, he was so achingly edgy. She was so blonde, he was so balding. Their celebrity seemed so at odds, so awkward. Yet the combination works.

Then consider Liam Gallagher and Patsy Kensit. Initially, Liam's fascination with the obvious, uppity blonde seemed to damage his fame stock, detract from his status. What did he see in her? We thought he was more fashionable than that . But, in the fullness of time, we watched her reinvent herself as an accomplished rock vixen, redress the balance, provide a more than adequate foil to his wild, reckless vulnerability. The Beckhams should equally, strictly speaking, cancel each other's celebrity out by being so unapologetically normal together, by revelling in their combined ordinariness, by allowing us sporadic chinks of insight into a lifestyle crammed with Indian takeaway-splattered tracksuits and Blind Date.

Yet that just enchants us more.

The basic appeal of the accomplished supercouple can be reduced to this: by hooking up with another, carefully selected celeb, you can eliminate your bad points, compensate for your own shortcomings, and hint at a softer, more vulnerable side. Attach yourself to someone smarter, prettier, more fashionable, hipper, funnier than you are, and you will automatically acquire these missing qualities by osmosis. They, equally, will benefit from your particular brand of star quality. Your public perception will become more complete, more exciting. Together, you are quite literally, the ultimate individual.

None of which will help Liz or Hugh right now. At this moment, it's a little too easy to picture Liz, swathed in mink in some cosy corner of Sudeley Castle, scanning the small print of her Estée Lauder contract nervously in case she comes across a "terminate in case of split from (highly) significant other" clause. And Hugh, flicking through some casting books for a suitable replacement. Although of course, there's always the possibility that they're both sobbing into the remains of the bottle of Bourbon they set about at 6am, playing all their key relationship CDs over and over, and stroking old photos. Either way, premieres will never be the same.

fields.headline: No: 1642 Hugo Chavez
fields.trailText: Name: Hugo 'El Loco' Chavez.
fields.body:
Name: Hugo 'El Loco' Chavez.

Age: 45.

Position: Former paratrooper and jailed coup leader. Currently president of Venezuela.

Appearance: Matches military red berets with avuncular tank tops - strange for the leader of the world's most image-conscious nation.

Are crimes against fashion a sackable offence? Unfortunately not, his considerable array of enemies might venture.

What's their gripe? They say he's mad, bad, and dangerous to know. Oh yes, and they're not too happy that he's all set to be re-elected for another six years at the weekend.

Sour grapes? There is the little matter of him having dissolved most of the democratically-elected institutions in the country since he came to power. And he has hinted at violence if he isn't voted back in.

But if he's topping the polls someone must love him. The poor do - 70% of the population, think he's great, because he's promised to impose tough taxes on the rich. Other buddies include Fidel Castro, Carlos the Jackal and Saddam Hussein.

Hang on, isn't he just another puffed-up Latino strongman? He would rather describe himself as a man of destiny, determined to sweep away decades of corruption that have brought the world's third biggest oil-producing country to its knees. He claims the church has been complicit in the graft - and as punishment has slashed its funding, and branded its bishops "pharisees".

Messiah complex? Well . . . it is said he likes to dress up as Venezuela's independence hero, Simon Bolivar, and ride around his garden on a white horse reciting the great man's quotes. However, he has firmly denied all rumours about him setting an extra place at dinner parties for Bolivar, who died in 1830.

Who does he think he is? Take your pick. He litters his speech with quotes from Jesus Christ and Jean Jacques Rousseau. He also likes to talk about himself in the third person.

Not to be confused with: The Second Coming, Robin Hood, Chevy Chase, Abdala 'El Loco' Bucaram, who used to be president of Ecuador.

webTitle: Black market in art faces crackdown

fields.headline: Black market in art faces crackdown
fields.trailText: The government yesterday announced that it is to examine ways of cracking down on the international black market in art and antiquities used by drugs barons to launder cash.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  Arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The government yesterday announced that it is to examine ways of cracking down on the international black market in art and antiquities used by drugs barons to launder cash.

Experts estimate that the illicit trade in Britain may be worth up to £500m a year.

Ancient artefacts looted from sites in Africa and the Middle East can be bought and sold legally in the UK, even if they were smuggled out of their country of origin illegally.

The age of the pieces and the nature of archaeology means it is often impossible to tell how something was obtained, and that, combined with their high value, makes them ideal for money laundering.

Yesterday's move comes after bitter criticism of government inaction by archaeologists and museum professionals, who are outraged at the British refusal - most recently in February - to sign Unesco and other international agreements to bar the trade.

The culture minister, Alan Howarth, said the government had been unable to sign after receiving legal advice that the protocols were in conflict with British property law. He added that this decision might be reconsidered by an expert panel, announced yesterday, which is to report by November.

Mr Howarth insisted he was "very unhappy" at the present situation, where it is legal for anyone to set up in Britain without a licence as an antiquities dealer and to sell objects which might have been illegally excavated, or stolen, and smuggled out of their native countries.

The trade ranges from massive temple carvings from Khmer temples in Cambodia, hacked off to order or stolen from stores, through frescoes and mosaics chiselled off walls in Europe, African bronzes, prehistoric carved stones from Britain and Ireland, down to millions of small archaeological objects, including Greek gold rings, Egyptian mummy jewellery, Phoenician coins, and humble domestic objects such as pottery oil lamps.

They are sold with minimal provenance or none at all, by galleries and specialist dealers, and are virtually untraceable. A report being prepared for the Museums Association and the International Conference of Museums covers recent police raids in Germany, which uncovered 60 crates of icons, frescoes and mosaics ripped from churches in northern Cyprus, and a raid two years ago on a villa in Sicily which held 30,000 Phoenician, Greek and Roman pieces, worth over £20m.

A House of Commons select committee is also investigating the trade, and has heard reports suggesting the British market could be worth up to £500m a year, and that international police forces are increasingly concerned at the involvement of drug cartels in the trade, both directly selling stolen antiquities and laundering money through the trade.

Yesterday Mr Howarth announced the setting up of an advisory panel of experts, both to investigate the extent of the British problem, and to advise the government on how to tackle it.

"I am very uncomfortable about the situation in which there is freedom to trade in objects which have been illegally exported or indeed stolen," he said. "I am intensely concerned that scandalous things may be happening."

webTitle: Get your (tricky) sums right and win $1m

fields.headline: Get your (tricky) sums right and win $1m
fields.trailText: One hundred years after a celebrated Paris conference set the arithmetical agenda for the last century, an American institute has offered to make a dollar millionaire of anyone who cracks one of the seven great mathematical problems.
fields.body:
One hundred years after a celebrated Paris conference set the arithmetical agenda for the last century, an American institute has offered to make a dollar millionaire of anyone who cracks one of the seven great mathematical problems.

"This is absolutely not a gimmick," said Professor Arthur Jaffe, president of the Clay Mathematics Institute in Massachusetts, announcing the prizes at the prestigious Collège de France yesterday. "Each of these problems is a classic central question that has resisted the best efforts of the best minds for many, many years."

They are not your average sums. Among them is the Riemann Hypothesis, widely regarded as the most important open question in pure mathematics. It is the only one of the seven problems to be retained from the list of 23 formulated by the legendary German mathematician David Hilbert at the Paris International Conference of 1900.

Like the Poincaré Conjecture and the five other problems, it is completely incomprehensible to most mortals. But that, according to Sir Andrew Wiles, the British mathematician who solved Fermat's Last Theorem in 1994, does not mean it is not important.

"These problems have been chosen because their solution will open up new worlds of mathematics as yet undreamed of," he said.

And, Prof Jaffe added, the resolution of apparently pure mathematical problems always affects non-mathematicians eventually.

"Without maths," he said, "there would be no computers, no semiconductors, no global positioning systems, no space race, no gene studies, no telecommunications."

To claim their prizes, the solutions must be published in a scientific journal of world repute and generally accepted by the maths community for two years. Only then will a board of independent experts consider the issue.

webTitle: Charity staff say no to arms cash

fields.headline: Charity staff say no to arms cash
fields.trailText: Staff at a leading children's charity are protesting against an attempt to win donations from Britain's biggest arms manufacturer.
fields.body:
Staff at a leading children's charity are protesting against an attempt to win donations from Britain's biggest arms manufacturer.

One member of staff has already resigned from the NCH Action for Children charity after he refused to work on its attempt to bring in sponsorship from BAe Systems, formerly British Aerospace.

NCH is one of three charities shortlisted to become the defence company's chosen beneficiaries and it would receive up to £600,000 of sponsorship. A decision is expected to be made today.

But NCH staff have objected to the idea. In a letter to managers, passed to the Guardian, staff said it was "unethical for a charity whose purpose is the welfare of children to enter into partnership with such a company".

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: With Mr Tony Blair bunking prime minister's questions for the Christ child, our thoughts to turn to his last encounter, when Labour's David Winnick began by asking: "Is it not good news that the murderous leader of the rebels in Sierra Leone has been captured and taken to a safe location. . ."
fields.body:
 With Mr Tony Blair bunking prime minister's questions for the Christ child, our thoughts to turn to his last encounter, when Labour's David Winnick began by asking: "Is it not good news that the murderous leader of the rebels in Sierra Leone has been captured and taken to a safe location. . ." Or that is what Hansard records. What the veteran Mr Winnick - "the stupidest man in the House" as Harold Wilson once called him at the dispatch box - really said was: "Is it not good news that the murderous leader of the rebels in Sri Lanka has been captured. . ." Why, you may wonder, did Mr Tony reply without correcting Mr Winnick? Because it was a planted question, and he wasn't listening. Had Mr Winnick asked "Will my Rt Hon friend confirm that he favours Anusol for his piles, and finds the preparation efficacious?" the reply would still have begun: "We can be very, very proud of our armed forces . . ." As to the morality of Hansard rewriting Mr Winnick to make Mr T look less daft, some may think this a rather more serious distortion than translating Prescott into English.

 So many years have elapsed since Harold Wilson made his remark that it is in sore need of review. In the weeks ahead we will be assessing some of the Commons's leading thickies with a view to announcing the Stupidest Person in the House 2000 award in July. A successful defence by Mr Winnick cannot be ruled out, although many people's idea of ante-post favourite will be my old friend Sir Archie Hamilton, the former Tory 1922 committee chairman who last year ducked out of a linguistics challenge against a talking chimp.

 As so often when a household name departs the planet, Michael Winner has personal memories. "John was a very close friend," says Michael, who directed him twice, "the perfect gent and very witty." By way of illustrating these qualities there is an anecdote . . . one of how, while shooting the 1988 film noir classic Appointment with Death, he persuaded his then girlfriend Jenny Seagrove to streak through a corridor at the Hotel King David in Jerusalem - and informed of this frolicsome hilarity, Gielgud replied: "Good for her - I thought she was such a timid girl." Aching sides, aching sides. But Michael, do you think you taught him much? "Not at all." What, no tips or guidance at all? "He was the easiest in the world to work with, a wonderful professional."

 Out of the blue a demand arrives from the Inland Revenue. "Balance of account at 16 May 00," reads the bottom line, "0.01". After a large brandy, I ring the Hammersmith tax office to discuss if I can pay it in instalments. It's the computer, says a nice woman. "You'd think in this day and age it would be able to distinguish between amounts, but it can't." The thing that's really bothering me, I say, is the fact that daily interest is charged on late payments. In a couple of years it might be 2p. "Let me check for you," says the woman concernedly. She disappears for two or three minutes and returns with good news. "You can just ignore it," she says. "It will be carried over to the July payment, and you won't be charged any interest." Well, thanks for setting my mind at rest. Who said these tax people had no heart?

 Concern grows that the Daily Telegraph is mounting a challenge the Guardian's dominance in the broadsheet segment of the yoof market. For the second time in a few weeks, a headline on the leader page has been a reference to a pop single. Following a play on the Pretenders' chorus "It is time for you to stop all of your sobbing," yesterday's leader about the flower show read: "Why we want to go to Chelsea." Regardless of Charles Moore's obsession with appearing cool, Elvis Costello and Ray Davies didn't write lyrics with a view to future adaptation in the Telegraph comment section. Poor show.

fields.headline: Veteran DJ to leave Radio 1
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Andy Kershaw, the veteran Radio 1 DJ of 14 years, is to leave the station, BBC controllers said yesterday.
fields.body:
Andy Kershaw, the veteran Radio 1 DJ of 14 years, is to leave the station, BBC controllers said yesterday.

His contract for the Thursday late night slot came to an end last week and has not been renewed.

Andy Parfitt, controller of Radio One, said: "Andy has been a dedicated Radio 1 presenter for many years and I appreciate the love and care that have gone into his work for the network."

The pair have not always agreed. Last year the DJ criticised his employer in his Independent column for a "condescending and insulting" attitude towards black Britons after broadcasts of gun-related rap records following the shooting of the Radio 1 presenter Tim Westwood. Mr Parfitt said at the time that the aim was to carry on the show as normal in Westwood's absence.

"Andy Kershaw is an undisputed expert in his sphere," he said yesterday. "But there are always new DJs and new forms of music looking to break on to a packed Radio 1 schedule. It is essential Radio 1 keeps moving, providing space to showcase the newest talent."

Kershaw's 12am to 2am slot will be replaced by a number of one-off programme specials, before a new series in September. A BBC spokesman said that Kershaw would continue to make freelance contributions to BBC radio.
Press Association

fields.headline: Husband reversed over wife
fields.trailText: A woman died after her husband accidentally reversed his car over her as she directed him out of a parking space, an inquest heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A woman died after her husband accidentally reversed his car over her as she directed him out of a parking space, an inquest heard yesterday.

Tewkesbury coroner's court heard that Leslie Miller, 78, unwittingly twice drove over his wife, Rachel, 63, when he reversed and then shot forwards again in a car park in Cirencester, Gloucestershire, in September last year.

She was taken to Cheltenham general hospital with severe chest and head injuries, but her family took the decision to switch off her life support machine that day because of the seriousness of her injuries.

The inquest heard that Mr Miller, of Golders Green, north London, reversed out of a parking bay at such speed he hit a Mitsubishi Shogun parked behind where his wife was standing.

A witness, Wayne Shill, said: "I saw a red car shoot out of a parking bay in reverse. I was amazed at the speed at which it was coming out.

"I was then aware there was a person behind it. I saw the car hit her. She fell to the ground like a rag doll. I saw the person disappear under the car and the rear wheels go over her right arm. It was stationary for about three seconds and then shot forward. The person was trapped under the car."

Mr Shill raised the car with a jack to free the woman.

Cheltenham and district coroner Lester Maddrell recorded a verdict of accidental death.
Press Association

webTitle: Has the Tate gone too far?

fields.headline: Has the Tate gone too far?
fields.standfirst: The gallery seems to be having second thoughts about the radical web artist it has commissioned, writes Mylene Van Noort
fields.trailText: The gallery seems to be having second thoughts about the radical web artist it has commissioned, writes Mylene Van Noort
fields.body:
How will visitors to the Tate's online gallery feel if they find a hairy black ear replacing substantial parts of a Turner? Or a Constable carved up to let in "Mum's chin"?

This is the puzzle being pondered by the Tate's curators after they commissioned their first web project. It was due to go online this week but the launch has been postponed, possibly until next month.

The artist they commissioned is Harwood, a member of the Mongrel multimedia group. This was either quite a gutsy or a truly naive move, for Harwood's work is always "gloves off". He proposed to make a mock version of the existing Tate website, to which one in three visitors to www.tate.org.uk would be diverted. Clicking through the various categories of the museum's site, visitors would be dropped into Harwood's version produced in the same structure and design, but with the "hacked" artworks.

Matthew Gansallo, senior research fellow for the Tate's national programme, did not plunge headlong into the new media project. Before giving the first commission, he and other Tate curators went to the Zentrum fur Medientechnologie in Karlsruhe, Germany, to visit the Net Condition exhibition, a comprehensive survey of the current state of net art, showcasting 69 projects. They held extensive talks with the ZKM's director Peter Weibel and drew up a short list of suitable artists.

Harwood of the Mongrel multimedia group and Simon Patterson were invited to develop the first web projects. Harwood's was to have been the first to go online. "We are now in the stage of reviewing the project," says Gansallo. "We're editing it at the moment. Of course this is done with full respect and in consultation with the artist."

It is clear, however, that the decision makers at the Tate feel uncomfortable with Harwood's work. The artist says they have asked for 25 changes, the most important being "Mongrel" Tate banners inserted in all the places the Tate is mentioned. This would take the sting out of the project and Harwood objects vehemently. And steering the concept through the Tate hierarchy might prove tough. He has to deal with press, marketing and communications departments before presenting the site to director Sir Nicholas Serota.

How would other international art collections view such a project? Christine van Assch, Centre Pompidou's new media curator for 20 years, wouldn't even dream of thinking up a "sub" site of the official Beaubourg one. Her comment is terse: "The Press Office would not allow it."

Van Assch acquired Rehearsal Of Memory, Harwood's first individual net art project, for the Parisian museum. It is on permanent display in the new media section on the first floor. Harwood made this CD-rom project in 1995 with inmates of Ashworth maximum security mental hospital. It is a powerful and evocative piece of work which uses digital techniques to create an unsparing experience of closeness to the inmates of Ashworth. To activate the material on the CD-rom you move your mouse over prisoners' bodies, as if you were touching their skin.

Mousing over a nose which was broken many times, cracked skin and thick rough lips set in a Rembrandtesque sombreness makes for an arresting sensation of intimacy. You are forced to bond with these thwarted lives and to listen to their tales of horrific crimes uttered without any charm or need to please. The wonder of Rehearsal Of Memory is that it has an uplifting quality. If Rehearsal Of Memory plays out the nightmarish existence of disturbed prison inmates, the Tate project is an acting out of a boy's dream of becoming an artist. Harwood frolics about with the Tate's treasures, messing with a Constable to make space for what was left out. Although these desecrated images bear Harwood's signature, they don't, as yet, have the concentrated gravitas of Rehearsal. At worst they recall tourists' snapshots - "Two cheesemakers in typical Dutch costumes with head of Aunt Daphne" - and tend towards silliness.

In the accompanying texts Harwood states his strong views on the social and economic circumstances under which the Tate collection was formed. This is the core theme of all Mongrel's work: to voice the lives and cultures of people who are not being valued by society at large.

Asked about the postponement, Gansallo says: "The Tate has never been averse to criticism. We are interested in creating good work that will be engaging. The discussion will not be about people being offended."

If the Tate goes forward with Harwood's project, the museum shows it really means its new slogan: "Tate is changing". If not, there is a possibility that the site will go online anyway. That's the radical openness of the internet.

fields.headline: Home burial for Barbara Cartland
fields.trailText: Dame Barbara Cartland was buried yesterday in a private funeral service for family and close friends. The romantic novelist, who died on Sunday, aged 98, was laid to rest in a cardboard coffin in the grounds of Camfield Place, her mansion home near Hatfield, Hertfordshire.
fields.body:
Dame Barbara Cartland was buried yesterday in a private funeral service for family and close friends. The romantic novelist, who died on Sunday, aged 98, was laid to rest in a cardboard coffin in the grounds of Camfield Place, her mansion home near Hatfield, Hertfordshire.

Around 150 relatives and friends gathered in the house, which was once owned by Beatrix Potter, before following Dame Barbara's coffin in silence to a 400-year-old oak tree which was planted by Queen Elizabeth I.

As mourners stood under the great oak, Dame Barbara's grandson, William, read one of her poems about love and the afterlife.

Her daughter Raine, who married Earl Spencer, father of Diana, Princess of Wales, read a passage from the First Letter of John. The service was led by the Rev John Cotton, former vicar of St Mary's in the nearby village of Essendon. Mourners then joined in singing the Perry Como ballad I Believe.

Like the other mourners, Judy and David Almond, neighbours of Dame Barbara who knew her for 23 years, took a leaf from the oak tree to remind them of the occasion.

One of those at the service was Lord Brocket, to whom Dame Barbara wrote while he was in prison for insurance fraud.
Press Association

fields.headline: Hold ups:  Police hunt 'laughing cavalier'
fields.trailText: Detectives investigating a series of bank and building society robberies are appealing for information about the "laughing cavalier" - an armed raider who looks up and smiles at security cameras after carrying out hold-ups.
fields.body:
Detectives investigating a series of bank and building society robberies are appealing for information about the "laughing cavalier" - an armed raider who looks up and smiles at security cameras after carrying out hold-ups.

Staffordshire police said the man is believed to have carried out four robberies in the past 10 months, escaping with thousands of pounds in Cannock, Wolverhampton, Stourbridge and Birmingham.

Staffordshire police and West Midlands police are hunting the man, who is described as aged between 40 and 50, about 5ft 10in tall, wearing a trilby hat and a brown-green tweed style jacket and carrying a black briefcase.

Detective Sergeant Laurie Whitby-Smith, of Staffordshire police, said: "The man appears to laughing and obviously finds what is going on very humorous. There are some concerns for his state of mind."

The officer added that the man handed over the same threatening typewritten note from his briefcase to cashiers. He opened his briefcase to reveal what appeared to be the barrel of a gun.
Press Association

webTitle: Russia threatens to bomb Afghan terror camps

fields.headline: Russia threatens to bomb Afghan terror camps
fields.standfirst:
Russia: special report
Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Russia threatened to launch air strikes on alleged terrorist training bases in Afghanistan yesterday, because of the Taliban movement's support for Chechen separatists.
fields.body:
Russia threatened to launch air strikes on alleged terrorist training bases in Afghanistan yesterday, because of the Taliban movement's support for Chechen separatists.

Senior ministers, military leaders and the head of the Kremlin's national security council said they could not exclude the possibility of staging bombing raids on Afghanistan.

On Monday Moscow claimed that the Taliban and the world's most infamous terrorist, Osama bin Laden, were training, aiding and supplying Chechen rebel forces.

President Vladimir Putin, meanwhile, went to the Belarus capital, Minsk, for a meeting of former Soviet republics devoted to "collective security" to discuss the potential for basing Russian troops and anti-terrorist forces in the independent states of central Asia.

The meeting is the latest evidence of Mr Putin's more robust approach towards exerting Russia's influence on its neighbours and his determination to project Russia as a great power.

He asserted Russian leadership of the collective security pact singed in 1992 between Russia, Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan, Kazakhstan, Armenia and Belarus.

The Taliban government in Afghanistan, denied Monday's claim by the Kremlin spokesman, Sergei Yastrzhembsky, that it was aiding and abetting the Chechen insurrection.

It warned Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan that they would be held responsible for any Russian aggression against Afghanistan.

Mr Putin's national security council chairman, Sergei Ivanov, responded yesterday by saying that the six signatories of the security pact had to clarify the legal terms under which Russia would deploy anti-terrorist units in central Asia.

He said in Minsk that he did not rule out "undertaking certain military actions" if the Taliban movement put pressure on "Russian allies, particularly Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan".

Leading member of the Russian parliament, from the communist speaker, Gennady Seleznyov, to the young liberal Boris Nemtsov, criticised the government's talk of possible air strikes as irresponsible, particularly given the disastrous history of Russian military engagement in Afghanistan.

But the foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, the deputy prime minister, Ilya Klebanov, and the defence minister, Igor Sergeyev, all kept up the war of words.

Tough talk in Moscow is becoming a hallmark of the Mr Putin's government.

Defence ministry sources told the Interfax news agency that plans to bomb Afghanistan had been drafted and awaited only a political green light.

fields.headline: Broccoli to help fight cancer
fields.trailText: British food scientists have developed a "super-broccoli" that delivers a powerful punch against cancer, it was revealed in the New Scientist yesterday.
fields.body:
British food scientists have developed a "super-broccoli" that delivers a powerful punch against cancer, it was revealed in the New Scientist yesterday.

The vegetable, soon to be tested on human volunteers, could be in shops in two years time.

It looks and tastes the same as ordinary broccoli but, if it lives up to expectations, it could make a difference to the incidence of colon cancer, which claims about 25,000 victims a year in Britain.

Compared with its ordinary counterpart, super-broccoli contains 100 times more of a chemical that helps neutralise cancer-causing substances in the gut. Sulphoraphane is found in all brassicas, which include brussels sprouts and cauliflower, but is most concentrated in broccoli.

Scientists at the government-funded John Innes Centre in Norwich bred super-broccoli by crossing the normal vegetable with a wild Sicilian relative.

Trials are due to begin next year comparing the effect of super-broccoli and ordinary broccoli on human volunteers.

Plant biologist Richard Mithen, from the John Innes Centre, said yesterday: "There has been a lot of research on broccoli both here and in the US for the past 10 to 15 years, and there is plenty of evidence to show that broccoli has this anti-cancer activity.

"We have produced a vegetable that has 100 times more sulphoraphane than normal and, according to laboratory tests, 100 times as much anti-cancer activity."

The anti-cancer properties of broccoli not only helped prevent bowel cancer but might also slow down already developing cancers, said Dr Mithen.

fields.headline: Web watch
fields.trailText: WebRewards | Virtual Kraftwerk
fields.body:
WebRewards

The something-for-nothing economy gained a new player this month. WebRewards.co.uk hopes to take on the likes of iPoints and Beenz by offering a small number of high-quality gift items in exchange for online purchases at its partner sites, such as Car Phone Warehouse and Easyshop. Registration is particularly easy and there are plenty of reward points on offer just for joining and alerting your friends. However, to get the really good rewards such as helicopter flying lessons or a micro skate scooter you are either going to be very rich or have access to a corporate expense account.

Director's cut

The website for director Michael Winterbottom's loose adaptation of Thomas Hardy's The Mayor Of Casterbridge is probably the most obsessive ever built, especially as it promotes a film deep in pre-production. Visitors to www.kingdomcomemovie.com can not only download trailers and take a virtual tour of the set but also review the rushes and keep tabs on the production schedule, thanks to daily bulletins. It has enough detail to satisfy even the most die-hard of movie buffs.

Kookiest film site doing the rounds? Lars Von Trier's Cannes-winning Dancer In The Dark, which stars Bjork. See www.dancerinthedark.com.

EuroSoccer

Euro 2000 is nearly upon us and a flurry of new footie sites has been launched. Soccernet has added a micro-site at www.soccernet.com/euro2000 with its own front page and content. The most novel feature, and the one most likely to cause a rumpus in the pub, is the score prediction service. OneFootball.com also tries to offer in-depth coverage, which means a lot of text-heavy pages, but it does have good travel and ticket facilities. Footie fanzine When Saturday Comes has launched a "fans think tank" at www.dottwo.com/onetouch, and there is an official site at www.euro2000.org.

The Fiver, Football Unlimited's irreverent tea-time take on the world of football, will be producing a special Euro 2000 newsletter. See www.footballunlimited.co.uk/euro for subscription details.

Computer love

Fans of the arch-priests of Kraut rock and single-handed inventors of techno will be delighted with www.kraftwerk.de. Refreshingly, the site has very little information, and the link to Kraftwerk's record company, KlingKlang, seems to be broken. However, a number of interactive pages "play" segments from the group's music. Which all leads to lots of fun, fun, fun on das internet.

Card guard

Worries about credit card security are often cited as the main reason customers are unwilling to shop online. Now www.card-guard.com hopes to allay security fears by offering a browser plug-in that records every transaction you make on the web. The basic service sets you back £17.50 a year, but will provide documentary evidence should the worst happen and your goods do not show up.

Web for zilch

Net4nowt.com, a directory devoted to free internet service providers (ISPs), includes exhaustive tables comparing them. Of most use is the comprehensive list of unmetered ISPs. See http://net4nowt.com/unmetered.

Afore ye go

AnywhereYouGo claims to be "the world's largest independent community of wireless developers" and has launched a Wap (wireless application protocol) testing service. It claims nearly one in four Wap applications has significant coding errors and offers tests for a variety of platforms. See www.AnywhereYouGo.com.

New and noted

Footage of live births can be seen at www.motherandbaby.com, but not that one; www.wowgo.com is a portal for teenage girls and clothes horses will want to look at www.style365.com. Last but not least, offers a comprehensive travel site. Sean Dodson
